fields.headline: Eager Keane bounces Czechs
fields.standfirst: Dada 16og, Harte 43, Robbie Keane 87 | Koller 4, 35
fields.trailText: Republic of Ireland 3 - 2 Czech Republic
fields.body:
A dramatic 87th minute winner by the Coventry City striker Robbie Keane enabled the Republic of Ireland to record a notable victory over the Czech Republic here last night.

The Irish twice came from behind before triumphing over the side who had gone through their 10-match Euro 2000 qualifying campaign with a 100% record.

With the driving wind and rain in their favour in the first half, the Czechs silenced the crowd after four minutes when a Petr Gabriel shot was deflected into a crowded Irish goal mouth and Anderlecht's 6ft 7in striker Jan Koller hooked the ball home from close-range giving Alan Kelly no chance.

But Mick McCarthy's team were level after 16 minutes following a short corner on the right by Mark Kinsella. Mark Kennedy sent in a dangerous cross and the Czech defender Karel Rada, under pressure from Niall Quinn, steered the ball into his own net.

Quinn, winning his 75th cap, shot just over following another Kennedy cross as the Czechs looked vulnerable to the aerial threat posed by the Irish.

In an all-Liverpool move Patrik Berger set up Vladimir Smicer but, after evading the challenge of Kenny Cunningham, he shot wide with the goal at his mercy.

The Czechs were lucky to survive a moment of inspiration from Robbie Keane on the half hour. A long ball out of defence by Gary Kelly was nodded down by Quinn and Keane was quickest to react but Ladislav Maier was out quickly to block his effort.

Koller, whose height was causing mayhem in the Irish defence, then scored his 11th goal in as many internationals, heading home a cross from the former Manchester United man Karel Poborsky in the 35th minute after Berger had carved open a hesitant Irish defence.

But Ireland were level just before the interval. Gary Kelly's well directed pass from the right found his Leeds team-mate Ian Harte, who stabbed the ball home from four yards. It followed another defensive blunder by the Czechs when Maier collided with Rada to allow Harte the space to register his fourth international goal.

With the elements in their favour after the interval, Ireland applied concerted pressure and were unfortunate not to take the lead in the 53rd minute. A wind-assisted cor ner by Kinsella on the left struck the underside of the bar with Maier beaten. The ball appeared to cross the line before Tomas Repka cleared but the referee waved play on.

Sunderland's winger Kevin Kilbane had an excellent opportunity in the 75th minute but elected to pass to the unmarked Robbie Keane, who shot wide from the edge of the box.

Then came that dramatic late winner from Robbie Keane. The substitute Steve Staunton sent over a corner from the left which was headed on by Quinn and Keane fired into the roof of the net from close range to the jubilation of most of the 30,543 crowd.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): A Kelly (Blackburn); G Kelly (Leeds), Cunningham (Wimbledon), Butler (Sunderland; Babb , Tranmere, h-t), Harte (Leeds); Kennedy (Manchester City; McAteer , Blackburn, h-t), Roy Keane (Man Utd), Kinsella (Charlton), Kilbane (Sunderland; Staunton , Liverpool, 82min); Quinn (both Sunderland), Robbie Keane (Coventry; Connolly , PSV Eindhoven,89).

Czech Republic (3-5-2): Maier; Gabriel , Rada, Repka (Suchoparek, h-t); Poborsky, Bejbl, Berger (Horvath, 72), Nedved (Rosicky, 82), Nemec (Latal, 63); Koller (Kuka, 68), Smicer (Wagner, 63).

Referee: B Coue (France)

webTitle: Healy's debut double gives McIlroy perfect start

fields.headline: Healy's debut double gives McIlroy perfect start
fields.standfirst: Cardoni 41 | Healy 21 48, Quinn 87
fields.trailText: Luxembourg 1 - 3 Northern Ireland
fields.byline: Malcolm Brodie at Stade Josy Barthel
fields.body:
David Healy has only rarely appeared in Manchester United colours this season but he made a two-goal international debut for Northern Ireland last night.

The 20-year-old needed only 21 minutes to break the deadlock against Luxembourg in the poorly attended friendly here. Only 1,118 fans including a mere two dozen from Northern Ireland saw him launch his career on the big stage.

The new manager Sammy McIlroy ushered in a new era with a plethora of fresh faces. There were only three survivors from the last game in the European championship qualifiers under Lawrie McMenemy which the Irish lost 4-1 in Finland.

Healy was quick off the mark, raising hopes that at last Northern Ireland had unearthed the deadly finisher they had lacked for so long. The youngster combined cleverly with Keith Gillespie to fashion the opening goal, playing a quick interchange with the Blackburn Rovers wing raider and rifling a low drive past the cruelly exposed Alija Besic.

Northern Ireland were playing controlled football, with Jim Magilton, recalled to action for the first time in 18 months, stamping his authority in midfield. But the Ipswich player was cruelly out of luck in the 35th minute when he crashed a superb volley against the crossbar; again Gillespie had created the chance with an electrifying run.

The Irish were rarely put under pressure but were stunned by a 41st-minute equaliser from the cultured foot of Manuel Cardoni, who beat the keeper Roy Carroll with an exquisite curling shot from 30 yards.

However, the second half was only three minutes old when Healy struck again, with the central defender Mark Williams the provider. The big Watford man robbed Jeff Strasser in the penalty area and when he squared the ball across goal Healy pounced to side-foot it home.

Then Healy turned provider for Northern Ireland's third goal three minutes from the end, teeing up the chance for the eager James Quinn to finish from close range.

Michael Hughes, who replaced Damien Johnson 11 minutes from time, almost made it four in the dying seconds but his drive thudded against the woodwork. Even so it was a satisfying introduction to international team management for McIlroy, who made sweeping late changes to give all his bench a taste of the action.

Luxembourg (4-5-1): Besic; Vanek, Schaack, Birsens ( Alverdi, 4min) , F Deville; Strasser, Saibene, Holtz ( Daniel , 75) , Braun ( Zaritski , 61) , Cardoni; Schneider ( Christophe, h-t). .

Northern Ireland (4-4-2): Carroll (Wigan; Taylor , Fulham, 75); Nolan (Sheffield Wed), Williams (Watford; Murdock , Preston, 66), Griffin (St Johnstone; McGibbon , Wigan, 90), A Hughes (Newcastle Utd); Gillespie (Blackburn; Robinson , Bournemouth, 89), Lomas (West Ham, capt), Magilton (Ipswich; Sonner , Sheffield Wed, 75), Johnson (Blackburn; M Hughes , Wimbledon, 78); Quinn (West Brom; Coote, Norwich, 87), Healy (Manchester Utd).

Referee: M Schuttengruber (Austria).

webTitle: Robinson strikes as Wales dig deep for victory

fields.headline: Robinson strikes as Wales dig deep for victory
fields.standfirst: J Robinson 10
fields.trailText: Qatar 0 - 1 Wales
fields.body:
Mark Hughes defended his defensive tactics in the desert after his Wales side narrowly beat Qatar through John Robinson's early goal in the Al Arabi stadium yesterday.

Hughes, who beforehand admitted this friendly was effectively the start of Wales's World Cup qualifying campaign, played with five defenders, two deep midfielders and only Nathan Blake up front; and his only substitution was to bring on another centre-back, Kit Symons.

But after victory in his first game since being confirmed as manager, he said: "Playing with only one striker is not a defensive tactic. The impor tant thing was winning. It was hard work on a very hard pitch in difficult, humid conditions."

Hughes pointed to the fact that Wales created some good chances towards the end, with the captain Gary Speed, their best player, missing with two point-blank headers.

So in the end Wales were indebted to the goal struck by the Charlton winger after 10 minutes. Paul Jones's long goal-kick was touched down by Speed on the edge of the Qatar area and Robinson arrived at full speed to half-volley past Ahmed Khalil.

Qatar: Khalil; Al Noobi, Z Al Kuwari, Kuwari, Altmanini, F Al Kuwari, Nadno, Mohamed, Hassan, Jassim, Fatih.

Wales: P Jones (Southampton); Delaney (Aston Villa), Barnard (Barnsley), Melville (Fulham), Coleman (Fulham; Symons , Fulham), Page Watford); Robinson (Charlton), Speed (Newcastle), Pembridge (Everton), M Jones (Leeds), Blake (Blackburn).

Referee: Abdul Aziz (Bahrain).

webTitle: 'A humble man who never got carried away'

fields.headline: 'A humble man who never got carried away'
fields.standfirst:
English football's mesmerising winger dies at 85
Frank Keating remembers the Wizard of Dribbl
The Matthews story
Obituary
fields.trailText: Sir Tom Finney, who played alongside his fellow England legend in many internationals in the 40s and 50s, led the tributes last night to Sir Stanley Matthews.
fields.body:
Sir Tom Finney, who played alongside his fellow England legend in many internationals in the 40s and 50s, led the tributes last night to Sir Stanley Matthews.

"I've so many memories of Stan, and he was the greatest in my era in terms of close control," he said.

"His game was attacking the full-back. I can recall on so many occasions him having great games for England. Shortly after [West] Germany won the World Cup in 1954 we beat them at Wembley, and Stanley gave the left-back an awful roasting that day.

"He was a humble man and he never got carried away by how well he played."

Bobby Robson, who spoke of his "grief" and described himself as a "close friend" of Matthews, said: "He was one of easily our greatest, greatest players. He would have played in today's game, he would have adapted, don't you worry about that."

The Newcastle and former England manager added: "He had immense skill: great skill off the ball, a beautiful dribbler."

Jimmy Armfield, a former England captain, praised both Matthews' skills and sportsmanship. "You could kick him and do anything with him and he would never retaliate. He was the perfect example of self-discipline. I never remember a referee speaking to him once, and he didn't speak to them either."

Another former England manager, Sir Walter Winterbottom, said: "Stan was very fit and one thing he had was that he was very quick off the mark.

"Wingers in those days just stayed on the wing, and Stan had that unique way of dribbling past people."

David Davies, the Football Association's executive director, described Matthews as "a great, great player".

"As a child I was thrilled when I watched him. I knew then he was a legend and I was lucky later in life to meet him, and unlike some legends he did not disappoint when you met him.

"He was a great ambassador and served football all over the world long after many players have packed it in. Our country should be very proud of him and very sad tonight."

Asked if the new Wembley stadium might include a monument in memory of Matthews, Davies said: "He will be remembered in a proper way; he was a legend worldwide."

fields.standfirst:
English football's mesmerising winger dies at 85
Frank Keating remembers the Wizard of Dribble
Obituary
Tributes
fields.trailText:
1915 Born Hanley, February 1. Third of four sons of Jack Matthews, 'The Fighting Barber'
1929 Joins Stoke at age of 14, sweeping dressing rooms and cleaning 46 pairs of boots
1932 Turns pro and makes league debut aged 17 at Bury
1933 Helps Stoke to Second Division championship
1934 First England cap against Wales, at 19 years and 240 days
1936 Stoke finish fourth in First Division - still their best performance
1937 Only England hat-trick, against Czechoslovakia
1939-46 Plays in 30 wartime internationals
1948 Footballer of the year; transferred to Blackpool for £11,500
1948 Loses 4-2 to Manchester United in FA Cup final
1951 Second Wembley defeat, 2-0 against Newcastle
1953 The Matthews Final: Blackpool beat Bolton 4-3
1956 European player of the year
1957 Wins 54th and final England cap against Denmark, aged 42 years and 103 days; European footballer of the year; awarded CBE
1961 Returns to Stoke in £2,500 deal 1963 Footballer of the year again; Stoke promoted; oldest player to score in a league game, aged 48
1964 Oldest player to score in the FA Cup, aged 49
1965 Awarded a knighthood while still active. Last game v Fulham aged 50 years and five days, then retires after 710 league games for Stoke and Blackpool - later says he quit too soon. Becomes manager of Port Vale
1967 Decides management is not for him and embarks on lifelong role as a roving ambassador for football
1987 PFA merit award
1992 Fifa gold merit order

fields.headline: Heskey hoists England standard
fields.trailText: England passed muster against Argentina last night. They mustered a sufficient number of accurate, imaginative passes to vindicate Kevin Keegan's decision to pack his midfield with ball players.
fields.body:
England passed muster against Argentina last night. They mustered a sufficient number of accurate, imaginative passes to vindicate Kevin Keegan's decision to pack his midfield with ball players.

Dennis Wise was the most consistent distributor while David Beckham provided a consistent quality of balls from free-kicks and corners. England's greatest success, however, was Leicester City's Emile Heskey, whose speed, power and aggression caused Argentina's defenders more problems than Alan Shearer.

Late in the game Shearer and Heskey gave way to Kevin Phillips and Andy Cole as England sought the victory their performance merited.

One international in six months, and that a friendly , was never going to tell Keegan a lot about England's chances in Euro 2000 or much about the sort of side he might choose for the opening match against Portugal. Like so many England fixtures, the prime purpose of last night's exercise was to obliterate bad memories of the preceding match.

By employing Beckham and Wise in central midfield, with Paul Scholes detailed to push forward to support the strikers, Keegan was entitled to ex pect an improvement on the poor passing and movement which led to England being booed off after Scotland won 1-0 at Wembley last November in the return leg of the European Championship play-off.

Argentina played with Gabriel Batistuta up front supported by Ariel Ortega and Juan Veron tucking in behind while Diego Simeone set about forging links between defence and attack. An early burst on the right from Ortega offered England warning, although Keegan's side began briskly enough, with a dangerously swerving free-kick from Beckham on the left volleyed clear by Roberto Sensini.

In Beckham's assured deliv ery of the ball at set-pieces lay a likely English advantage, although Heskey, starting his first international at this level, was a growing influence. After 10 minutes a left-wing corner from Beckham found Alan Shearer losing his marker, Roberto Ayala, to head just wide of the far post.

The speed of Argentina on the break was always going to test the fragile defensive qualities of Keegan's highly theoretical midfield and from the outset it was clear that Wise would be covering a lot of ground. Yet the combination of Beckham's accuracy and Heskey's willingness to take the ball wide on either flank helped England to dominate the game territorially during the first half-hour.

One delightful through ball from Wise found Heskey outpacing the defence on the right before crossing low for Jason Wilcox to see a centre from the left cut out by Pablo Cavallero, the Argentine goalkeeper. Then Heskey forced his way past Sensini on the opposite flank before centring for Shearer to go sprawling as Jose Chamot challenged him, although Wembley's claims for a penalty were somewhat hopeful.

By this time Beckham had been cautioned by the German referee for a high lunge from the side at Cristian Gonzalez. While the foul was hardly serious it was a reminder to Eng land of what they can expect from referees this summer.

Nor did Herr Merk have any truck with Ortega's attempt to win a penalty by diving over Kieron Dyer's challenge after he had beaten Gareth Southgate. It brought the Argentine a yellow card.

England might have been ahead at half-time. In the 42nd minute another profound long pass from Wise again found Heskey in space, this time on the left. The Leicester striker laid another low cross into the goalmouth but Ayala intercepted the ball before it could reach the incoming Scholes.

Rio Ferdinand replaced Martin Keown for the second half which meant that England,for once, were playing a genuine sweeper. Wise, however, remained England's main provider from deep positions, effortlessly spraying the ball to open up the wings.

Argentina were still reluctant to raise the tempo of their game, yet the danger for England's defenders was always there.

Early in the second half Ortega and Veron set up a narrow-angled scoring chance for Gonzalez which gave David Seaman a rare moment of urgent action.

Batistuta, whose contribution had been minimal, gave way to Hernan Crespo just before the hour. Soon afterwards Dyer, a sporadic influence on the right for England, was replaced by Phil Neville.

Shearer, while lacking nothing in industry, was struggling against the close attentions of Ayala. With Kevin Phillips on the bench and Heskey still full of running Keegan had the opportunity for a further, perhaps more meaningful, experiment.

England (3-4-1-2): Seaman (Arsenal); Keown (Arsenal; Ferdinand, West Ham, h-t), Southgate (Aston Villa), Campbell (Tottenham); Dyer (Newcastle); P Neville, Man Utd, 59min), Beckham, (Man Utd; Parlour, Arsenal,72) Wise (Chelsea), Wilcox (Leeds); Scholes (Man Utd); Shearer (Newcastle; Phillips, Sunderland, 78), Heskey (Leicester; Cole, Man Utd, 79)).

Argentina (3-1-3-2-1): Cavallero (Espanyol); Ayala (Milan), Sensini (Lazio; Pochettino, Espanyol, 35), Chamot (Milan); Simeone (Inter); Zanetti ( Inter), Gonzalez (Valencia), Arruabarrena (Boca Juniors); Ortega (Parma), Veron (Lazio); Batistuta (Fiorentina; Crespo, Parma, 57).

Referee: M. Merk (Germany).

An early burst on the right from Ortega offered England warning, although Keegan's side began briskly enough, with a dangerously swerving free-kick from Beckham on the left volleyed clear by Roberto Sensini. In Beckham's assured deliv ery of the ball at set-pieces lay a likely English advantage, although Heskey, starting his first international at this level, was a growing influence. After 10 minutes a left-wing corner from Beckham found Alan Shearer losing his marker, Roberto Ayala, to head just wide of the far post. The speed of Argentina on the break was always going to test the fragile defensive qualities of Keegan's highly theoretical midfield and from the outset it was clear that Wise would be covering a lot of ground. Yet the combination of Beckham's accuracy and Heskey's willingness to take the ball wide on either flank helped England to dominate the game territorially during the first half-hour. One delightful through ball from Wise found Heskey outpacing the defence on the right before crossing low for Jason Wilcox to see a centre from the left cut out by Pablo Cavallero, the Argentine goalkeeper. Then Heskey forced his way past Sensini on the opposite flank before centring for Shearer to go sprawling as Jose Chamot challenged him, although Wembley's claims for a penalty were somewhat hopeful. By this time Beckham had been cautioned by the German referee for a high lunge from the side at Cristian Gonzalez. While the foul was hardly serious it was a reminder to Eng land of what they can expect from referees this summer. Nor did Herr Merk have any truck with Ortega's attempt to win a penalty by diving over Kieron Dyer's challenge after he had beaten Gareth Southgate. It brought the Argentine a yellow card. England might have been ahead at half-time. In the 42nd minute another profound long pass from Wise again found Heskey in space, this time on the left. The Leicester striker laid another low cross into the goalmouth but Ayala intercepted the ball before it could reach the incoming Scholes. Rio Ferdinand replaced Martin Keown for the second half which meant that England,for once, were playing a genuine sweeper. Wise, however, remained England's main provider from deep positions, effortlessly spraying the ball to open up the wings. Argentina were still reluctant to raise the tempo of their game, yet the danger for England's defenders was always there. Early in the second half Ortega and Veron set up a narrow-angled scoring chance for Gonzalez which gave David Seaman a rare moment of urgent action. Batistuta, whose contribution had been minimal, gave way to Hernan Crespo just before the hour. Soon afterwards Dyer, a sporadic influence on the right for England, was replaced by Phil Neville. Shearer, while lacking nothing in industry, was struggling against the close attentions of Ayala. With Kevin Phillips on the bench and Heskey still full of running Keegan had the opportunity for a further, perhaps more meaningful, experiment. Argentina (3-1-3-2-1): Cavallero (Espanyol); Ayala (Milan), Sensini (Lazio; Pochettino, Espanyol, 35), Chamot (Milan); Simeone (Inter); Zanetti ( Inter), Gonzalez (Valencia), Arruabarrena (Boca Juniors); Ortega (Parma), Veron (Lazio); Batistuta (Fiorentina; Crespo, Parma, 57). Referee: M. Merk (Germany). Minute-by-minute match report Wiseacres proved wrong

webTitle: Short but sweet, the Wiseacres are proved wrong as Dennis leaves menace behind

fields.headline: Short but sweet, the Wiseacres are proved wrong as Dennis leaves menace behind
fields.standfirst: The 'naughty but nice' imp of midfield repays trust of Keegan
fields.trailText: Asked once to describe himself, Dennis Wise responded with a single word: short. So while it would be wrong to suggest he left here last night with his head high, the Chelsea captain could afford one of his impish grins. This was Dennis largely without the menace. Even the tunnel was still standing at the end.
fields.body:
Asked once to describe himself, Dennis Wise responded with a single word: short. So while it would be wrong to suggest he left here last night with his head high, the Chelsea captain could afford one of his impish grins. This was Dennis largely without the menace. Even the tunnel was still standing at the end.

Sure, there was the customary booking for a foul on Cristian Gonzalez but this was a controlled, impressive display by Wise on his first international start for five years.

Having repaid Kevin Keegan's trust with a busy performance in front of the defence, it would be a surprise to find him omitted from the Euro 2000 squad. Keegan explained he wanted the "good things" and largely he got them.

The evening had begun promisingly for Wise. In the lead-up to such a big match he was presumably warned by Keegan to steer clear of the bottle. Sure enough, to the relief of team-mates and opponents, he took the field without Lucozade in his hand. Sensibly, it was one of England's backroom staff who handed him a drop of the isotonic stuff before kick-off and quickly whipped the bottle away.

Lining up for the national anthems beside the 6ft 3in Martin Keown, Wise was his usual bundle of energy. It was clear the last thing the Chelsea captain wanted was to be standing still.

So it must have surprised no one that not even a lost boot, sustained in a challenge with Argentina's captain Roberto Sensini, prevented him playing on early on. Immediately Wise was on his feet, looking for a pass, controlling the ball with his left sock. More of a shock was that it took fully a dozen minutes for the 33-year-old to receive his first talking-to from the German referee. That was for a characteristic welcome-to-Wembley challenge on Juan Veron. Just to prove he was on his best behaviour, Wise extended a hand to the Lazio midfielder. He likes to see himself as "naughty but nice".

Certainly there was plenty to admire in his early contributions. At Wimbledon he was known as The Rat - always nibbling at you, John Fashanu explained - and he rarely gave Argentina space to breath. Nipping in with neat interceptions, playing simple passes, rarely wasting possession, he was in his element. All mixed in, of course, with the odd foul.

Although he gradually dropped deeper into a holding role he displayed an impressive range of passing and was involved in several of England's best moments. Three times in the first half he released Emile Heskey with perceptive through-balls. It was from his right-wing cross that Heskey headed wide.

But no Wise contribution is complete without a yellow card and it duly arrived in the 46th minute, though that did not take the competitive edge off his game. Straight away he was clattering into an opponent, cajoling team-mates with words and clenched-fist salutes. After all the questions, Keegan could afford to feel Wise after the event.

webTitle: Leicester on Reds alert over Heskey

fields.headline: Leicester on Reds alert over Heskey
fields.trailText: Leicester City are to make concerted efforts to keep their England striker Emile Heskey in the face of increasingly urgent interest from Liverpool.
fields.body:
Leicester City are to make concerted efforts to keep their England striker Emile Heskey in the face of increasingly urgent interest from Liverpool.

Although there is an agreement that would see Heskey leave for Anfield at the end of the season for a club-record fee of about £9m, Leicester's chairman John Elsom says he wants him to stay.

It had been thought that, with Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler injured, Liverpool would try to push through the deal after Leicester play in Sunday's Worthington Cup final.

But Elsom denied that Heskey was seeking a move to Merseyside. "I think it's quite the opposite, he's very happy to stay here," he said.

"I would like Emile to be playing for us next season. He is contracted to us and as far as I'm concerned nobody is trying to change that. There is a clear value in keeping this team together."

Dwight Yorke has rejoined Trinidad and Tobago in the United States as they prepare for today's Gold Cup semi-final against Canada in Los Angeles.

The Manchester United striker played in his national team's group matches but missed the quarter-final golden-goal win against Costa Rica on Sunday because he was at Leeds for the Premiership leaders' 1-0 win.

He was withdrawn after 30 minutes at Elland Road with a thigh injury, casting doubt over his further involvement in the Gold Cup. But United and the FA of Trinidad and Tobago gave him the green light to return, although the club insist he will not be fit for the semi-final.

"This has not been an easy situation for me," said Yorke. "I love representing my club and country. Thankfully the decision was taken out of my hands.

"I have been getting intensive treatment for my injury at the club and I'm not sure whether I'll be fit to play, but I will have a fitness test once I get back there.

"The semi-finals of the Gold Cup is a huge game for Trinidad and Tobago, but equally the European games coming up for the club are just as important."

Celestine Babayaro returned to Chelsea on Tuesday, more than a week after he was due back at the club from the African Nations Cup after Nigeria's defeat on penalties in the final.

The defender, who according to some sources had contracted malaria and to another, his guardian, had been held up by civil unrest in northern Nigeria, flew back into London from Lagos and yesterday returned to training with the club.

Chelsea's assistant manager Gwyn Williams dismissed the malaria report but said: "He's back and that's the main thing. He'll train with the players not away on international duty and then we'll have a chat."

Babayaro's international team-mate Nwankwo Kanu was reported to be back at Arsenal, on schedule.

Fifa plans to draw up a list of professional referees to officiate in the 2002 World Cup. Their salaries would be paid by national associations in countries with a professional league.

webTitle: Marseille keeper Porato fails light-bulb test

fields.headline: Marseille keeper Porato fails light-bulb test
fields.trailText: The Marseille goalkeeper Stéphane Porato will miss both of his club's forthcoming Champions League matches against Chelsea after injuring himself while changing a light bulb at home.
fields.body:
The Marseille goalkeeper Stéphane Porato will miss both of his club's forthcoming Champions League matches against Chelsea after injuring himself while changing a light bulb at home.

The 26-year-old, who made his debut for France in November, fell from a stepladder and will be out for three weeks with a sprained left knee.

Chelsea travel to Marseille's Stade Vélodrome next week for the resumption of their European campaign, with the return match at Stamford Bridge a week later.

Porato's injury could not have come at a worse time for Marseille. The defenders William Gallas, Jean-Pierre Cyprien and Franck Dumas, as well as the influential midfield player Peter Luccin, are injured; the club are bottom of Champions League Group D after two games, with no points and no goals; they have slumped to within five points of the relegation zone at home; and they were knocked out of the French Cup by Gueugnon of the Second Division.

Newcastle United protested yesterday to the Peruvian Football Association that Nolberto Solano played in the Gold Cup in Calfornia despite his club having said he was injured.

Bobby Robson, Newcastle's manager, allowed Solano to join the Peru squad on the understanding that their officials would study medical reports on a thigh injury and then send him back to England. But Solano, whose injury had kept him out of Newcastle's previous two matches, played in a 1-1 draw against Haiti last week and was forced to come off with four minutes remaining after aggravating the problem.

Robson said: "I told him not to come back injured. He will have to deal with me when he returns. I wouldn't have risked him in that game but Peru did and now they are returning an injured player. They will find out we are tough customers to deal with and Solano will find that out as well."

The International Olympic Committee president Juan Antonio Samaranch wants more experienced players to improve the standard of football in the Sydney Games, a move which may spark a new row with Europe's top clubs.

Clashes are almost certain to occur as clubs are asked to release players for the Olympic tournament, which runs from September 15 to October 2 and coincides with the early part of the season in much of Europe.

At the Atlanta Games in 1996 the rules allowed each nation to pick only three players aged over 23. But Samaranch has said he is in favour of more older players taking part in Sydney. "I don't like the idea of three over-23 players," he said. "As IOC president I'll have to fight for there to be more. I'd like there to be five or even seven over-23s playing."

The G-14 lobbying group of European clubs, including Real Madrid and Manchester United, have already highlighted the problem and have suggested that the Champions League should be suspended for the duration of the Olympic tournament.

webTitle: The song remains a shame: why I'm quitting Wisden

fields.headline: The song remains a shame: why I'm quitting Wisden
fields.standfirst: After eight years of digesting English failure, Matthew Engel is changing diets
fields.trailText: After eight years of digesting English failure, Matthew Engel is changing diets
fields.body:
Wisden 2000 made its way to the printers on Monday night. It will be published on April 6. And then my ability to comment on events from the most wonderful pulpit in sport will come to at least a temporary end. I'm taking a year off. Someone else (Graeme Wright, from whom I took over the job eight years ago) will edit Wisden 2001.

I don't believe in digging in forever, and eight years is a pretty decent term. Of the 13 men known to have edited Wisden since 1864, only three have lasted longer. (Six of the 13 have died in office, most of them with disconcerting suddenness.)

The United States constitution prohibits holders of the presidency from staying on beyond eight years. It's fair to say that modern US presidents are more likely than Wisden editors to get literally shagged out. The Wisden job, though, is tiring enough, especially for someone who also has responsibilities to the Guardian and to a family.

But any cricket-lover knows that bowlers can keep going far longer if they're taking wickets. I have been obliged to edit Wisden against a background of failure. This is not failure on the part of the almanack itself - we have, miraculously, maintained our annual sale of nearly 40,000 - but of English cricket.

Sydney Pardon, the greatest and longest-serving of all Wisden editors (1891-1925), did not have to report and explain defeats against New Zealand. He did have to deal with some pretty hefty Ashes defeats. ("Humiliating," he wrote in 1922, "... never before was an England side so slow and slovenly.") But it has been the relentlessness of the failures in the 1990s which has been unique.

In the 1980s, when I was the Guardian's cricket correspondent, England lost an awful lot of matches. But they won the Ashes three times and, when they failed, they did so on a more heroic scale.

That was a time when English football was in eclipse: defeat on the field worsened by hooliganism, bordering on terrorism, off it.

The best footballer in the country was Bryan Robson. As a headline figure he wasn't a patch on Ian Botham, or David Gower, or Graham Gooch. Cricket was fashionable, and the talk of the public bar and the bus queues. Now the nation is more interested in what David Beckham wears under his shorts or sarong than in anything Nasser Hussain or Alec Stewart might do.

The World Cup last summer was England's great opportunity: a once-in-a-generation chance to play in the game's top tournament in front of their own people with conditions skewed to their advantage. They blew it, and followed up by losing, appallingly, to New Zealand.

Given that there are 1,600 pages in Wisden 2000, England's affairs are only a small part of its content. Indeed, the book has been planned not as an inquest on English cricket but as a celebration: of the game throughout the 20th century. We shall be announcing, for instance, the Wisden Five Cricketers of the Century.

But you can't hide in the past. The England team creates the mood and sets the standards: young people need role models, stars to emulate. They need a Warne or Tendulkar or Lara to inspire them. England have had no such player in years.

It's tiresome for the England players to keep being slagged off. After all (give or take the odd aberration from the selectors), they're the best we've got. It's even more tiresome for Mike Selvey and the rest of the cricket correspondents who are expected to watch every day of every Test, which the Wisden editor is not. But I've done my best to home in on what I thought was wrong. It seems like time to let someone else have a crack.

These things change. With my luck it will probably change this summer, when England take on another fading team, West Indies (for the Wisden Trophy, as it happens); maybe Graeme Wright will get the chance to celebrate the moment. But, frankly, it doesn't matter who the singer is; the song has got to change.

Matthew Engel is a Guardian columnist and a former Guardian cricket correspondent.

webTitle: Door opens for Thorpe and Hick

fields.headline: Door opens for Thorpe and Hick
fields.standfirst: England return in good heart but bad lack of middle-order quality
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain plans for the future as England return home in good heart but with a bad lack of middle-order quality.
fields.body:
There is a notion that Graham Thorpe and Mark Ramprakash have merely to give a nod of assent and they will be welcomed back into the England team amid more hugging and blubbing than you get on This Is Your Life.

This is not entirely the case. It is a measure of Nasser Hussain's character that, despite tripping at the two most important of the three hurdles he faced this winter, the England captain returns home tomorrow with his reputation enhanced and his power base greatly strengthened. If senior players absent this winter are to return to the England side, it will be on the captain's terms.

After the final one-day international against Zimbabwe was washed out by Cyclone Eline here yesterday, Hussain said: "We will have to bring back a couple of quality players but we also need to keep the team spirit and the fight we've achieved on this trip.

"There are no excuses now. Duncan [Fletcher, the coach] and I have seen most things. We have seen the experienced players in the past year or so and this winter we have seen the younger ones. Now we must gel the two together and do the best thing for English cricket for the next year. We must be really firm and solid.

"I like volatile players. I like to see people get angry in the dressing room. But we must somehow retain what we have created on this trip. I'll be surprised if we don't reintroduce certain players but it will only happen one or two at a time."

Hussain is known to admire Thorpe, who made himself unavailable for the Test series in South Africa. He was available for the one-day tournament that followed but the selectors rightly declined the offer. Despite his proven class Thorpe, especially on tour, has been too self-contained and introverted for England's liking.

Ramprakash was available but not picked. This was not on grounds of ability; in the past two years he has often been the side's best batsman. But the intensity of his desire to succeed has not always endeared him to the dressing room.

Thorpe would help repair the soft centre of England's batting and Ramprakash's best chance is to open alongside Michael Atherton.

There are also evangelical whispers about bringing out the best in Graeme Hick. There is not room for all of them, especially with Michael Vaughan deserving a place. But the selectors got England's batting wrong this winter; the quality has been far too thin.

"The middle order does need looking at." said Hussain. "So does the bowling when the ball is doing a bit. We have not always controlled it well. We have to look at no-balls and at handling the pressure.

"In the one-day games we have chased well when we have needed 180 or 190 and Nick Knight and myself have got us off to a good start. But the recent one-day matches have been low-scoring. We must be able to chase 270 or 280 after losing a couple of early wickets.

webTitle: The Wizard of Dribble and ever the gentil, parfait knight

fields.headline: The Wizard of Dribble and ever the gentil, parfait knight
fields.standfirst:
English football's mesmerising winger dies at 85
The Matthews story
Obituary
Tributes
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Matthews raised dribbling to the very highest degree. They say he would have been smacked and barged and elbowed out of today's game.
fields.body:
At last night's news I found myself going straight to Alan Ross's enduringly descriptive poem:

"... he draws defenders towards him, the ball a bait.

They refuse like a poisoned chocolate, retreating, till he slows his gait

To a walk, inviting the tackle, inciting it."

That was exactly as I remember it as a boy when, awestruck, I first saw him play on the right-wing. He was old then, back in the stripes of Stoke City. He not only mesmerised me. He mesmerised 60,000 at Stamford Bridge. Certainly he made a monkey of Chelsea's defence that day; and they were in their 20s, he was 50.

They say Matthews today would have been smacked and barged and elbowed out of his unique footballing talent. He was a dribbler. But he did not invent dribbling, that is, beating a defender with a shimmy and a shuffle and a dare and a close-quartered hopscotch. He simply raised dribbling to the very highest degree, and the universe knew he had changed his world completely.

I sent Sir Stanley a Christmas card. I hoped he was feeling OK. He rang back, of course, and said "Sure." I had telephoned earlier in the winter, with condolences, when his beloved Mila had died. You just felt you had to ring. Ever the gentil parfait knight, he went through the motions but you knew, and so did he, that there was actually no reason to call. When Lady Mila had gone, he knew he would not be too long behind her.

He had travelled the world, living in Malta, South Africa and Canada. But he came home to Stoke, where his father had eked a living as a barber and a prizefighter. Now, he said in his dotage, if I have to go down to the shops I have to "pass the ruddy statue".

In truth, he was proud of it, I think, as it stood at the entrance of his home town of Hanley, a life-size bronze showing him spry and jaunty on the ball, dallying with it but, possibly, waiting to win a Cup final with it. And the inscription says: "His name is symbolic of the beauty of the game, his fame timeless and international, his sportsmanship and modesty acclaimed."

A couple of years ago his grand Hungarian rival Puskas - one of the few players you could bracket in the same aura as Matthews - came to England to promote a book. Sir Stanley helped him promote it back at Wembley. Stan arrived in a tizz, sorry to be held up in London's traffic.

Puskas was posing for pictures in a goalmouth but spotted Matthews 100 yards away. The Hungarian hurried tubbily to embrace the sheepish Englishman, alone on the right touchline, of course. They snogged a while, then Matthews said, "Puskas, you were the greatest." And Puskas said: "Maybe, but you are the very, very, all-time greatest." It was touching to be there.

On September 26 1930 the Stoke Sentinel noted that Burnley that Saturday would be "up against a very useful 15-year-old outside-right S Matthews, who had been doing great things in private trials". The following Monday the Sentinel reported a forthright 2-1 victory in which "Matthews frequently gained the applause of the crowd".

Twenty-three years later Matthews mesmerised the whole Coronation country and many parts of the Commonwealth and world as well. His Blackpool team played Bolton and, with a minute left, it was 3-3. Raymond Glendenning's dulcets on the wireless told the world: "... Taylor to Matthews on the right... Matthews beats one man, beats two... moves in... he centres... it's Perry... Perry has scored, Perry has scored!" All thanks to Stan. And the young Queen knighted him.

A defender, a stalwart one, Roy Sproson, once described what it was like to defend against Stan: "You have to fancy yourself against him for a start, else you might as well go and buy a Green 'Un there and then. He came at you fast enough, then ponders a bit in front of you, sort of jockeying, shimmying, already asking how you fancy it. It's his classic situation, that. So then he sort of leaps at you in a split second but shoves the ball far too much in front of him. So this time, you're all right, and you smile to yourself.

"Then, unbelievable. Just as I've taken it off his toe, me just an eighth of an inch from the ball and glory - and he's found another gear, two ruddy gears, and his toe comes up and sniffs it past you and he's skipping past my sliding leg and he's away... I thought I had him, I knew I'd had him but now I'm flat on my backside with all the crowd laughing... and I know that genius is genius and I'm just a fairly good full-back."

And I can say, "I saw Matthews play." That sets me a class above already.

fields.headline: Police race failures exposed
fields.standfirst:
Only 260 extra ethnic officers among 5,000 new recruits as numbers in some forces drop
Special report one year on from Macpherson
Full table of results for 2000
The Stephen Lawrence Family Campaign
Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: More than a third of police forces have failed to hire a single extra black or Asian officer in the year since the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report demanded a rapid increase in recruitment, a Guardian survey reveals today.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins, Vikram Dodd  and  Sally James
fields.body:
More than a third of police forces have failed to hire a single extra black or Asian officer in the year since the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report demanded a rapid increase in recruitment, a Guardian survey reveals today.

The number of ethnic minority officers has fallen in nine of the 43 forces in England and Wales and seven others have recorded no increase.

The Guardian questionnaire, marking the first anniversary of Sir William Macpherson's landmark report, asked forces for the progress they have made on basic measures seen as the first stage in eradicating racism in the ranks.

With the exception of the Metropolitan police, forces have managed to recruit on average fewer than two officers each in the past year. In total, 260 extra Asian and black officers were taken on across England and Wales last year out of 5,000 new recruits, despite demands from the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the police become "the champions of a multi-cultural society".

Only the Met managed to recruit significant numbers of black and Asian officers - 184 - more than twice the number taken on by all the other forces. In the Met, the focus of Sir William's criticism, 4% of officers are now black or Asian, compared with a fifth of the population in London. The force still pledged to hire 5,000 more ethnic minority officers by 2009.

The Guardian survey also shows that almost two-thirds of forces have failed to meet Sir William's demand that they train staff fully in racial awareness and cultural diversity, with only 17 complying. The training is either still in development or only partially implemented in the others. And almost half the forces (20) still do not have tests to measure whether their officers have racist attitudes, as recommended by her majesty's inspector of constabulary.

Superintendent Peter Williams, national secretary of the police superintendents' association, said more time was needed. "The recruitment process can take 18 months. Training programmes have to be devised correctly before they are undertaken. A truer picture will emerge 12 months from now."

Tony Burden, vice-president of the association of chief police officers, added: "There are some excellent initiatives under way."

However, the national black police association said the Guardian's findings were independent evidence that even basic changes had not taken place in the past 12 months. Its chairman, Paul Wilson, said: "The measures are bread and butter ones that should have been progressed immediately after the inquiry... They haven't even got to the first hurdle. Though there's a lot of frenetic activity now, there's a hope within forces that this issue will go away, that the agenda will change. There's no evidence that things have improved for black officers."

The managing director of the Ionann, a company appointed by the home office to train forces in community and race relations, told the Guardian an overwhelming number of officers had a problem with race and some "don't see black people as individuals".

Dianna Yach said the firm had worked with eight forces to assses attitudes to Asians and Afro-Caribbeans. "Two-thirds of police officers have a problem addressing the race issue, either because of ignorance, confusion or being difficult. I suppose, based on the feedback we've had, one third are very resistant to change.

"They don't think there is a problem, they can't see the connection between race equality and service delivery. A third are confused and resentful, but not actively resistant. A third are switched on and are willing to learn."

Yesterday Mr Straw unveiled a progress report which showed that half of Sir William's 70 recommendations had already been implemented. He said the inquiry had had a cathartic effect on race relations and had opened up the eyes of white people to what it felt like to be black or Asian. "What's important is that the police embrace this agenda for change."

webTitle: Michael Colvin MP and wife feared dead after blaze guts mansion

fields.headline: Michael Colvin MP and wife feared dead after blaze guts mansion
fields.standfirst:
More about Michael Colvin MP
ITN video of the fire
fields.trailText: Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola were today missing, feared dead after fire gutted their country house in Hampshire.
fields.body:
Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola were today missing, feared dead after fire gutted their country house in Hampshire.

Tangley House, in the village of Tangley near Andover, was swept by flames fanned by high winds early today. Firefighters tried to rescue the two people reported trapped in the house but were beaten back by the heat.

Detective Superintendent Mike Lane said police believed the couple had died in the blaze.

The couple's butler, Alvaro Pereira, raised the alarm around 4am when a worker from Mr Colvin's 1,000-acre estate spotted smoke and flames billowing from the 10-bedroom property.

Hampshire police officers at the scene confirmed that the couple were reported to be in the house when the fire broke out and remained unaccounted for.

About 70 firefighters and 10 fire appliances were this morning still at the scene damping down the large country house, which was almost totally destroyed by the blaze.

Malcolm Eastwood, chief fire officer for Hampshire Fire and Rescue Service, said : "[The house] has been totally devastated by fire. Around about 95% of the building has been involved in fire and the rest has been smoke damaged.

"The fire had been whipped up by the wind which acted like a blow torch. It was white flame, completely engulfing the house.

"The water supply was totally inadequate as you get in a rural area. We have had to bring in water carriers.

"Initially the call told us that there were two persons reported in the property.

"Crews tried to get into the house on the west side of the building where the people were reported, but were fought back by flames."

Lizzie Perry, chairwoman of Romsey Conservative Club, confirmed that Mr Colvin and his wife were believed to have been at home last night.

She said: "It is my belief that they were at home last night. We are very, very shocked." Ms Perry added that she had spoken to the MP yesterday afternoon and he was in "good spirits".

Jane Kennedy Scott, a spokeswoman for Hampshire police, said the cause of the fire was not currently being treated as suspicious.

fields.trailText: Andrew Marr and Tom Nairn have produced books on an almost identical topic: the growth of nationalism in Britain and the likely breakup of the United Kingdom. It seemed an obvious pairing, yet few papers made the connection. Nor did they ask their political heavyweights to assess the daunting thesis - that our current political arrangements are unsustainable. Perhaps the burlesque of the London mayoral race has diverted eyes from the more important issues.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr and Tom Nairn have produced books on an almost identical topic: the growth of nationalism in Britain and the likely breakup of the United Kingdom. It seemed an obvious pairing, yet few papers made the connection. Nor did they ask their political heavyweights to assess the daunting thesis - that our current political arrangements are unsustainable. Perhaps the burlesque of the London mayoral race has diverted eyes from the more important issues.

Of the two, Andrew Marr's The Day Britain Died (Profile Books, £7.99) gained more attention (the fact that it was backed by a TV series may have helped). Marr is one of Britain's - we can, presumably, still use that term - most insightful commentators, as fellow pundit Matthew Parris made clear in the Times. "When one learns that the author has 'travelled around the country', 'meeting people', the heart sinks," he wrote. "Meeting which people? Who chose them? Why? But then the eye moves to the author's name: Andrew Marr. The heart lifts. This will be the product of a real mind, a singular literary flair, an integrity still intact. Such an author is capable of stamping a book - maybe even a television series - with an idea."

And, he concludes, Marr has. "Shorn of the many intriguing sideways insights the author provides, the central idea is simple, powerful, and finally persuasive: Englishness exists. England's senses of itself go back more than a thousand years, albeit in different forms, and unless England is recognised and given a new sense of its own security, then all hopes for a liberal, open, democratic and tolerant future are in danger... Yet England has been pushed into a corner where it is expected to passively await its future. That, in itself, is dangerous."

Parris's focus on that strand of Marr's book was perhaps a little perverse: the view from north of the border looked rather different. "What does it mean to be British, he asks. The answer: not a lot," wrote James Robertson in Scotland on Sunday.

"Almost nothing to most Scots, nor, in fact, to the people hardest hit by the disintegration of the 'British' label, those for whom it has been a threadbare safety net against racism. Many who immigrated between the 50s and 70s, who came as a consequence of the historical fact of empire, now find that the identity they thought was theirs to put on has been discarded by others in favour of Scottish, Welsh and even English ones.

"The term 'British', it is now clear, was created and sustained for only one reason: the empire. Without the empire, it is redundant. Marr puts this into a wider context: the Americanisation of the world; the growth of Asian and Pacific economic power; the end of Communism and the new Europe. Identity is flexible now: all of us have become Europeans and Americans to some extent in the way we live our lives."

Several reviewers mentioned that the book had evidently been written in a rush (Marr admitted as much in the introduction). "This book, at first, feels deadeningly over-familiar," wrote Andy Beckett in the Guardian. "Andrew Marr has produced - at speed - a volume heavily reliant on quotes from his fellow pundits and polemicists. Here are half-page sections and hurried references from Jeremy Paxman's The English, Peter Hitchens's The Abolition of Britain, Simon Heffer's Nor Shall My Sword: The Reinvention of England - all recent books, all concerned with the temperature of the nation in the early fevers of devolution, and all slightly patched together, short on original fact and thought."

But Beckett quickly warmed to the book, especially when Marr took to the road and started to quote the opinions of anxious Brits. "The Britain that emerges is mixed-up, complicated, and 'in a state of constant flux'," concluded Beckett. "The supposedly cruel capital, for example, absorbs immigrants more easily than allegedly friendlier regions. The English patriots of the Home Counties know more about Normandy than the north of England. The idea of Englishness itself, Marr suggests, may never, at any time, have meant the same thing to everyone.

"His writing relishes these tensions and contradictions: English tabloid culture is neatly summarised as 'swagger and self-pity'; the 'strange, sharp flavour' of modern Britain is crisply evoked. Marr concludes that only a federal country, with separate parliaments for each of its parts, can hope to hold such a hybrid together. He fears a complete break-up, interestingly, for the squeeze it might put on minorities."

Meanwhile, Tom Nairn's After Britain: New Labour and the Return of Scotland (Granta, £15.99) got shorter shrift. A ponderous review by T M Devine in the Times found the book "eloquent and sophisticated" but had difficulty explaining why. "We may indeed be seeing the first stages of a general reconfiguration of relationships within the British archipelago which, inter alia, disperses power from Westminster and by so doing maintains the political links between England and Scotland," wrote Devine.

"If London can respond positively and sympathetically to such a dynamic, the best bet for the future is probably a framework of federalism, rather than 'Scottish independence' in the classic form delineated in Tom Nairn's stimulating book." I think the publicists will just be satisfied with the word stimulating.

Bernard Crick, in the Independent, was less well disposed to Nairn, dismissing his notion that the Scottish people felt the gaping wound of their lost state as "romantic nonsense". "Nairn, amazingly, is an old-fashioned sovereignty man," Crick pointed out with a nice touch of irony. "The British state is worn out, so therefore a Scottish state is needed."

There was a more generous review in the Observer. "Nairn is certainly a beast seen as fleetingly in these northern islands as the Arctic char or the wild cat - a genuine native intellectual... It seemed an obvious pairing, yet few papers made the connection. Nor did they ask their political heavyweights to assess the daunting thesis - that our current political arrangements are unsustainable. Perhaps the burlesque of the London mayoral race has diverted eyes from the more important issues. Of the two, Andrew Marr's The Day Britain Died (Profile Books, £7.99) gained more attention (the fact that it was backed by a TV series may have helped). Marr is one of Britain's - we can, presumably, still use that term - most insightful commentators, as fellow pundit Matthew Parris made clear in the Times. "When one learns that the author has 'travelled around the country', 'meeting people', the heart sinks," he wrote. "Meeting which people? Who chose them? Why? But then the eye moves to the author's name: Andrew Marr. The heart lifts. This will be the product of a real mind, a singular literary flair, an integrity still intact. Such an author is capable of stamping a book - maybe even a television series - with an idea." And, he concludes, Marr has. "Shorn of the many intriguing sideways insights the author provides, the central idea is simple, powerful, and finally persuasive: Englishness exists. England's senses of itself go back more than a thousand years, albeit in different forms, and unless England is recognised and given a new sense of its own security, then all hopes for a liberal, open, democratic and tolerant future are in danger... Yet England has been pushed into a corner where it is expected to passively await its future. That, in itself, is dangerous." Parris's focus on that strand of Marr's book was perhaps a little perverse: the view from north of the border looked rather different. "What does it mean to be British, he asks. The answer: not a lot," wrote James Robertson in Scotland on Sunday. "Almost nothing to most Scots, nor, in fact, to the people hardest hit by the disintegration of the 'British' label, those for whom it has been a threadbare safety net against racism. Many who immigrated between the 50s and 70s, who came as a consequence of the historical fact of empire, now find that the identity they thought was theirs to put on has been discarded by others in favour of Scottish, Welsh and even English ones. "The term 'British', it is now clear, was created and sustained for only one reason: the empire. Without the empire, it is redundant. Marr puts this into a wider context: the Americanisation of the world; the growth of Asian and Pacific economic power; the end of Communism and the new Europe. Identity is flexible now: all of us have become Europeans and Americans to some extent in the way we live our lives." Several reviewers mentioned that the book had evidently been written in a rush (Marr admitted as much in the introduction). "This book, at first, feels deadeningly over-familiar," wrote Andy Beckett in the Guardian. "Andrew Marr has produced - at speed - a volume heavily reliant on quotes from his fellow pundits and polemicists. Here are half-page sections and hurried references from Jeremy Paxman's The English, Peter Hitchens's The Abolition of Britain, Simon Heffer's Nor Shall My Sword: The Reinvention of England - all recent books, all concerned with the temperature of the nation in the early fevers of devolution, and all slightly patched together, short on original fact and thought." But Beckett quickly warmed to the book, especially when Marr took to the road and started to quote the opinions of anxious Brits. "The Britain that emerges is mixed-up, complicated, and 'in a state of constant flux'," concluded Beckett. "The supposedly cruel capital, for example, absorbs immigrants more easily than allegedly friendlier regions. The English patriots of the Home Counties know more about Normandy than the north of England. The idea of Englishness itself, Marr suggests, may never, at any time, have meant the same thing to everyone. "His writing relishes these tensions and contradictions: English tabloid culture is neatly summarised as 'swagger and self-pity'; the 'strange, sharp flavour' of modern Britain is crisply evoked. Marr concludes that only a federal country, with separate parliaments for each of its parts, can hope to hold such a hybrid together. "We may indeed be seeing the first stages of a general reconfiguration of relationships within the British archipelago which, inter alia, disperses power from Westminster and by so doing maintains the political links between England and Scotland," wrote Devine. "If London can respond positively and sympathetically to such a dynamic, the best bet for the future is probably a framework of federalism, rather than 'Scottish independence' in the classic form delineated in Tom Nairn's stimulating book." fields.headline: Rams to trample Black Cats
fields.standfirst: Sam Delaney, our stand-in in the stands, offers you the best tips for the weekend
fields.trailText: Sam Delaney, our stand-in in the stands, offers you the best tips for the weekend.
fields.body:
One can only assume that Sunderland's supporters chose the nickname 'The Black Cats' in a desperate bid to bless the side with some much-needed luck. Since the heady days of early December when Peter Reid's team thrashed Chelsea 4-1 and all talk was of an unlikely title push, their form has taken a drastic nose-dive. Indeed, their last league victory was on December 18th, since when they have endured beatings at the hands of such inauspicious opponents as Everton and Coventry. Their visitors this weekend are similarly average: Derby County. The Rams, however, have been quietly compiling a solid run of form with which they have edged away from the relegation zone. In fact, they have only lost one game in their last six. So, considering this contrasting form, offering 100/30 on the Derby win seems somewhat foolhardy of the generous men at Ladbrokes and William Hill.

The bookmakers have displayed similar shortsightedness in the case of the Middlesborough versus Leeds fixture. The odds on offer would suggest that everyone is expecting Leeds to secure an away win, despite their recent dip in form. While it's probably beyond Bryan Robson's rag, tag and bobtail side to take all three points, the draw seems a more than likely outcome. Boro have a good record at the Riverside Stadium and their strong defence should be capable of containing the youthful Leeds attack. The last five corresponding fixtures have produced deadlock (three goal-less draws, two one-alls) so expect something similar this time round. The odds are universally 9/4.

Another game to avoid for entertainment but embrace for profit is Sheffield Wednesday versus Newcastle. While Newcastle would appear to have the edge, Wednesday are a resolute force at home. Their defence concedes just a touch over a goal per game at Hillsborough, so a 1-1 draw (the outcome in two out of the last three corresponding fixtures) seems likely. Ladbrokes offer a tempting 12/5. Assuming Newcastle get that one goal, backing Nicolas Dabizas to score it would be advisable. He's scored four goals already this season, which is more than enough to have earned the towering Greek the title of "goalscoring centre-back". Nonetheless, Coral offer an extravagant 33/1 on him being first scorer.

fields.headline: Dark side of the web
fields.standfirst:
Net shopping could lead to even greater social exclusion, writes Roger Cowe

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: The internet comes with a lot of promises. Some of those are environmental: that it will save energy and cut down on waste. Some are social: that it will provide access to information for everyone and access to the biggest markets for the smallest players. But what if the net lets us down? What if e-shopping adds to total consumption, results in more vehicle journeys, not fewer, and worsens the plight of town centres?
fields.body:
The internet comes with a lot of promises. Some of those are environmental: that it will save energy and cut down on waste. Some are social: that it will provide access to information for everyone and access to the biggest markets for the smallest players.

But what if the net lets us down? What if e-shopping adds to total consumption, results in more vehicle journeys, not fewer, and worsens the plight of town centres?

Answers to these questions and more will emerge next year from a research project run by Forum for the Future, the think-tank founded by the environmentalist Jonathon Porritt. The investigation was launched recently by Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, and is backed by several large companies who hope to gain from the new marketplace, including Sun Microsystems, the Post Office and the consumer products giant, Unilever.

"The internet is rapidly becoming the most important medium for both interactions and transactions between people and organisations," says Shanker Trivedi, vice president for Sun Microsystems in the UK and Ireland. "We must ensure we are aware of the impact of this new dot.com paradigm on individuals and the environment."

His concern is that the internet revolution could backfire. Instead of democracy and sustainability, we could end up with social exclusion and new environmental problems. There are clear - potential - social and environmental benefits, but there could also be a black side to the web revolution. The research project will weigh the balance between the positive and negative aspects. First, the dehumanising potential of many "digital jobs", set against the potential gains for local economies and smaller firms.

There also is the worry that e-shoppers are likely to be the most wealthy, while the poor most desperately need to find bargains. If the e-lite replaces traditional buying with remote shopping, physical shops will be in trouble. They will have less custom to finance their expensive premises. That sounds great if it means an end to hypermarkets on the edge of town which threaten traditional shops. But what if it means closures of high street outlets instead?

Next, consider the physical end of the internet transaction. A small number of products can be delivered down the wire - music and software, and potentially anything currently on the written page (such as this newspaper). This is positive for the environment, resulting in lower consumption of materials from newsprint to packaging, and less physical distribution.

But most shopping cannot be completed this way. It is useful for small items such as books which can be sent through the post, but bulkier goods such as clothes and food require special deliveries. It is easy to imagine a scenario where this results in greater environmental damage, not less - quite apart from the physical dangers from wild van drivers careering up and down our streets.

Shopping remotely, whether through traditional mail order or new media, is more likely to result in dissatisfaction. The colour isn't quite right, the size is wrong. That means more two-way trips. Then there are the items you forget when skipping down Tesco's screen catalogue, which you would spot on the shelves as you struggle past with the trolley. That is another car journey, perhaps.

Even worse, it is possible that families freed from the chore of Saturday morning supermarketing will hop in the car and whiz miles down the motorway to some leisure paradise for the day. Finally, the internationalisation of retailing could produce a boom for air freight, as more and more goods are shipped round the world to satisfy shoppers hungry for a bargain and blind to the environmental effects. The range of such issues thrown up by ecommerce is substantial.

James Wilsdon, senior policy adviser at Forum for the Future, says : "The jury is still out on whether the digital economy will evolve into a powerful ally of sustainable development, or a spur to greater social exclusion and environmental destruction.

"There is an urgent need for dialogue between policy-makers and the companies who will be driving the dot.com revolution."

That dialogue will be achieved by the involvement of eight leading companies. The research will be carried out by a number of think-tanks. Forum for the Future will concentrate on opportunities for eco-efficiency, dematerialisation and the potential shift from products to service-based businesses, while seven other organisations will work on issues such as transport, energy use and carbon dioxide emissions, as well as wider policy issues.

The New Economics Foundation (NEF) will look at ways of improving access to the web and the dangers of worsening social exclusion if that cannot be achieved.

Alex MacGillivray of NEF said the net had the potential to be positive but without wider access it would remain primarily a middle class phenomenon. "The purchasing power of buying clubs is fine, but at the moment that is for middle class people. The people who really ought to get the benefits of lower prices are the people who at the moment are the least likely to get online."

NEF is exploring the potential to open up the net to poorer communities by providing reconditioned computers. Even then there is the question of whether old machines can capitalise on the net's potential. "You don't want people being on ine but not being able to use the best services", according to MacGillivray .

These complexities will be clearer when the researchers finish their task next year, but much will depend on how e-shopping affects consumers' behaviour. It will take several years for that to emerge.

fields.headline: Channel 5 swoop for £40m soap
fields.trailText: Channel 5 has poached the rights to screen ITV's long-running Australian soap opera Home and Away in a landmark deal worth at least £40m.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has poached the rights to screen ITV's long-running Australian soap opera Home and Away in a landmark deal worth at least £40m.

The three-year-old channel swooped to steal the hit series, which attracts up to 8m viewers a day, after an auction lasting more than four months. It is the first time Channel 5 has stolen a show from its longer-established rivals.

ITV is thought to have twice matched Channel 5's bids but the show's producers are understood to have been swayed by a commitment from the newcomer to the long-term future of the show in a deal of more than five years at around $12m (£7.5m) a year.

Neither channel would comment on the deal yesterday while negotiations over exactly when the show might transfer to Channel 5 are completed.

Home and Away, which is shown twice a day on ITV, is a staple of the channel's top 30 rated programmes, despite its teatime scheduling. Screened five days a week, it is a regular ratings banker and boosts audiences for ITV's regional and early evening news bulletins.

ITV's director of programmes, David Liddiment, is understood to be deciding whether to let Channel 5 screen the show immediately after it finishes its run on ITV, thought to be in July.

Under the terms of ITV's previous contract with Home and Away's Australian producers, Seven Network, the channel has an exclusivity clause that prevents any other broadcaster screening the soap for up to 12 months after ITV ceases transmission.

But Channel 5 executives are believed to be trying to persuade Mr Liddiment that it is in the viewers' best interests not to take the soap off air and to let its storylines continue on its new home without a year's hiatus .

Sources close to the deal suggest that Channel 5 is considering appealing to the show's fans to lobby ITV if they are faced with a long gap in the series run.

fields.headline: Cybershopping:  Only available online
fields.standfirst: www.shoppingunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: If Gordon Brown's plans to reduce the cost of internet access haven't convinced you that it's time to get online, some of the deals available only over the net, just might.
fields.body:
If Gordon Brown's plans to reduce the cost of internet access haven't convinced you that it's time to get online, some of the deals available only over the net, just might.

Take the financial offerings. www.smile.co.uk , the Co-operative Bank's internet service pays a mouth-watering 4.75% on current accounts, whereas its real-world equivalent pays no interest at all. And until March 6, Egg credit-card holders can get 5% cashback (compared with the normal 2%) when they use their card in the Egg online Shopping Zone.

www.discountpensions.co.uk - the online arm of London-based actuary Geoffrey Bernstein, is also after your business. Until the end of the tax year it has a very seductive offer: a rate of just 0.5% commission on internet sales, whereas typical commission is about 5.5%. That's more money in your pension fund, and much less to the middlemen.

Literary investments are offered at www.onlineoriginals.com , where you can test your ability to spot a bestseller. This online-only publisher has an e-royalty offer, which allows you to buy a percentage of future online earnings of titles it publishes. It costs US$500 (about £322).

If you have the more mundane matter of home-improvements to consider go to www.hi-revolution.com - a free internet service, that finds a "thoroughly vetted contractor" to do the job for you. All you have to do is enter details of the job you need done. The site will match your requirements to accredited firms, text message them the job specification and put the first three companies to respond in touch with you. Hi-revolution will even guarantee the work.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.trailText: Czech and Speake taps
fields.body:
Czech and Speake taps

Ooh, lover, feeeel the quality. I suppose one justification for paying more than £500 for your bathroom taps is that you know you'll be able to turn them on with your toes. Nothing can be more irritating than those smooth modern taps that you can't get a proper grip on, and so have to sit up, waving your paperback dangerously close to the water and dislodging the ashtray/ wineglass/ joint carefully balanced on the side . . . but of course, you may be a more military bath-taker, with one of those nifty little racks to keep your bathing things in. In which case, we apologise. No doubt your personal affairs are also in perfect order, and so the thought of blowing £645 on a set of taps (with shower pillar chucked in) doesn't faze you in the slightest. In which case, call Czech and Speake without delay. Czech and Speake taps: 0800 919 728.
