webTitle: Where did our cheap jeans go?

fields.headline: Where did our cheap jeans go?
fields.standfirst:
The supermarkets promised us affordable deals on designer goods last year. There was endless talk of Calvin Klein and Levi's at the checkouts - yet it never happened. John Crace asks why the stores have failed to deliver on the big-name brands

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week the supermarkets announced a price war, but you don't have to be a cynic to wonder why. Their prices are under intense scrutiny from the department of trade and industry. This week, as the row about "rip off Britain" rumbles on, the Competition Commission suddenly announced that it was looking into the issue of local monopolies. If companies are abusing their power at a local level, it will force them to sell some of their stores. In an apparent attempt to win back their approval rating, the supermarkets have responded with a price war.
fields.body:
This week the supermarkets announced a price war, but you don't have to be a cynic to wonder why. Their prices are under intense scrutiny from the department of trade and industry. This week, as the row about "rip off Britain" rumbles on, the Competition Commission suddenly announced that it was looking into the issue of local monopolies. If companies are abusing their power at a local level, it will force them to sell some of their stores. In an apparent attempt to win back their approval rating, the supermarkets have responded with a price war.

A few pence off Flora is all very well, but it is nothing compared with what we had been promised. There was a time when the supermarkets and chain stores seemed determined to be the consumers' friend, by selling designer goods at discount prices. But what was once feted as a flood, has been reduced to a trickle.

In 1991, Superdrug became the first major retailer to undercut high-street prices for branded goods by buying perfume from overseas factories and retailers with excess stock (a trading area known as the "grey market", or parallel imports). Slowly others followed suit. In 1997, Tesco bought a large supply of Levi's jeans and sold them for £15 less than normal high-street prices. This, we were told, was a war being fought on our behalf by the large supermarkets against price-fixing designer labels to ensure we got the best deals.

Since then Asda, Sainsbury and Safeway have joined in the fun and bought up the odd batch of grey market Calvin Klein, Sony and Tommy Hilfiger clobber, but your average punter would have been very lucky to get on the right end of any of these bargain-basement deals. For all the hype from the "consumers champions" you would be hard pushed to believe that the supermarkets were scouring the world for the best deals judging by their stock.

Tesco have recently offered some cheap Nike trainers; Asda have had some cheap sunglasses, but the pickings are few and far between. Tesco say they save the consumer £32,000 per day with grey market imports. It sounds great, but actually works out at about 23p per person per year. Moreover, even though Superdrug has forced Givenchy and Yves St Laurent to supply them directly, it no longer claims to be the cheapest operation in town.

So what's gone wrong with our brave new world of cheapo Levi's? Well, for one thing, the designer brands don't like it. They argue that selling their products in the supermarket devalues their brands and that consumers need high levels of sales advice and service. But since a survey commissioned by the Consumers' Association in December last year indicates precisely the opposite, one can only conclude that their principal objection to the grey market is that it robs them of the ability to determine the price.

Every time a supermarket dabbles in the grey market, the designers take legal action. Sony won a high court injunction against Tesco over PlayStation, and Tommy Hilfiger, Nike, Levis and Adidas have all reached out-of-court settlements with various supermarkets.

Brussels is also firmly on the designers' side. In a landmark ruling at the European Court of Justice last year, the judges (using a piece of trademark legislation that was ironically intended to protect the consumer) effectively prohibited the importation of goods without the manufacturers' consent. And you can bet your life they won't give in.

Gary Lux, chairman of the European Parallel Importers Coalition, believes that such protectionism is blatantly anti-competitive. Moreover he reckons the brands want to have it both ways. "We know that when some brands have excess stock, they secretly release it on to the grey market," he says. "They're actually happy with the deal as they are getting a fair price. But when it reappears in another market, they cry foul."

Last year, following the EU ruling, a select committee of the department of trade and industry came down on the consumers' side, and recommended that the restrictions on designer goods sourced from outside the EU should be scrapped. But the road to European law is immensely bureaucratic and torturously slow. And given that last week it was revealed that the DTI had rigged its survey to prove that "rip-off Britain" is a myth by excluding a large number of awkward items, one perhaps should not expect any urgent action.

What, then, can you do? If the goods won't come to you at the right price, then you can go to them. Logically, the easiest way ought to be through the internet. After all, what's to stop you clicking straight on to Guess? in the US and buying at the rock bottom stateside prices. Well, quite a lot actually. Guess? have gone out of their way to ring-fence their site to keep out unwanted Brits. And everyone else, for that matter. We can look, but not touch. No orders are shipped outside the US. The same goes for other designer labels. Territories are defended just as zealously in cyberspace as they are in the high street.

You won't necessarily have any more luck if you try the retailers themselves. The first page you hit when you type in Dressmart.com - a site which offers a bespoke tailoring service for brands, such as Gieves & Hawkes, Mulbery and Aquascutum - is one which asks you to click on one of the seven countries listed: the UK, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, Finland or Norway. If you're not from any of these, then too bad. You'll have to go elsewhere. More disappointingly still, even though six of the seven countries are within the EU there are no benefits of membership. You still have to pay the going rate for each territory.

Maria Dall, the marketing director for dressmart.com in the UK, explains her company's rationale. "We believe that designers have a right to control their e-commerce," she says. "We need to respect that right and don't want to jeopardise their standards. We only sell in territories for which we have permission. We don't want to undercut their high-street outlets. We believe the internet is about ease and convenience, not discounting."

This is rather one in the eye for those of us who hoped that it might be about all three things, and it is something of a relief to find one rag trade site that thinks so too. Zercon.com is Shaun Dunn's baby. He sells all the big names, such as Dolce & Gabbana, Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, DKNY and Versace and freely admits he sources everything on the internal European grey market through agents and middlemen. "It's sometimes a bit hit and miss, because you have to take what you can get," he says. "Sometimes it's this season's fashions, sometimes it's older stuff. But it's fine by me, as not everyone wants the latest fashions, and I can sell everything for roughly half the high-street prices." How long zercon.com survives is another matter. As sure as eggs is eggs the designer labels will do their utmost to squeeze his supply chain.

Life is distinctly rosier if you are not a slave to branding. Companies such as Matalan buy bulk imports of clothing from the far east which they sell for knock-down prices. You needn't worry about the quality or sticking out like a sore thumb, either - everyone's wearing them. Peacock, which sources a small percentage of goods from the grey market, and Matalan are two of the few clothes retailers to have bucked the national trend and increased turnover in the last year.

Of course, there's always abroad. Other than fags, booze and new transport, you can bring back whatever you like from inside the EU. For example, there are extremely cheap flights to Ireland where the exchange rate may net you a 30% reduction on some makes of computers. And if you happen to be going to the US or the Far East anyway, feel free to stock up and pay any duty on your return.

But if this seems like the answer to all your prayers, then remember this. Not all electronic goods are compatible throughout the world and all product complaints have to be referred back to the country in which they were bought. The Consumer Association says that while abroad you should always pay for goods in excess of £100 by credit card as, in theory, the card issuer is jointly liable with the supplier. Needless to say, this may be harder to enforce in practice. So, for the time being, it's business as normal. Caveat emptor.

Did you turn your Fiver into a share in www.kamikazefootball.com? If not, you've still got chance to turn it into £10K!

SILENCE FOR SIR STANLEY

The death of Sir Stanley Matthews has brought together the Premiership and the Football League. All games in all four leagues this weekend will pay their respects to the former England winger with a minute's silence. There will also be a minute's silence before the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington) at Wembley on Sunday.

"We will be talking to the other football authorities about how we can mark an appropriate memorial to Sir Stanley," said Football League spokesman John Nagel. "It is early days yet and we have not started any discussions."

Matthews was capped 54 times for England and made 710 Football League appearances for Stoke and Blackpool, continuing to play professionally into his 50s. Aged 85, he died at North Staffordshire Nuffield Hospital yesterday following a short illness.

CLICK FOR A CLASSIC

1953. Blackpool 4, Bolton Wanderers 3. Relive Stanley's greatest hour here .

COL @ COV

A couple of hours ago, Colin Hendry, the why-on-earth-did-Rangers-bother- signing-this-bloke-for-£4m-if-they-weren't- ever-going-to-play-him defender, looked as though he'd finally made good his escape from Ibrox. Everything looked just fine as he set off down south for a press conference in which Coventry were going to unveil him and "Peruvian hotshot" (www.ccfc.co.uk) Ysrael Zuniga as their new signings. However, like so many of his tackles, Hendry's flight was very late, and it all had to be called off. Poor Colin.

Let's hope he didn't take the disappointment too hard, though - everything will be finalised tomorrow. Hendry will sign a two-and-a-half year deal with the Sky Blues, with the transfer fee dependent on appearances. Gordon Strachan is well made up. "It's a good deal. The man has got experience. I think he can play for another three years," said wee Gord, sticking to short sentences.

Excitement invariably takes hold of Gordon, though, and it wasn't long before more complicated grammatical structures were attempted: "I look at some centre-halves who are playing now, like Richard Gough and Steve Bould, and I think that Colin has plenty of time. He will bring leadership to the club and the back-four area, which is what we are looking for."

One of the first things Colin and Ysrael will do at Coventry is take a four day "sunshine break" (www.ccfc.co.uk again - who writes this stuff?) with their team-mates at the La Manga complex. Hmm. New signings. La Manga. Do you think there's a story here? "It wouldn't happen with our lot in a million years," insisted City chairman Bryan Richardson, unwisely tempting fate.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If I was Mark I just wouldn't pick Ryan Giggs." - Qatar manager Dzemal Hadziabdic gives Mark Hughes the benefit of his big-match experience.

BEST LEFT UNSAID

Best did it. Whiteside did it. And now David Healy is the latest in a proud line of Old Trafford fledgling sensations to enjoy instant international glory, knocking in two goals on his full Northern Ireland debut. A Belfast boy, fleet of foot... it could only be a matter of time before the inevitable comparisons began. And now, Northern Ireland's legend of yesteryear has paid him the ultimate accolade.

"I think, to be honest, that he will go on and score more goals than me by looking at him," said QPR's Iain Dowie, casting stunned silence amongst the Windsor Park faithful. Did he really think Healy (one night, two goals) could be the new Iain Dowie (10 years, 12 goals)? "He's got it," he confirmed, sparking street parties on the Shankill Road.

"He may be disappointed," speculated Dowie bizarrely. "That's the mark of a good player, if he's his own worst critic," said the man credited with inspiring the Highbury chant, 'We've got Dennis Bergkamp, you've got Iain Dowie'. Meanwhile, Dowie - dropped for the game against Luxembourg - is "available in emergencies if needed".

THE RUMOUR MILL

Liverpool are interested in reserve goalkeeper Pegguy Arphexad, who will be available on a free transfer in four months time.

PSV Eindhoven striker Luc Nilis is to spend three days training with Aston Villa later this month with a view to a permanent move.

West Brom will bid for Barnsley's Trinidad and Tobago international striker Clint Marcelle.

Southampton defender Richard Dryden is considering a loan move to Oxford.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers chairman David Murray has denied reports that his club have already signed Fernando Ricksen from AZ Alkmaar for £3m. Murray said: "There is no truth at all in the claim we have already signed this player and there is no deal nearing completion. I don't doubt that the player said he would love to join Rangers when asked about us, but to say he is now definitely joining us is very premature."

NTL have been linked with a £15m bid for 9.9 percent of Middlesbrough. NTL already run Boro TV and want to tie up the club's media rights for the future.

Motherwell will offer boss Billy Davies a new contract.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Question Time (10.50pm)
Leeds chairman and all-round laid-back bloke Peter Ridsdale is on this. Well, if Garth Crooks can present Dispatch Box...

ITV: World Football (2.30am)
This conjures up images of the beauty of football.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.35am)
As does this.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (1am)
And this.

Argentinian Football (2.35am)
And even this.

Footy Shorts (4.10am)
But all this reminds us of is Dennis Wise.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11.45pm SS1)
"Marek Janowski's interpretation of Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen may be considered cold. But it's a very detailed rendition, true to the score," opines Clive Mendonca.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 3am)
Shunted onto Sky Sports 2 now, are we? You want to watch that, McCaff. It's a slippery slope to Granada Breeze, you know.

Sky Sports 3: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am SS1)
Sepp Blatter in disguise, playing crazy japes on tourists, pensioners in the park, etc.

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am SS1)
Bobin and Armstrong try banter. It fails.

World Cup Classics (10pm)
Yugoslavia v Zaire. Many, many, many, many goals. Many more than Scotland managed, anyway.

British Eurosport: Football (8pm)
France v Poland. Take our tip - tune in with three minutes to go.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)
West Ham go on long runs in Europe. Southampton win comfortably. We're saying nothing.

fields.headline: 300,000 homeless in Mozambique
fields.trailText: The president of Mozambique has appealed for about £30m in aid to deal with the aftermath of massive floods caused by a combination of the worst rains in 50 years and tropical cyclone Eline, which hit the country on Tuesday.
fields.body:
The president of Mozambique has appealed for about £30m in aid to deal with the aftermath of massive floods caused by a combination of the worst rains in 50 years and tropical cyclone Eline, which hit the country on Tuesday.

At least 160 people are believed to have died in the flooding, and about 300,000 people have been left homeless, with many cut off without food or drinking water.

With large parts of southern and central Mozambique inaccessible after weeks of rain, the extent of the damage and the final death toll were still unclear yesterday. Huge tracts of land are under water, and officials say 800,000 people have been affected in some way. Meteorologists forecast that a second storm, cyclone Felecia, will hit the region within days.

"The needs are for the urgent alleviation of the situation," said the president, Joaquim Chissano. "For reconstruction we will need seeds and agricultural implements because, as soon as the water goes away, we will need to plough and plant again, along with blankets, tents and more food for the displaced."

The cyclone destroyed houses, knocked out power lines and uprooted trees as it hit land near the port of Beira with winds up to 160 mph.

Two people were electrocuted by falling power cables. Kate Horne, Oxfam's representative in Mozambique, flew to Chibuto town in Gaza province yesterday. She said that in one village, 14 families driven from their homes by the floods were crammed into one small house.

"It looked like all of that part of Gaza had become sea with the occasional tree sticking up or bit of road. People left their houses in such a hurry. All the women said they watched the rains flood their fields, and the fields are their only source of income for the year. Then they watched their goats and cattle drown. Then they watched their houses fill up and they ran for higher ground," she said.

President Chissano and the United Nations say that £8m is needed for emergency food and medical supplies, and to provide basic shelters for the homeless. A further £22m will be required to rebuild the infrastructure, government officials say.

Britain and other EU countries have already sent more than £1m in emergency aid, and a UK disaster management team is being provided. Aid workers say the greatest danger now is from waterborne diseases and malaria.

South African and French air force planes resumed aid flights yesterday but the collapse of a bridge between the capital, Maputo, and the town of Xai-Xai further hampered relief efforts.

Mozambican officials say in private that South Africa is compounding the misery by easing pressure on its dams through the release of surplus water into the Limpopo river which flows on through Mozambique.

After leaving Mozambique, Eline weakened, but still brought heavy rains as it moved on to Zimbabwe.

She said that in one village, 14 families driven from their homes by the floods were crammed into one small house. "It looked like all of that part of Gaza had become sea with the occasional tree sticking up or bit of road. People left their houses in such a hurry. All the women said they watched the rains flood their fields, and the fields are their only source of income for the year. Then they watched their goats and cattle drown. Then they watched their houses fill up and they ran for higher ground," she said. President Chissano and the United Nations say that £8m is needed for emergency food and medical supplies, and to provide basic shelters for the homeless. A further £22m will be required to rebuild the infrastructure, government officials say. Britain and other EU countries have already sent more than £1m in emergency aid, and a UK disaster management team is being provided. Aid workers say the greatest danger now is from waterborne diseases and malaria. South African and French air force planes resumed aid flights yesterday but the collapse of a bridge between the capital, Maputo, and the town of Xai-Xai further hampered relief efforts. Mozambican officials say in private that South Africa is compounding the misery by easing pressure on its dams through the release of surplus water into the Limpopo river which flows on through Mozambique. After leaving Mozambique, Eline weakened, but still brought heavy rains as it moved on to Zimbabwe.

fields.headline: Mystery of the pink punter
fields.standfirst: The fabled 'pink pound' represents the purchasing power of gays. But advertisers are beginning to wonder whether it isn't an illusion
fields.trailText: How many gays?
fields.body:
How many gays?

 Conventional wisdom says male gays number between one in ten and one in eight of UK men (2.9m to 3.6m)

 Sample surveys suggest one in 25 of the (male) population - 1.2m UK men

 The biggest study of sexual lifestyles and practices to date (conducted 1990-92) found 6.1% of men or 1.8m reporting some form of homosexual experience and 3.4% of women or 1m. That makes 4.7% of the total population or one in 21

Is there such a thing as the "pink pound" - which makes the gay community an economic force to be reckoned with? We cannot answer until we know how many gay men and women there are - and we don't. It could be as many as one in 10 of the population, giving a UK total of 6m adults. The box shows how estimates vary: yet another study estimated that only 500,000 adult men in England could be defined as gay - if that means those homosexually active during the 12 months prior to the survey. But this survey asked about any sexual experience between two people of the same gender, which does not necessarily indicate orientation. If people were asked to label themselves as heterosexual, bisexual and homosexual, a much lower gay percentage might result.

As for gays' economic status, Gay Times conducted a self-completion survey of its readership in 1993 and 1998. Channel 4 organised a self-completion survey in the mid 90s. Both samples centred on white, middle-class men. Gay Times found they had income higher than average but Channel 4 suggested their income was lower than average - so much for popular beliefs about the pink pound. These samples, however, were of people frequenting gay venues and they may not be typical.

Methodological problems have not, however, stopped the press from asserting the pink pound is big and bouncy. The London Evening Standard recently asserted that 77% of gays fall into ABC1 economic groups. This finding was attributed to Market Assessment Publications but all it had ever claimed was that readers of gay magazines and newspapers are more upmarket - not that they are typical of the gay population at large.

More important, no research exists to demonstrate that gay men and women think or act or spend differently from anyone else. So with no real information on numbers, potential and actual spending, lifestyle and behavioural differences and other relevant trend data, most judgments about gays' economic strength are based on anecdote plus some obvious knowledge of gay lifestyles - for example gays tend not to have children. That gays have a propensity to consume more than average amounts of alcohol is based on observations of London's Soho (Compton Street), Manchester's gay village (Canal Street), Brighton, Glasgow and now Newcastle upon Tyne. Typical?

But if the pink pound is a myth, that does not mean there is not a gay market. There is certainly a gay press. Gay Times has a circulation of about 65,000; Attitude 55,000; and Diva 35,000. (Although there are several weekly and monthly free titles, such as Boyz and the Pink Paper, their product advertising is limited).

The gay press advertises gay products and services to gay readers but also mainstream drink, fragrances, clothing, music, books, tobacco and entertainment. Also, many of those involved in research for (and the production of) drugs to combat HIV also advertise.

Additionally, some products are advertised in the context of gay-themed television, for example Queer as Folk on Channel 4. During the first series (March/April 1999) and its subsequent repeat (January 2000) adverts included Carling, Guinness, Lion bars and Vodafone. The diversity was justified since anecdotal evidence suggests the 2.1m audience was mixed in sexual orientation.

Besides the media, gay festivals are hosted up and down the country. Again sponsors are spread between the obvious "leisure" industries (drink and tobacco) and mainstream suppliers of cars, air travel and internet services. The London lesbian and gay film festival, now in its 13th year, counts Channel 4, Stella Artois, American Airlines, Time Out and the Canadian High Commission among its backers. Business backs gay charity: WH Smith and the Halifax have assisted the National Aids Trust and NatWest has sponsored several events for the Stonewall Trust.

Is all this, then, a sign of identifiable pink purchasing? Drink companies are definitely targeting gay men and women. Bass Brewers, for example, own and run some 24 or so pubs and clubs dedicated to a gay clientele. But alcohol aside, and the near isolated strategy of Virgin Megastores who run specific gay shopping evening events in one or two of their stores, representatives from other industries are very sparse in terms of overt marketing to the gay consumer. The argument is that overt advertising of any kind can both be divisive and damaging to the brand.

We conducted 20 in-depth interviews with leading advertising agents and found few could recollect any instances where campaigns directly targeted at gay men and women were part of their or the clients' strategy. Take the latest series of ads for Impulse deodorant. The two gay characters are part of the plot, yes, but they do not detract from the brand. It is part of a series of ads which are humorous, with that required twist reflecting 90s' attitudes and values, but still focus on the product itself. When gay men are asked, they say they are not prepared to support products or brands that overtly targeted them.

In fact, both heterosexuals and gay people see very little relevance in categorising individuals on the basis of their sexual inclinations. In today's fragmented and complex world we all need to connect to multiple references in order to build a balanced and gratifying sense of identity. Sexuality is an element, but at the same level as so many others: culture, sports, taste in wine, music.

The opportunity exists for marketers and advertisers to recognise gay lifestyles and imagery in conjunction with all other types of consumers - men and women; young and old; black and white; and yes, gay and straight. But we see no evidence that gay people represent a missed marketing opportunity. Their pink pounds have already been spent.

 Simon Burrows is at Marplan RI and Daniel Dumoulin at RI Qualitatif; this is based on a report to be delivered to a Market Research Society conference in Brighton on March 16

fields.headline: Eyes wide open
fields.standfirst: Alejandro Amenabar cut his teeth making low-budget thrillers. Can he handle a star like Nicole Kidman, asks  Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: Alejandro Amenabar cut his teeth making low-budget thrillers. Can he handle a star like Nicole Kidman?
fields.body:
A pessimist would say that Hollywood views the rest of world cinema as little more than a cheap talent pool or research-and-development lab. The studios keep an eye out for novelty hits to rework as Billy Crystal vehicles, while ambitious auteurs dutifully sign up to make travesties of their own best work.

This week we can ponder the future of another candidate for the mill. Spanish director Alejandro Amenabar has already sold the remake rights to his film Open Your Eyes to Tom Cruise. Whether or not the remake ever happens, Amenabar has now bought himself enough credit to make his next film in English with Nicole Kidman. The Others will be a French-Spanish co-production, backed by Miramax.

Is Amenabar, 27, tough enough to work the system? Soft-spoken and slight, he speaks English fluently but with a touch of nerves. He looks as though he should still be working on his first-year student short. But at the age of 23 he had already completed his first feature, Tesis, an intelligent psychological thriller about snuff films. He not only wrote and directed it but composed the score. As a student, he taught himself soundtrack writing because he didn't trust anyone else to get the feel he wanted.

He's hard-headed, then, and has already learned to deal with both success and hostility. Open Your Eyes was hugely popular in Spain, but Amenabar took much flak from critics who accused him of not being a sufficiently Spanish director. He's not particularly, he admits. Among his current peers, he feels affinity with Basque director Julio Medem, whose recent Lovers of the Arctic Circle shares two of its stars with Open Your Eyes. But above all he worships the trinity of Hitchcock, Kubrick and Spielberg.

Open Your Eyes is a labyrinthine story about a young man who's horribly disfigured, then miraculously reconstituted, and about two women, one of whom may be a double of the other. Put like this, it makes little sense, but on screen Amenabar breaks and remakes his own narrative rules with supreme confidence.

It's about fooling the viewer, he explains. "As the title says, it's a film in which you have to keep your eyes wide open. As the main character goes crazy, the audience is supposed to go crazy. It's risky - part of the audience can get sick watching the film. It's also a film to be seen at least three times, then you can get the whole. Of course, it's not a film for children."

The film's most outrageous stroke is an 11th-hour turn towards sci-fi in the form of cryogenics - the freezing of a human in an attempt to cheat death. "I wanted to take the science-fiction world and put it into everyday reality," Amenabar says. He admits that the ending provoked much laughter at the film's premiere. Yet it is grounded in fact, he insists. He did extensive research into the subject. "It was very impressive. You can have the whole body frozen, or just the head, which is cheaper."

Born in Chile but raised in Madrid, Amenabar came to film through the horror-video collection of the Americans next door. He studied film at Madrid's Universidad Complutense, where he met his friend and close collaborator Mateo Gil, co-writer of Open Your Eyes and now a director in his own right. But he failed the directing course in his fifth year, and is still fuming about it. He got his revenge when he made Tesis, naming the serial killer after the teacher who failed him. He apologised later, he says.

Tesis was a taut, paranoid speculation on voyeurism and violence, in the Peeping Tom tradition. Amenabar admits he didn't do much solid research on snuff movies - "I just read a book and some news, and of course I wouldn't have dared to get into that world. For me it's creepy and disgusting."

As for the existence of snuff movies - generally regarded by commentators as a ghoulish urban myth - he says that if you can imagine the worst, then it probably happens. "A human being for me is the most horrible thing in the world, the thing I'm most afraid of. But that's not the question in the film - the question is how the media treat violence. After the film was released, there were a lot of Spanish TV films treating violence very morbidly - really, really disgusting. I don't know who decides that when somebody falls down from a building they just have to repeat it and repeat it and repeat it."

Amenabar doesn't offer any clues to whether his next film will be as mind-bending as his first two. Budgeted at around $15m - about 10 times as much as Open Your Eyes - The Others is set in post-war Jersey, although shot in northern Spain, and will be a ghost story about "a sort of neurotic woman - she's Catholic, and she hears noises upstairs".

He realises that working with a big name like Nicole Kidman will require a whole new field of management expertise. "She's a star but I want to keep this film away from the Hollywood system. To me it's a temptation, and at the same time it can be a nightmare. I know so many directors from so many countries have failed trying to get in the system: they feel they've been betrayed. I don't want my career to be like that. I'm very concerned about how this film should be sold to the audience, but I don't want a group of 20 people giving opinions." The challenge, he says, is: "We have to understand that it's a film with Nicole Kidman, and she has to understand - I think she does - that it's a Spanish film."

Amenabar is either very naive or a deceptively tough cookie. There's always the chance, of course, that his imagination may simply prove too strange for Hollywood. But he's probably doing the right thing sticking to the thriller genre, which has seen him all right so far. "For me, it's the easiest way to express my obsessions. But I think this next one, and maybe another one, and then I'll have to wash my brain and change my ideas." And if he can wash Hollywood's brain a little in the process, then so much the better.

Open Your Eyes is out on Friday.

fields.headline: The Guardian Profile: Michael Colvin
fields.standfirst: MP and wife feared dead after blaze guts home
fields.trailText: Michael Colvin, the Conservative MP missing and feared dead with his wife after a fire at his home in the Hampshire village of Tangley, is known throughout Westminster as a Tory of the old school.
fields.body:
Michael Colvin, the Conservative MP missing and feared dead with his wife after a fire at his home in the Hampshire village of Tangley, is known throughout Westminster as a Tory of the old school.

The wealthy 67-year-old landowner, the son of a Royal Navy captain, was educated at Eton and Sandhurst.

He went on to become a captain in the Grenadier Guards serving in Berlin, the Suez campaign and Cyprus, turning to property investment and farming when he left the army.

His first move into politics came in 1964 when he served on Tangley Parish Council in his home village. He then climbed through the ranks of being a district councillor, county councillor and on to the Conservative Research Department before being selected as candidate for the seat of Bristol North West.

He captured the seat in the Thatcher landslide of 1979 but was regarded inside the Commons as a "wet" with limited chances of promotion inside her government.

In 1983 he switched to safer seat of Romsey and Waterside in Hampshire - later known as Romsey - where he had a majority at the last election of 8,585.

In parliament he took an interest in foreign affairs, becoming chairman of the Conservative Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Committee. He supported trade links with South Africa and urged recognition of the "homelands" set up for black South Africans by the government.

But he was mainly known as a defence and aviation expert, becoming chairman of the Defence Select Committee in 1995.

He is president of the Westminster Shooting Club and captain of the House of Commons team and was involved in resisting attempts, in the wake of the Dunblane massacre, to close down the club.

He hit the headlines in 1997 when he was convicted of polluting a village water supply by discharging 200,000 gallons of waste water from a slurry pit on his 855-acre Home Farm in Tangley.

In 1994 the low-profile MP was caught up in the Tory sleaze row over claims that he failed to declare a consultancy with a South African public relations firm.

He is chairman of the Council for Country Sports and spent eight years as vice-chairman of the British Field Sports Society.

He once bought the village pub, The Cricketers Arms, to save it from closure. Said to be a close friend of the Prince of Wales, he is also a qualified pilot, parachutist and a keen artist.

webTitle: Government support urged for occupational pensions

fields.headline: Government support urged for occupational pensions
fields.trailText: The government must take action in the budget to boost the occupational pension sector or it will risk driving the multi-billion pound sector into decline, the main industry body warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government must take action in the budget to boost the occupational pension sector or it will risk driving the multi-billion pound sector into decline, the main industry body warned yesterday.

In its budget submission, the National Association of Pension Funds said there was an urgent need to restore employers' confidence in occupational pension schemes.

It warned of the dangers of putting too much emphasis on employee share schemes.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, announced details of a new "all-employee share scheme" in the pre-budget report, which is aimed at dramatically increasing the number of people who invest in the company they work for.

fields.headline: London nail bomber pleads manslaughter
fields.trailText: Nail bomber David Copeland today admitted to the manslaughter of three people in a pub explosion in London  last year.
fields.body:
Nail bomber David Copeland today admitted to the manslaughter of three people in a pub explosion in London last year.

Appearing at the Old Bailey Copeland, 23, denied murdering the three but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

The prosecution said they were not minded to accept the pleas at present and the hearing was adjourned until March.

Copeland, an engineer from Cove, near Farnborough, Hampshire, also admitted causing three explosions in London last year.

The first attack took place on Saturday April 17, in Brixton, south London. It was followed a week later by the blast in Brick Lane, in the East End.

The third attack, on April 30, targeted the Admiral Duncan public house in Old Compton Street, Soho. It killed three people: Andrea Dykes, 27, John Light, 32, and Nick Moore, 31. They were on their way to see a musical to celebrate Mrs Dykes's pregnancy. Mrs Dykes's husband Julian was seriously injured.

It killed three people: Andrea Dykes, 27, John Light, 32, and Nick Moore, 31. They were on their way to see a musical to celebrate Mrs Dykes's pregnancy. Mrs Dykes's husband Julian was seriously injured.

fields.headline: Israel's torture jails exposed
fields.trailText: The photograph shows a fresh-faced boy with longish hair and jeans too close-fitting for the liking of the pro-Iranian group that he is accused of supporting. He sits on a sofa and smiles into the camera, out of school for the day. Sixteen years old and not a care in the world.
fields.body:
The photograph shows a fresh-faced boy with longish hair and jeans too close-fitting for the liking of the pro-Iranian group that he is accused of supporting. He sits on a sofa and smiles into the camera, out of school for the day. Sixteen years old and not a care in the world.

The date is September 1, 1986. The place Mays al-Jabal in Israeli-occupied south Lebanon. Before the day is out Israeli-backed militiamen will burst in and take him away for 13 and a half years - 13 of them in jails across the international border, where a recent report by Israel's state comptroller acknowledges that security officials often exceeded the "moderate physical pressure" permitted.

Terry Anderson, the American journalist held hostage for six and half years, last week demanded $100m in damages from the Iranian government, which he blames for his kidnapping in 1985. Kamal Rizq will be seeking rather more than $150m from Israel - with a bonus, perhaps, for the torture he suffered.

Mr Rizq, 30, was as much a hostage as the Westerners who went missing in Lebanon. After serving a three-year sentence for supporting the Lebanese resistance, he was held in near-isolation for a further 10 years in the hope that he could be traded for Israelis missing in action in Lebanon. A "bargaining chip" in pursuit of a "vital interest of state", in the words of the 1997 Supreme Court ruling that gave after-the-fact justification to his detention. In plain English, a hostage.

But while the Western hostages - Mr Anderson, John McCarthy and Terry Waite - are household names, those of Israel's Lebanese hostages are unknown, even though there are 16 of them at present and they have been held longer, and at times more brutally, than any Westerner.

The state comptroller's report, written in 1995 but kept secret until this month, refers only to the torture of Palestinians in Israel. The testimony of Mr Rizq and other Lebanese released in recent weeks - from Israel proper and from Khiam prison in Israeli-occupied south Lebanon - make clear that torture was not limited to the period of the intifada.

Like Ali Taube, who was only 14 when he was tortured with electricity, Mr Rizq's most fearful days came in Khiam. Here, he says, he was hooded, tied to a pole and beaten for days on end, deprived of sleep and kept in the cold. For the first 15 days he was locked in solitary confinement in a room one metre square. Fellow prisoners had electricity shot through their fingertips and genitals.

Dr Jamal Hafez, a French-trained psychotherapist who has treated scores of former Khiam inmates, says 80% suffer from "prison trauma". He says: "Khiam is a place where they try to destroy you psychologically."

Although Khiam is, ostensibly, under the control of Israel's client militia, the South Lebanon Army, inmates say they have glimpsed Israeli officers there, Israeli helicopters fly overhead when there is unrest, and uniforms bear Hebrew labels. It is a place, Mr Rizq says, "where the SLA does the dirty work and Israel has deniability".

Mr Rizq was not tortured in Israel - "unless you count 13 years of unwarranted imprisonment". But for many Lebanese who have gone straight to Israel without passing Khiam, where 139 people are still detained, Israel is a place of terrible memory. Kassem Qammas, a member of the pro-Iranian Hizbullah party who was captured in 1987 and released last month, was repeatedly beaten on a wounded leg and has the scars to prove it. He says he was starved, submitted to extreme temperatures and strapped to a small chair for up to three days, his arms and legs bound behind him. Sometimes an unseen hand rocked the chair so violently that he lost consciousness.

A German initiative to locate Ron Arad, an Israeli pilot shot down in October 1986, has won the release of five Lebanese hostages and is probably the best hope for the remaining 16. Israel's High Court was expected to publish a ruling banning hostage-taking last December. But the ruling has still not been made public.

The hostages' families have no doubts about the reason for the delay: Germany's mediation with Hizbullah - and the new usefulness of "chips". They are not surprised that no one is asking for an explanation. Their sons have always been Israel's "forgotten hostages".

fields.headline: Iran reformers triumph in poll
fields.trailText: Iran's reformers capped their nationwide parliamentary victory this week by capturing nearly all the seats in Tehran, the main battleground for political and social change.
fields.body:
Iran's reformers capped their nationwide parliamentary victory this week by capturing nearly all the seats in Tehran, the main battleground for political and social change.

Of 30 parliamentary seats in the capital, President Mohammed Khatami's allies were leading in 28 seats. Final results are expected on Wednesday. His brother, Mohammed Reza Khatami, finished first.

The president and his allies have beaten their conservative rivals decisively at the ballot box - but their triumph may prove a mixed blessing. Millions of voters who handed reformers a victory in parliamentary polls last Friday did so expecting swift and significant change.

Since his election in May 1997, Mr Khatami was granted a grace period because he faced so many obstacles. The current parliament, dominated by his conservative rivals, was a hindrance to turning his policies into law.

"If the vote in 1997 for Khatami was a vote for change, the vote this time was to accelerate the pace of change and to show their [the voters'] dissatisfaction with the current pace," said the political commentator Saeed Leylaz.

And Meysam Saeedi, a reformist and, at 30, the youngest candidate in the elections, told a Western news agency: "It was a vote to legalise and institutionalise Khatami's reforms."

Having improved their president's fortunes, Iran's empowered voters now have high expectations that will be difficult to meet. The Islamic Iran Participation Front ticket, headed by Mohammed Reza Khatami, made grand promises to voters. Its radical programme included pledges to improve citizens' rights, to cleanse the judiciary of special interests, and to establish political parties.

Despite their solid victory, there is no guarantee that the reformist candidates will follow the president's agenda. More than 50 seats were won by independents, many of whom are closely aligned with Mr Khatami's conservative foes. One reformist candidate, Fariba Davoudi, said: "I see names of winners who call themselves reformers but who are really conservatives. To be a reformer you have to believe in the rule of law and believe in citizens' rights, but some of the winners do not believe this in their hearts."

The president will also face increased pressure from conservative-dominated institutions still outside his domain, all of them determined to hold on to power. The conservatives who control the judiciary, for example, are unlikely to relinquish easily such a major centre of power.

Standing in the way of profound change is Islamic law. The interpretations of Islamic law by Iran's politicians will still ultimately have to meet the approval of the clerical establishment.

Among the demands of Iranian voters are improved rights for women. While more women receive a university education and are employed than at any other time in Iran's history, they are rarely able to divorce without their husbands' consent and face impossible odds in gaining custody of their children.

But many reformers believe the Islamic texts, which form the basis of the Iranian constitution, do not give women such freedoms.

Iranians are also eager to get law enforcement out of their private lives. Under President Khatami the morality police, or basij, has become less zealous, but still routinely stops young single men and women who socialise in public places.

Some 80% of the electorate voted for reformist candidates in almost all the main cities, including Mashhad, Iran's second city, home to the country's holiest shrine and traditionally a conservative stronghold.

Abdullah Nouri, a dissident cleric now serving a five-year sentence for criticising the system last year, was freed for three days to taste the victory that could have been his.

webTitle: A Web of workaholic misfits in the making?

fields.headline: A Web of workaholic misfits in the making?
fields.trailText: The Internet is creating a class of people who spend more hours at the office, work still more hours from home, and are so solitary they can hardly be bothered to call Mom on her birthday.
fields.body:
The Internet is creating a class of people who spend more hours at the office, work still more hours from home, and are so solitary they can hardly be bothered to call Mom on her birthday.

Those are some of the conclusions of a major new study of Internet users conducted by Stanford University's Institute for the Quantitative Study of Society. But even before its official unveiling here last week, the survey of 4,113 people was receiving extensive criticism, guaranteeing another round of debate over the effect of this new technology.

"We're moving from a world in which you know all your neighbors, see all your friends, interact with lots of different people every day, to a functional world, where interaction takes place at a distance," said Norman Nie, a Stanford professor of political science and director of the institute. "Can you get a hug, a warm voice, over the Internet?"

A quarter of the survey respondents who use the Internet more than five hours a week said they spend less time with friends and family, either on the phone or in person. Ten percent said it had reduced out-of-home social activities.

While personal interaction - not to mention time with such old-fashioned media as newspapers and, particularly, television - lost out, employers benefited. One in four respondents said the time he or she spent working at home had increased, while time spent at the office had either stayed the same or gone up as well.

No wonder Ford Motor Co. recently said it would give all its employees a personal computer and Internet connection, Nie said. "They just bought themselves hundreds of thousands of hours of free labor," he said. "You no longer have to pack a briefcase to work at home. Now it's all sitting there waiting for you."

Yet one reason they're not getting everything done at the office may be that they're so busy writing e-mails to far-flung chums, ordering books from Amazon.com, sending cards via BlueMountain.com, checking on the price of Cisco stock, researching their vacations in Tuscany, gambling on electronic lotteries and gazing upon Pamela Anderson Lee's raw beauty.

While Nie believes the Internet is, on balance, making employees more productive, other experts disagree. William D Bygrave, who teaches at the Blank Center for Entrepreneurship at Babson College in Massachusetts, used to monitor the daily traffic for the Drudge Report, which cyber-muckraker Matt Drudge would helpfully post at his site.

"I noticed his weekday traffic was much, much greater than his Saturday and Sunday traffic, even though he was breaking new stories on weekends to heighten interest in his TV show on Saturday evening and his radio show on Sunday evenings," the professor said.

Two-thirds of those surveyed spend less than five hours a week on the Net, and their behaviour changed little. But the longer people have been hooked up to the Net, the more time they spend on it, the study found, and Nie predicted that the trend toward social withdrawal would only increase, which meant the issue should be closely examined now.

"The automobile promised a great many things and delivered them," he said. "But if we began to think of the negatives at the beginning of the last century, maybe we'd have done some things differently, and it wouldn't take two hours on a rainy day to get from San Francisco to Palo Alto" - the 40-mile route he drives every day.

But critics dismissed most of what Nie - a former study director at the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago and a senior scientist for Gallup - concluded, as well as the research he used to get there.

"The assertion that the Internet is socially isolating has not held up to serious scrutiny," said Donna Hoffman, co-director of the eLab at Vanderbilt University in Nashville. "All of the research evidence I've seen points the other way - not to mention the anecdotal evidence."

In its negative implications, the study seemed to echo a much smaller one conducted in 1998 by the Carnegie-Mellon University Human-Computer Interaction Institute, which found "small but reliable declines in social and psychological well-being" among heavy Net users.

That study came in for a barrage of criticism. Some argued that part of the reason for the depression might have had to do with the fact that those surveyed all lived in Pittsburgh.

"There's a lot of professional rewards for focusing on the negative," said James Katz, a professor in the department of communication at Rutgers University in New Jersey. His own research showed that "more than a million new friendships have been found online that have led to face-to-face meetings."

"Being free from the strictures and the sanctions of your neighbors and family used to be considered good," Katz said. "This is what America and the Wild West were founded on. It used to be considered good. Now we have a new, endless frontier, and suddenly we have a lot of people wringing their hands."

Patrick McKeown, a business professor at the University of Georgia who recently wrote a textbook that explores the issue of living in Internet time, said it would be best to avoid value judgments about what the Net is doing to people.

"These are the facts of life as we know it. The Net puts us into social contact in a different sense than what we were used to," McKeown said. "It's now the faceless people you can communicate with."

fields.headline: Weblife: security
fields.standfirst: Shields up, we're under attack, says  Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: The information superhighway is a two-way street: if you can get out into the virtual world, then some of the less savoury inhabitants could also get into your personal computer. Scary, isn't it?
fields.body:
The information superhighway is a two-way street: if you can get out into the virtual world, then some of the less savoury inhabitants could also get into your personal computer. Scary, isn't it?

OK, so you have nothing to hide and nothing worth stealing, so no-one's going to invade your PC, right? Wrong.

The computer intruders out there don't know what you've got until they've had a look around your hard drive. And once they've done that, who knows what they might do? Even if they just deleted or renamed a few files, or changed some data, that wouldn't be very nice.

As wake-up calls go, you might think this is late: intruders have been breaking into computers for at least 20 years. But this was mostly people with home computers breaking into large corporate networks, usually for fun. Now they are breaking into home computers and it's no fun at all.

My own wake-up call came soon after British Telecom introduced its free (0800) internet service at the weekends. Instead of getting on and off the net in a hurry, I'd stay on for hours, which made my PC much more noticeable.

And for the first time, I became aware of other users trying to access my machine, or at least testing the "ports" through which computers listen to the net. (To find out which ports are listening on your PC, simply open a DOS window, type netstat -a and press Return. Do you know which programs are using those ports? If you see 12345 or 31337, be very afraid.) Today I can get at least 50 alerts over a weekend.

My interest in "firewalls" - special programs designed to keep intruders out - took a sudden leap.

My son, who is 14 and knows everything, told me not to be silly (I paraphrase slightly). Every kid has a port scanner, he said, and they probe people's ports when they're bored. It doesn't mean they can get into your PC. Not in my case, because - unlike you - I'd spent several hours going over the thing with the computer equivalent of a fine-tooth comb. But people can get into a PC, and do almost anything they like, if there's a "trojan" such as NetBus or Black Orifice or SubSeven sitting on the hard drive.

That's why many of those "innocent" probes are for the ports that these remote control programs usually use, such as 12345. In other words, would-be intruders are not looking for your PC in particular, just for any machine with a trojan that provides backdoor access.

Of course, you wouldn't have installed such a program deliberately, but it might still be present. It might have been concealed in a game that you downloaded from the net (whacked any moles recently?) or emailed to you as an attachment.

Someone else - not you - might have got one from a pirate software CD.

Part of the problem is the growing trend to hide what's going on, to make computing seem simpler than it really is. What about all those programs that various websites install on your PC or Mac for your convenience? What about the routines concealed in Java or JavaScript or ActiveX controls? How many people know what they do?

There are several web pages that will show you how vulnerable your computer is, without doing anything illegal. Privacy.net has a good one which can probably tell you your name, the name of your PC, the name of your workgroup, the name and address of your internet service provider, and sometimes your email address. More personal information may also be stored on your PC in "cookies" including details of web pages visited and advertisements viewed. (Cookies are small text files that websites can deposit in your PC's Cookies folder, unless you set your browser to reject them. This is done from the Tools menu in Microsoft Internet Explorer 5: select Internet Options then the Security tab.)

For an even more worrying experience, go to the Gibson Research Corporation website and invite it to probe your computer's ports. Steve Gibson is much more paranoid than I am about people getting access to your computer, and he just might be right.

Fortunately there now seems to be a solution, and for home users with Windows PCs, it's free. Go to the Zonelabs website and download the new ZoneAlarm 2.0. Find the 1.5 megabyte file called zonalm20.exe, on your hard drive and double-click it to install the program.

ZoneAlarm is a firewall that monitors all the internet traffic in and out of your PC. It will stop websites from sneakily accessing your hard drive, and will keep out intruders doing port scans or trying to find trojans. For an illustration of its effectiveness, go back to Privacy.net and GRC's site and retest your machine for privacy and security.

ZoneAlarm is not a panacea. For example, once you've allowed your browser access to the internet, there's nothing to stop you from downloading a trojan.

Nor will it stop you from running email attachments that you should have no compunction about deleting on sight.

However, it will stop things happening in the background that you probably wouldn't know about, unless you'd already bought a firewall such as BlackICE Defender.

Nor does ZoneAlarm check for trojans such as NetBus and SubSeven, or for viruses and other nasties. You should do this separately using a virus checking program. There are lots available: just make sure you use the latest version of a program that also checks for trojans.

As for those cookies, Webroot's Window Washer (or MacWasher) can be used to clear them out, and you can download a trial version from the website. But installing ZoneAlarm should be just the start of a more defensive attitude to computing.

It's time we stopped letting website designers shove all sorts of rubbish at us in the name of a more "personal" experience when that seriously compromises our security and our privacy.

 For detailed information on firewalls and listening ports, see www.robertgraham.com/pubs/firewall-seen.html

My son, who is 14 and knows everything, told me not to be silly (I paraphrase slightly). Every kid has a port scanner, he said, and they probe people's ports when they're bored. It doesn't mean they can get into your PC. Not in my case, because - unlike you - I'd spent several hours going over the thing with the computer equivalent of a fine-tooth comb. But people can get into a PC, and do almost anything they like, if there's a "trojan" such as NetBus or Black Orifice or SubSeven sitting on the hard drive. That's why many of those "innocent" probes are for the ports that these remote control programs usually use, such as 12345. In other words, would-be intruders are not looking for your PC in particular, just for any machine with a trojan that provides backdoor access. Of course, you wouldn't have installed such a program deliberately, but it might still be present. It might have been concealed in a game that you downloaded from the net (whacked any moles recently?) or emailed to you as an attachment. Someone else - not you - might have got one from a pirate software CD. Part of the problem is the growing trend to hide what's going on, to make computing seem simpler than it really is. What about all those programs that various websites install on your PC or Mac for your convenience? What about the routines concealed in Java or JavaScript or ActiveX controls? How many people know what they do? There are several web pages that will show you how vulnerable your computer is, without doing anything illegal. Privacy.net has a good one which can probably tell you your name, the name of your PC, the name of your workgroup, the name and address of your internet service provider, and sometimes your email address. More personal information may also be stored on your PC in "cookies" including details of web pages visited and advertisements viewed. (Cookies are small text files that websites can deposit in your PC's Cookies folder, unless you set your browser to reject them. This is done from the Tools menu in Microsoft Internet Explorer 5: select Internet Options then the Security tab.) For an even more worrying experience, go to the Gibson Research Corporation website and invite it to probe your computer's ports. Steve Gibson is much more paranoid than I am about people getting access to your computer, and he just might be right. Fortunately there now seems to be a solution, and for home users with Windows PCs, it's free. Go to the Zonelabs website and download the new ZoneAlarm 2.0. Find the 1.5 megabyte file called zonalm20.exe, on your hard drive and double-click it to install the program. ZoneAlarm is a firewall that monitors all the internet traffic in and out of your PC. It will stop websites from sneakily accessing your hard drive, and will keep out intruders doing port scans or trying to find trojans. For an illustration of its effectiveness, go back to Privacy.net and GRC's site and retest your machine for privacy and security. ZoneAlarm is not a panacea. For example, once you've allowed your browser access to the internet, there's nothing to stop you from downloading a trojan. Nor will it stop you from running email attachments that you should have no compunction about deleting on sight. However, it will stop things happening in the background that you probably wouldn't know about, unless you'd already bought a firewall such as BlackICE Defender. Nor does ZoneAlarm check for trojans such as NetBus and SubSeven, or for viruses and other nasties. You should do this separately using a virus checking program. There are lots available: just make sure you use the latest version of a program that also checks for trojans. As for those cookies, Webroot's Window Washer (or MacWasher) can be used to clear them out, and you can download a trial version from the website. But installing ZoneAlarm should be just the start of a more defensive attitude to computing. It's time we stopped letting website designers shove all sorts of rubbish at us in the name of a more "personal" experience when that seriously compromises our security and our privacy.  For detailed information on firewalls and listening ports, see www.robertgraham.com/pubs/firewall-seen.html

fields.headline: Straw's flawed plan
fields.standfirst: Guardian home affairs editor Alan Travis examines the home secretary's doomed strategy to restrict trial by jury
fields.trailText: 1pm: Guardian home affairs editor Alan Travis examines the home secretary's doomed strategy to restrict trial by jury
fields.body:
Jack Straw will try to appease the growing Labour revolt over his plans to restrict access to jury trials by announcing a new package of concessions today, but his attempt already looks doomed to fail.

This seems to be a clear case of the home secretary failing to heed the old political adage: "When you find yourself in a hole, stop digging."

The warning signs were clear enough when his own loyal backbenchers in the House of Lords, including many new Labour peers, such as Baroness Kennedy, joined Liberal Democrats, Conservatives and crossbenchers and threw out the entire mode of trial bill by a majority of 96 a month ago.

It was the first time since legislation paving the way for the abolition of the Greater London council in 1984 that a government bill had been killed in the House of Lords.

But instead of waiting a year, as Lady Thatcher had done when she suffered one of her most humiliating parliamentary defeats, Jack Straw pressed on and today will publish his mode of trial (number two) bill. Except this time he will not make the mistake of starting its life in the hostile environment of the House of Lords.

Instead, it is to be forced first through the House of Commons under the protection of Labour's 170-strong majority. The idea is that with an overwhelming endorsement by the elected chamber, the upper house, even after the hereditary peers have been slung out, will not feel able to reject it a second time.

It would then turn into a battle between the democratic Commons and the unelected House of Lords. That at least is the current Straw plan.

But trouble has already reared its head for Mr Straw in the shape of a Commons rebellion led by the Labour barrister and MP for Medway, Robert Marshall-Andrews, and the Old Etonian Labour MP for Stoke on Trent Central, Mark Fisher, which has already attracted the support of 57 other Labour MPs.

It threatens to reduce Labour's Commons majority for the bill to such an unimpressive level that the House of Lords would feel justified in throwing out the measure once again.

So what is all about? Well, defendants accused of serious crimes are sent straight to the crown court to be tried by a jury. Those accused of minor offences have their cases heard by the magistrates.

But there is a group of "middle-ranking" offences such as burglary and theft where defendants - about 18,000 a year - currently have the choice as to which court hears their cases.

Jack Straw says that hardened criminals use this choice to abuse the system and waste time in the hope that a gullible jury will acquit them. He claims that scrapping the right to choose jury trial will save more than £100m a year.

In order to achieve this, the bill contains a test "of reputation and livelihood". This was designed to ensure that those who had no previous convictions, a full-time job and a nice home got a jury trial, while the persistent offender was not allowed to play the system and confined to a hearing in the much cheaper magistrates court.

This has led to complaints of two-tier justice whereby a bank manager will automatically enjoy a jury trial, while the homeless and unemployed will be banned from access to the crown court. Mr Straw will announce this afternoon he is dropping this test.

But his critics maintain this will do little to undermine the basic principle of the bill which they argue removes a fundamental civil liberty.

Watch out for more fireworks to come as you witness the spectacle of Jack Straw's bill being shot down in flames for a second time.

webTitle: Analysis: Why has violence flared in Mitrovice?

fields.headline: Analysis: Why has violence flared in Mitrovice?
fields.trailText: The divided town of Mitrovice, in the north of Kosovo, has become the flashpoint for mass protests and sniping attacks as peacekeeping forces struggle to keep apart gunmen and stone-throwing mobs.
fields.body:
The divided town of Mitrovice, in the north of Kosovo, has become the flashpoint for mass protests and sniping attacks as peacekeeping forces struggle to keep apart gunmen and stone-throwing mobs.

Split between a predominantly Serb population in the north and a largely Albanian community in its southern half, Mitrovice is accumulating the kind of reputation Belfast once enjoyed in the 1970s. Tear gas, barbed wire and house to house weapon searches are in danger of becoming the order of the day.

The resurgence of ethnic unrest in Kosovo follows months of arson attacks and sectarian murders as the two communities in the province have sought revenge for last year's war and massacres. Serbs have left in their tens of thousands, fleeing north to the relative safety of Serbia proper as ethnic Albanians chase out those who were once their neighbours but whom they now blame for mass killings.

Nato officials in Brussels will hold a crisis meeting tomorrow on the upsurge of ethnic violence in Mitrovice. Officials of the alliance have blamed this week's flare-up on the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic. Nato's supreme commander, General Wesley Clark, has claimed Mr Milosevic is conducting a new campaign of covert operations in and around Kosovo in an attempt to destabilise the peacekeeping operation.

"Mitrovice is going to be multiethnic, and that means ending the intimidation and other dirty work of the military units, gangs and thugs who have been sent there by Belgrade," Gen Clark said. American and British troops have recently been despatched to the city to reinforce the French contingent. Paris yesterday announced it was flying out an extra battalion.

Part of the problem has been that although Nato originally planned to have 49,000 soldiers in K-For to help restore order in Kosovo, only 30,000 troops were ever sent. Nato commanders yesterday issued an urgent appeal for reinforcements.

The alliance is facing domestic political resistance to its call for help. Nato countries may support the Balkans force in principle but many find their armed forces overstretched by other peacekeeping commitments around the world.

Britain said today that it would not be sending any more troops to Kosovo. "There have been no further requests," a ministry of defence spokesman said. "The plan is to make use of what is out there."

In Athens, Nato's secretary-general, Lord Robertson, urged alliance members to remain calm and insisted that there were sufficient resources. "There is no panic," he said. "We have enough troops in Kosovo to deal with the situation."

Mitrovice lies on the edge of an enclave in the north of Kosovo where Serbs still form the majority of the population. In the coming days, Nato peacekeepers are planning to begin resettling ethnic Albanians in three high-rise apartment buildings in the Serb-dominated sector of town, north of the Ibar River. The move to reintegrate Mitrovice is likely to provoke further clashes.

webTitle: Southall inquiry blames train operators and driver

fields.headline: Southall inquiry blames train operators and driver
fields.standfirst:
Summary of report's findings
The issue explained: rail safety
fields.trailText: The failure of a key safety system, lack of training, lax safety  procedures and failures of communication all contributed to the Southall rail crash, an official accident report said  today.
fields.body:
The failure of a key safety system, lack of training, lax safety procedures and failures of communication all contributed to the Southall rail crash, an official accident report said today.

But the long-awaited report also pointed blame at the driver of the high-speed train in the fatal 1997 accident. The health and safety commission report said Larry Harrison had "failed to heed" two warning signals, but it also highlighted failures in safety measures by First Great Western trains and poor guidelines by track operator Railtrack.

The report listed 93 recommendations for improvements to rail safety in the wake of the Southall crash which killed seven people and injured 139. "There is no reason he (Harrison) should have missed the signals," said professor John Uff, who led the inquiry. The driver was unable to account "for his inattention", the report said.

The health and safety commission said it accepted professor Uff's findings and would give British rail companies three weeks to respond on how they intended to implement the recommendations.

His report came just days after the start of an inquest into the Paddington train crash that killed 31 people last year. The Paddington crash last October, two years after the Southall crash, has forced the government to make changes in rail safety, stripping track operator Railtrack of some of its safety responsibilities.

Health and safety commission chairman Bill Callaghan called for urgent action in the wake of today's report. "The victims have waited too long for this report," he said. "Professor Uff has produced an independent, thorough and detailed report. The underlying issues are that the system broke down as a result of the fragmentation of the industry; there is a need for a new positive safety culture and a need to look at human behaviour as much as equipment in effective safety systems."

Mr Callaghan said he had written to all train operating companies asking for a response within three weeks on how they intend to implement the recommendations. "I know it is tough and there will be those in the industry who say it can not be done," he said. "Let them be in no doubt that those who use and work on the railway will not tolerate any delay."

Jenny Bacon, director general of the health and safety executive said: "This report gives all concerned in the industry including the regulators a clear blueprint for action. Of concern to HSE are the more fundamental problems uncovered by the report. These include indications of a poor safety culture throughout the industry, the extent to which industry fragmentation continues to hinder safety issues and the underlying weaknesses that it highlights in the training and resourcing of maintenance crews."

Giving evidence about going through two danger signals before the crash, Mr Harrison was "simply unable to account for his actions". Earlier, he had been seen driving into Bristol Parkway station with both his feet up on the front console which revealed he was "a man capable of a somewhat cavalier disregard of convention".

But the report said there was no firm evidence that Mr Harrison had used the bag in which he was rummaging only moments before the crash to weigh down the driver's vigilance device (DVD), which drivers have to press down and depress regularly to stop them falling asleep.

The report said Mr Harrison "might simply have dozed off between the successive warnings from the DVD long enough to have missed two signals".

The automatic train protection (ATP) safety system - which brakes trains in emergencies - was fitted on the Great Western train but was not switched on because some of the company's drivers, including Mr Harrison, were not trained to use it.

The Swansea to London express sped past a red light and collided with a freight train crossing the line ahead of it. Great Western and Mr Harrison were acquitted of manslaughter but the company was later fined £1.5m under the health and safety at work act.

fields.headline: Southall inquiry: the findings summarised
fields.trailText:
Inquiry chairman Prof John Uff found that the primary cause of
the accident was the failure of the driver of the high speed
Great Western train to react either to signals SN280 or SN270.
fields.body:
Inquiry chairman Prof John Uff found that the primary cause of the accident was the failure of the driver of the high speed Great Western train to react either to signals SN280 or SN270.

The closing speed of the two trains at the point of collision was probably in excess of 80 mph. The crash resulted in the deaths of seven passengers and 139 people being injured, some severely.

The report found that there were no relevant faults on the track or signals, neither of the two main protection systems fitted to the high speed train - Automatic Warning System (AWS) and Automatic Train Protection (ATP) - were operational at the time of the accident.

AWS would have alerted the driver to the warning signals. ATP would have prevented the train passing the red signal.

Great Western Trains was fined £1.5m after admitting health & safety breaches but manslaughter charges against the company and train driver Larry Harrison were dropped.

Prof Uff's report identifies lessons to be learned and makes recommendations including:
 Driver training and procedures should be tightened up.
 AWS is to be regarded as vital to the continued running of a train and AWS and other train-borne safety equipment should not fail in service through preventable causes.
 Crashworthiness and safety procedures in passenger vehicles should be reviewed.
 Safety briefings for passengers should be adopted on a trial basis.
 Inter-company rights and obligations in equipment added to rail vehicles must be defined.
 System authorities should be created to oversee safety projects including AWS and ATP.

Further recommendations are:
 ATP should be maintained on Great Western lines and an extension to the present coverage of ATP on Great Western lines should be considered.
 Technical accident investigations should be directed by HSE.
 The rail industry inquiry procedures should be reviewed to ensure all necessary rail safety issues are subject to rapid action."
