webTitle: Krzysztof Kieslowski: A Short Film About Killing

fields.headline: Krzysztof Kieslowski: A Short Film About Killing
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies: This week, number 56: Krzysztof Kieslowski's A Short Film About Killing
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies: This week, number 56: Krzysztof Kieslowski's A Short Film About Killing
fields.body:
No European director of recent years, not even Pedro Almodovar, has been as admired, at least by critics, as Krzysztof Kieslowski. Yet he had to wait many years for recognition outside Poland. The films that brought him into prominence were the Decalogue, loose commentaries on the Ten Commandments, originally made for Polish television. Each hour-long film was set within the same Warsaw suburb, and the whole project took 18 months to shoot. Two of them were extended by Kieslowski into features - A Short Film About Killing and A Short Film About Love. They illustrated "thou shalt not kill" and "thou shalt not commit adultery", and either would be candidates for my 100 best list.

I choose Killing because of the furore it caused in some circles. In Poland, the film was instrumental in the abolition of the death penalty. But not everybody admired it. At Cannes, it only received the minor Jury Prize; one juror called it a second-rate copy of an American film and another said that it should be banned outright.

Only myself and Henning Carlsen, the Danish director, supported it. We nominated it for Best Film - a choice of which its opponents approved, thinking it would have no chance of that award with the final jury. To everyone's surprise, Kieslowski won.

The film is not easy to watch, being the story of a lumpen young man who kills a taxi driver and is caught, brought to trial, condemned to death and executed. Both deaths are dreadful; Kieslowski is clearly trying to tell us that both are morally repugnant. The taxi driver is battered with a stone and dies slowly, while the long-winded bureaucratic precision of the hanging was apparently so horrendous to film that Kieslowski's team had to break off in the middle.

It should be emphasised, though, that the two most violent scenes are not lingered over. We see neither too little nor too much. They are there to shock us, but for a good reason. What makes them powerful is the rest of the film. It is shot by Slavomir Idziak with the aid of lowering, ochre-coloured filters that render the young man's world like a purgatorial nightmare. Never has Warsaw and its environs looked so depressing.

The murderer has come from a bad home and his lack of education is palpable. He is a pathetic figure who would seem set for a life of tragedy. Not for a moment does the film let us off the hook, and the atmosphere it sustains is one of the most menacing I've encountered.

Most considering the work of this outstanding director would probably choose a film from his later Three Colours Trilogy, made largely in France. Brilliant as these were, his style became too refined, sometimes dominating the content. While it is almost impossible to conceive of Kieslowski making a bad film, in the Decalogue, and particularly in Killing, style and content were perfectly matched.

Brilliant as these were, his style became too refined, sometimes dominating the content. While it is almost impossible to conceive of Kieslowski making a bad film, in the Decalogue, and particularly in Killing, style and content were perfectly matched.

webTitle: Spice Girls face £1m bill for breaking deal

fields.headline: Spice Girls face £1m bill for breaking deal
fields.trailText: The Spice Girls today lost their high court defence against the sponsors of their 1998 tour and will now have to pay Italian motorcycle manufacturers Aprilia around £1m in damages and court costs.
fields.body:
The Spice Girls today lost their high court defence against the sponsors of their 1998 tour and will now have to pay Italian motorcycle manufacturers Aprilia around £1m in damages and court costs.

There is to be a further hearing to determine the exact amount of the claim against the Spice Girls. Aprilia sought damages of £434,564 or £1m depending on whether it could establish its claim for misrepresentation or breach of contract.

The Spice Girls launched a claim against Aprilia for £212,000 in unpaid sponsorship and royalty fees but this was dismissed. The motorcycle firm responded with its own action.

Aprilia had a £500,000 deal with the group to promote its products (including a Spice Sonic scooter featuring a picture of all five singers), and says that Geri Halliwell's departure cost it £1.6m in lost profits.

The company claims the Girls were aware that Ms Halliwell intended to leave when they signed the sponsorship deal.

The judge, Mrs Justice Arden, said there was an implied misrepresentation. Ms Halliwell left the group after logos had been designed and the advertisement completed.

She said Aprilia would not have entered into the agreement to provide the Spice Girls with £450,000 in sponsorship fees and £112,000 in guaranteed royalties on the scooter if it had known that a member of the band was leaving at the end of May 1998.

During the hearing, Ms Halliwell said it had "not even crossed my mind" that the scooter's logo would be out of date if she were to leave the band.

She had told the four other Girls in March 1998 that she wanted to leave in September, but admitted that they had probably not taken her seriously.

Baby Spice Emma Bunton confirmed in court that they had never thought Ms Halliwell would abandon the band. "Things were said quite flippantly at the time," she told the court, confessing that she had a "terrible memory".

When Ms Halliwell left the band in May 1998, Aprilia decided not to settle the balance of sponsorship fees. The company had incurred large costs in marketing material and producing the Spice Sonic scooter.

It is not yet clear whether Spice Girls Ltd or Ms Halliwell, who has pursued a successful solo career since leaving the band, will pay the largest share of the damages and court costs.

webTitle: NHS bed shortage sends operation cancellations soaring

fields.headline: NHS bed shortage sends operation cancellations soaring
fields.standfirst: Download the national audit office report
fields.trailText: The NHS today came under renewed fire when a report found that record numbers of people are having their operations cancelled on the day they are scheduled because of bed shortages.
fields.body:
The NHS today came under renewed fire when a report found that record numbers of people are having their operations cancelled on the day they are scheduled because of bed shortages.

Such shortages mean hospitals are frequently in breach of the patient's charter, which states that nobody should have their surgery cancelled on the day of admission, the national audit office report said.

The report sparked more criticism of the government's handling of the NHS. Liberal Democrat health spokesman Nick Harvey said: "This report confirms that the NHS is stretched to the limits. Despite their grand claims, Labour have not done enough to save the NHS."

The shortage of beds during the flu outbreak over Christmas forced prime minister Tony Blair to promise more spending on the NHS, a pledge that was later watered down to "an aspiration". But chancellor Gordon Brown is almost certain to announce an increase in NHS funding in his budget next month.

The latest report on the NHS's shortcomings will put further pressure on the government to improve health services. The NAO said that in 1999 57,000 patients in England had operations cancelled by their hospitals for non-medical reasons on the day of admission - the highest number since the patient's charter was introduced. And one in five patients in casualty departments waits more than the maximum two hours set down by the charter before being seen.

One third of hospitals say that demand for beds exceeds availability at least once a day. A record 6m people stayed in hospitals for at least one night last year, while the number of beds has consistently fallen in recent years. The recent winter crisis in the NHS highlighted the bed shortage, with people queuing for hours in accident and emergency departments and patients ferried hundreds of miles in the search for an intensive care space.

Hospitals are improving, with a 20% increase in the number of trusts employing bed managers in the last two years. But poor management of beds is partly to blame for the situation, the head of the national audit office Sir John Bourn said. Few hospitals have systems to monitor and update bed availability, with nine out of 10 trusts relying on bed managers to physically inspect the situation or phone wards several times a day to get information.

Trusts should assess patients before they are admitted to hospital and liaise better with other care agencies to improve discharge procedures, he said. Bed managers should also be moved away from day to day "crisis management" and plan strategically ahead to maximise bed space.

Sir John said: "This winter has reminded us again of how crucial it is that hospitals manage their bed stock effectively. We have found significant variations in performance between hospitals in admitting and discharging patients and managing beds."

A spokeswoman for the department of health said: "Too many patients have had their operations cancelled at the last minute because the critical care bed they needed had become unavailable. That is why we have set up a review of the critical care system to make sure it is properly integrated with the rest of the NHS."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Michael Mann beats Spike Lee to Ali, Robert Redford to direct biopic of Nobel Prize-winning mathematician, Sylvester Stallone keeps busy
fields.body:
 Michael Mann has beaten rival Spike Lee to land the job of directing the upcoming Muhammad Ali biopic. The Columbia-backed production is one of the hottest prizes on the movie calendar. Last year, Barry Sonnenfeld was said to be committed to the project, with frequent collaborator Will Smith to star as Ali. Then Sonnenfeld bailed out to direct the comedy Big Trouble for Disney and the picture was up for grabs again. The movie is now tentatively scheduled shooting this autumn, with Mann directing and Smith still starring. Cuba Gooding Jr is rumoured to be the current front-runner for the role of George Foreman, who Ali memorably bested in 1974's Rumble in the Jungle.

 Robert Redford's next behind-the-cameras stint will be directing the biopic A Beautiful Mind for Universal. Based on the book by Sylvia Nassar, the film will chart the true-life experiences of John Forbes Nash Jr, a mathematical genius who won out over schizophrenia to win the Nobel Prize. Tom Cruise is interested in playing the lead (keen perhaps to revisit the Oscar-winning angst he showed on Born on the Fourth of July) and the film starts shooting in September.

 In the same week as his split from Universal, Sylvester Stallone looks to have gone into overdrive. Variety announced that the brawny star is to star as a bank-robber on the run in Morton Orwell, a low-budget thriller for the independent production house Seven Arts International. Meantime Stallone is also throwing his weight behind Champs, the script he has written about the American auto-racing circuit. Stallone will star and the film will be backed by Franchise Pictures. The Hollywood Reporter reports Franchise chairman Elie Samaha as claiming that Stallone has already been in talks with director Renny Harlin (who worked with Stallone in Cliffhanger) with a view to persuading him on board. But perhaps Samaha and Stallone are letting their enthusiasm run away with them. A representative of Harlin later announced that no negotiations had taken place and that the director was startled to hear that they had.

webTitle: Zellweger to star as Bridget Jones

fields.headline: Zellweger to star as Bridget Jones
fields.trailText: American actress Renee Zellweger has signed to play single thirtysomething Bridget Jones in Universal's upcoming adaptation of the bestselling "diary" by British journalist Helen Fielding
fields.body:
American actress Renee Zellweger has signed to play single thirtysomething Bridget Jones in Universal's upcoming adaptation of the bestselling "diary" by British journalist Helen Fielding. But what is v.good news for Zellweger looks to be a snub for the crop of homegrown actresses previously said to be in the running. Ever since the project was announced, industry insiders predicted that the role of scatty, chain-smoking Ms Jones would be fought out between the likes of Kate Winslet, Minnie Driver and Alex Kingston.

Hailing from the small town of Katy, Texas, the statuesque Zellweger initially looks miles away from Fielding's heroine - more Lone Star than London lonely-heart. But the thirty-year old actress won plaudits for her role as Tom Cruise's love interest in 1996's Jerry Maguire and is generally held to be one of Hollywood's most underrated players. She will next be seen in Neil Labute's Nurse Betty and the Farrelly Brothers' comedy Me, Myself and Irene opposite long-term partner Jim Carrey.

Zellweger is said to be consulting a voice coach in order to master a London accent. Universal already have a finished script, co-scripted by Fielding alongside her friend, Notting Hill scribe Richard Curtis and experienced screenwriter Andrew Davies. A director has yet to be announced.

fields.headline: Ford bails from Soderbergh film
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford has bailed out of the Steven Soderbergh picture Traffic in order to commit to an as-yet-unnamed other project
fields.body:
Harrison Ford has bailed out of the Steven Soderbergh picture Traffic. The actor had been due to star in the controversial overview of the drugs war in America but pulled out in order to commit to an as-yet-unnamed other project, Variety reported last night.

Ford's eleventh hour departure has thrown the Fox Searchlight production into crisis. According to sources, Traffic is due to go before the cameras on April 2 and the studio is desperately casting around for a star to fill Ford's shoes. Al Pacino, Tommy Lee Jones and (more worryingly) Kevin Costner are among the big names said to have expressed an interest.

Loosely based on an acclaimed BBC mini-series, Traffic was to have heralded a bracing change of direction for Ford. Last month saw the actor sign up with an agency for the first time in fifteen years with the aim of gaining access to riskier, less formulaic pictures. Scripted by Steve Gaghan, Traffic looked to fit the bill perfectly, with its no-holds-barred assault on the drugs trade in the US and an ambitious, maverick director in Steven Soderbergh. Ford was to have played the role of Robert Lewis, a district judge appointed as a drugs tzar whose war on the narcotics trade is undermined when his 16 year old daughter becomes addicted to crack cocaine. Catherine Zeta-Jones is pencilled in to co-star as the unsuspecting wife of a cocaine dealer, but Ford's departure is rumoured to have weakened her own commitment to the project.

As reported in Film Unlimited last week, Ford was said to have become frustrated with the slow pace at which Traffic was progressing and had become bogged down in protracted salary negotiations with Fox, who were determined that the film should keep within a small-scale budget of $30-40m. But these negotiations had been resolved at the tail-end of last week and the film looked set to begin production with Ford on board.

Inevitably, commentators are already speculating that Ford got cold feet over Traffic's content and has retreated to the safer, more conservative, and better paid world of mainstream movie-making. Last night his long-term manager Pat McQueeny confirmed that the actor had left Traffic in order to make "an action film", widely believed to be either the next Jack Ryan movie or the next Indiana Jones movie.

webTitle: Girl wins battle to wear trousers to school

fields.headline: Girl wins battle to wear trousers to school
fields.trailText: A girl aged 14 was celebrating a legal victory yesterday after her school agreed to let her and her classmates wear trousers as part of their uniform.
fields.body:
A girl aged 14 was celebrating a legal victory yesterday after her school agreed to let her and her classmates wear trousers as part of their uniform.

In the first challenge of its kind against a school, the equal opportunities commission backed Jo Hale and her mother, Claire, after they threatened to take Whickham comprehensive, Gateshead, to court on sex discrimination grounds.

In the settlement yesterday the school agreed to change its uniform policy from September, allowing girls to wear trousers and, more bizarrely, allowing boys to wear knee-length skirts and white socks.

Claire Hale, 47, who lectures in clinical nursing at Leeds university, said the school had been guilty of sex discrimination in requiring Jo to wear a skirt in winter when it was clearly impractical.

The school governors had at last made a sensible decision, she said. "I hope that schools all realise that this is the way of the future." While it would not become law, "I hope the outcome is influential in other cases where silly rules discriminate against girls."

Mrs Hale last night wrote to David Blunkett, education secretary, asking him to issue a circular making it clear that girls can wear trousers.

Jo said she was delighted for herself and her friends. "Now I will be glad to put this all behind me and get on with my schoolwork. After all, if you're in class and doing your work then what does it matter if you're wearing trousers?"

The EOC's chairwoman, Julie Mellor, said the result delivered consistency, since trousers were now considered conventional dress in schools, businesses and institutions throughout Britain and the rest of the world.

The settlement was "a victory for common sense. Trousers are smart and practical for the rigours of school life, and there is no reason for girls to be prevented [from wearing them]".

Jo and her mother lodged legal papers last September. They did not question the school's right to have a uniform policy but claimed that its refusal to let girls have the choice to wear trousers amounted to sex discrimination.

The EOC said it was the first challenge of its kind to the legal right of a school to enforce its dress code. A number of schools have agreed to allow Muslim girls to wear trousers and long-sleeved tops so as not to breach race discrimination laws.

Yesterday Peter Maugham, Whickham's chairman of governors and a Gateshead Liberal Democrat councillor, said the school had agreed to settle reluctantly. "We have not changed the uniform, we have simply extended the present uniform so that both sexes can wear which ever one they want to," he said. It meant that the boys could "come to school in the girls' skirts - but they would be bonkers if they did."

Hilary Slater, EOC solicitor, said: "There is a strong argument that it is unlawful to prevent girls from wearing trousers to school now that trousers are an acceptable form of dress for women on virtually any occasion. Trousers are now the outfit of choice for women in a wide variety of situations: Gwynneth Paltrow at a film premiere, Emma Thompson at the Oscars, Cherie Blair on official engagements.

"I hope the settlement in Jo's case will persuade other schools to review their uniform policies to eliminate unlawful sexual discrimination."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Get me to the church
fields.body:
Get me to the church

This column and its followers must by now be experts on the intricacies of gas meter reference numbers, telephone billing systems and washing machine warranties. What we lack, however, is romance. Then, earlier this month, Consumer received an SOS from two beleaguered couples trying to plan a double wedding in Antigua. Siblings Stuart and Lesley Cain and their fiances Joanne Lucas and Martin McMeechan of the Isle of Wight booked a fortnight's package for 42 people through Virgin Holidays. "If you want a simple wedding with no fuss, it's no problem," boasted the brochure blithely. The trouble, of course, with package holidays, is that if you change your arrangements you pay the penalty, but if the travel company does you must lump it.

Six months after their booking, the party's chosen hotel was removed from the brochure and new reservations made in a pricier alternative. Virgin eventually offered to halve the cost of the package as compensation, and all was bliss - until the flights were cancelled. Virgin Atlantic had decided to redraw their schedules which meant that the party would have to curtail their holiday by two days or extend it (and the cost) by two days. They chose the latter only to find that their hotel was fully booked for the extra nights. With only three months to go before the wedding the party was still in the dark about its arrangements and, although the whole package came to £60,000, Virgin said it was unable to help them further.

 It's amazing what a PR department can do. Having refused further compensation, Virgin Holidays, has now decided that true love must rank above profit and will charter an aircraft to fly the party from Antigua to Barbados so that it can pick up a direct flight to London. The cost will be graciously borne by Virgin.

The ghost train

Reaching the Caribbean is a doddle compared with trying to cross Britain on the privatised railway system. In January Stella Britzolakis bought a £1209.60 three-month season ticket through South West trains. This, she was assured, entitled her to commute from Coventry to London on both Virgin and Silverlink trains.

After a month of eventless travelling she was then told by a Virgin inspector that the ticket was only valid on the Silverlink service. Britzolakis later made further enquiries and discovered that her investment did not entitle her to travel on Silverlink either. Why? Because she had paid too much for her ticket. South West Trains staff in Portsmouth then endeavoured to enlighten her. The ticket was valid for Virgin but only on trains routed via Northampton. There was just one hitch; no Virgin trains travel via Northampton. Virgin also declared that there is no such thing as a season ticket on the Coventry to Euston route and that she'd have to pay the daily fare of £70.

Silverlink, meanwhile, had been doing its own investigations and discovered that her ticket was certainly valid - for journeys from Coventry to Rugby.

A clue to the mystery is unearthed by the Central Rail Users Consultative Committee. The rail fares manual used by the South West trains clerk lists a fare for a London via Northampton route, but it is a phantom service. The only operator who runs this route is Silverlink and its season ticket costs less than the fare quoted. No one else operates that route. "It's bizarre," says a spokesman. "I've never come across anything like it and I must admit I don't know what the customer can do about it." Over to you John Prescott!

Which way?

The mystery of what tickets are valid for which routes appears to baffle rail staff as much as their hapless passengers. Julian Hayward of Bracknell points out that the condition that used to allow commuters to travel "by any reasonable route" has been quietly changed to "any permitted route". Thus guards no longer have the discretion to decide if a passenger is trying it on or not, and passengers are left to work out the conundrum of what a permitted route is. If there's a direct line to your destination, go for it. "Failing that," says Hayward, "you have to consult the Association of Train Operating Companies (ATOC) routing guide, which is a byzantine tome of rules and maps. Most staff on the ground don't understand it fully and some not at all."

"I saw a copy of the routing guide once and got the fright of my life," says the man at the Association of Train Operating Companies. "There are a couple of people who understand it - they wrote it." Permitted routes, he explains, were introduced to streamline operations once 25 profit-hungry companies replaced British Rail. fields.bodyText: Get me to the church This column and its followers must by now be experts on the intricacies of gas meter reference numbers, telephone billing systems and washing machine warranties. What we lack, however, is romance. Then, earlier this month, Consumer received an SOS from two beleaguered couples trying to plan a double wedding in Antigua. Siblings Stuart and Lesley Cain and their fiances Joanne Lucas and Martin McMeechan of the Isle of Wight booked a fortnight's package for 42 people through Virgin Holidays. "If you want a simple wedding with no fuss, it's no problem," boasted the brochure blithely. Virgin eventually offered to halve the cost of the package as compensation, and all was bliss - until the flights were cancelled. Virgin Atlantic had decided to redraw their schedules which meant that the party would have to curtail their holiday by two days or extend it (and the cost) by two days. fields.headline: Serial thinker
fields.standfirst: Comfortably seated in his spotless loft for lofty thoughts, an occasionally animated michael Ignatieff talks to Sabine Durrant about death, divorce, life as an intellectual - and his new work on Kosovo and conflict
fields.trailText: Michael Ignatieff, the Canadian intellectual, was once quoted as saying he watched a lot of junk TV. Does he still? He looks a bit agonised. "We rarely miss an episode of Frasier," he says. "But, no, that's not junk is it? That's really good stuff. Er . . ." Peak Practice? "No, I don't watch Peak Practice." Taggart? "No." Home and Away? "No." He frowns, his satanic black eyebrows becoming one. Finally, he says, without much hope in his voice: "Is Our Friends in the North junk?"
fields.body:
Michael Ignatieff, the Canadian intellectual, was once quoted as saying he watched a lot of junk TV. Does he still? He looks a bit agonised. "We rarely miss an episode of Frasier," he says. "But, no, that's not junk is it? That's really good stuff. Er . . ." Peak Practice? "No, I don't watch Peak Practice." Taggart? "No." Home and Away? "No." He frowns, his satanic black eyebrows becoming one. Finally, he says, without much hope in his voice: "Is Our Friends in the North junk?"

If such a thing were possible, Michael Ignatieff has, over the past 10 years, become even more like Michael Ignatieff. In 1990, around which time, as one of The Late Show's reviled presenters, he first became an icon of high-mindedness, A Day in the Life found him "pottering along" in a big Victorian house, full of the smells of cooking and the shrieks of small children.

These days, a commentator on the philosophy of war, the philosophy of nationalism, the philosophy of human rights, he resides in a warehouse in that hip triangle of London between Hoxton and the City, with white walls and vast wooden floors and groupings of modern furniture in pink and acid green. There are some blown-up lines of Brodsky in a frame: "The dust settles down on objects / in summer like winter snow." Two Burmese cats, one grey, one black, pad across the reaches of floor, nails clicking. It's a world without mess, or distraction, or sticky fingers, the perfect context for serious thought. Not for Ignatieff the cluttered study of academe. A loft for lofty things.

Ignatieff, 52, is wearing black corduroy trousers and a black polo neck. He is looking a little rounded, chin seeping into his jowls. He still has that angular helmet of Thunderbird hair, but there are wispier tufts coming out of his ears. Less Alan Hansen these days, more John Redwood. He has a cold coming on. When his new wife, Suzanna Zsohar, a book publicist, inquires if we'd like tea, he sinks his head into his shoulders like a little boy and puts his hands out beseechingly. "Special tea for colds," he implores.

Perhaps it's the snuffle that gives him the air of a Victorian lady as he reclines on to his yellow cushions, the colour of supermarket waxed lemons. It's certainly not the subject matter. His latest book, Virtual War, the third in a trilogy around the subject of ethnic nationalism, is subtitled: "Kosovo and Beyond." He has a television series, Future War, in the offing, too. At one point in the making of this, he watched a training exercise of US marines in which they "did that thing you see in the movies: one, two, three, round the wall. Right? Into the line of fire." A British marine next to him pointed out how the squad leader's M60 carbine barrel was protruding from the edge of the wall by a millimetre. "I said, 'What difference does that make?' He said, 'The difference is you'd be dead in Belfast.'"

He has the language of modern warfare at the front of his mind, too. He talks about "gun camera footage" and "ZTC contact video conferences" as easily as one imagines him once talking about Proust - only he may never have talked easily about Proust. "I was never terribly happy with the idea of the arts," he says now. "I mean -" he wriggles his shoulders and adopts a mockingly pretentious sneer "- The ARTS, damn it."

But for all this, there is about him an air of ennui, the downside perhaps of finding in most experiences "an academic question" or something "philosophically interesting". All those points to make about masculinity and the nation state and human rights when Milosevic flexes his muscles by sending a jet plane down a runway to zip past Holbrooke's ear: "Yeah, OK, the planes are fun." He says he dislikes cynical scepticism in others, that if he were 18 "instead of wasting my time with a graduate degree [Harvard], I would be out there in Africa somewhere". But that graduate degree (not to mention the five honoraries) is hard to shrug off. Even the interview becomes a subject of his own inquisition. "Here I get heavily ideological," he might say. Or: "That's the long answer; the short answer is . . ." Or: "Everything I have to say about blah is cliché . . ." Or, when asked what he does when he's not working: "Another ghastly pause."

He says there was one occasion when he was in Kosovo, when he was on a hillside (there he was up high again) looking down on the refugee camp at Stankovec, when he "had this fury". "But most of the time," he adds, "I don't feel that." He says all this in a very slow voice, so laid back it's almost comic. He continues caressing the black Burmese with long rhythmic strokes. Ditto when he talks about the provision of care for Alzheimer patients in this country (his mother suffered from it). He feels so angry about this: "I feel some obligation to do something about it, one of these days."

Or when he almost, but not quite, gets hot under his polo neck about the Canadian reputation in this country (he has Scottish and Russian blood, has lived here for 30 years, but retains his Canadian nationality). "There was a silly programme, it just consisted of one set of Canadian jokes after another. Jack Dee. And the joke which went on for 45 minutes was that Canadians lack a sense of humour. Firstly, it went on a bit too long even for British ears. Secondly, I thought what a provincial, stupid . . ." He pulls himself together, audibly cools himself down. "Brrrr."

So who is Michael Ignatieff? He is part of the chattering classes, he says: "Part of a stage army who says, 'This has got to stop' and then, in mass, it does have political effect." But he distances himself quite quickly from this group: "They are rightly despised for being metropolitan and for being snobby and for being champagne this and champagne that." He was once an academic, but no longer; once a hack, but wouldn't call himself that now. He has voted Labour since 1970, but he's not really one of them. "I'm not tribal Labour. I'm a Liberal at heart. Different tradition, different language."

He has tried screenwriting - the first draft for Ralph Fiennes' Eugene Onegin. ("Ralph thought I could speak Russian. I didn't disabuse him.") But he is not a natural at it. He has also been a novelist. Asya, his first novel, a historical saga set in Russia, was not favourably received. "That"s a charitable understatement," he says, giving a hollow laugh. It's testament to his own bravery, or to something anyway, that he went on to write another. Scar Tissue, about his mother's Alzheimer's, was shortlisted for the 1993 Booker. Did you do it to show them? "Show them ?" he says dismissively. "I didn't do it to show 'them'. I did it to show myself."

I wondered what he thought of the trend to write about subjects once covered in fiction as autobiography. He becomes more staccato: "I had to do it in fiction because some of the people were still alive. It is still very painful to talk about it. Scar Tissue is the only book I've ever written when I've felt completely toxic, ill. I was so upset by my mother's illness and death. I haven't got anything interesting to say about this. The thing about Alzheimer's is, 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.' I was frightened and repelled by it. I'm still repelled by it . . ." Then he adds: "But to the degree that Scar Tissue was based on personal experience, the experience wasn't mine. It was my brother's. He was there. I was the absent brother."

He says he has nothing interesting to say about divorce either. "Absolutely standard painful. When you initiate it, it is an experiment on live tissue and we don't know how the experiment will come out. I think my kids are OK [he has a 16-year-old son and a 12-year-old daughter]. I touch all available pieces of wood." He used to suffer from a chronically bad back, but it's "gone, all gone". It's because he's happier, he says. The reason? "She's sitting in the next room."

Can you, I ask, be too clever by half? "You absolutely can," he says. "Absolutely. There are a lot of things that can't be fixed by intelligence. You can have fantastic mental discrimination and no moral judgement. You need intelligence coupled with good human radar." And does he have good human radar? "No," he says shortly.

At the end of the interview, we push the cats off our laps and look at some pictures on another wall across the room. The secret to his happiness comes out of a small office to join us and some light ribbing ensues. They talk about the art they are going to buy when their boat comes in. "Which boat?" asks Ignatieff. "Any boat," says Zsohar. She then tells me that the black cat, whose name is Eric and who is a casualty from her "previous life", has taken to Ignatieff very firmly. "Eric loves him. And you, I think, love him back, no? He was not sure at first, but now . . . two gentlemen together. Two portly middle-aged gentlemen in love with each other."

Ignatieff beams, a man in black in a white room. Then he says, apropos of nothing, as if he's just remembered: "I do the lottery. I won a tenner once."

Virtual War, by Michael Ignatieff, is published by Chatto and Windus today, price £12.99

fields.headline: Bodyline and bodily obstruction
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Could you please explain what "Bodyline bowling" means, and when it was banned? asks Emon
fields.body:
Could you please explain what "Bodyline bowling" means, and when it was banned? asks Emon

Bodyline was the term invented to describe the tactics used by England's touring team in Australia in 1932-33. Worried about the prolific batting of Don Bradman, England captain Douglas Jardine instructed his quick bowlers - Harold Larwood, Bill Voce and Bill Bowes - to bowl fast short-pitched bouncers at the batsmen, backed up by several close fielders on the leg side, plus some deeper fieldsmen as well. This meant that almost the only way the batsmen could score was by hooking or pulling, both chancy shots with so many fielders on the leg side and the ball zeroing in on your head. After angry protests by the Australians - and some nasty injuries - the laws were changed to restrict the number of leg-side fielders. Currently you can position only two men behind square on that side of the wicket, which means that hooks and pulls are less likely to be caught.

In a league match last season the umpire insisted on our forward short leg standing up straight rather than crouching down before he would allow the bowler to continue. Is the umpire really allowed to do this? asks Bruce Coker

Law 41.3 says that no part of a fielder's person may extend over the pitch, and Law 42 (Unfair Play) also provides for the umpire to step in if any fielder "incommodes the striker", which might include, for example, a close fielder moving while in the striker's line of sight. But as far as I can see the umpire shouldn't instruct a fielder to stand upright, although he would be within his rights to tell him to keep still. If you want an official ruling you should write to the secretary of MCC (the guardians of the Laws), at Lord's Cricket Ground, London NW8.

Has anyone played football for Scotland and cricket for England? asks Nick Dawes

No-one has played soccer for Scotland and cricket for England, but in the 1890s Gregor MacGregor, the Middlesex wicketkeeper, played eight Tests for England and 13 rugby internationals for Scotland.

When Jonty Rhodes ran out Inzamam-ul-Haq in the 1992 World Cup, did Inzamam have a runner? asks Gavin Michel Singh

All the accounts I can find refer to Inzamam being run out after being sent back, which suggests that he didn't have a runner. Qamar Ahmed, the Pakistan journalist, is also sure that he didn't. The Wisden Almanack reported: "Inzamam, seeking a leg-bye, turned back to see the low-flying Rhodes crashing through the stumps."

This one is a bit of an old chestnut: it's Captain Cook, who skippered the first ship to reach Australia, in 1788.

This meant that almost the only way the batsmen could score was by hooking or pulling, both chancy shots with so many fielders on the leg side and the ball zeroing in on your head. After angry protests by the Australians - and some nasty injuries - the laws were changed to restrict the number of leg-side fielders. Currently you can position only two men behind square on that side of the wicket, which means that hooks and pulls are less likely to be caught. webTitle: The best critical judgment scene: Topsy-Turvy

fields.headline: The best critical judgment scene: Topsy-Turvy
fields.trailText: The morning after the opening night of his and Sullivan's Princess Ida, WS Gilbert (Jim Broadbent) stands in his drawing room scanning the papers. His wife Lucy (Lesley Manville) and staff hover nervously as he reads aloud.
fields.body:
The morning after the opening night of his and Sullivan's Princess Ida, WS Gilbert (Jim Broadbent) stands in his drawing room scanning the papers. His wife Lucy (Lesley Manville) and staff hover nervously as he reads aloud.

"Today's Times. 'Princess Ida will probably run for a year, keeping the Savoy treasury agreeably replete all the while. All of London will probably flock to hear it. So will our provincial and American cousins and continental visitors. Copies of its words and music will be sold by the tens of thousands.'"

Lucy steps forward.

"How splendid, Willy."

"Sugared words, Lucy. Listen."

Gilbert's face reddens as he reads on.

"'Still, I cannot pronounce it to be in any way an improvement on its predecessors. To me, words and music reveal symptoms of fatigue. Arthur Sullivan cannot write in anything other than a pleasing manner, but on more than one occasion, Princess Ida is lacking in the freshness of The Pirates Of Penzance or The Sorceror.'"

He pauses for effect.

"Oh, is it ? 'WS Gilbert abundantly proves he is still the legitimate monarch of the kingdom of Topsy-Turvydom' - thank you very much - 'but his incongruities are more elaborately worked up than usual, and therefore less funny . Moreover, the story is a dull one .'"

He hurls the paper at his butler.

"BURN IT!"

See also: Citizen Kane, The Producers, The Rebel, All About Eve

Don't see also: Dr Terror's House Of Horrors

Pointless trivia: Jim Broadbent played Station Porter in Breaking Glass, the 1980 movie vehicle for singer Hazel O'Connor.

fields.headline: BT must get the message
fields.standfirst: Victor Keegan on why we need to clear the decks for rapid  adoption of broadband communications in the home
fields.trailText: Victor Keegan on why we need to clear the decks for rapid adoption of broadband communications in the home
fields.body:
Why has British Telecom lost the plot? When Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, called last week for a cut in the cost of internet access, BT reacted like a wounded tiger. Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive, issued a strongly worded statement warning him to keep off his patch and not to interfere with BT's private business. He told the chancellor that BT's timetable for opening up the local loop to competition - set for July 2001 - could not be changed without BT's permission.

I've got news for BT. It can. It may have escaped the corporation's notice but it still has a virtual monopoly of the "local loop" - the last mile of wire between the telephone exchange and the domestic consumer. The government still has the right, indeed the duty, to make sure that where monopolies are operating against the public interest, they are opened up to competition. If the government threatened to refer BT's monopoly of the local loop to the monopolies commission then you would see it wake up quickly from its digital slumber.

It has already happened in America. The dismantling of the monolithic Bell telephone system into competing "Baby Bells" is one of the reasons why America's cheap phone calls (flat monthly rental and then unlimited free usage) have led to a huge internet take-up rate. This has had a big knock-on effect on the rest of the economy. The more people use the internet cheaply, the more scope there is for faster expansion of e-commerce, and greater incentive for companies to create products to feed the web's booming population (and then export them). Two crucial infrastructural factors determine the future success of the internet economy.

The first is low cost access (to drive demand and increase online usage times) and the second is broadband access to determine supply (or "content"). They go together. The broader the bandwidth and the cheaper the access, the quicker companies will develop innovative broadband content for the mass market and for specialist applications.

The ability, for instance, to transmit high quality television or film instantaneously over the internet (in two directions) will not only open up a consumer market for films, less popular football matches and so forth, but could also radically change health and education. Poor schools could eavesdrop on better schools, medical operations could be done remotely and the relationship between GPs and patients - and consultants and nurses - could be revolutionised.

BT fails on both counts. Its prices are still far too high in general and if you doubt this, look at the advertisements in the Guardian and elsewhere to see competitors undercutting BT on international calls by up to 90%. The fact that there are even worse examples of monopoly behaviour among other European telephone giants doesn't alter the argument, it merely underscores the size of the problem. Monopolies behave the same everywhere.

The availability of broadband raises the uncomfortable question: what should be done when what is best for the shareholders clashes with what is best for the economy as a whole? If BT regards its role as maximising profits for shareholders then it will want to prolong its monopoly and milk it while it is there. Under pressure from the regulatory body, BT has agreed to open up the local loop to competitors. But it won't happen until July 1, 2001, and then will only be the interim technology ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line).

This offers fast reception of signals but much slower outward transmission (hence the asymmetry). It will be fine for downloading films and for online shopping - but it won't be powerful enough to take film-quality video in two directions. This is where many of the most exciting applications lie (such as high-speed video conferencing). The alternative (already in use on BT's trunk routes) is fibre optics which have almost unlimited two-way transmission capacity. And why July, 2001? Someone should tell BT that its competitors are living in internet time where things happen next week, not next year. If BT really thinks it can't offer ADSL before July next year then the government should start an instant internet auction to see whether any start-ups could do it quicker.

For 15 years BT has been trying to persuade the government to let it wire Britain with broadband capacity. The proviso was that it would need to pump "entertainment" down the channels (meaning video films) in order to make it commercially worthwhile. The government at first refused BT permission to send entertainment down the wires because it didn't want to upset the cable companies who were laying cables around around the country (albeit cherrypicking the most profitable regions) in order to provide competition for BT. If BT had been allowed to wire the country with fibre optics (each strand of which can carry up to four million phone calls simultaneously) on a "common carrier" basis then there would have been no need to dig up the roads for cable in the first place.

When the government eventually started to think about removing the ban on providing entertainment services, BT seemed to cool on the idea of truly broadband access, unlike online nations like Finland and Singapore. Britain now has a golden opportunity to seize the initiative in the race for broadband access. And this will still be very important during the wireless revolution because even cell phone calls are routed through cabled networks.

BT now looks like a giant that is losing its way in the internet world. It has looked on, embarrassed, while Vodafone (market capitalisation £160bn), a company that barely existed when BT (market cap, £63bn) was privatised, has soared ahead of it to become one of the four most valuable companies in the world. Pundits are beginning to refer to BT as a takeover target. The Lex column of the Financial Times has even suggested it should make a takeover bid for Dixons to get its hands on its Freeserve subsidiary, in order to use Freeserve's management to exploit its own customer base.

BT's problem is not of its own making. It arises from the Conservative government's mistake in privatising it, leaving its domestic monopoly intact. It should have been either split between its "common carrier" obligations and its commercial services or broken up on the Bell model. Now it is facing a fresh crisis because its perceived duty to its shareholders clashes with the national interest which demands that affordable - and that means much lower prices than BT is contemplating - broadband internet access be rolled out as quickly as is humanly possible.

There is still time for BT to realise that a cut-price broadband policy would not only be good for the UK economy but actually good for shareholders as well. Why? Because it would convince the increasingly sceptical City that it knew the direction the internet was going. But it must act fast. It is becoming a question of wake up - or break up.

fields.headline: Tony Blair takes his time
fields.standfirst:
Bruges was a landmark. Ghent is not

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: A prime minister cannot make a heavily promoted speech on Europe in Ghent without invoking Mrs Thatcher's speech at the College of Europe just down the canal in Bruges in 1988. Hers was great not in its content, a ragbag out of her handbag, but in its consequences. Bruges forged a political movement and so shaped the Tory party's fate. Ghent, 2000, does not bear comparison.
fields.body:
A prime minister cannot make a heavily promoted speech on Europe in Ghent without invoking Mrs Thatcher's speech at the College of Europe just down the canal in Bruges in 1988. Hers was great not in its content, a ragbag out of her handbag, but in its consequences. Bruges forged a political movement and so shaped the Tory party's fate. Ghent, 2000, does not bear comparison.

Tony Blair delivered what is self-evidently the official message, as parroted daily by Britain in Europe: forget the euro, focus on identifying the Tory party as enemies of European Union. His twist was to exclude the Tories from any association with EU reform. He has good cards to play on making Brussels better and slimming the continent's heavyweight welfare states. Both can, not implausibly, be given a New Labourish colouring, though Mr Blair's lectures can sound insufferably Pecksniffian. So the government seeks to fix on the Tories a mask of such frightfulness that the electoral horse need glance only once before galloping off. That leaves the coast clear for Labour to put off its decision on the euro, hoping things will come right on the night.

We happen to think there is some merit in delay, disappointing as it is to those who like their politics to resound with stern principle and those who seem to think Europe is the central issue in modern British politics. Do they include Mr Blair? In Ghent he talked of "collective failure": the UK's hesitation over Europe was its "greatest miscalculation" since 1945. He cannot mean that, for if he did he would surely be obliged to resolve the euro question by some bold stroke, out-front leadership, barnstorming across the country with or without a bus. He shows no sign of committing that political folly. The price is surely more practicality about EU membership - and fewer visions.

British politicians become implausible when they make visionary speeches, which would sound good in French, which prizes a certain loftiness. Mr Blair is no exception. Ghent may be a necessary exercise in the vocalising of Europe for its elites but someone needs to play to domestic audiences. It is the voters and readers of xenophobic newspapers who must be addressed, persuaded, and, above all, informed. British ministers who go gallivanting in Lisbon need reminding of the ambiguities and deformations of public opinion: how (the evidence says) people become more balanced about UK participation when they engage with fact and argument, how the "nuclear option" of withdrawal commands only superficial support, how ambiguous are British views about the US as an alternative port in the global storm.

The agenda of the inter-governmental conference and the Lisbon summit next month are stupefying in their complexity. Mr Blair said yesterday that Ghent was not the place for a detailed analysis. Perhaps not, but it will not do either for the problems of Poland's and Hungary's accession, reform of decision making and the democratisation of European government to go on being consigned to expert, exclusive groups. The prime minister had some tantalising things to say yesterday about how national legislatures might be better used to unpack and legitimise participation in EU - let us hear more of yesterday's somewhat opaque doctrine of subsidiarity. And "us" cannot just be Belgian assemblies. Bruges struck nerves in the body politic, some of them the nasty, twitching ganglia of nationalism. Mr Blair's liberal vision in Ghent is going to have no easy route into the British public's vitals.

webTitle: Blair can no longer afford to be vague about the euro

fields.headline: Blair can no longer afford to be vague about the euro
fields.standfirst:
It is time to shift the debate on the single currency towards reality

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: There are several reasons why a third of the British people say they'd like this country to leave the European Union. Everything they hear about it is bad. The euro debate is conducted in language of frightening extremism about superstates, and the rest of the phobic rubbish pumped out in grey print or red headlines which long ago stopped dealing in complicated truths. Add German corruption, Austrian fascism, French anti-beefery, Spanish donkey-beating, and it's no wonder the exit option, never hitherto contemplated, has become something to talk about.
fields.body:
There are several reasons why a third of the British people say they'd like this country to leave the European Union. Everything they hear about it is bad. The euro debate is conducted in language of frightening extremism about superstates, and the rest of the phobic rubbish pumped out in grey print or red headlines which long ago stopped dealing in complicated truths. Add German corruption, Austrian fascism, French anti-beefery, Spanish donkey-beating, and it's no wonder the exit option, never hitherto contemplated, has become something to talk about.

But there's another reason. The government's own tactics encourage the conversation. By saying the euro can't be discussed, they make Europe itself the issue. They put the radical question centre stage. Insisting that the British people must first be converted to "Europe", they invite others to say the opposite. Tory MEPs openly advocate getting out. William Hague's front bench contains voices that welcome this new context, and get close to saying the same. The new plausibility of apocalypse makes Hague's own half-way-out extremism seem more acceptable, and ensures that he will never be caught saying a single thing in favour of the European Union.

The government, having unleashed the question, believes it can get the right answer. The tactic confronts people with the existential choice, it thinks, and makes it easier to paint Hague as an exit man. But it is dangerous. It forces ministers to start their case further and further back. It avoids what everyone knows is the point. As time passes, this severance of the euro from "Europe" has to end.

Meanwhile, Mr Blair presses on with his chosen line. His speech in Ghent repudiated all Euro-scepticism. It was of a piece with last week's white paper on enlargement and reform, which was a sweeping statement of pro-Europeanism. One senior official told me he had been trying to write a white paper like that for the last 15 years, only to be repelled by successive Tory foreign secretaries. There's no doubt that, in this prime minister, Britain has her first durable leader with the conviction, power and tenacity to rectify the dismal 50-year history he talked about yesterday.

But his approach, keeping the euro strictly off-limits, is still suspect. It places heavy emphasis on concepts that mean little to the British people, while being gratuitously abrasive to many other Europeans. To talk about economic reform - more liberal trade, flexible working, market-driven business rules, less social protection - may run with the grain, as described in the new issue of Prospect by Michael Maclay, Douglas Hurd's former adviser, who offers a close-textured, if optimistic, picture of the politico-economic convergence, on Anglo not Euro terms, that is quietly going on.

Whether the Blair mission will get anywhere is another matter. At one level it's platitudinous: a call for a pan-European response to global technological change. It is intended to conclude at the Lisbon summit next month with a triumphant endorsement of the Anglo-Saxon approach. Judging by conversations I had in Paris last week, France's collaboration in such a Blairite political triumph cannot be relied on. In any case, even if the other 14 accept some version of the British way to a European economic miracle - and why on earth should they, given the superior economic performance of several of them? - how is this supposed to influence the average British voter to reconsider the anti-euro propaganda with which he has been bombarded daily for years?

Another speech yesterday took a different line. Addressing the Britain-in-Europe council, Kenneth Clarke was startlingly off-message. BiE, under heavy Millbank influence, is supposed to keep away from the euro. That was Blair's condition for supporting it. But Mr Clarke, with his usual directness, said that, as far as he could see, BiE had no other purpose than to prepare the country for the coming referendum on the euro, and proceeded to make some vigorous arguments in favour of the currency.

In so doing, he stayed the right side of premature commitment. Wait and see is still his position, as it is that of the majority of Brits if you look at all closely at the doomy opinion polls. But he showed how a speech could be constructed that did not surrender official hesitation, pending exchange-rate and other convergences, while still making an unashamed case for the benefits a successful euro would bring to Britain. He took the heat out of the wilder predictions, ridiculously spun by BiE staffers, about job-losses that would follow permanent exclusion. The picture he put forward was of incremental rather than seismic damage: a slow waning of investment, a gradual thinning of prosperity, an ineluctable retreat to the political and economic margins, once it became clear that the pound was going to remain at the mercy of the dollar, yen and euro, and that Britain was opting out of the forum that set the rules for the single market.

This will be the terrain of the referendum, if and when it is held. The armies of Euro-scepticism already march across it with all guns blazing. The other side, so far, has not only run away from battle but proclaimed the virtue of doing so. Yet Mr Blair's grand assertions of Britain's sincere European-ness make no sense unless they contemplate the necessity to fight and win the existential contest.

I now believe the internal argument about how to do this, rather than being put off until after the election, is active. Contrary to earlier indications, the present nervous silence of ministers could yet be broken. Two weeks ago there was apparently a meeting between messrs Blair, Brown, Cook and Byers to discuss the euro, which made the unanimous decision to aim for a referendum early in the next parliament after all, and to tailor political strategy accordingly.

The critical issue is whether and when this becomes a public commitment. Gordon Brown didn't do it in New York on Tuesday, though he did scotch the rumour that the next stage of euro-changeover planning had been abandoned. The words to look for most keenly in future speeches - maybe starting with Robin Cook on Monday - are those that re-commit, other things being equal, to an early referendum, the original promise which has been waning for the last several months.

This would spike the hopes of the other side, which thinks it has intimidated Blair to do the opposite. But it would also restore debate to a realistic plane. Once the referendum pledge is re-made, the euro will have to start being restored, Clarke-like, to the centre of discussion. That's the case people need to hear, the choice for which there is no substitute. Talk of exit is an indulgence, a fatuity, a diversion that phobes feel comfortable playing with. It's a proxy for the real thing, which the government should no longer be so faint-hearted as to legitimise.

webTitle: Clarke hits out at Blair's EU timidity

fields.headline: Clarke hits out at Blair's EU timidity
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Kenneth Clarke yesterday launched a powerful attack on Tony Blair's handling of Europe, claiming that the prime minister's failure to speak up in favour of the European single currency was threatening to turn Britain into a "second-rate" country.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and  Ian Black  in Ghent
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke yesterday launched a powerful attack on Tony Blair's handling of Europe, claiming that the prime minister's failure to speak up in favour of the European single currency was threatening to turn Britain into a "second-rate" country.

In an intervention that upstaged a pro-European speech by Mr Blair in Ghent, Belgium, the former Tory chancellor said that the government's timidity had allowed "way-out" Eurosceptics to dominate the debate.

His remarks underlined the growing frustration of the Tory pro-European heavyweights who signed up to the cross-party Britain in Europe campaign with Mr Blair last year, only to find that the prime minister can barely bring himself to mention the euro.

Within hours of Mr Clarke's speech in London to the BiE's governing body of politicians, trade unionists and business people, his criticisms were borne out when Mr Blair devoted just one paragraph to the euro in his Ghent speech. "Our position on the euro... will remain exactly where it is," the prime minister said as he trotted out the government's familiar position. "In principle we are in favour of joining a successful single currency. In practice we have to get the economic conditions right."

His cautious remarks contrasted sharply with those of Mr Clarke, who said that pro-Europeans should be prepared to stand up and argue the case for joining the euro. "Being indecisive about the single currency for too long could lead to a situation where Britain goes down the league table again compared with the most dynamic countries in the world," Mr Clarke said.

Britain would end up "taking our chances on the rollercoaster" if it opted for the instability of the pound rather than the stability of the euro. "So long as we remain in the waiting room we have diminished our influence in the union," Mr Clarke said.

Across the Channel, Mr Blair delivered his most combative speech on Europe, insisting that the argument in favour of the European Union had not been lost in Britain.

Downing Street hopes that by speaking up in favour of the EU in general terms and sidestepping the euro, Mr Blair will slowly swing public opinion behind Europe. Only then can ministers be more explicit about the single currency.

In an address to an invited audience in Ghent's medieval town hall, Mr Blair praised the EU as one of the outstanding political achievements of the 20th century. "The project has succeeded brilliantly," he said. "It has turned the age-old rivalry between France and Germany into friendship and partnership [and] has provided the framework for Europe's prosperity."

He sought to counter the Eurosceptics, who portray themselves as the only true patriots, by saying that Britain has been at the heart of Europe throughout its history. "No king of England if not king of France," he said, quoting Shakespeare's Henry V to underline his point.

However, he admitted that Britain's "ambivalent or indifferent" relations with Europe during the last 50 years had been damaging. "Britain's hesitation over Europe was one of my country's greatest miscalculations of the post-war years," he said.

He contrasted his own views with Margaret Thatcher's famous speech in nearby Bruges in 1988, in which she famously evoked the spectre of a "European super-state".

"My disagreement with Mrs Thatcher's speech is not that its criticisms were all unjustified," he said. "It's that the response to the criticisms was that Britain should withdraw into its shell and opt out. From it stemmed the isolationist and hostile view of the European Union that.. began the opt-out mentality that characterised Britain's relations with Europe for almost a decade."

Mr Blair's speech was designed to coincide with a new campaign by Britain in Europe, which warns that Euroscepticism could severely damage the British economy. But some of the group's supporters were angered after BiE appeared to distort the findings of an independent report to claim that 8m people would lose their jobs if Britain withdrew from the EU.

Mr Clarke launched a thinly veiled attack on BiE when he said it was guilty of issuing "highly unlikely figures".

1993
April 22: Stephen Lawrence murdered in Eltham, south- east London.

July 29: CPS drops murder charges.
fields.body:
1993
April 22: Stephen Lawrence murdered in Eltham, south- east London.
May 7: Neil and Jamie Acourt and Gary Dobson arrested.
June 3: Luke Knight arrested.
June 23: Knight charged with murder.
July 29: CPS drops murder charges.

1994
August: Police launch second investigation under a new senior officer.

1995
April 22: Mr and Mrs Lawrence kick off private prosecution at Greenwich magistrates court.
August 29: Dobson charged with murder.
September 11: Knight and Neil Acourt sent for trial. Dobson follows on December 6.

1996
April 16: Trial at Old Bailey begins.
April 24: Trial collapses.after judge rules that identification evidence of Duwayne Brooks is inadmissable.

1997
August 1: Jack Straw announces a full public inquiry.

1998
March 24: Public inquiry opens in south London.
November 13: Inquiry ends after sittings in Manchester, Birmingham, Bradford and Bristol.

1999
February 24: Macpherson report published.

webTitle: People linked by an urban tragedy

fields.headline: People linked by an urban tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Lawrence: special report
Special report one year on from Macpherson
Full table of results
The Stephen Lawrence Family Campaign
fields.trailText: The key figures in the Stephen Lawrence tragedy became household names. This is how they have fared in the promised new era of race relations.
fields.body:
The key figures in the Stephen Lawrence tragedy became household names. This is how they have fared in the promised new era of race relations.

Neville Lawrence
Stephen Lawrence's father serves on Jack Straw's race steering group and is part of the police's protected witness scheme.

Last Christmas he was stopped by police and questioned about a robbery while driving in north-west London.

The incident has led to a formal complaint and an investigation is under way.

In the last year he and Doreen Lawrence have divorced. Neville has talked about the hurt of his marriage failing, and the continued pain caused by the failure to bring his son's killers to justice.

He and Doreen are locked in a battle for compensation from the Met, as well as suing the five prime suspects for the murder for damages.

Imran Khan
Khan was the solicitor for Stephen's parents and for his work won awards cementing his reputation as one of Britain's leading radical lawyers.

A partner in an east London law firm, he has also become involved in two high profile race cases of the post-Lawrence era.

He is representing the widow of Jason McGowan, one of two black men found hanging in Telford, Shropshire, in circumstances his family say are suspicious. He is also representing the young Asian student who was racially attacked by a white gang alleged to involve two Leeds United footballers.

Duwayne Brooks
He was with Stephen when he was murdered and is recovering slowly from post traumatic stress disorder.

Mr Brooks is suing the Met over the way they failed to treat him as a surviving victim of the attack that killed his friend. The force is trying to have his claim thrown out of court.

Mr Brooks is facing a charge of indecent assault at the Old Bailey next month.

Michael Mansfield QC
The radical barrister was lead counsel for the Lawrences and his forensic cross examination of officers elicited answers that embarrassed the force.

He represented the family of Ricky Reel at his inquest, where the jury sided with the family in returning an open verdict, rejecting the police's account that the Asian teenager's death was accidental. More recently he represented the family of IRA man Diarmuid O'Neill at the inquest into his killing.

He is also a leading and founding member of the national civil rights movement, set up in the wake of the Macpherson report to campaign for racial justice

Ros Howells
The veteran community activist from south-east London served as an adviser to the Lawrence's campaign.

Mrs Howells, 68, played a part in smoothing relations between Mr and Mrs Lawrence and the home secretary. Last June she was ennobled and became one of 22 new Labour working peers.

Sir Paul Condon
The former commissioner of the Metropolitan police clung to his job despite calls for him to quit.

His term as Britain's most senior police officer ended last month, with the Lawrence inquiry findings casting a cloud over his reforms of the force.

From his Kent home Condon, who jealously guards his family's privacy, is pondering his future. His replacement as commissioner was Sir John Stevens.

DI Ben Bullock
Second in charge of the flawed first murder investigation into Stephen's death, Bullock was the only officer to face disciplinary charges.

At the hearing Mr Bullock, 50, was found guilty of mishandling two minor elements and received a caution for neglect of duty.

He has now retired from the force on medical grounds after being diagnosed as suffering from stress.

Deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve
Turned down the job of deputy chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary to head Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force.

Asian and black community activists say that his personal style has been vital to what improvement in relations there has been in the past year.

His unit secured murder convictions against the killers of Michael Menson, found burning in the street, after police initially concluded the musician had tried to commit suicide.

Working relations with Sir John Stevens are not good, but it is thought that his loss would seriously undermine the Met's efforts to boost its performance and image on race.

Sir William Macpherson
The author of the report that shook up race relations has watched with dismay as his findings have been attacked for demoralising the Met's officers after he found the force guilty of institutional racism.

From his home, Newton Castle in Scotland, he kept his counsel for most of the year.

But last week he told the Guardian of his anger at personal attacks and that the Met had to buckle down and eliminate discrimination.

Macpherson, a clan chief, has returned to the retirement he came out of to chair the inquiry.

Bishop John Sentamu
The only black member of the panel of inquiry, Sentamu is the Bishop of Stepney in east London.

The issue of race and police came back to affect him last month when it was revealed that he had been stopped and questioned while driving near St Paul's cathedral.

The five suspects and Clifford Norris
All five suspects are believed to be at the centre of the continuing police investigation into the murder.

After one television interview, they have tried to keep a low profile.

But David Norris and Jamie Acourt were in court last May, and admitted stealing 32 boxes of empty soda syphons and were fined.

The remaining three suspects Neil Acourt, Luke Knight and Gary Dobson have kept out of trouble.

Clifford Norris, the gangster father of David, is in jail after being sentenced to nine years in prison in 1996 for drugs and firearms offences.

Customs and excise have won an appeal allowing them to seize the Norris's luxury £600,000 house in Chislehurst, Kent, after a confiscation order for £386,000 worth of proceeds from his drug deals.

His brother, Alexander, has been released from his jail term.

webTitle: Yard unit at sharp end of war against racism

fields.headline: Yard unit at sharp end of war against racism
fields.standfirst:
Policing Community-based teams fight to restore Met's credibility

Special report one year on from Macpherson
Full table of results
fields.trailText: Policing Community-based teams fight to restore Met's credibility
fields.body:
Detective Sergeant Matt Robins is in a bit of a mood. He is clutching a mug of instant coffee as if his career depends on it and grumbles that an 18-year-old friend with half his qualifications has just been offered a job as a salesman on a comparable salary (not including commission) with a company car.

Robins, 33, an officer for 10 years, did not join the Metropolitan police to make money, but it has been frantic and he feels entitled to a mid-morning moan over a piece of chocolate cake.

On the day of the Guardian visit he is in south London in charge of the community safety unit at Brixton police station, one of 32 set up across London 12 months ago as part of a strategy to change the way the Met tackles race and hate crime.

Few people outside the force have heard of CSUs, yet they are pivotal to the way London is being policed.

In 10 weeks since November 29 this CSU has been asked to assess and review 1,057 cases in Lambeth. The workload, Robins explains, is huge and varied; an Asian man slashed across the neck near Kennington tube station in what seemed to be an unprovoked attack, but is more likely to have been a bungled robbery; reports of Kosovan/Albanian refugees terrorising black youths; a gay couple who woke to find they had been burgled by thieves who had daubed "poof" and "batty licker" on the living room wall; a man attacked on Clapham Common who does not want his wife to know why he was "cruising" there.

"And that's just the hate crime," says Robins. "Ninety per cent of the cases that come to us are DVs [domestic violence]." To Robins, sifting through hundreds of reports in the cramped second floor office with his small team of predominantly white sergeants, detective constables and police constables might not seem like the sharp end of 21st century crime fighting, but this is where Sir William Macpherson believes the fight for the Met's credibility with ethnic minorities will be won or lost.

The CSUs are satellites in an empire being built by Scotland Yard's racial and violent crimes task force.

As well as domestic violence, they are referred reports on crimes that have been flagged as having possible racial, homophobic or anti-semitic motivation. They are building up databases and using techniques like covert videoing, to secure prosecutions. This CSU is linked to community groups, another confidence builder deemed essential if the wounds exposed by the Macpherson report are to be healed.

Robins's unit is experiencing growing pains. The CSU is dealing with 30% of all crimes in the area, but has only 21 officers. The workload is massive because uniformed officers, anxious not to ignore potential hate crimes, refer everything to the CSU rather filter the genuine cases.

"We have to deal with a lot of road rages and neighbour disputes," says Robins.

He says these incidents should not be excluded but pleaded for extra staff to cope. "Despite what people might think, we don't have van loads of racists armed with baseball bats beating up black and Asian people. We do have vulnerable communities that need protecting."

Recruiting the right calibre of officers for the CSUs is also problematic. There is a lot of pastoral work, and those who have moved from, for example, macho murder squads, have floundered.

Acting DS Steve Williams gave up "kicking down doors" to join a CSU. "It was extremely hard. There were occasions when I could see what the problem was, but there was nothing I could do. You have to learn to deal with people in a different way."

Williams, 28, is one of the young officers liaising with CSUs from the task force's higgledy-piggledy first floor office at New Scotland Yard. In a year in which the Met has had precious little to shout about, the task force achieved a notable success - the conviction of the men who murdered the black musician Michael Menson. And it is also working slowly, patiently, to conclude the most lamentable episode in the force's recent history. The unit cannot bring back Stephen Lawrence, but there is expectation that the people who killed him can be taken to court.

The high profile investigations represent, however, a small fraction of the task force's work. It has been charged with overhauling the force's conduct towards relatives of victims, an area which makes up 20% of Macpherson's report.

Next month some of the Met's hardest-nosed officers will be spirited away for a week's training at Hendon to "road test" a new family liaison training regime.

The course will be the blue-print for a Met-wide programme to be introduced this summer.

Developing lay advisory involvement is another contentious area - the 35-members of the original panel suspended their work last November claiming they were being sidelined and ignored, but the show was put back on the road after a weekend's peace talks in Bournemouth.

The task force has probably the most sophisticated intelligence gathering and assessment system of any unit outside M15, but it means little without work on the ground.

Acting DS Paul Charlton is a young black officer working at the unit. He is Duwayne Brooks's family liaison officer and is heavily involved in CO24's effort to root out racists at football matches.

On the tube going to an evening community meeting in Lewisham, south-east London, he says he thinks that the Met is moving in the right direction.

Like the rest of the staff, he has faith in 'JG' - John Grieve, the deputy assistant commissioner in charge of the task force. The extent of "the problem" of racism outside the force is greater than inside, he says.

At the town hall the 30-strong audience is made up almost entirely of police officers.

Lewisham's borough commander, Mike Humphrey, describes how a football supporter was arrested for chanting racist abuse during home games at Millwall.

He is filmed shouting over and again "cut the black cunt, kill the black cunt, cut the coon".

The people around him, including children, are laughing.
