fields.headline: The response so far
fields.standfirst:
An edited version of the home office's summary of progress on the 70 recommendations of the Lawrence report

Special report one year on from Macpherson
Full table of results
fields.trailText: An edited version of the home office's summary of progress on the 70 recommendations of the Lawrence report
fields.body:
1-2: That a ministerial priority be established for all police services to increase trust and confidence in policing among minority ethnic communities.

Action taken: The home secretary announced in June 1999 that increasing trust and confidence in the police force would be a ministerial priority.

Four performance indicators to judge the police by have been put in place using existing information, including recorded racist incidents, recruitment, retention and progression of ethnic minority staff, and the use of stop and search and its impact on different ethnic groups.

3-5 and 8: Inspectorate of constabulary to be given powers to inspect the Met and other forces with standards similar to Ofsted, as well as recruiting and using lay inspectors.

Action taken: Report of Met inspection published last month, reviewing community and race relations strategy. New model for inspections by April, and it is hoped two full time inspectors specialising in race and diversity will be in post by April 1.

7: Functions and powers of the Metropolitan police authority should be the same as other police services, including the power to appoint all chief officers, while membership of all police authorities should reflect ethnic mix of communities.

Action taken: From July the MPA will have similar powers to police authorities outside London, with the power to appoint up to the level of assistant commissioner. The commissioner and deputy commissioner will remain royal appointments. The ethnic breakdown of the membership of police authorities was published in July last year, showing 6.6% of members are from ethnic minority groups. Selection panel for MPA established; advertisements produced for vacancies.

9: A freedom of information act should apply to all areas of policing, subject to the "substantial harm" test for withholding disclosure.

Action taken: The FOI bill, published in November, covers all aspects of policing with two exceptions - information relating to informers and information held for purposes of investigation or prosecution. These can be overridden where disclosure is deemed in the public interest.

10: Investigating officers' reports resulting from public complaints should not attract public interest immunity and should be disclosed to complainants subject to "substantial harm" test.

Action taken: Consultation on new procedures has begun.

11: Race relations legislation should apply to all police officers.

Action taken: Government has said all public services are to be brought within scope of race relations act. Bill published and committee stage completed.

12-17: A racist incident should be any incident perceived to be so by the victim or any other person. Includes crimes and non crimes, which must be investigated with equal commitment. Reporting of racist incidents should be encouraged, and information shared by police, local government, housing and education agencies.

Action taken: Police, CPS, home office and other agencies have adopted the inquiry's definition of a racist incident. Racist incidents standing committee is working on a code of practice.

18-19: Acpo should review good practice guide for police response to racial incidents and should consider producing a manual for investigation.

Action taken: Text has been agreed subject to amendments.

20-22: Metropolitan police service should review procedures at scenes of incidents and procedures for recording and retaining information.

Action taken: Immediate review of Met scenes of incidents procedures and new logging procedures in place.

23-28: Family liaison officers should be available at local level, must be trained in racial awareness and cultural diversity. Investigating officers should know the importance of family liaison and informing victims families about the crime and investigation. Requests or complaints by families should be reported to a senior officer.

Action taken: Acpo is reviewing family liaison to develop it as a specialism. Training courses have been set up in 12 forces to standardise and implement changes.

29-31 and 44: Police and home office should develop guidelines on handling victims and witnesses, with training and witness liaison officers. Local minority ethnic contacts used to assist handling and interviewing sensitive witnesses. Bail conditions imposed to prevent victim and witness intimidation.

Action taken: Legislation on vulnerable and intimidated witnesses passed. Victim support working party reported and changes are to be introduced.

32-34: CPS to ensure racial motivation for crime should be addressed both when deciding to prosecute and at court. No plea bargaining in racial crimes.

Action taken: Claimed recommendations implemented.

35-37: CPS to ensure victims and or families consulted and informed personally with speed and sensitivity of any proposal to discontinue proceedings.

Action taken: Claim already being done. The decision to discontinue should be fully recorded and disclosable to victim and family save in exceptional circumstances.

38: Consider giving court of appeal power to permit prosecution after acquittal when viable fresh evidence is presented.

Action taken: Home affairs select committee currently reviewing "double jeopardy".

39: Consideration be given to amendment to allow prosecution where offences involve racist language and behaviour, and of offences involving possession of offensive weapons, that can be proved to have taken place in a non-public place.

No action.

40-41: Consideration to be given to allowing victims or victims' families to become civil parties to criminal proceedings, and to ensuring they receive all relevant information.

Still under discussion.

42-43: Evidence and documents should be disclosed in advance to interested parties at an inquest and legal aid should cover costs of victims and their families.

Action taken: Disclosure accepted in relation to deaths in custody while costs provided in exceptional cases.

45-47: First aid training for public contact officers to be revised.

Action taken: Working group has made recommendations.

48-54: Immediate review of racism awareness in police force, including training for all staff. Ethnic communities should be involved.

Action taken: Beginning last April a 3-year programme to deliver training to national standards has been set up by national police training. To date 14 force-based projects have been established.

55-57: Changes to police disciplinary and complaints procedures should be implemented and monitored. Disciplinary action should be available for at least 5 years after retirement. Racist words or acts should lead to disciplinary action.

Action taken: New procedures since last April; the home office is reviewing sanctions after retirement, while racist language and behaviour is now breach of police code of conduct.

58: Home secretary to consider steps to be taken to ensure serious complaints against officers are independently investigated.

Action taken: Feasibility study in progress.

59: Home office to review and monitor promotion for officers.

Action taken: Targets set for inspector to Acpo rank and selection for the senior command course.

60-63: Stop and search powers to remain unchanged but records, available to the person stopped, must be kept. Records to be monitored, and published.

Action taken: Pilot sites set up in four areas.

64-66: Targets for recruitment, progression and retention of ethnic staff, with reports sent to home secretary and published.

Action taken: Targets set last April. Home office strategy document produced.

67-69: Consider ation of amendment to national curriculum aimed at valuing cultural diversity and preventing racism, with schools recording all racist incidents, to be published.

Action taken: Statutory study for citizenship for all 11-16 year olds from September 2002, covering national, regional, religious and ethnic identities. All schools required to have anti-bullying policies in place.

70: Implement local initiatives aimed at promoting cultural diversity and addressing racism.

Action taken: Home secretary has written to all local partnerships to highlight issue.

The Stephen Lawrence Family Campaign
fields.trailText: In an exclusive interview on the first anniversary of the Macpherson report, Doreen Lawrence tells  Vikram Dodd  of the pain of living without her murdered son, Stephen, and of her anger with police and politicians.
fields.body:
In an exclusive interview on the first anniversary of the Macpherson report, Doreen Lawrence tells Vikram Dodd of the pain of living without her murdered son, Stephen, and of her anger with police and politicians.

The healing qualities of time have failed Doreen Lawrence. One year on from the report into Stephen's death, seven years on from her son's murder, that tragedy and the fight for justice exact a toll that threatens to overwhelm her.

Mrs Lawrence gave a candid insight into the turmoil she faces because of racism - the murderous racism of a white gang, and the institutional racism of those supposed to catch them.

While racism for some may be hard to define, for Mrs Lawrence its effects are something she lives with every day, manifested by something as simple as watching television.

"I think about Stephen all the time. If you're watching TV and you see a child at a certain age, you think about what Stephen was doing at that age.

"With my emotions I can't watch anything to do with sadness. Seeing someone else's pain brings my own to the forefront."

Mrs Lawrence is menaced by so much in the life she has found herself having to lead. The pain from the betrayal by the police, the knowledge that Stephen's killers are still free, and the implosion of her marriage under the strain - all these are pressures enough to fell anyone.

But added to these are the pressures of unwanted fame, the pressure of ensuring her two other children are not suffocated by all going on around them and have room to flourish. And somewhere in that list of demands on her emotional energy, she has to deal with her own lingering pain from the loss of her firstborn child, and the cruelty of memory.

In the past year, that pain has not got any better. "It's like a numbness that's there, and there's nothing you can do to make it any easier. When I think about Stephen, what more can I do to bring some justice for him? I have gone as far as I can go. I don't really know what else to do. Apart from going and arresting those people myself, what can I do? It's as if they're laughing all over again."

Doreen and Neville Lawrence overcame so much to get the truth about their son officially recognised in the Macpherson report. Mrs Lawrence says the lessons were not learned.

She dismisses a home office steering committee on race, on which she sits, as a "talking shop" and believes the police are waiting for the outrage to die down. "I was hoping they would recognise that they've made mistakes and say we live in a society that's multi-cultural and we should police everybody in the same way.

"I don't see anything happening. The police are still very angry about the report and the fact they have to make changes. I feel under attack from the police."

Some officers said Macpherson's findings caused a drop in stop and searches, which led to an increase in street robberies. "That's complete rubbish. They can't just stop and search a person because they're black or drive a flash car."

She believes that Scotland Yard's patronising attitude towards her family has not changed and that it is demonstrated by their refusal to admit that they should pay compensation for their errors. "From Stephen's murder their whole attitude towards us as a family is that we should shut up and take whatever we're given. They don't think anybody should question their attitude or demand anything from them."

A year ago today, everybody was full of promises for Mrs Lawrence. The day the report was released Tony Blair asked to see her and promised support for her family's cause and for racial justice.

"For whatever reason they have fallen short of the promises. There's a funny balance. They want to implement changes but they want to please middle England as well. I don't believe they're getting the balance right."

Mrs Lawrence is trying to perform her own balancing act, fighting for justice for Stephen while keeping life as normal as possible for herself and her children, Stuart and Georgina. "If you're not careful you get sucked into a life where you forget how to live. The fact is that I have two children and the focus is on their future even though the other side of me is still looking for something for Stephen."

Like her lost son, Mrs Lawrence has become an icon. She has come to represent qualities of determination and courage. But she has to cope with an internal battle within herself.

"If I feel something needs to be done and I need to do it then I'll do it. Then another day I'm so lost in my own thoughts that all I can do is manage to function for that day. Sometimes, once I come in on a Friday, I don't leave my home again until the weekend's over to go to work.

"I haven't got the energy for it, I haven't got a sense that I want to go out and meet people, I just want to be in my own little world with my children."

In fighting injustice Mrs Lawrence became a celebrity, a status she finds stressful. Refuge from its demands at times leaves her a recluse in her "own little world" in her house. "I don't have anybody coming up and saying 'Hello are you Mrs Lawrence?' or 'I'm really sorry about your son.' Everybody means well but it's just being reminded all the time. At home I don't have that, I have my own memories of Stephen which I can live with."

Mrs Lawrence says her continued suffering is so severe that it sometimes leaves her in a near catatonic state. "My thing is just to go really quiet. I don't speak to anybody, just shut myself off." That includes from her children.

"Then Georgina will have a go at me, 'You don't talk to me, you don't do this, you don't do that, I might as well not be here.' I can't break out of that, I just can't. What do you say? There's nothing I can say. The next day I'll say I'm sorry.

"The fact that you want to moan and cry out, I can't do that to my children. You're trying to make sure they have some happiness in their lives. If I'm telling them about my own sadness that will make them sad and I don't want to do that to them." She stops for a split second and remembers why: "As a mother I don't want to do that."

The toll of the struggle for justice was a major factor in her divorce from Neville. She felt "alone and unsupported" by him. "I don't think it was inevitable, I suppose I was hoping it would never happen. Stephen happened [his murder] and I felt that I couldn't continue like that. I was alone."

There is an end point to her struggle. "I need to have an end. The end would be somebody being jailed for Stephen's murder." Until then she cannot give up.

On top of all the roles she fulfils, Mrs Lawrence is a student welfare officer and is studying for an MSc in therapeutic counselling, having earned her first degree in humanities.

The values she imparted to Stephen, the importance of education, God and family, are those that in her continuing darkness provide intellectual stimulation and comfort.

"I have a great belief in God and I believe that he has kept me and carried me along. Without having that belief I don't think I could continue."

But to lose a son, to suffer all she has suffered, that must have tested her faith? "Oh yeah, the fact that he allowed my son to be killed and he wasn't there for him."

A second source of strength for her, and of solace amid the maelstrom, is her children. "They provide me with a will to live, a will to continue, a will to know that I have to keep strong for them."

Her voice drops. "I have to keep strong for them."

"With my emotions I can't watch anything to do with sadness. Seeing someone else's pain brings my own to the forefront." Mrs Lawrence is menaced by so much in the life she has found herself having to lead. The pain from the betrayal by the police, the knowledge that Stephen's killers are still free, and the implosion of her marriage under the strain - all these are pressures enough to fell anyone. But added to these are the pressures of unwanted fame, the pressure of ensuring her two other children are not suffocated by all going on around them and have room to flourish. And somewhere in that list of demands on her emotional energy, she has to deal with her own lingering pain from the loss of her firstborn child, and the cruelty of memory. In the past year, that pain has not got any better. "It's like a numbness that's there, and there's nothing you can do to make it any easier. When I think about Stephen, what more can I do to bring some justice for him? I have gone as far as I can go. I don't really know what else to do. Apart from going and arresting those people myself, what can I do? It's as if they're laughing all over again." Doreen and Neville Lawrence overcame so much to get the truth about their son officially recognised in the Macpherson report. Mrs Lawrence says the lessons were not learned. She dismisses a home office steering committee on race, on which she sits, as a "talking shop" and believes the police are waiting for the outrage to die down. "I was hoping they would recognise that they've made mistakes and say we live in a society that's multi-cultural and we should police everybody in the same way. "I don't see anything happening. The police are still very angry about the report and the fact they have to make changes. I feel under attack from the police." Some officers said Macpherson's findings caused a drop in stop and searches, which led to an increase in street robberies. "That's complete rubbish. They can't just stop and search a person because they're black or drive a flash car." She believes that Scotland Yard's patronising attitude towards her family has not changed and that it is demonstrated by their refusal to admit that they should pay compensation for their errors. "From Stephen's murder their whole attitude towards us as a family is that we should shut up and take whatever we're given. They don't think anybody should question their attitude or demand anything from them." A year ago today, everybody was full of promises for Mrs Lawrence. The day the report was released Tony Blair asked to see her and promised support for her family's cause and for racial justice. "For whatever reason they have fallen short of the promises. There's a funny balance. They want to implement changes but they want to please middle England as well. I don't believe they're getting the balance right." Mrs Lawrence is trying to perform her own balancing act, fighting for justice for Stephen while keeping life as normal as possible for herself and her children, Stuart and Georgina. "If you're not careful you get sucked into a life where you forget how to live. The fact is that I have two children and the focus is on their future even though the other side of me is still looking for something for Stephen." Like her lost son, Mrs Lawrence has become an icon. She has come to represent qualities of determination and courage. But she has to cope with an internal battle within herself. "If I feel something needs to be done and I need to do it then I'll do it. Then another day I'm so lost in my own thoughts that all I can do is manage to function for that day. Sometimes, once I come in on a Friday, I don't leave my home again until the weekend's over to go to work. "I haven't got the energy for it, I haven't got a sense that I want to go out and meet people, I just want to be in my own little world with my children." In fighting injustice Mrs Lawrence became a celebrity, a status she finds stressful. Refuge from its demands at times leaves her a recluse in her "own little world" in her house. "I don't have anybody coming up and saying 'Hello are you Mrs Lawrence?' or 'I'm really sorry about your son.' Everybody means well but it's just being reminded all the time. At home I don't have that, I have my own memories of Stephen which I can live with." Mrs Lawrence says her continued suffering is so severe that it sometimes leaves her in a near catatonic state. "My thing is just to go really quiet. I don't speak to anybody, just shut myself off." That includes from her children. "Then Georgina will have a go at me, 'You don't talk to me, you don't do this, you don't do that, I might as well not be here.' I can't break out of that, I just can't. What do you say? There's nothing I can say. The next day I'll say I'm sorry. "The fact that you want to moan and cry out, I can't do that to my children. You're trying to make sure they have some happiness in their lives. If I'm telling them about my own sadness that will make them sad and I don't want to do that to them." She stops for a split second and remembers why: "As a mother I don't want to do that." The toll of the struggle for justice was a major factor in her divorce from Neville. She felt "alone and unsupported" by him. "I don't think it was inevitable, I suppose I was hoping it would never happen. Stephen happened [his murder] and I felt that I couldn't continue like that. I was alone." There is an end point to her struggle. "I need to have an end. The end would be somebody being jailed for Stephen's murder." Until then she cannot give up. On top of all the roles she fulfils, Mrs Lawrence is a student welfare officer and is studying for an MSc in therapeutic counselling, having earned her first degree in humanities. The values she imparted to Stephen, the importance of education, God and family, are those that in her continuing darkness provide intellectual stimulation and comfort. "I have a great belief in God and I believe that he has kept me and carried me along. Without having that belief I don't think I could continue." But to lose a son, to suffer all she has suffered, that must have tested her faith? "Oh yeah, the fact that he allowed my son to be killed and he wasn't there for him." A second source of strength for her, and of solace amid the maelstrom, is her children. "They provide me with a will to live, a will to continue, a will to know that I have to keep strong for them." Her voice drops. "I have to keep strong for them."

webTitle: Mugabe hints he will not run for re-election

fields.headline: Mugabe hints he will not run for re-election
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, reeling from the defeat of his constitutional referendum last week and facing unprecedented pressure from within his party, has apparently decided not to run for re-election when his term expires in 2002.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, reeling from the defeat of his constitutional referendum last week and facing unprecedented pressure from within his party, has apparently decided not to run for re-election when his term expires in 2002.

"I do not want to wait to retire until I am back on all fours, in my second childhood," Mr Mugabe said in a television interview to mark his 76th birthday this week.

"I want to have the energy to write my memoirs and do many things, so there will come a time when it will be appropriate to retire."

He did not state definitively that he will not run for re-election, but this is the closest he has come to doing so. He has been in power since 1980 and, under the Lancaster House constitution, can run for an unlimited number of terms.

Mr Mugabe declared his retirement plans at a meeting of the 220-member central committee of his Zanu-PF party last Friday. The emergency meeting was to plan strategy for the parliamentary election, due in mid-April, after the failure of the government's constitutional referendum.

Mr Mugabe attacked the party leadership for letting him down and being "caught flat-footed" in the referendum campaign. But he was taken aback when several members stood up and criticised him for the referendum's rejection and the party's unpopularity, according to sources present.

Widespread corruption and economic mismanagement by Mr Mugabe's cabinet had caused inflation of 60%, unemployment of 50% and fuel shortages, said Dzikamayi Mavhaire, an MP from Masvingo province, who called on him to resign from the presidency of both the country and the party.

Mr Mavhaire was suspended from party leadership posts two years ago for urging Mr Mugabe to step down. But this time he was backed by other party leaders, including Irene Zindi and Charles Ndlovu. They blamed Mr Mugabe for damaging the party, calling on him to step down and appoint a new cabinet free from the taint of corruption charges.

Mr Mugabe "wriggled", said one source, but refused to say when he would step down. He said a cabinet would be chosen after the new parliament was elected in April, though he had not yet set a poll date.

Mr Mugabe wrestled to keep control of his party by condemning primary elections - in which many of his candidates have been opposed - as a "source of unhealthy ructions". He said "decisive primary election" would no longer determine candidates.

There had been false reports that the president would resign as party head last December, and then again on his birthday. But the increasing challenge he faces from within his party appears to have convinced him not to run again.

The government yesterday went on the offensive against the small independent press. Charges of criminal defamation were pressed against Clive Wilson, publisher of the Sunday newspaper the Standard, its editor, Andrew Moyse, and a reporter, Chengetai Zvauya.

The three were charged with publishing a false report that the draft constitution had been printed in September 1999, long before the public hearing on it was completed.

Last year two Standard employees were illegally detained and, according to convincing evidence, tortured.

webTitle: We have a long way to go, Straw admits

fields.headline: We have a long way to go, Straw admits
fields.standfirst:
Despite an apparently fundamental change in society's attitudes, the drive to combat institutional racism has faltered

Special report one year on from Macpherson
Full table of results
Stephen Lawrence: special report
The Stephen Lawrence Family Campaign
fields.trailText: The momentum behind Jack Straw's pledge to combat institutional racism in Britain has faltered in the past 12 months but the home secretary says he is still confident that the Lawrence inquiry report will yet prove a watershed in attitudes to racism in Britain.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Nick Hopkins  and Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
The momentum behind Jack Straw's pledge to combat institutional racism in Britain has faltered in the past 12 months but the home secretary says he is still confident that the Lawrence inquiry report will yet prove a watershed in attitudes to racism in Britain.

He is coming under increasing pressure to step up the pace of change not only within the police but across the whole of the public sector

After riding out a barely concealed anti-Macpherson backlash from some police officers, the accusation that the home secretary now most commonly faces on race is that things are not changing fast enough. As Hugh Harris, acting chairman of the commission for racial equality, put it: "Some impressive steps have been taken, but only by a limited number of organisations. The message of the Lawrence report was that everyone needs to accept the urgency of change and take responsibility for seeing that it happens."

Mr Straw acknowledged this yesterday: "We have a long way to go. Changing policies can be done on paper but changing attitudes is much more difficult," he said. He said he was very conscious that the Scarman inquiry report into the inner city riots in the early 1980s had also been published "on a fair wind" but then progress fell away. "I am very anxious the Lawrence inquiry report is followed through by action."

But in the background there are complaints that other government policies such as on asylum are unleashing a new wave of racist rhetoric in parts of the media which may be indirectly fanning an increase in racist attacks.

Mr Straw admitted yesterday that only the "easy side" of the 70 recommendations in the Macpherson report into the black teenager's murder had so far been implemented. About half the "action plan" has been put into effect, including race awareness training, new disciplinary powers to weed out racist officers and a clearer definition of what constitutes a racist incident. But other recommendations such as a new ministerial priority to improve the confi dence of ethnic communities in the police and more frequent official inspections of the Metropolitan police are more vague in their outcome.

Other key areas are proving a lot more difficult to act on. Increasing the total number of black and Asian police officers at a time when overall police numbers are falling has not been achieved by a significant number of forces.

The Telford case also raises the question whether the police outside London in mostly white areas have also learned the lessons of the Lawrence inquiry report in their approach to crime which victims or their families believe to be racist.

It has not been a year of steady progress. When the new race relations bill was published race equality campaigners were stunned to find it only dealt with direct acts of discrimination and did not extend to outlawing indirect or institutional racism. The struggle to persuade Mr Straw to extend the bill to cover institutional racism threatened at one point to halt progress on the rest of the programme.

The battle over the use of "stop and search" powers in London, which was indicative of a backlash among police officers, also undermined the pace of change. Claims by some officers of a link between a rise in muggings in the capital and the fall in routine searching of black youth left a nasty taste.

But there have been more optimistic moments. The disappointment many race equality campaigners felt at Mr Straw's initial reluctance to legislate against institutional racism turned to delight when he announced that the race relations (amendment) bill would cover indirect discrimination and would introduce a positive duty for public bodies to promote race relations.

This week's Guardian/ICM opinion poll also suggested there has been a fundamental change in social attitudes towards racism in the family and at work in the last five years.

Across Whitehall there has been a visible change in culture. In the home office itself an 800-strong network of black and Asian staff working in the immigration system, the prison service, and every other section has been set up. It is being copied in other departments. Recruitment, retention and promotion targets are being set in every department in Whitehall for the employment of minority ethnic staff. Police forces are setting targets that mirror the size of their black and Asian populations while ensuring an significant ethnic presence in forces in mainly white parts of the country.

But even if this is significant progress, it only underlines how much more needs to be done. For example, an unpublished survey of minority ethnic staff in the home office showed that one in three of them said they had faced incidents of racism, bullying or harassment at work in the past 12 months.

While Whitehall is setting equality targets few other organisations have yet moved in the same direction. So far only about 10% of local authorities have a workforce representative of their minority ethnic communities.

Of the outstanding issues from the Macpherson report, it appears unlikely that using racist language in a private place will become a criminal offence. Nor does there appear any rush to scrap the "double jeopardy" rule so that uncon victed defendants can be tried again when new evidence comes to light. Despite the fact that Mr Straw said yesterday he still wanted to see a police complaints system in which the police did not investigate themselves, this still seems a long way off. The home secretary is waiting to see how the new police disciplinary code, which comes into effect in April, works out before making any decisions.

The police response to the Macpherson report - expressed in terms of low morale, lack of confidence and unwillingness to engage - could be seen most strikingly in the extraordinary drop in the number of stop and searches. The then Met commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, warned that the "grieving" for the loss of the force's reputation would result in crime rates soaring. They did.

For the Police Federation, which represents rank and file officers, here was an opportunity to seize the initiative and condemn Macpherson - vilified as a "late flowering liberal" - for going too far. The bar-room analysis was simple and crude. Stop and searches go down. Street crime, particularly muggings, rise.

The answer from the high command at Scotland Yard was to press ahead with refining stop and search techniques at seven pilot sites, and to wait for a piece of research into the subject by Marian FitzGerald, a former home officer adviser. But when Stephen Lawrence's father, Neville, and John Sentamu, the bishop of Stepney and the only black adviser on the Macpherson inquiry team, were both stopped by police, it seemed little had changed.

Ms FitzGerald's study also appeared to offer the Met further support. She said there was a link between the fall in searches and the rise in crime. But her conclusions were discredited by Jeremy Penzer, a London School of Economics statistician, who had analysed the figures for her.

"It is a complete misrepresentation of my findings," he said.

In his first interview as the new Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens said all officers would be given training to ensure stop and searches are conducted politely.

New evidence shows the drop in stop and searches in London seems to be levelling off. The pilot sites are returning healthier figures: arrest rates, it seems, from searches are up from 10% to 18%, and the ratio of black people searched to white is falling from 4.4 to 3.3 to one.

webTitle: Hilton's gamble on the net pays off

fields.headline: Hilton's gamble on the net pays off
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It was no surprise when Hilton, the company formerly known as Ladbrokes, took the plunge and changed its name. It was keen to trade in its old backstreet betting image for the far more glamorous Hilton brand - and hopefully along the way ditch its well deserved reputation as one of the FTSE's most dependable disappointments.
fields.body:
It was no surprise when Hilton, the company formerly known as Ladbrokes, took the plunge and changed its name. It was keen to trade in its old backstreet betting image for the far more glamorous Hilton brand - and hopefully along the way ditch its well deserved reputation as one of the FTSE's most dependable disappointments.

So it is with a measure of amusement that the past few days have seen the company's shares motoring on the back of the betting business, which is now viewed as the jewel in Hilton's crown.

Online betting, it is believed, could lure millions of new, wealthier punters. After all it is not as though the majority of the population does not bet on principle - only 6% may regularly venture inside a betting shop, but 70% have a regular flutter on the lottery.

So since the company announced its £100m investment in internet betting last week, Hilton's perennially underperforming shares have been in relative overdrive, climbing from 160p - their lowest for four years - to 211p. More than £800m has been added to the value of the company.

Today the company announced its full-year results, and profits are expected to be up from £277m to £300m-£320m. But having had a taste of e-business, investors want more - in the shape of information about how the company intends to use the web to boost business in its hotels.

No news will not be good news. At least one analyst - Matthew Naylor at Williams de Broe - believes the shares have already risen further than justified. He points out that cyber-betting services could swiftly become oversupplied and that Hilton is trading at a premium compared with other hotel operators.

The hotel business, meanwhile, is "steady if unspectacular", says Deutsche Bank. Even the Hilton chain's ebullient boss David Michels admits the British Hilton business is "ex-growth".

Long term, the only thing analysts really want to hear - and the only news which will generate a change in the shares - is that Hilton is going to merge with its US namesake and so create a global business. Undoubtedly it will happen, but it could be a long and unprofitable wait.

fields.headline: Amazon.co.uk going mobile
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bookshop browsers who go home to check the prices on Amazon before committing themselves can now save a journey: the internet retailer's UK website will be available on mobile phones from today.
fields.body:
Bookshop browsers who go home to check the prices on Amazon before committing themselves can now save a journey: the internet retailer's UK website will be available on mobile phones from today.

The biggest name in online shopping said yesterday it was launching what it claimed was the first European service that will let customers complete a transaction from their handset without making a voice call.

Owners of Nokia or Motorola mobile internet phones will be able to access Amazon.co.uk anywhere and buy books or CDs by typing in a user name and password. Calls will be charged at data rates, which Amazon said are lower than voice calls.

Although only a handful of gadget lovers are surfing the mobile internet, research quoted by Amazon forecasts 48m people worldwide will own suitable phones by 2002.

fields.headline: Autonomy launches 'killer Wap'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge software company, yesterday announced an intelligent technology which will allow "smart phones" to search the internet for their owner's interests. Intelligent wireless application protocol (i-Wap) will automatically personalise information delivered to mobile phones and palmtops and filter out irrelevant information, chief executive Dr Mike Lynch said.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge software company, yesterday announced an intelligent technology which will allow "smart phones" to search the internet for their owner's interests. Intelligent wireless application protocol (i-Wap) will automatically personalise information delivered to mobile phones and palmtops and filter out irrelevant information, chief executive Dr Mike Lynch said.

"Wap as it is just won't work. Mobile devices don't have the capability to process large amounts of internet content and their speed isn't that great.

webTitle: Open will outdo Freeserve, say experts

fields.headline: Open will outdo Freeserve, say experts
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Open, the interactive television service which launched in October will have "significantly" more users than Freeserve, the country's largest internet service provider, by the end of the year a City investment bank predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
Open, the interactive television service which launched in October will have "significantly" more users than Freeserve, the country's largest internet service provider, by the end of the year a City investment bank predicted yesterday.

Mike Hilton, media analyst at ABN Amro forecast the service could have 3m active users by the close of 2000 suggesting that e-commerce will find a more natural home on the TV than the PC.

The figures were released in a research note on converging media as Open announced three more partners to its service. Electrical goods retailer Comet, travel firm First Choice and insurer Cornhill joined the roster of content providers including Asda, Argos, Carphone Warehouse, Scottish Power and Unilever.

Open, which is owned by BSkyB, British Telecom, banking group HSBC and Japanese electronics business Matsushita, is only available on SkyDigital.

The service claims more than 450,000 people have registered for e-mail services and that in the run-up to Christmas e-commerce revenues were running at up to £1m a week.

Open also announced the launch of an online betting service run by Blue Square. Consumers need to register and prove they are over 18 with the first bets likely to be made on the Grand National in April.

Ladbrokes, another of Open's content providers, also intends to launch an online betting service.

webTitle: Buffett makes a tech stock U-turn

fields.headline: Buffett makes a tech stock U-turn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Warren Buffett, the man often described as the world's best investor, appears to have abandoned his long-held contempt for overvalued technology shares by buying a stake in Microsoft.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett, the man often described as the world's best investor, appears to have abandoned his long-held contempt for overvalued technology shares by buying a stake in Microsoft.

The latest move by Mr Buffett's company, Berkshire Hathaway, follows his repeated warnings that technology shares were overvalued and that he did not understand them. It also comes after a patch of poor performance by the firm.

Mr Buffett had wanted to keep the purchase of 167,500 Microsoft shares a secret for up to a year but the US securities and exchange commission rejected the request for secrecy and Berkshire reported its purchase late on Tuesday.

Some analysts suggested that the tentative purchase, worth about $167m (£104m) at the end of September, could reflect Mr Buffett's personal relationship with Microsoft's co-founder Bill Gates as much as a conversion to the world of technology. Mr Buffett has been described as a mentor and good friend of Mr Gates and the pair are known to play online bridge together.

A Berkshire official refused to discuss the purchase yesterday. Previously, the company has bought a stake in First Data Corporation, which processes payments for e-commerce companies.

The surprise in the Microsoft stake is that Berkshire typically buys stakes in undervalued groups and holds them for a long period of time.

Berkshire has attracted an almost cult-like following with its adherence to stocks Mr Buffett can understand. However, many of these stocks, including companies such as Coca-Cola and Gillette, have underperformed the market in the past year as technology shares have raced ahead.

Shares in Berkshire fell almost 4% on Tuesday before rebounding slightly yesterday morning. The company, which has enjoyed compound annual returns of about 25% in the past 35 years, has seen its premium rating fall in the past year.

The company has publicly denied that the 69-year-old Mr Buffett wants to retire. Under SEC rules, investment funds with more than $100m in assets under management have 45 days from the end of each quarter to disclose changes to the firm's holdings.

webTitle: Things that go bug in the FT site

fields.headline: Things that go bug in the FT site
fields.standfirst:
Relaunch hurts core brand

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Ten days after the relaunch of the Financial Times online offering, the product is so riddled with defects that it should be undermining the share price of the paper's parent, Pearson.
fields.body:
Point your browser and see for yourself. It is FT.completelyuseless. It may be foolhardy for the financial pages of one newspaper to throw stones at the European market leader in the business of financial journalism - especially when the subject is one that all "old media" firms are having trouble cracking. But, 10 days after the relaunch of the Financial Times online offering, the product is so riddled with defects that it should be undermining the share price of the paper's parent, Pearson.

Prickly FT executives admit to "teething problems" with the site but insist they have received a hugely favourable response. But judging by the daily content of FT.com, such a response can only be treated as evidence that there is a hitherto undiscovered market in three-day-old news and computer error screens.

One of the great under-reported facts of the moment is that as we allegedly wing our way to the internet economy, the technology regularly melts down, bringing us back to boring old industrial earth with a bump.

But techno-gripes aside, there are important issues concerning the way Pearson develops its premier brand and protects and grows its market position.

It is said that early last year the FT's chief executive, Stephen Hill, who had clearly "got it" before most of peers, flew into silicon valley and commenced a tour of every big name in the area - from Oracle's Larry Ellison down. He was there to discuss the FT's "big idea" - to create the ultimate global business information internet portal.

The big advice that came back from the valley's girls and boys was that while this was a great idea which the FT was in a real position to deliver upon, it should stick to what it knows best - content. All the technology, Mr Hill was told, should be outsourced.

One or two even put proposals to the FT. Hewlett Packard, for instance, is said to have offered to construct the entire site, maintain it and continue running the infrastructure in return for a small percentage of the e-commerce revenues FT.com was likely to generate.

But the whispered word from Southwark Bridge is that the FT - perhaps keen to protect its editorial independence - turned down all offers, deciding instead to build as much of the site as possible in-house with the help of only a couple of small contractors. A year on, with the home team's effort up and creaking, there are rumours that FT.com will have to be unplugged for a fortnight in order to tackle all the bugs.

Late last month, competing newspaper groups were left looking flat-footed when Pearson placed a big line of new stock at £22 a share, raising £250m to invest in its internet business. Here was a British company with a premier brand using the power of the internet to extend its franchise globally.

That strategy still makes buckets of sense, but it is a long way from FT.completion.

FT.com

Hard sell

Techno-sceptics are pretty thick on the ground just now. But while it is no surprise to find the odd one lurking within the walls of the Bank of England or creeping down the splendid art deco corridors of Unilever House, it is a surprise to see one popping out of Palo Alto, 40 miles south of San Francisco.

This is not a Californian bag man, socially displaced by the local cyber-rich. He is Tom Perkins, the man who almost singlehandedly funded the whole party in the first place.

Mr Perkins is one of the founders of Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, the west coat venture capital firm which backed Jim Clark's Netscape when it was just a piece of demonstrations software in Stanford university.

In its 28-year existence Kleiner Perkins has achieved an internal rate of return of 37% a year on its investments. Over the past five years the annual rate has been running at 204%, and over the past three years the figures come out at a jaw-dropping 346%.

But according to comments made at an America's Cup dinner in New Zealand over the weekend accompanied by Mr Clark, Mr Perkins reckons the party might be over.

"Can the stock market value of all these companies continue?" he asked. "I don't think it can, I think it's a bubble." He went on to compare the internet boom with all sorts of other proven bubbles - lasers, mini-computers, biotech, and so on.

Mr Perkins's argument is that with such a large part of dot.com spending going on advertising, at the present rate the flow of venture capital will simply run out. "I don't think there's going to be enough money in the pool for all these companies on their second and third trips to the well," he said.

Mr Clark is not so downbeat. "Don't be shy. And go forward," he told his audience, adding that if the country wanted to cash in it should shake off its British heritage. We are too hard-wired into the old economy, apparently.

webTitle: BA invests £100m to boost online operations

fields.headline: BA invests £100m to boost online operations
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday announced a £100m investment over the next two years, as part of its online ventures strategy aimed at reducing the cost of travelling.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday announced a £100m investment over the next two years, as part of its online ventures strategy aimed at reducing the cost of travelling.

The new businesses, grouped together as the airline's eVentures, will include an online travel agency offering customers a one-stop shop for flights, hotels, car hire and other travel services.

The site will be owned by a group of European airlines. It will enable them to offer a consumer travel site, while cutting the cost of selling and distributing tickets. Currently, fewer than 2% of the airline's tickets are sold online. The aim is to increase this to 50% by 2003. Revenue generated online is expected to rise from £45m a year to £700m within two years.

The latest technology will enable customers to find out through the internet, and on the latest mobile phones, whether their flight is leaving on time, to check in online or book car rental and hotel accommodation.

In the second venture, the loyalty programme, Air Miles, wholly owned by BA, will significantly expand its online activities. Air Miles will seek to become Britain's leading e-currency.

BA will also invest in a new "lifestyle" portal designed to meet the e-commerce needs of the airline's core customers. It will be run as a joint venture with an online media company and a technology partner, and will be operational this summer.

Suppliers will also be affected. A new division eProcurement will take advantage of the latest internet-based buying techniques, including auction style tendering.

Bob Ayling, BA's chief executive, said: "Through these eVentures we will look to exploit the best of BA with the best outside partnerships to add value for our shareholders."

fields.headline: Too much for one man
fields.standfirst:
Mr Milburn needs to reshape his new deal

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Frustration at the top of the health service is a familiar disease. A new health secretary arrives full of resolve to improve it, but the vision becomes eroded in face of the size and different interests within Europe's biggest organisation
fields.body:
Frustration at the top of the health service is a familiar disease. A new health secretary arrives full of resolve to improve it, but the vision becomes eroded in face of the size and different interests within Europe's biggest organisation. Four months ago Alan Milburn returned to Richmond House, where he had already served as a junior health minister, intent as the new boss on making the NHS fairer, faster and more responsive to patient needs. But already he is disillusioned at the gap between policy and delivery. He appears exasperated by "the forces of conservatism" in the institution and the hierarchical distance which separates him from the young high-flying managers, doctors and nurses who are introducing innovation and change.

Now he is considering a new approach: a modernisation board which would include the best performing professionals from hospital trusts, primary care groups and health authorities. It would recognise the fact that the NHS is too big to achieve change by top-down management. The new board members would act as missionaries, persuading their less well performing neighbouring hospitals and authorities to change.

The scheme is not as daft as leaks suggest. The NHS national executive would remain, but be stripped of its regional directors and supplemented with public health and social service executives. There would be joint meetings of the new executive and the modernising board. But it raises an enormous number of questions. One gift bestowed on the NHS by the Tories was more respect for managers. A second was an attempt to separate policy from management, although that failed. The new move makes the minister responsible not just for policy, but for implementation and management too. No one can do all this. Contrary to the teachings of Aneurin Bevan, dropped bedpans should be left to nurses. Mr Milburn should offer an early clarification in the Commons.

webTitle: Beds crisis forces NHS surgery delays

fields.headline: Beds crisis forces NHS surgery delays
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: One in three hospitals in England are cancelling operations every day because of a shortage of beds, according to a national audit office report.
fields.body:
One in three hospitals in England are cancelling operations every day because of a shortage of beds, according to a national audit office report.

Sir John Bourn, head of the NAO, reported to parliament a record number of cancelled operations - the highest since 1992 when the patient's charter stated that operations should not be cancelled on the day the patient was expected to arrive in hospital.

In the year to September 1999, nearly 57,000 patients had operations cancelled for non-medical reasons - normally because there was no bed for them - on the day of admission or the day after.

The report highlighted much good practice and urged hospitals in crisis to learn from those that were doing better. But the scenario it painted, of beds full of elderly people who ought to have been moved out of hospital while other patients had operations cancelled that they had waited months for.

Almost all acute hospitals now had bed managers, responsible for filling and emptying beds as efficiently as possible, but they lacked computer systems that could tell them which beds were available. Most hospitals - 92% - relied on someone running around the wards checking on empty spaces.

The report recommended that more patients could be admitted to hospital on the day of their operation, rather than the eve, and suggested that they did not need a bed until they came out of theatre. If 10% more patients went in on the day of the operation, the NAO estimated that 180,000 more bed days a year could be released.

webTitle: Team of outsiders to drive NHS reform

fields.headline: Team of outsiders to drive NHS reform
fields.standfirst:
Health secretary creates 'strategy' unit of academics and doctors prompting Tory accusations of politicising the civil service

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Health secretary Alan Milburn has secretly created a unit of outside professionals to work full time within the department of health and drive forward the Blairite revolution in health care delivery for the NHS - without extra cash.
fields.body:
Health secretary Alan Milburn has secretly created a unit of outside professionals to work full time within the department of health and drive forward the Blairite revolution in health care delivery for the NHS - without extra cash.

In a move which will prompt Conservative charges that Labour is further politicising the civil service, seven leading figures from universities, think tanks and the private sector have agreed to join a new strategy unit. It will work on the same floor as the Milburn ministerial team in Whitehall.

Among the people recruited via discreet public advertisements last autumn - in accordance with civil service rules - are Chris Ham, professor of health policy at Birmingham university and Richard Murray, a health economist from the McKinsey management consultancy.

John van Reenen, a labour market economist, will help reshape the NHS's 900,000-strong labour force. The civil service commission which monitors the neutrality rules for officialdom has approved the new set-up.

"Milburn is the first cabinet minister to set up a strategy unit in his department to bring in outsiders to tackle health strategy and policy. They will bring fresh intellectual drive to help shape the next phase of NHS modernisation over the next five to eight years," said one insider.

The Tory health spokesman, Philip Hammond, complained that "under Labour power is more and more centralised in Whitehall'.'

The move, disclosed to the Guardian last night, came after the health secretary had revealed that 15 doctors, senior nurses and NHS managers are to be invited to join a beefed-up NHS management board in the wake of Sir Alan Langland's resignation this week as the service's chief executive.

Downing Street wants to raise spending to EU levels by 2006 provided the economy can afford it and NHS professionals allow ministers to "modernise" and reform the way they work. If all hospitals can become as efficient as the best, the cash crisis can be resolved, he argues.

The "toe to toe" management revolution which Milburn allies were promoting yesterday will bring managers from different NHS disciplines to the top table at the department as part-time non-executive board members, working with more traditional Whitehall figures, to improve medical performance.

The board would include Mike Richards, the "cancer tsar" and Peter Homa, who runs the new commission for health improvement. The move, leaked yesterday, surprised many Whitehall officials, including the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.

But Mr Milburn's strategy unit breaks further new ground, in line with the cabinet secretary's declared policy of opening up Whitehall to more outsiders.

fields.headline: Small cars become safer
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: A dramatic improvement in the safety of small cars, the size more likely to be driven by women and younger drivers, has been shown in crash test results published today.
fields.body:
A dramatic improvement in the safety of small cars, the size more likely to be driven by women and younger drivers, has been shown in crash test results published today.

But while they showed better protection for occupants in the event of a crash, they found "little progress" on providing pedestrian protection.

The crash tests, using dummies, were the latest in a series in the European new car assessment programme, Euro NCAP, run by the European commission, governments, and motoring clubs. Seven cars were tested: the Fiat Punto, Volkswagen Lupo, MCC (Mercedes) Smart, Hyundai Atoz, Vauxhall Corsa, Honda Logo, and Lancia Ypsilon (not on sale in the UK).

Each got stars for crash survivability, four for the best and one for the poorest. When tested by Euro NCAP in 1997, only two of the seven got three stars for front and side protection of occupants. This time the Punto and Lupo got four and the others three, apart from the Ypsilon's two.

On pedestrian safety, all seven got two stars, an improvement on 1997 when five received one star.

Euro NCAP said the tests showed the risk of chest injuries from impact forces through seatbelts. Restraints did not always protect children from neck and head injury as well as they should, while sometimes the risk to a child in a rear facing restraint opposite an airbag was poorly explained.

fields.headline: Lord Irvine adjourns Paddington inquest
fields.standfirst:
Paddington train crash: special report
Interactive guide to how the trains collided
fields.trailText: The inquest into the deaths of the 31 people killed in the Ladbroke Grove train crash was adjourned yesterday in unprecedented circumstances.
fields.body:
The inquest into the deaths of the 31 people killed in the Ladbroke Grove train crash was adjourned yesterday in unprecedented circumstances.

After hearing evidence on the third day of the hearing at Westminster council chambers, coroner Paul Knapman adjourned the inquest at the request of the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, pending the conclusion of a public inquiry into the accident by Lord Cullen.

Under an amendment to the access to justice act passed in January and being used for the first time, the jury were dismissed without being required to reach a verdict.

The purpose of the inquest was to allow the deaths of the victims to be registered. The lord chancellor is empowered to halt such an inquest at any time, but it was felt in this case that it would be useful for the families to hear details of their relatives' deaths.

Louise Christian, head of the Ladbroke Grove victims solicitors group, said: "It has been good for families to come and hear the circumstances in which their loved ones died, and we're grateful to the coroner for allowing them that opportunity."

She added that Dr Knapman should consider resuming the inquest after the Cullen inquiry had reported: "I believe a number of my clients will want the inquest to resume, particularly if they feel ... a verdict of, for example, unlawful killing would be appropriate."

It is thought unlikely that the inquest will be resumed, although legislation allows the coroner to reconvene the hearing "if he believes there is exceptional reason for doing so."

The legislation, specific to accidents where a public inquiry is due to be convened, was introduced to stop the duplication of evidence heard by inquests and inquiries, and to prevent subsequent delays. Juries are compulsory in rail crash inquests.

The public inquiry into the Southall rail crash of 1997 did not begin taking evidence until two years after the accident. Lord Cullen will begin to hear evidence in May. A criminal investigation by British transport police, Operation Brodie, is also continuing.

Earlier the inquest heard details of the deaths of the final six victims of the crash, which happened shortly after 8.10am on October 5 when a three-carriage Thames train bound for Bedwyn, Wiltshire, from Paddington collided with a First Great Western train travelling in the opposite direction.

It emerged that one of the victims may have survived the collision, and died trapped in the wreckage. A postmortem examination of Allan Stewart, 28, an accountant raised in New Zealand, revealed that he had endured "a period of survival" of between one and 59 minutes following the accident.

The jury also heard details of the death of Fiona Grey, 33, an IT consultant from Dumbarton.

She had started a new job in London just two days before the accident. At the time of the collision Ms Grey was sitting in the front carriage of the Great Western train next to her new boss, with whom she was lodging in Didcot, Oxfordshire.

webTitle: Train guards delay strikes to allow talks

fields.headline: Train guards delay strikes to allow talks
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Train guards yesterday voted for a series of five 24-hour strikes, but will postpone their action for a week pending talks with train operating companies.
fields.body:
Train guards yesterday voted for a series of five 24-hour strikes, but will postpone their action for a week pending talks with train operating companies.

Rail, Maritime and Transport union members voted for action at 16 of the 25 companies. At seven others they voted against. The remaining two companies operate driver-only trains. Guards are protesting against changes to their role.

The strikes were put on hold by the RMT when it received a letter from South West Trains, a subsidiary of Stagecoach, apparently indicating support. Jimmy Knapp, general secretary, said the union could see "the prospect of a considerable breakthrough in our case".

Last year Railtrack, after an official review by the health and safety executive, altered the railway rules to give overall responsibility to the train driver to enhance the safety of passengers and the train "as a whole".

The union claims the "real reason" was to free the guard of his or her responsibilities and allow the job to cover on-board sales "such as tea and biscuits". The RMT believes that the guard is there to guard. It has also been balloting some RMT drivers on strike action, arguing the driver has enough responsibility without adding to it.

Next week's talks will be with Railtrack and the Association of Train Operating Companies, which represents companies such as Virgin, National Express, and Connex; yesterday the association said it welcomed talks and was optimistic of agreeing a deal.

An independent report on the guards' role, commissioned by the rail companies, was said last night to have exposed ambiguities: although the new rule was safer if a train broke down, the old rule was thought safer in the aftermath of a crash.

fields.headline: Why God isn't primetime
fields.standfirst:
Also: Our repulsive nation
The insurance
Anglican ambition

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: For some reason the excellent James Boyle, who recently announced his resignation as head of Radio 4, has never received anything like the recognition he deserves for his courage in regenerating that institution's ancient, seemingly immutable schedule.
fields.body:
For some reason the excellent James Boyle, who recently announced his resignation as head of Radio 4, has never received anything like the recognition he deserves for his courage in regenerating that institution's ancient, seemingly immutable schedule.

Before he hands over to persons unknown, let's hope he receives credit for defying the forces of green ink, saving future generations from the horror of Sport on Four, the Afternoon Shift, Weekending and Breakaway. True, their replacements were not always all that one might have wished, but often there was no contest. One thinks, in particular, of the religious programmes which, until 1998 when Boyle repositioned them, subjected all Radio 4 listeners to compulsory religious instruction.

Long after most schools had jettisoned formal morning worship, R4 was still broadcasting daily prayers, daily services and, on the sabbath, replacing the usual current affairs with a sort of grown-up version of Sunday school. All this when real-life organised worship was freely available daily in churches all over the country.

Even now, after Boyle's removal of Anglican ceremonial to earlier slots and to long wave where they can serve the devout without oppressing Catholics (who form the larger congregation) and non-Christians, BBC radio still behaves as if it were a missionary for the established church, with its daily reminders that we are about to miss the morning service, early morning prayers and the inescapable Thought for the Day. If this occasionally maddens non-believers, it must, at least, endear the BBC to the Church of England, whose dwindling congregations, declining status and internal incoherence hardly seem to merit such public genuflections.

On the contrary. Next Tuesday the General Synod will debate a motion from a private member, Mr Nigel Holmes, calling on the BBC to broadcast more peak time religious programmes and "restore the hours of religious television to the average of the 1980s".

So ferociously do Synod members feel about the BBC's inadequacies, that Holmes's motion has attracted more signatures (226) than any other private members motion for more than 10 years. What can have hurt them so badly? Most of all, to judge by Holmes's report on the subject, it is the moving to an earlier slot of Sunday, on Radio 4, which has reduced the audience by 25%.

Holmes compares this outrage with the eviction to long wave of Yesterday in Parliament. "There is a close parallel between church and state," he avers. "Parliamentary leaders trusted the BBC to fulfil its public service obligations, just as church leaders have for more than three-quarters of a century."

Apart from the glaring objections to his comparison - the church exists to provide spiritual, rather than temporal guidance; it does not, if you discount its little gang of leglislating bishops, govern the country; it is not elected; its internal deliberations are irrelevant to non-members, and so on - Holmes's insinuation of some contractual bond betrayed, is misleading.

The BBC is under no obligation in its charter to supply programmes that satisfy the Anglican church, any more than it has formal duties towards country dwellers, old people or cat lovers. Moreover, three quarters of a century ago, church leaders were distinctly rattled about their disciples in broadcasting. In 1936, the BBC's annual report noted that, "No development has been more marked than the gradual disappearance of the obviously nervous suspicion with which they [church leaders] first regarded the intrusion of 'wireless religion' . . . "

Maybe the C of E should have stayed nervously suspicious instead of getting petulant. Certainly its subsequent conversion to the benefits of pious showbiz, and the subsequent years and years of religious broadcasting, much of it, as requested, at peak time, do not seem to have done much to preserve the number of Sunday worshippers, which last year slumped to fewer than 1m. On the other hand, I suppose, the figures might be even worse without it.

In her thoughtful new book, The C of E, the State It's In, Monica Furlong, a practising member of the church, suggests that it must accept that things are not, as it likes to protest, going swimmingly. "The church," she says plainly, "has suffered a steep decline since the beginning of the 20th century, as well as an immense loss of status and influence. There is no need to dwell on pessimism, doom and gloom, but rather to let ourselves know what we are actually feeling, acknowledge the bewilderment of loss, face it, live through it, as those who suffer from bereavement have to do."

Instead of which, the Anglican church is in denial, talking up its attendance figures, glossing over its marginalisation, self-importantly pronouncing on everything from sex education to GM foods, insisting that it must having the starring role in something as dim as the dome or as spiritually irrelevant as the BBC schedules. What sort of religion needs "peak time" slots in order to feel good about itself? Besides, if the church persists in its claims, it must at some point allow other religions, and supersitions equivalent broadcasting privileges. There are now more practising Roman Catholics in this country than active Anglicans: should this not be reflected on the BBC? When it comes to that, belief in aliens is now more widespread among young people, than belief in God. Maybe they should invite one on Thought for the Day.

The best thing the Anglican church could do, if it wants to retain its role as the BBC's premier religion, is keep quiet. As all the fuss around the wretched dome ceremonies showed last year, the more it insists on its right to prominence, the more it accentuates the flimsiness of its claims, and draws attention to its rivals.

Pressed to offer more programming, the religious affairs department has now come up with such highlights as Emma Freud on religion and sex and a series called the Soul of Britain, investigating the country's "spiritual free market". The programmes are probably not what the Synod is hoping for: Nigel Holmes, at least, fears that the Rev. Ernest Rea, the BBC's head of religious broadcasting, is "disposing of the principles behind public service religious broadcasting, which have not been ashamed to recognise the importance, both past and present, of the Christian faith in this country". But as Rea points out, the largest group of believers in Britain is labelled "vague faith". It is not the BBC's job to convert them.

Bloody English

A quotation from Tennyson about Irish people last week has inspired some crushing correspondence, some of it suggesting that such casual slurs would never have appeared, had they concerned another nationality. Whether or not this is true - I've always considered the Belgians a fairly safe bet - it seems only fair to even the balance. Here, then, are a few comments by non-English litterateurs, on the failings of our island race. Prosper Merimée's comment that "Everything that can be done with money, good sense and patience they do, but of the arts they have no more idea than my cat," can hardly be disputed, while Heine's broader generalisation, "What a repulsive nation, what a disagreeable country! How strait-laced, how commonplace, how egotistical, wie eng, wie englisch," seems equally apt. My favourite, however, is this, from Dostoevsky's Summer Impressions, 1863: "Everyone is drunk, but drunk joylessly, gloomily and helplessly . . ." Plus ça change. . .

Insurance scam

The possible merger of the Norwich Union and the CGU, has yet to attract more than passing sympathy for the 5,000 people whose jobs and livelihoods are threatened. I'm sure this indifference will be shortlived. It can only be a matter of time, before public figures who have been agitating for government aid for impoverished farmers, turn their attention to the to insurance men and women of Norwich - many of whom, no doubt, come from generations of insurance men and have known no other way of life. All they need, to move hearts and minds, is some symbol of insurance as picturesque as an unwanted baby calf or worthless sheep.

Shocking stuff

The fear of comfy chairs, dismissed as absurd when it was depicted in Monty Python many years ago, has become reality. A possible EU directive, ordaining wider seats in British theatres, is now, according to a Sunday paper, alarming directors who consider physical discomfort essential to the theatre-going experience - or anyway, to keeping audiences awake. Sir Peter Hall confided that excruciating seating arrangements at the Wagnerian theatre in Bayreuth make it "the most interesting theatre" he has ever worked in: "It keeps you on your toes . . . " But could not the development of state-of-the art seats just as easily work for the directors of boring plays, as against them? Concealed wiring, for instance, would enable the director to administer mild - and less mild, according to taste - electric shocks during unendurably tedious episodes - the comic scenes in As You Like It, for example, or every other line of Racing Demon.
