fields.headline: Hush fund
fields.trailText: In his interview with Joe Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, New York, (Master builder, February 18) Stephen Moss wrote that only a tiny amount of its funds comes from the government. This is a common error. Nearly 40% of the Met's funds are donations that come with a hefty tax break - subsidy administered by different means.
fields.body:
In his interview with Joe Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, New York, (Master builder, February 18) Stephen Moss wrote that only a tiny amount of its funds comes from the government. This is a common error. Nearly 40% of the Met's funds are donations that come with a hefty tax break - subsidy administered by different means.

The question is whether these means are better or not. The tax break system has several disadvantages. It is expensive and time-consuming for the company, because they have to chase after many separate donors. It is theoretically less secure than direct funding because a sponsor's passions may be fickle, and it always carries the danger of too much influence. A tax break is discreet - so discreet that your report missed it altogether.
David Pountney
Munich
fields.bodyText: In his interview with Joe Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, New York, (Master builder, February 18) Stephen Moss wrote that only a tiny amount of its funds comes from the government. This is a common error. Nearly 40% of the Met's funds are donations that come with a hefty tax break - subsidy administered by different means. The question is whether these means are better or not. The tax break system has several disadvantages. It is expensive and time-consuming for the company, because they have to chase after many separate donors. It is theoretically less secure than direct funding because a sponsor's passions may be fickle, and it always carries the danger of too much influence. A tax break is discreet - so discreet that your report missed it altogether. David Pountney Munich

webTitle: Labour appears to be electing for a fratricidal war

fields.headline: Labour appears to be electing for a fratricidal war
fields.trailText: I was never a great Ken fan; I voted for Blair as leader, supported him over Clause 4, approved of his rapprochement with Murdoch and the City and, yes, I voted for Frank. I could probably be described as an archetypal New Labour councillor, yet the patience even of loyalists like me has been worn ever thinner by the arrogant, ill-advised and politically maladroit antics of Downing Street and Millbank (Labour bid to scupper Livingstone, February 23).
fields.body:
I was never a great Ken fan; I voted for Blair as leader, supported him over Clause 4, approved of his rapprochement with Murdoch and the City and, yes, I voted for Frank. I could probably be described as an archetypal New Labour councillor, yet the patience even of loyalists like me has been worn ever thinner by the arrogant, ill-advised and politically maladroit antics of Downing Street and Millbank (Labour bid to scupper Livingstone, February 23).

And now, try as they might, they cannot deny the dismal result of their handling of the selection process, because their strategies have brought the party to the verge of schism and they have only themselves to blame. I have not seen such crass and monumental incompetence as over devolution since the days of John Major's premiership. Labour high command does not seem to realise (or perhaps it does not care?) that a tiny handful of in-house zealots apart, its behaviour is now alienating even its own loyalists. For those like me, on whom the party depends to get the job done at grass-roots level (because so many of the rank and file have melted away) there is an overwhelming feeling that nobody up there is paying attention. Before tragedy descends further into farce, the prime minister should start listening less to his court eunuchs and more to the despatches coming in from the field.

In the meantime, for those of us who are trying to remain loyal, albeit with gritted teeth, just a shred of humility on the part of Downing Street and Millbank would go a very long way.
Cllr Simon Stanley
Kensington and Chelsea
Ken Livingstone is wrong to claim "I welcomed" the electoral college. I was surprised and disappointed by the decision but, like most other members, I accepted, once the decision had been taken, that the election would have to be contested on that basis. Ken did the same.

What Ken has to explain is why he has changed his position on so many fundamental issues over the past year. He claims he is totally opposed to the public private partnership for the Underground. But less than a year ago when parliament was considering the Greater London Authority bill, he not only failed to speak against it, he actually voted twice for it. Having given a clear pledge that there were no circumstances in which he would stand as an independent, Ken should now stop trying to find spurious justification for breaking his word.
Nick Raynsford MP


Two days before Frank Dobson's selection as Labour candidate, I received my copy of Inside Labour, the magazine edited by Margaret McDonagh, the Labour party's general secretary, and sent free to party members. In an article on the party's history by Joe Haines I read: "John Smith ... did leave a lasting mark on the party: it was he who forced through the adoption of one member, one vote, ending the iron grip of the block vote on party decisions."
Charles Hobday
London

fields.headline: George Carey's street cred
fields.trailText: Andrew Brown (Shepherd without a flock, February 22) seems to have been basing his views about the Church of England solely upon matters relating to the church as institution and not as the living and vibrant community with which the Archbishop of Canterbury was involved here in Essex last weekend.
fields.body:
Andrew Brown (Shepherd without a flock, February 22) seems to have been basing his views about the Church of England solely upon matters relating to the church as institution and not as the living and vibrant community with which the Archbishop of Canterbury was involved here in Essex last weekend.

Far from being full of intrigue and falling apart, our experience of the church is that it is proving against all the cultural odds to be alert, strong and on the ball. Dr Carey saw local parishes instrumental in the regeneration of deprived housing estates, acting as a rallying point for new partnerships in the community, as well as working with the homeless and drug addicts.

There's internal vitality too. Last Sunday I confirmed 65 people from all walks of life. The comprehensiveness of the community means there will be differences - but that's our church's genius. I was impressed to see the pastoral wisdom and Christian goodness of Dr Carey at street level. No wonder the Queen wants him to stay.
Rt Revd Laurie Green
Bishop of Bradwell
It was simplistic to blame Dr Carey for the decline in numbers in the Church of England. All voluntary societies have smaller numbers - scouts, Young Conservatives, women's institutes, trades unions. With an emphasis on personal rights and choices, people work more as individuals. George Carey has done no better or worse than anyone else in encouraging new people to go beyond individualism and join the church.
Revd Vincent Ashwin
Haydon Bridge, Northumberland

fields.headline: Adopting the right course
fields.trailText: It can sound like a good idea to speed up the adoption process (When love is not enough, February 23). However, in my experience parents who desperately want to adopt are not necessarily naturally suitable adoptees. They might start out that way, but can come to regret their actions, with dire consequences for the child.
fields.body:
It can sound like a good idea to speed up the adoption process (When love is not enough, February 23). However, in my experience parents who desperately want to adopt are not necessarily naturally suitable adoptees. They might start out that way, but can come to regret their actions, with dire consequences for the child.

I was eight months old in the 50s when the couple who adopted me responded to the post-war campaign for parents. (My natural mother had had a fling while her husband was away fighting). I was handed over to an absolutely horrible woman. She was barren and suspected her husband might leave her because of that. However, they ran their own business, had a proper house, a previously adopted son and seemed like a good enough bet, I guess.

Her husband left her. My brother and I were treated with absolute indifference all our lives. Some days she barely knew or cared where we were or who we were. After the age of 11, I missed most of my schooling while I was running her corner shop. I have few photographs of myself as a child. I never had a birthday party. I had never had a bedroom and was made to cook and clean for lodgers daily.

Could my misery have been prevented? I believe so; but it would have meant slowing down the adoption process. Being childless and wanting a family or feeling sorry for children in care is not nearly enough to prevent years of damage.

Of course prospective parents should have every scrap of information on the child; but they should also subject themselves to as much ongoing scrutiny as is required to ensure the child is being treated well. I would even go so far as to say that children should be asked their views at least annually. I don't know if I would have been better cared for in an institution, but I do know that when my adopted mother was hospitalised when I was nine, the few months I spent in a children's home were the happiest of my childhood.
Name and address supplied

You are right to warn against the dangers of an adoption crusade. But the alternative is not just high-quality residential care. Much more could be done to keep children with their own families. In Guardian Society (February 9), I reported on a neighbourhood project on an estate which, in a 10 year period, saw only one child go into care. Its essential features were that its staff lived in the area and stayed long-term. The treasury is drawing up plans for a new children's fund for voluntary projects. It should give priority to those which are locally controlled and which are rooted with local families. Prevention would be promoted.
Bob Holman
Glasgow
bob@holman24.fsnet.co.uk


Ten years ago Tayside social work department closed down the independent children's home I had run for 15 years because all future emphasis was to be on fostering and adoption rather than residential care. Scores of children benefited from placement with us over those years, some moved on to successful "family" placements, some to disastrous ones, and others stayed with us long-term.

When we were closed down 13 children (all in their teens) had to be found alternative placements. One older teenager suffered from the breakdown of subsequent placements and eventually committed suicide. I do hope Tony Blair's radical review of adoption procedures will pay adequate attention to such vital considerations. There is, 10 years on and despite the crop of children's homes "abuse scandals", a call from many quarters to reopen residential homes for young people.
Les Potter
Bristol
lespam@mcmail.com

fields.headline: Winning numbers
fields.trailText: You comment that a number of Millennium Commission projects are behind schedule (North south divide, February 22). In fact over 80% of projects expected to be complete by the end of 2000 are already finished or on schedule to finish. Around one third of all Millennium Commission projects are already open and enjoying public support.
fields.body:
You comment that a number of Millennium Commission projects are behind schedule (North south divide, February 22). In fact over 80% of projects expected to be complete by the end of 2000 are already finished or on schedule to finish. Around one third of all Millennium Commission projects are already open and enjoying public support. The Millennium Commission is investing £1.3bn in 200 new buildings, environmental projects and visitor attractions on over 3,000 sites across the UK. We believe that quality is more important than timing when it comes to such a major investment in the social and economic infrastructure of the UK. It was never our intention that all projects be completed by the year 2000 and the average delay across the projects is less than the industry average.

You state that many smaller projects have been cancelled. This is incorrect. In some cases projects are unable to raise the necessary matched funding or get planning permission and therefore cannot take up the commission's offer of grant. This does not preclude them from coming on line at a later date or with other sources of funding.

London has not received more than its fair share of funding from the Millennium Commission. The grant per head in London is around £19, which is lower than the UK average of £21 and far lower than areas such as Yorkshire and Humberside with £32 and Scotland with £39. The Millennium Commission is spreading £2bn of lottery money all around the UK on projects, festivals and awards to individuals.

Every region and county of the UK will benefit from our work and it will be a lasting legacy for generations.
Mike O'Connor
Director, The Millennium Commission

fields.headline: Momentum in Michigan
fields.standfirst:
Senator McCain is back in the frame

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The best and worst of American politics have been on show this week. The energy stirred by the insurgent campaign of the Vietnam war hero John McCain has captured the imagination of millions of Americans - most of them not Republicans. It has done that rare thing in politics: aroused genuine public excitement.
fields.body:
The best and worst of American politics have been on show this week. The energy stirred by the insurgent campaign of the Vietnam war hero John McCain has captured the imagination of millions of Americans - most of them not Republicans. It has done that rare thing in politics: aroused genuine public excitement. The turnout in Tuesday's ballot in Michigan was a record high, with more than twice the usual number of voters heading to the polls. We have seen these crusades before, of course: from Gene McCarthy's protest against Vietnam in 1968 to Pat Buchanan's self-styled peasants' revolt in 1996. One does not have to like their message to admire these bursts of energy, thrown up every four years by the primary process. They make politics live.

Unfortunately, the ugly side of America's electoral method has also been visible. The brief contest in Michigan turned into a mudbath as both Senator McCain and his opponent, Texas governor George W Bush, fought a viciously dirty campaign. No blow was too low, as Mr McCain used the latest automated phoning techniques to hit voters with a pre-recorded message blasting Mr Bush as an "anti-Catholic bigot" - a tough charge in heavily Catholic Detroit. The Texan shot back with auto-calls of his own, announcing that John McCain took a dim view of Christian conservatives. The sad lesson of the Republican story so far is that such negativity works: Mr Bush's dirty war won South Carolina, Mr McCain's revenge won Michigan.

Now, though, the race gets really interesting. The usual logic dictates that a Republican candidate must tack right to win the primaries, then head to the centre to win the presidential election itself. Mr McCain has turned that logic on its head. He won in Michigan by appealing to Democratic and independent voters - just the people Republicans will need to win in November. Can he keep up this trick, effectively winning the Republican nomination even when Republicans themselves do not want him? Not for long: the next few primaries are mainly "closed" affairs, barring all but registered Republicans. Still, the coming contests are mainly in more moderate states - like California, New York and Massachusetts - where the senator's rebel image may play well. We cannot help but wish John McCain luck: not because we agree with him, but for daring to prove that in politics there is no such thing as a foregone conclusion.

fields.headline: You're effing wrong
fields.trailText: Sorry, but the first perfectly pronounced "fuck" on a British stage was not by Sir John Gielgud in 1972 (Effing is off, rules theatre computer, February 23). He was preceded by Gerald James as William Blake in my play Tyger, presented by the National Theatre at the New Theatre in London on July 20 1971 (which also included probably the first on-stage use of clitoris). Beautifully delivered, with a Welsh inflection, the immortal line was: "If you can't beat 'em - fuck 'em!" I offer this, free of copyright, as a slogan for Ken's mayoral campaign.

fields.headline: Mitrovice violence prompts troops call
fields.standfirst:
Radio intercepts suggest Serbs are orchestrating trouble in city

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato commanders in Kosovo yesterday urgently demanded that reinforcements be sent to the province after claiming to have intercepted radio contacts between local Serbs and police units in Serbia.
fields.body:
Nato commanders in Kosovo yesterday urgently demanded that reinforcements be sent to the province after claiming to have intercepted radio contacts between local Serbs and police units in Serbia.

The latest evidence suggesting that Belgrade may be orchestrating the violence in the northern city of Mitrovice emerged as neighbouring Macedonia put some troops on high alert because of the deteriorating security situation.

"Nato does not have the troops it needs in Kosovo," a senior Nato official confirmed last night. "We have asked for reinforcements and the request has support."

The K-For peacekeeping mission in Kosovo was originally supposed to have 49,000 troops, but the force now numbers 30,000. There are also 7,000 soldiers from non-Nato countries. Others contingents are stationed in Macedonia.

Serious overstretch has forced Britain to cut the number of its troops in the province to under 4,000, from a peak of more than 10,000 last summer.

Nato commanders have requested that an additional battalion be deployed and that the Nato strategic reserve be placed on reduced notice. The request for more troops had "received support" from Nato's North Atlantic council, and an emergency meeting on the crisis is planned for tomorrow.

As well as monitoring radio conversations between Serbs, Nato intelligence has observed Yugoslav army movements in the Kosovo border area. They are thought to be training manoeuvres but could be transformed into something more aggressive at short notice.

Unrest has also been growing in Serbia proper. Ethnic Albanian guerrillas have conducted small-scale infiltrations of an ethnic Albanian enclave across the border.

But it was the mounting pressure in Mitrovice which triggered the request for extra peacekeepers. US, British and Canadian troops have already moved in to help the French in the flashpoint city, where Nato units struggled on Monday to hold back up to 70,000 ethnic Albanians protesting against Serb violence.

Hundreds of peacekeeping troops yesterday fanned out through what the military called "hot zones" of the city to conduct house-to-house weapons searches.

"There are still a lot of arms to recover, but this is a sign - we are here and we will continue to be here as long as it takes," said Captain Alain Racine of the French 8th Para troop brigade. By early afternoon, his squad had recovered three Kalashnikov assault rifles, several other rifles, camouflage uniforms and a variety of other weaponry.

Capt Racine said most of the weapons were recovered from caches in ruined buildings, adding that there was no way of telling if they had been hidden by Serbs or Albanians.

The UN also announced a plan to return Albanians to their homes in the northern, Serb-dominated side of the city and to create a secure zone from north to south.

Capt Racine said most of the weapons were recovered from caches in ruined buildings, adding that there was no way of telling if they had been hidden by Serbs or Albanians. The UN also announced a plan to return Albanians to their homes in the northern, Serb-dominated side of the city and to create a secure zone from north to south.

webTitle: French anger at US-British global spying

fields.headline: French anger at US-British global spying
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The publication of a highly provocative report by the European parliament has brought to a head concerns about a worldwide eavesdropping network dominated by the US and Britain.
fields.body:
The publication of a highly provocative report by the European parliament has brought to a head concerns about a worldwide eavesdropping network dominated by the US and Britain.

The report - by the parliament's justice committee - says that the network, code-named Echelon, infringes rights to privacy. It coincides with a number of European investigations charging the US with industrial espionage and increasing French distrust of the close intelligence cooperation between "Anglo-Saxon" nations.

The parliamentary report claims that the Echelon network is capable of listening in on "billions of messages per hour" - including telephone calls, fax transmissions and private emails - and intercepts sensitive Europe-wide commercial communications.

The existence of the Echelon network was confirmed recently by an official US government document published on the internet. Yesterday Duncan Campbell, the British freelance journalist who helped compile the report, told the committee it was run by the US National Security Agency (NSA) with Canada, Britain, Australia, and New Zealand. The British element is based at the GCHQ station in Morwenstow, north Cornwall.

Charles Pasqua, the former French interior minister and a member of the committee, said British participation gave its an unfair advantage over its EU partners. "The rules of the game are rigged and they are rigged especially by the British. This is shocking," he said.

The report describes a number of cases in which US companies allegedly won contracts destined for European firms after NSA intercepted conver sations. The Airbus consortium and Thomson CSF of France were among the reported losers.

A former NSA agent, Wayne Madsen, told Australian television last year that the US used information gathered from its base in Australia to win a half-share of a significant Indonesian trade contract for AT&T which intercepts showed was initially going to NRC of Japan.

Meanwhile, in a 100-page report submitted recently to the French defence ministry's strategic intelligence arm, DAS, software giant Microsoft is accused of colluding with the US intelligence services to spy on foreign businesses, amid suspicions that the company planted "back door" spy holes in its MS-DOS operating system and Windows software.

According to yesterday's Le Figaro, the spying devices would enable the NSA to penetrate a company's networks and read top-secret documents.

Microsoft said it had never, in France or any other country, installed a system allowing the NSA or other US government agencies to decode encrypted data coming from a computer equipped with Windows.

Lawsuits against Britain and the US for their role in Echelon have been lodged in France, and parliamentary inquiries are under way in Italy and Germany. In the US, a congressional investigation into Echelon's implications for privacy rights begins later this year.

Last night, the foreign office said British intelligence services worked "entirely within the law". This allowed interception in the interests of Britain's "economic well-being" as well as to protect national security. A spokeswoman added: "We do not engage in bulk surveillance, whatever Duncan Campbell says."

fields.headline: France sends reinforcements to Mitrovice
fields.trailText: France will send up to 700 extra troops to Kosovo to reinforce the Nato presence there. Alain Richard, the French defence minister, told a press conference in Washington that the extra battalion was intended "to make real provisions so that we take control of the situation."
fields.body:
France will send up to 700 extra troops to Kosovo to reinforce the Nato presence there. Alain Richard, the French defence minister, told a press conference in Washington that the extra battalion was intended "to make real provisions so that we take control of the situation."

The new troops will be sent to the divided city of Mitrovice where tensions between the ethnic populations of Serbs and Kosovo Albanians have been rising in recent weeks.

Troops from other Nato countries moved into the city on Monday to assist the French contingent in maintaining control.

Nato generals made an urgent call on Wednesday for reinforcements among suspicions that the Serbian government may have a hand in provoking unrest in Mitrovice.

The Nato force of 30,000 troops is significantly smaller than the 49,000 originally envisioned. There are suggestions that a further unit of US marines may be sent to the region, although William Cohen, the US defence secretary, said no decision had been taken.

Neighbouring Macedonia has also put troops near the border on alert because of fears the unrest may spread.

webTitle: Has feminism killed the American marriage?

fields.headline: Has feminism killed the American marriage?
fields.standfirst: Getting wed is on the wane in the US. So is murdering your spouse.  Sharon Krum examines the connection
fields.trailText: For the past week, Americans have been galvanized by a television game show that ended with the winner marrying a woman he had never met. Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? featured as its ultimate prize not a bank account but a rich bachelor and a white wedding.
fields.body:
For the past week, Americans have been galvanized by a television game show that ended with the winner marrying a woman he had never met. Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? featured as its ultimate prize not a bank account but a rich bachelor and a white wedding.

Yet after millions of Americans watched 50 women parade in swimsuits, then explain without shame why they wanted to marry Californian property developer Rick Rockwell for his money, the disgust at the stunt registered with Richter-like force. Newspapers expressed shock and outrage. On talk radio and the Internet, the microwave marriage upstaged a bitterly contested presidential primary.

How could all these women and one man make such a mockery of the sacred institution of marriage, people demanded to know. Whatever happened to the practice of marrying someone in spite of their flaws, not because of their assets? When did marriage vows change from "for richer or poorer" to "for richer and richer"?

Ironic that it took a glitzy, low-brow TV quiz show and not the usual army of psychologists, priests and government ministers to get the public here to debate the meaning of marriage in 21st-century America. "I haven't seen anything like this since the OJ Simpson trial opened up the conversation about domestic violence," said Los Angeles psychologist Dr Robert Butterworth. "This marriage between strangers (already on the rocks) has made the country finally tackle the issue of what it really means to get married and stay married."

As the debate raged, University of Missouri criminologist Richard Rosenfeld unknowingly stepped into the fray. He presented a paper at the Academy for the Advancement of Science conference in Washington DC, documenting how the decline in marriage rates in the US led directly to a fall in spousal homicide. While in 1996 (the most recent year for which figures are available) 75% of domestic murder victims in the US were women, overall the rate of murder in American marriages has plummeted 36% since 1976. (By comparison, 50% of domestic murder victims in England and Wales were women, according to the Home Office.)

If you did nothing but listen to the broadcast media in America this week, you would think defending the sanctity of marriage was the nation's top priority. But if you noted Rosenfeld's findings, the truth revealed itself to be something quite different. The fact is, Americans are not the great champions of marriage they pretend to be. Marriage rates have never fallen so low, nor is cohabitation filling the void. Americans are choosing to stay single longer and women in particular don't see marriage as an economic or social necessity.

"The marriage rate in America was 8.3 per 1,000 people in 1998, the lowest since 1958," Rosenfeld says. "Fewer marriages means fewer opportunities for spousal violence."

But the statistics do not mean domestic abuse is no longer a fixture in the American home. While there is a downturn due to fewer marriages and more domestic violence services, it is still an issue with which many married women have to contend. "It's the proximity of the relationship and the influence of alcohol, handguns [50% of domestic murders here involve a gun] and financial problems that causes homicide."

Rosenfeld is right, but he is only telling half the story. The other reason marriage rates are falling, why men are killing their wives, is the changing role of women both inside and outside the home. Forty years of feminism have thrown American men into a blind panic. The boundaries that once defined an American marriage are not so much blurred as erased. Women now work and earn their own money. They are not sexual naïfs on their wedding day. Inside their marriages, they have redefined the word "wife" to mean equal partner, not unpaid housekeeper.

Men locked into the idea that marriage means they play the breadwinner and man of the house are in shock. They complain that marriage to the new American woman - educated, financially independent, sexually liberated - emasculates them. As Susan Faludi so aptly titled her new book on the plight of the American male, they feel "stiffed".

Subsequently, the switch in marriage roles sends them over the edge. As Butterworth says, a lot of domestic abuse is really anger at women leading independent lives within a marriage. "With the rise of the women's movement, roles changed dramatically. Married men don't 'own' their wives any more. A lot of men would just love to wish away the women's movement but they can't. I think it's fascinating that so many American men today are marrying foreign brides who are much more passive in relationships."

While some men still seek out women willing to play the traditional wife, others are avoiding marriage. Statistics show children of divorce are less likely to marry and divorced adults are more likely to live together than remarry. For women, there is no fear that without a husband they will become social pariahs, so they opt for what they see as the better bet: permanent singleton status or cohabitation.

"There is a huge psychological difference for Americans between marriage and living together," Butterworth says. "If you are not married, you can change the arrangement any time. If you are a victim of domestic violence, you can walk out. Living together gives women freedom because it allows them to sidestep the stereotypes. A lot of religious denominations say, for instance, that the husband is ruler in the house. Without marriage, there is no battle. Women get to redefine the boundaries."

So where do all these shifting goalposts leave the once celebrated American marriage? Has feminism killed it? Is it now a television stunt and not a sacred vow? Well, yes and no. Americans will still marry, but the marriage of 50s TV sitcoms, with Mom in the kitchen and Dad at the ad agency, is dead and buried. The more women own their lives, the less they look for men to create a role and lifestyle for them. And, as Butterworth notes, men threatened by the new face of American marriage are heading overseas to find a partner willing to recreate the 50s inside the home.

"The future of American marriage is going to be very interesting," he concludes. "I believe it will continue to decline. And I also believe whoever chooses to get married now understands the roles are interchangeable and nobody will be embedded in stereotypes any more." Millionaires who think money, not equality, will buy them love need not apply.

fields.headline: Sex life on Mars
fields.standfirst:
Who'd have thought it: Nasa experimenting with coitus in space. Caroline Sullivan considers the consequences

Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Instant gratification. That's our problem. We want it all and we want it now. And that evidently includes sex in space. No longer is it enough for astronauts merely to take their protein pills and put their helmets on, as David Bowie put it, happy in the knowledge that they're creating their personal place in posterity. Now they expect sex to be part of the equation, like teenagers who can't wait to get home to consummate their love and do it right there, round the back of the disco.
fields.body:
Instant gratification. That's our problem. We want it all and we want it now. And that evidently includes sex in space. No longer is it enough for astronauts merely to take their protein pills and put their helmets on, as David Bowie put it, happy in the knowledge that they're creating their personal place in posterity. Now they expect sex to be part of the equation, like teenagers who can't wait to get home to consummate their love and do it right there, round the back of the disco.

A French scientist, Pierre Kohler, has supposedly uncovered secret documents on zero-gravity sex experiments conducted by Nasa in 1996. "The aim was to establish the most effective ways to have sex in space. They were obviously thinking about couples spending long periods of time in space together," he reveals in a book on the Mir space station, The Final Mission.

Whatever happened to a bit of character-building abstinence? Isn't it possible for these couples to keep their minds off their crotches just this once, for the greater good?

Celibacy wasn't a problem for Laura Supra, part of Nasa's longest-duration test team on earth, who says: "That's one of the things you give up by going up there." And Musa Manarov, who spent a year on Mir, agrees: "A young guy could go for three years without women."

That's the spirit. Why not send them up together? It would save Nasa the cost of the "inflatable tunnels and wall-mounted straps" they found were necessary to keep couples from floating to opposite ends of the spaceship.

They did come up with four unspecified positions that could be achieved while drifting untethered, which potentially sounds like fun until you consider what happens when the participants uncouple. Where does what a friend delicately describes as "the goo" go? By the same token, those who get their kicks from peeing on other people might find weightlessness gives them a taste of their own medicine and S&M fans will be denied that satisfying crack of whip on flesh, which means space-coitus will pretty much be restricted to the basics.

Then there's the nuisance of retrieving bits of your spacesuit from where you've strewn them as you wafted around. No, you'd be smart to opt for the wall straps. In fact, the only advantages of celestial schtupping - and this will be put to the test this century, on a three-year mission to Mars - have nothing to do with the act itself. No tiffs about who sleeps on the wet patch, for example, because it'll be all over the place (see above reference to goo).

Whether he'll respect you in the morning is immaterial in the eternal black night of deep space. Morning never comes and neither does the inevitable agonising about who should phone who. Finally, there would be no need, as depicted in countless sci-fi films, to stop at another planet en route to pick up a love interest, and no worries about the alien offspring that might result from such a union.

It's interesting that Nasa should find it necessary to carry out the experiment, since space travel has hitherto revelled in its very sexlessness. It's a heroic, ennobling pursuit and those who do it, invariably men until relatively recently, seem to be liberated from fleshly imperatives. Given the Tipper Gore-esque wives waiting for them back in Houston, maybe it's the only chance they get to experience the pleasure of platonic companionship and the bonds formed of being braver and smarter than the rest of us.

Certainly there was never anything less than professional in the relationship between Star Trek's Lieutenant Uhura and the men on the Enterprise. And in Lost In Space (the 60s TV version), the harassed mother and father gave the impression sex was the last thing on their minds.

But for some, such as cosmonaut Svetlana Savitskaia, there will be an illicit thrill to the whole idea. She's rumoured to have bedded, if that's the word, one of her male colleagues on the Salut-7 space station back in 1982. Perhaps it was just a way of venting pent-up energy, but I'll wager the idea of doing it in a spaceship, with others nearby, had a lot to do with it. A similar sense of adolescent naughtiness probably attended the coupling of two strangers on an American Airlines flight from Dallas to Manchester recently. Sometimes it's more tantalising to defer gratification, even - especially? - on a trip to Mars.

webTitle: McCain an able adversary but can he burn Bush?

fields.headline: McCain an able adversary but can he burn Bush?
fields.standfirst:
Real test is ahead for man most Republicans love to hate

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: When reporters finally reached Senator John McCain by phone at his home in Phoenix, Arizona, on Tuesday night, it was clear from the noise at the other end of the line that there was a hell of a party going on. And why not? For, as an exuberant Mr McCain said later that evening at his victory rally: "What a difference a couple of days make."
fields.body:
When reporters finally reached Senator John McCain by phone at his home in Phoenix, Arizona, on Tuesday night, it was clear from the noise at the other end of the line that there was a hell of a party going on. And why not? For, as an exuberant Mr McCain said later that evening at his victory rally: "What a difference a couple of days make."

What a difference indeed. Over the past few days, the rollercoaster primary struggle has revealed the two sides of the John McCain phenomenon more sharply than ever. There is the man who is splitting his Republican party down the middle in his contest with George W Bush. And there is also the man who promises to unify a new "McCain majority" of Republicans, independents and Democrats. Then there are the two sides of the man himself. Impetuous McCain in defeat in South Carolina on Saturday, yet magnanimous McCain in victory in Arizona on Tuesday.

On Saturday night in South Carolina the McCain camp were drinking cold revenge not cold beer. Mr McCain was visibly angry in defeat. George W Bush's juggernaut had thumped him 53% to 42%. The Arizona senator had thrown away an opinion poll lead. There was nothing graceful about his concession speech in Charleston.

"I will not take the low road to the highest office in the land," Mr McCain said bitterly. "I want the presidency in the best way, not the worst way."

Mr McCain came out swinging in Michigan on Sunday and Monday. Campaigning with a new aggression, the Arizona senator knew that Michigan was a win-or-bust effort. His language reflected his gung-ho urgency. It struck some observers as intemperate.

"You saw Star Wars, right?" Mr McCain told an audience in Saginaw late on the eve of polling in Michigan, using an image he has frequently invoked in the past few weeks. "I'm like Luke Skywalker trying to get out of the Death Star. They're shooting at me from everywhere."

Turning point

This time, he went further. "Everybody's against me. Governor Engler [the Michigan Republican governor], Governor Bush, all the governors, all the senators. But we're going to kill 'em. We're going to win this election."

Less than 24 hours later, back home by now, a new Mr McCain took the stage in Phoenix to mark his double triumph in Arizona and Michigan. In Arizona, Mr McCain won comfortably by 60% to Mr Bush's 36%. In Michigan, the biggest state to vote in the primary calendar so far and the one that Governor Engler had promised would be "asbestos" for Mr Bush against a McCain brush-fire, Mr McCain hit back with a 50% to 44% win.

It was a turning point in the campaign for two reasons. First because, from today, the Republican primary battleground shifts from "open" to "closed" primaries. It shifts from states like New Hampshire, South Carolina and Michigan, in which independents and Democrats can flood the Republican process, to states like California, New York and Connecticut - all of which vote on March 7 - where only Republicans can vote. Until now, the open primaries have been the McCain campaign's life-support system - Michigan, where only a minority of the voters in the primary were Republicans, was the most spectacular example. Now the battle is for Republican voters alone, terrain on which Mr Bush, the Texas governor, is far stronger than his challenger.

The second turning point, though, is that Michigan and Arizona made Mr McCain even more credible than he had been after New Hampshire. Tuesday proved that Mr McCain is not a one-state wonder. It proved that defeat in South Carolina was not a knock-out blow. Tuesday could have ended the McCain insurgency. Instead, it not only kept it alive but also made it a genuine threat to Mr Bush.

It gets tougher now for Mr McCain. He has fresh impetus from Michigan and Arizona - and he could win again in Washington state next week - but he must adapt to the new politics of the Super Tuesday campaign on March 7 or perish.

That imperative was reflected in his victory speech in Phoenix. Mr McCain had spent much of the day drafting the brief but crucial address with his strategist, Mike Murphy, and his campaign manager, Rick Davis, and the words he used were highly significant. They reflected the McCain campaign's now desperate need to break Mr Bush's continuing grip on the core Republican voters who hold the result of the contest in their hands.

Teddy's boy

"I want to make a special plea tonight to my fellow Republicans," Mr McCain began. "Don't fear this campaign, my fellow Republicans. Join it. Join it."

In many recent speeches, Mr McCain has often identified himself with Theodore Roosevelt, the swashbuckling military adventurer who took on the "robber barons" of America's first industrial revolution. This time he added the name of Ronald Reagan. "I am a proud Reagan conservative," he said. "I love the Republican party."

The question, though, is whether the Republican party loves John McCain. The reality is that about a quarter of them do, but most of them don't. A lot of them, the religious right in particular, genuinely hate him. Mr Bush reached out to religious conservatives to save him after New Hampshire. They delivered for him in South Carolina, but their tactics backfired in Michigan, especially among the Catholic voters who are so important in the crucial midwestern states like Illinois, Wisconsin, Iowa and Ohio where a presidential election is often lost and won.

"We are creating a new majority, my friends," Mr McCain concluded on Tuesday night, "a McCain majority." The next three weeks will show whether that claim is, as the senator says, Al Gore's nightmare, or if it is simply John McCain's pipe dream.

The next round...

The attention of the Republican presidential contenders now focuses on the next round of contests.

This weekend, barely noticed by the media and unvisited by the candidates, there are Republican caucuses in some of the more distant corners of the United States empire. American Samoa, Guam and the US Virgin Islands vote on February 26, with Puerto Rico Republicans voting a day later.

Next week brings two important state primaries on February 29. One is in Washington state, where John McCain hopes to win in a state with 37 convention delegates. Meanwhile, George W Bush is hopeful of winning in Virginia, with 56 delegates. On the same day, North Dakota holds its Republican caucuses, with 19 delegates at stake.

Then it is on to "Super Tuesday" on March 7, when 16 states - including California and New York - hold primaries or caucuses, between them selecting 613 delegates, almost 60% of the 1,033 needed to win the Republican nomination. Most commentators think the contest will be settled that day.

If the issue is still in doubt after Super Tuesday, then the contest will move to the south on March 14, "Southern Tuesday". Six states hold Republican contests that day, including Texas and Florida, governed by the Bush brothers.

The last time the Democrats held a primary contest was in New Hampshire on February 1. That will change on Super Tuesday, when the Al Gore-Bill Bradley contest resumes in the same states where the Republicans are voting on March 7 and March 14.

John McCain For President
George W Bush For President

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Arizona Republic
fields.body:
Arizona Republic

In recent years, Senator John McCain has become a champion of campaign finance reform. But more than a decade ago, he took free trips to the Bahamas with savings and loan tycoon Charles Keating. He still takes big money from interests appearing before his [senate] committees.

As a senator, he's pilloried tobacco companies, though his wife owes her personal millions to beer sales.

He prides himself on his personal integrity yet admits he wasn't faithful to his first wife.

He courts the veteran vote yet is despised among veterans.

Some say Mr McCain's seemingly principled positions are all for show, helping him build his maverick image with a windmill tilt or two.

Washington Post

John McCain's strong showing in Michigan and Arizona shows that the fight for the Republican nomination is not yet over, and suggests that Mr McCain's anti-establishment promise to cleanse politics has a powerful resonance.

Now his candidacy cannot be dismissed as a fluke, the more so because in Michigan he had the entire state Republican establishment against him.

George W Bush also had the support of pro-life and Christian conservative organisations.

All of that bought him no more than a rough draw with his challenger. That cannot be a heartening message for his campaign.

New York Times

As this ever-surprising Republican contest heads for more battles across the country, one of its most striking aspects is the increasingly nasty and personal nature of the combat.

A new tone of religious animosity has crept in, especially as several spokesmen for the Christian conservative movement in the south have rallied to Governor Bush's cause.

McCain supporters say Michigan was swamped with recorded telephone messages from the religious broadcaster Pat Robertson, singling out a former senator, Warren Rudman, who is Jewish, as "a vicious bigot" for criticising the Christian Coalition.

Bush supporters, for their part, accused the McCain campaign of condoning other calls suggesting that the governor is anti-Catholic.

Detroit Free Press

Senator John McCain limped into Michigan, but he leaves walking on air. In the wake of his twin wins in Michigan and Arizona, Republicans across the nation may take a new look at their party's strategy.

The fundamental premise of George W Bush's presidential campaign was that he was the most electable Republican candidate.

Now that premise is in question. By bouncing back from defeat in South Carolina, Mr McCain strengthened his claim that he can assemble a broad coalition that can drive the Democrats from the White House.

fields.headline: Maligning and whining Hollywood style
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: It is a campaign straight out of a Capra film. A decent guy takes on the system, and the brutes who run the system move in to destroy the upstart. They paint the populist hero as crazy or deceitful. After a bout of self-pity, he rallies with some sentimental hooey about US ideals and routs the ruling-class bullies.
fields.body:
It is a campaign straight out of a Capra film. A decent guy takes on the system, and the brutes who run the system move in to destroy the upstart. They paint the populist hero as crazy or deceitful. After a bout of self-pity, he rallies with some sentimental hooey about US ideals and routs the ruling-class bullies.

"Why, your type's as old as history," John Doe tells his tormentors. "If you can't lay your dirty fingers on a decent idea and twist it and squeeze it and stuff it into your own pockets, you slap it down. Like dogs, if you can't eat something, you bury it!"

With the help of moderates and without the religious right smothering him, Mr McCain won in Michigan, so he can continue to dog the son of the establishment.

What's remarkable about the Republican race is that the arcs of the two campaigns mirror the arcs of the candidates' life stories.

Mr Bush started in New Hampshire as a slacker. As in his life, he relied on his name and powerful friends to keep him afloat in his campaign until he decided to apply himself late in the game. "This is a process of steeling me to become your president," he told Newsweek on the eve of the South Carolina primary.

Usually, people get their steel before they run for president. Anyhow, Mr Bush probably should have spelled it "steal". He purloined everything he could lay his hands on from the McCain campaign - the populist bus, the reformer message, the one-on-one town halls, even the design of the website.

Mr McCain, who spent his life getting in trouble for his impulsiveness and thin skin, let his emotions get away from him in the last couple of weeks. If there was one thing that was obvious, it was that the Bush team, humiliated in New Hampshire, was going to be ruthless and vicious in that most conservative and wired state for the Bushes, South Carolina.

But when it began to happen, Mr McCain reacted viscerally rather than cerebrally. He was furious about Mr Bush trotting out a discredited veteran to trash him; he was enraged that a boy scout got a push-polling call branding him "a liar"; and he overreached in a television commercial. He capped a bad week by using a self-defeating caustic tone in his South Carolina concession speech.

So far, we've learned that one candidate drifts and the other gets wound up. So now we know what we already knew. New York Times

webTitle: McCain changes tack to target Republican faithful

fields.headline: McCain changes tack to target Republican faithful
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The Republican party's presidential nomination battle entered a critical phase yesterday as a re-energised John McCain threw everything into an attempt to convert his latest primary wins over George W Bush into the capture of hearts and minds among the Republican faithful.
fields.body:
The Republican party's presidential nomination battle entered a critical phase yesterday as a re-energised John McCain threw everything into an attempt to convert his latest primary wins over George W Bush into the capture of hearts and minds among the Republican faithful.

The Arizona senator's guerrilla campaign surged forward again after decisive victories in the Michigan and Arizona primaries on Tuesday, just three days after Mr Bush appeared to have regained the initiative by winning in South Carolina.

An exuberant Mr McCain boasted in his victory remarks that he was creating "a McCain majority" in US politics. "The great thing about this victory yesterday was we have proved that we can reassemble a coalition that reaches out across party lines," he said.

Mr Bush took comfort from the fact that he continues to win majorities among the Republican party's core supporters, who will be increasingly influential in the upcoming primaries.

"Republicans overwhelmingly supported my candidacy. It seems I'm getting stronger and stronger with Republicans as the primaries go on," the Texas governor said during a campaign stopover in Missouri. "My spirits are high. I knew this was going to be a long struggle."

Mr McCain defeated Mr Bush by 60% to 34% in his home state of Arizona, and took Michigan by 50% to Mr Bush's 44%. The conservative campaigner Alan Keyes finished a distant third in both contests. Mr McCain now has a 94 to 58 lead over Mr Bush in national convention delegates elected so far, though both men are far short of the 1,033 required to secure the party's nomination for president.

But the struggle is now increasingly focused on Republican voters alone, and on the March 7 "super Tuesday" elections, when 16 states hold primaries and caucuses which will be decisive in both the McCain-Bush Republican contest and in the Democratic party race between Al Gore and Bill Bradley.

Before that, there are Republican primaries next week in Washington state, where Mr McCain campaigned yesterday, and in Virginia. But the chief battlegrounds are now the vote-rich states of California, New York and Ohio, all of which vote a week later.

The most important Republican battles on March 7 will be decided by the party's voters alone, unlike the Michigan primary where independents and Democrats participated in large numbers to support Mr McCain. With this in mind, the senator is now compelled to change tack and focus on the core Republican voters who have consistently supported Mr Bush. Despite losing in Michigan, Mr Bush won 66% of the Republican vote, to 29% for Mr McCain.

The Texas governor wasted no time in trying to shore up his lead among the party faithful in preparation for the March 7 contests, as well as unveiling his first Spanish-language television advert of the campaign, which will begin airing in California this week.

Mr McCain took his campaign to Washington state yesterday. Speaking in Spokane, he invoked the greatest of all Republican presidents in support of his dramatically successful strategy of capturing all-party support. "The party of Abraham Lincoln is an inclusionary party. The party of Abraham Lincoln is a party of addition and not division."

Mr McCain's victory speech on Tuesday immediately signalled the new turn towards Republican voters. Describing himself as "a proud Reagan conservative", he said: "Don't fear this campaign, my fellow Republicans. Join it. Join it."

webTitle: Gore waking up to worst nightmare

fields.headline: Gore waking up to worst nightmare
fields.standfirst:
Democrats look to derail Vietnam war hero's bandwagon

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush was heading for a church meeting with Latino voters in Los Angeles yesterday as part of a bid to win back wavering Roman Catholic voters as California prepares for its primary on March 7.
fields.body:
George W Bush was heading for a church meeting with Latino voters in Los Angeles yesterday as part of a bid to win back wavering Roman Catholic voters as California prepares for its primary on March 7.

But Democrats in the state are now much more concerned at the appeal of the man who last night described himself as "Al Gore's worst nightmare" - John McCain.

The primary, on "Super Tuesday" which is seen as the watershed for the campaign for both men, is a "closed" one; that is to say that the Republican party's 162 delegates will be allocated solely by the way registered Republicans vote.

This means that the crossover appeal of Mr McCain which served him so well in Michigan, where Democrats and independents ensured his victory, is blunted. Mr McCain is already trying to address this problem.

At his victory speech, he urged Republicans not to fear his campaign, and insisted: "We are creating a new majority, my friends, a McCain majority." In a clear bid to win wavering Californian Republicans, he said: "I am a proud Reagan conservative."

It is this new coalition that is giving Democrat organisers pause for thought. The latest polls show that if Mr McCain were to run against Mr Gore for president he would beat him by up to 20 percentage points.

Mr Bush, meanwhile, is seen by Democrats and independents as much more vulnerable and less impressive than the plain-speaking Mr McCain. Mr Bush has a far slimmer poll lead over Mr Gore and is seen as incapable of winning over many floating Democrats or independents.

Come November, the Democrats would far rather find themselves fighting a man they can portray as shallow, shifty, weak and in the pocket of big-money interests than a Vietnam war hero with an easy manner.

An edgy-looking and defensive Mr Bush arrived in California with a message for Mr McCain. "He's going to learn in the long run," he warned. "It's going to be Republicans and like-minded independents who are going to make the decision in this primary."

Mr Bush's visit last month to the far-right Bob Jones university in South Carolina, with its reputation for being virulently hostile to Catholics, has won him few friends on the west coast. The fact that the university bans inter-racial dating has also raised questions in California about his judgment and his ability to reach all parts of the vote.

fields.headline: Learning is 'good for your health'
fields.trailText: The government yesterday launched a search for the country's oldest "learner", as it published independent research confirming that learning is good for your health.
fields.body:
The government yesterday launched a search for the country's oldest "learner", as it published independent research confirming that learning is good for your health.

Malcolm Wicks, the junior education minister, appealed to the estimated 1m people aged 85 and over to come forward if they were engaged in any study or learning activities or simply brushing up skills, to prove that "age is no barrier to learning, sharing and fun".

Mr Wicks said the research into the impact of learning on older people - commissioned from the institute for employment by the department for education and employment - was the first study of its kind. People now lived longer which meant that retirement could last thirty years, he told a London seminar.

The survey of more than 300 people aged 50 to 71 found that 74% who said their health was excellent or very good were engaged in some form of learning. As well as links between education and good health, the research showed that learning had a positive effect on people's enjoyment of life, self-confidence and ability to cope. More than a quarter reported more involvement in social, community or voluntary activities as a result of learning.

"The research demonstrates the value of learning and how it can benefit older people," Mr Wicks said. "I want learning opportunities to open up new avenues for everyone from the youngest to the oldest. No one can afford to stop learning when they leave school."

Mr Wicks pointed out that there were now more than 1m people aged 85 and over, compared with fewer than 60,000 in 1901. He hoped many centenarians would come forward, citing the "inspirational" 107-year old Fred Moore of New Milton, Hampshire, who has been attending weekly art classes for 25 years.

The research also looked at the reasons why older people might not take up learning. A quarter of the respondents said they had done enough learning in their life; 22% felt too old. Family responsibilities were a factor, with non-learners likely to be spending free time with grandchildren.

webTitle: Couples vie for 'two in a bed' stunt

fields.headline: Couples vie for 'two in a bed' stunt
fields.trailText: When John Lennon and Yoko Ono had their week-long bed-ins they were making a serious protest for world peace. Now Radio City 96.7 FM in Liverpool is offering £10,000 to the couple who stay in bed the longest - for a stunt. Presumably it will have to be for considerably longer than seven days.
fields.body:
When John Lennon and Yoko Ono had their week-long bed-ins they were making a serious protest for world peace. Now Radio City 96.7 FM in Liverpool is offering £10,000 to the couple who stay in bed the longest - for a stunt. Presumably it will have to be for considerably longer than seven days.

Four couples, yet to be chosen, will take part in the contest from March 10 in Cavern Walks, next to the Cavern Club, on what would have been Lennon's 60th birthday. They will have only a radio and each other for company (apart from the station team and security staff).

They will be fed in their beds. Sheets will be changed regularly. A 10-minute break - shower and toilets to hand - will be allowed every two hours; any other breaks taken will mean disqualification.

The winning couple will get a holiday in Canada, staying in the hotel suite in Montreal where John and Yoko staged one of their protests in 1969.

Tom Hunter of Radio City 96.7 FM said: "It will certainly be an interesting experiment in human relationships."

Last year the station gave a car to a bar worker who lived in it for 18 days, beating three other contestants.

fields.headline: Meningitis warning to students
fields.trailText: One in four students is at risk of meningitis because they have not been vaccinated against the potentially lethal brain disease, a group of GPs warned yesterday.
fields.body:
One in four students is at risk of meningitis because they have not been vaccinated against the potentially lethal brain disease, a group of GPs warned yesterday.

Outbreaks of meningitis often follow high rates of 'flu, and students are particularly susceptible to the meningitis C strain, which accounts for 40% of cases.

In September last year the government began a campaign to vaccinate all first-year undergraduates with the meningitis C vaccine, giving protection for three years.

A survey of students by the Primary Care Virology Group, an independent group of GPs, found that 25% had yet to be vaccinated - although 91% of the 610 questioned were aware of the campaign and 77% thought meningitis was a "very serious" infection. Of those not vaccinated, 53% said they had simply "not got round to it", despite cases of students dying of the disease.

In Huddersfield, for example, 62% of students had not been vaccinated, and in London 41% had not. Low levels of registration with GPs in university towns were partly to blame; in London and Huddersfield only a third of freshers had registered with a doctor.

In York, where 94% of first-year students were registered with a family doctor, the vaccination rate was 91%.

Elsewhere, the survey found the percentage vaccinated to be: Wolverhampton 57%, Hatfield 78%, Glasgow 81%, Cambridge 82%, Leicester 85%, Birmingham 85% and Cardiff 91%.

A rolling programme for mengingitis C will eventually result in all under-18s being vaccinated.

fields.headline: Killing of son's lover 'irrational'
fields.trailText: A deeply religious man who beheaded his son's former lover with an axe thought he would "live happily ever after", Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A deeply religious man who beheaded his son's former lover with an axe thought he would "live happily ever after", Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.

A psychiatrist, Tony Nayani, said he believed Anthony Phillips, 43, was suffering from an abnormality of mind when he killed Lorraine Howell, his next door neighbour, last May after discovering she had given birth in November 1998 to a girl, Lauren, fathered by his son, Jamie, now 17.

Dr Nayani, giving evidence for the defence, said Phillips, of Wolverhampton, who denies murder but admits manslaughter on grounds of diminished responsibility, was severely depressed at the time. He had believed that Mrs Howell, 34, was a "paedophile rapist" for sleeping with his son when he was 15.

Phillips "could see God's hand everywhere and he could see the devil's hand everywhere", said Dr Nayani. "This description of God's relevance and interference in his life places him on the boundary of psychological abnormality." Phillips believed Mrs Howell had "enticed" his son and should be prosecuted.

Discussions Phillips had with another psychiatrist, in which he had said he would be able to live happily afterwards if he killed Mrs Howell, were evidence of how irrational he had become, said Dr Nayani.

Phillips has elected not to give evidence.

webTitle: Bodies find may resolve air mystery

fields.headline: Bodies find may resolve air mystery
fields.trailText: The frozen remains of three people, one a woman, have been found high on a volcano in the Andes where a British airliner crashed 52 years ago.
fields.body:
The frozen remains of three people, one a woman, have been found high on a volcano in the Andes where a British airliner crashed 52 years ago.

The find was made by Argentinian mountaineers. Their 17-member expedition was yesterday making a hazardous descent by foot and on mules carrying the remains, and also pieces of the plane, from near the crater of the 21,848ft Tupungato volcano, close to the border with Chile.

The Stardust airliner, a converted world war two bomber operated by the now defunct British South American Airways, vanished with out trace during a snowstorm on August 2 1947, en route to Chile. On board were five crew and six passengers: three Britons, a German, a Palestinian and a Swiss.

Following the crash teams from Britain, Chile and Argentina searched the Andes by air and on skis but found nothing. Though a build-up of ice on the plane causing it to crash was the most likely explanation for its disappearance, there was speculation that it had been sabotaged to kill a British diplomatic messenger reportedly on board.

Last month five mountaineers climbing through ice fields atop Tupungato by chance stumbled across the remains of the four-engine plane.

Yesterday the Argentinian army released a photograph taken by its expedition at the site. It showed a rocky slope covered with scraps of clothing and a severed human hand.

An army spokesman said that after searching several days the group had recovered the remains and also pieces of the engines and landing gear on the debris-strewn slope some 16,500ft up the volcano. Getting that high had been a difficult climb, said the spokesman, and one member of the expedition had to be evacuated earlier this week with breathing difficulties.

The expedition hopes that its discoveries will enable the crash to be explained. The plane's last message has puzzled aviation investigators for years. Radio operators in Chile reportedly received a Morse code message reading STENDEC - an acronym that has no recognised meaning.

fields.headline: Executives warned to cut stress
fields.trailText: Company executives were yesterday urged by the Institute of Management to act on the pressures caused by excessive workloads before they move into the stress "danger zone".
fields.body:
Company executives were yesterday urged by the Institute of Management to act on the pressures caused by excessive workloads before they move into the stress "danger zone".

Almost half of 800 managers surveyed by the institute said they were unable to cope with their workloads and struggled to meet targets.

Workload pressures could easily turn to stress, which damaged performance at work as well as personal lives, the institute said.

Among the pressure points highlighted in the institute's report were poor senior management, office politics, and poor communication.

Most of the managers polled said they now had more responsibilities and heavier workloads than a year ago. The biggest problems were deadlines, constant interruptions, and incompetent senior managers. Most complained of tiredness, disturbed sleep, loss of temper, headaches and lowered sex drives.

Mary Chapman, the institute's director general, said: "For many [executives], unmanaged workplace pressures are leading to stress, with serious implications for the health and wealth of individuals and organisations.

"Leaders of organisations need to work with individuals to identify and deal with the root causes of stress and develop a healthier workplace culture."

fields.headline: Internet isolates, says Carey
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A warning that the internet is in danger of becoming a substitute for real relationships was made last night by the Archbishop of Canterbury.
fields.body:
A warning that the internet is in danger of becoming a substitute for real relationships was made last night by the Archbishop of Canterbury.

In the first public comment by a senior churchman on the new technology, George Carey told the audience at a lecture on citizenship in Liverpool: "Increasingly we are not only citizens of the world but also citizens of the worldwide web.

"Clearly access to information and the ability to tap resources not otherwise available can be a potent tool of empowerment. But it can also be exclusive and isolating."

The archbishop's intervention was his second in four days, following a weekend attack on the morality of public figures. Although he is an internet user himself and composes sermons on a laptop, Dr Carey voiced concerns about the risk of isolation and alienation among some computer enthusiasts. The speech was issued by Lambeth Palace as an email message.

Reminding his audience of the novelist EM Forster's famous phrase, "only connect", the archbishop said: "Forster had something more in mind than a PC with a modem. You may argue email can be a way of making important connections. That's true but it can also be a distorting and unsatisfactory one in which self-deception and evasion are prominent.

"The Christian emphasis is on relationships not just connections. Yes we have to make contact but it is the quality of that contact that matters. We must be sure that the virtual community is at the service of real communities, not a substitute for them. It must be a tool for inclusion, not a weapon for exclusion."

Dr Carey also spoke warmly of recent contacts the church had had with government ministers concerning moves to repeal clause 28.

Senior Anglicans have had private meetings with ministers to secure a modified statutory framework ensuring the promotion of family values if the clause, forbidding the "promotion" of homosexuality, is to be repealed.

Signalling a tacit acceptance that the clause will be repealed, church leaders including Dr Carey and the Roman Catholic archbishop-elect of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, have called for children to be given a moral framework based on the family, enshrined in law.

Dr Carey said: "Strong support should be given to promoting marriage as the fundamental building block of family life.

"I am pleased that ministers have been prepared to listen carefully to our views and priorities in considering a statutory framework for future guidance to schools."

fields.headline: Councils investigate staff benefit fraud
fields.trailText: Three Scottish local authorities are the focus of inquiries into allegations that scores of council staff have been falsely claiming hundreds of thousands of pounds in benefits.
fields.body:
Three Scottish local authorities are the focus of inquiries into allegations that scores of council staff have been falsely claiming hundreds of thousands of pounds in benefits.

Up to 80 staff and former staff of Glasgow city council face prosecution over alleged fraudulent claims worth more than £500,000.

A separate investigation at East Dunbartonshire council has uncovered 50 cases of irregular benefit claims worth around £90,000, and inquiries are under way at North Lanarkshire council into alleged fraud.

The investigations are part of joint effort by the benefits agency and the local authorities to crack down on housing and council tax benefits fraud by council workers.

In Glasgow 18 employees are facing internal disciplinary action, although no one has yet been suspended, a council spokeswoman said yesterday.

The benefits agency, which can refer cases straight to the procurator fiscal recommending criminal prosecutions, said even more cases could come to light.

A spokeswoman said. "We have still got more records to check. All the cases will be considered for prosecution; it depends on individual circumstances."

Glasgow council, the biggest in Scotland, said 80 full- and part-time staff may have been involved in fraudulent claims over the past seven years. The investigation involved checking the council's payroll records against its own and the benefits agency's payment information.

Most alleged fraud claims were for income support, incapacity benefit or job seeker's allowance, said a spokesman. Many were for full housing benefit or council tax benefit.

Jimmy Andrews, the council's chief executive, said: "We are one of the biggest employers in Scotland, with over 36,000 staff, and unfortunately it is a fact of life that a small number of employees are wrongly claiming money from the state or the council. That means less money for services."

A spokesman for East Dunbartonshire council said 14 staff were likely to be prosecuted, and other cases were under investigation.

fields.headline: £700,000 award over building works bungle
fields.trailText: A woman who lost her home and career and was declared bankrupt in a 12-year legal battle over renovations to her flat had a damages award of more than £700,000 approved by the court of appeal yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who lost her home and career and was declared bankrupt in a 12-year legal battle over renovations to her flat had a damages award of more than £700,000 approved by the court of appeal yesterday.

The life of Kathleen Saigol, a television producer, had been ruined by the wrangle over work to the flat in south Kensington, London, Lord Justice Otton said.

The managing agents, Congreve Horner and Co, who were ordered to pay her £713,644 damages, are to challenge her claim to an estimated £1.6m in legal costs at the appeal court and are seeking to take the case to the House of Lords. The builders Cosmur Construction (London) Ltd were ordered last year to pay her £91,249 and were not involved in yesterday's appeal.

The judge, sitting with Lord Justice Buxton and Lady Justice Hale, told how Mrs Saigol, 50, who is divorced, had been comfortable with £100,000 in savings, £200,000 in capital and a £50,000 a year income to look after her two sons.

She decided to spend £130,000 on renovations to her flat, valued at £475,000 in 1987. She had been advised that the work, planned to take six months, would increase its value by at least £250,000.

"As a result of the gross incompetence of those responsible for the refurbishment of the block of flats, and her flat in particular, her life has been ruined," the judge said.

"She suffered severe and continuing damage to her health, the indignity of bankruptcy, 11 years of litigation, a disrupted family life, a nomadic existence, loss of her home and her professional career. This state of affairs should never have come about."

Mrs Saigol - "the central figure in this tragic saga" - lived in the largest of seven flats in an Edwardian block with her sons, Matthew, then 17, and Pasha, seven.

The residents obtained the freehold and formed a company, Cranley Mansion Ltd. They decided to go ahead with structural refurbishment including a new roof, a new lift, repair of external brickwork and eradication of dry rot.

Mrs Saigol was liable for 19% of the cost of the works. In addition she had plans drawn up for a new roof terrace, roof lantern light, new windows, rewiring and new plumbing. She arranged loans with Dunbar Bank, of £400,000, and a smaller sum from Lloyds Bank.

webTitle: IRA is 'playing poker' Mandelson tells US

fields.headline: IRA is 'playing poker' Mandelson tells US
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday accused the IRA of playing poker with the crumbling peace process, as George Mitchell expressly ruled out a return to try to save the Good Friday agreement.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington  and John Mullin
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday accused the IRA of playing poker with the crumbling peace process, as George Mitchell expressly ruled out a return to try to save the Good Friday agreement.

The Northern Ireland secretary met the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and Sandy Berger, a national security adviser, in Washington. He echoed the call by the Irish government for the IRA to declare its war over, again holding out the prospect of faster demilitarisation if progress were made on decommissioning.

Mr Mandelson said: "If decommissioning is the IRA's last card, I wish they would stop playing poker with the Northern Ireland's democracy, its peace and prosperity."

He is not alone in his propaganda offensive in the US. The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, had already met Mr Berger, while Sinn Fein chief negotiator Martin McGuinness is in Washington today.

Mr Mandelson said that 26 army bases had been closed and patrols were down by two-thirds; the 15,000 troops on operational duty were fewer than at any time since 1970. "I can and will go further, if politics is working and the real security threat, including from dissidents, allows me to do so. Progress on decommissioning is in itself an ingredient in assessing that threat."

He emphasised that implementation of other reforms in the agreement would continue: the human rights commission, the equality commission, and implementation of Chris Patten's proposals on the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

Mr Mitchell has told President Bill Clinton and the British and Irish governments he will not return to Northern Ireland. He said yesterday: "While I remain deeply committed to the people there, I have been involved nearly five years and I simply have to devote some time to my family and my business." He refused to blame either side for the crisis, saying it would only make things more difficult.
