webTitle: Corrupt CPS clerk 'was in fear for life'

fields.headline: Corrupt CPS clerk 'was in fear for life'
fields.trailText: A clerk in the crown prosecution service told a jury yesterday he took money to reveal intelligence on "a notorious and feared" criminal family because he and his fiancée were threatened.
fields.body:
A clerk in the crown prosecution service told a jury yesterday he took money to reveal intelligence on "a notorious and feared" criminal family because he and his fiancée were threatened.

Mark Herbert, 31, a policeman's son who played rugby for London Welsh, said he was warned by the Adams family "do not mess about".

At the Old Bailey he said he was also told: "They want to be your friends... You don't want to upset them." He passed over case details and a list of informants. He said the family had wanted the list "because it was useful to plug any gaps in leaked intelligence".

Asked by his counsel, Andrew Trollope QC, why he did it, Herbert said: "Because of the fear I was in. They knew where my fiancée lived. They would take drastic measures against us if I refused them.

"If I was not an asset, I would be a liability."

The prosecution alleges Herbert abused his position out of arrogance and greed. At the time, 1998, he was working on a legal team dealing with investigations into the London-based Adams family, Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, had told the court. Herbert yesterday agreed that by handing over the material he was in breach of the law and had created unknown risks to others.

He told the court a "Gypsy looking" man approached him and talked to him about his fiancée, Sian Williams, and where she lived in Swansea. When he asked whether the man was a friend of hers, he was told they had a mutual friend - Terry Adams.

Herbert, from Twickenham in west London, and Kevin Sumer, 41, a nightclub door manager from Brentford in Middlesex, deny a joint charge of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. Herbert alone denies corruption - a £500 bribe. He also denies two charges of disclosing information without lawful authority, for which Sumer is accused of aiding and abetting.

The prosecution has alleged the Adams and their associates formed a feared organisation "steeped in the highest levels of criminal activity".

Herbert, while working at the prosecution's headquarters in central London, copied computer files and passed them to Sumer, who gave them to Billy Isaacs, a man allegedly connected to the family.

Herbert was allegedly in debt and moonlighted as a nightclub bouncer in addition to his £14,000-a-year post. He was taken on by Sumer, the court had heard, who learned where he worked. Herbert got payments of £500 cash as well as his doorman's wages.

He told the court: "I had to keep the money, for fear of upsetting Sumer."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Abused children 'being left to suffer'
fields.standfirst:
The issue explained: Children in care
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: Social workers have reacted furiously to claims by doctors that they are leaving children to be repeatedly abused in order to produce sufficient evidence that they should be taken into care.
fields.body:
Social workers have reacted furiously to claims by doctors that they are leaving children to be repeatedly abused in order to produce sufficient evidence that they should be taken into care.

The claims are made today in an attack on the children act by two leading paediatricians who say that the legislation, and its interpretation by social workers, have set back the battle against child abuse.

In an article in the Archives of Disease in Childhood, published by the British Medical Association, the paediatricians Nigel Speight and Jane Wynne say: "Most paediatricians we have approached who have a special commitment to child protection work admit feelings of near despair about the state of child protection in this country."

Social work leaders have described the criticism as "outrageous" and the doctors' analysis as "deeply flawed". The department of health said the act was working well overall.

The children act became law in 1989, and took effect in 1990, as part of an overhaul of the child protection system following the Cleveland child abuse controversy.

Dr Wynne, of Leeds general infirmary, was caught up in the controversy as a co-inventor of the anal dilation test that was used by Cleveland doctors to diagnose sexual abuse and trigger the removal of children from their families.

Dr Wynne and Dr Speight, of Dryburn hospital in Durham, point out that the number of children taken into care dropped by a third, from 60,000 to 40,000, between 1991 and 1995.

The doctors say it is unlikely that abused and neglected children were being taken into care unnecessarily before 1991, or that there was an improvement in preventive and therapeutic work that produced such a dramatic effect over the following four years.

The reality, they say, is that the act has shifted the emphasis of child protection towards keeping the family unit together. The swift intervention possible before 1990 has been replaced by "a leisurely assessment process with the child still in the abusive home".

Because the act requires a higher standard of proof of abuse, moreover, "social workers feel they have to let the child be re-abused to show the judge ... that they are only having recourse to legal proceedings as a last resort."

The doctors admit that their argument is deliberately unbalanced as a way of stimulating debate. In one case study, they described how a three-year-old girl was left for six months in an abusive home, despite signs "heavily suggestive" of penetrative anal abuse, before the local authority's solicitor agreed there was sufficient evidence to test in court.

Criticising the idea that social workers should work with abusive or neglectful parents, the paediatricians say: "You do not enter into partnership with criminals during the investigation of a crime until the crime has stopped and the criminal has confessed and expressed remorse."

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said social work had been "overly adversarial" before 1990 and there should be no return to the practices of those days.

She said that before the children act the principle reasons for taking children into care were behavioural difficulties and family problems.

The health department said: "Rigorous inspection, audits and research carried out through the 1990s show that the children act, in largest part, is serving children well. The act's supporting regulations and guidance are constantly being reviewed."

fields.headline: If the cap fits
fields.standfirst:
Prince meets young homeless in Caribbean

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles had a taste of this yesterday when he met street children  at a refuge centre in Trinidad's capital, Port of Spain.
fields.byline: Matt Wells in Trinidad and Tobago
fields.body:
Away from the white beaches and the coconut palms, the Caribbean way of life is not always idyllic.

Prince Charles had a taste of this yesterday when he met street children at a refuge centre in Trinidad's capital, Port of Spain. In between the smiles and joking, he heard some harrowing stories. He spoke to Neil (not his real name), a nine-year-old who had been abused by his grandmother when younger. Neil, the prince was told, had run away to the centre three times, but staff were legally obliged to return him to his family. Police beat him up when he went to them for help.

Sister Roberta O'Flaherty, a nun from Dublin who runs the Credo Centre, said that only now had she been able to secure the legal papers to allow Neil to remain at the centre for homeless children. "He is doing very well with us now," she said .

Her centre has received funding from British Gas Trinidad and Tobago, and it paid for the playground visited by the prince yesterday.

Since it was founded in 1997 by the Credo Foundation for Justice and the Holy Faith Sisters, the centre has taken 150 children off the streets of Port of Spain, giving them a basic education and, where possible, reintegrating them into their families.

As Prince Charles looked round, the children presented him with a baseball cap, which he accepted enthusiastically. He put it on back to front - just like Prince William in Canada a few years ago - but quickly took it off again. "It's too small," he joked to the boys.

The prince later flew from Trinidad to its sister island Tobago, where he visited the parliamentary assembly in the capital, Scarborough. He talked to assembly members, including Carlyle Dick, representing the Speyside district. "That's a very good name," the prince said when introduced, warming to a Highlands link.

On the prince's arrival in Trinidad on Monday to tour Commonwealth territories in the Caribbean, the president of the two island nation, Arthur Robinson, had presented him with a silver chalice given by the assembly in 1795 to the island's first lieutenant governor. The governor's descendants had sent the chalice for auction in London in 1982; President Robinson had himself paid £2,500 to rescue it.

Yesterday the prince officially returned the chalice to the assembly, where it will be on permanent display.

webTitle: Stanley Matthews, English football's mesmerising winger, dies at 85

fields.headline: Stanley Matthews, English football's mesmerising winger, dies at 85
fields.standfirst:
Frank Keating remembers the Wizard of Dribble
The Matthews story
Obituary
Tributes
fields.trailText: Football mourned the loss of one of its most brilliant sons last night following the death of Sir Stanley Matthews, at a private hospital near his home in Stoke-on-Trent.
fields.body:
Football mourned the loss of one of its most brilliant sons last night following the death of Sir Stanley Matthews, at a private hospital near his home in Stoke-on-Trent.

The news of the death of one of football's greatest wingers, who became a legend during a playing career that spanned 33 years, came hours before England's friendly against Argentina at Wembley last night.

Both teams wore black arm bands for the match and a minute's silence was held before kick-off.

Sir Stanley, 85, a former Stoke City, Blackpool and England winger who was twice a European footballer of the year, was admitted to the North Staffordshire Nuffield hospital last week after suffering a fall at his holiday home in Tenerife, Spain.

Pélé once described him as the man who could show us how football should be played, and he is still considered one of the greatest players ever to grace professional football, where he became known for his mesmerising dribbling skills.

His biographer, Peter Buxton, a retired sports editor who covered Sir Stanley's halcion days as a Stoke City player, said: "Sir Stan really was a living legend. He stood for everything that was good in sport."

Newcastle boss Bobby Robson said: "He had immense skill - a beautiful dribbler."

David Davies, chairman of the Football Association, said: "He was a great ambassador. He served football all over the world long after most players packed it in."

Sir Bobby Charlton said: "I loved Sir Stanley. Magic, absolutely magical player."

Sir Stanley, who played until he was 50, later turned his hand to management with Port Vale, and was renowned for his fitness. He jogged every morning and would fast on one day a week.

But two years ago he suffered a heart attack. His wife Mila, who died last year, said then the trouble was he still thought he was 55.

fields.headline: Listeria scare over pork tongue
fields.trailText: The government yesterday issued a health warning after an outbreak of listeria in France resulted in seven deaths. The virus is believed to come from fresh refrigerated pork tongue in jelly which has been produced in France.
fields.body:
The government yesterday issued a health warning after an outbreak of listeria in France resulted in seven deaths. The virus is believed to come from fresh refrigerated pork tongue in jelly which has been produced in France.

The department of health warned: "As a precautionary measure, the public should not consume pork tongue in jelly that has been bought or produced in France."

So far, 23, cases of the virus have been detected across France, seven of which have been fatal. Two-thirds of those affected are reported to have eaten pork tongue in jelly and laboratory tests indicated this was the single source of the outbreak, a department spokesman said.

He added that although there was at present no evidence to implicate any spe cific company, one French company, Sapar, had recalled production of various meat products, including pork tongues in jelly, because of listeria contamination.

It is not thought that these products are widely distributed in the UK. But the department of health spokesman advised that meat products sold under the brand names of Sapar, Antoine Auge or Delice de Suzon should not be consumed.

So far, 23, cases of the virus have been detected across France, seven of which have been fatal. Two-thirds of those affected are reported to have eaten pork tongue in jelly and laboratory tests indicated this was the single source of the outbreak, a department spokesman said. He added that although there was at present no evidence to implicate any spe cific company, one French company, Sapar, had recalled production of various meat products, including pork tongues in jelly, because of listeria contamination. It is not thought that these products are widely distributed in the UK. But the department of health spokesman advised that meat products sold under the brand names of Sapar, Antoine Auge or Delice de Suzon should not be consumed.

webTitle: Work in progress: Matt Lucas, actor

fields.headline: Work in progress: Matt Lucas, actor
fields.trailText: In my last columnette I wrote about my role in the Oxford Stage Company's production of Troilus And Cressida, currently on tour (tickets still available at all prices!), and wondered how I would be able to adapt to the life of an actor, having spent the majority of my career either behind a desk or a drumkit.
fields.body:
In my last columnette I wrote about my role in the Oxford Stage Company's production of Troilus And Cressida, currently on tour (tickets still available at all prices!), and wondered how I would be able to adapt to the life of an actor, having spent the majority of my career either behind a desk or a drumkit.

Well, the truth is I'm having a lovely old time. I was unaware however, when accepting the job, that the cast would be required to take part in a post-show discussion with the audience at each venue. Last week, it was Warwick Arts Centre, situated on the university campus.

Therefore, tired as ever, following a three-hour performance (of which we give eight a week), I found myself, glass of whisky in hand, sitting on a chair alongside a dozen or so actors (some of whom were smoking, in that brilliant "we're on stage, we can smoke, you're in the audience, you can't" way pioneered in episodes of Parkinson in the 70s).

Now, in the play I don't wear my glasses, and the lights shine in my eyes anyway, so I can never see the audience. I also appear in character, rather than as my dull self. Anyway, there on stage we sat, with the lights on in the auditorium, looking out at maybe 30 stragglers spread out over the vast 600 seater, each waiting impatiently to show off their knowledge of Shakespeare. And I could stomach this. Just. And I clenched my fists as I listened to myself, speaking sensitively and intelligently about "the text".

But when, half an hour in, an old man - sitting with his beleaguered wife - silently, desperately, slid his hand into a crisp packet, popped one in his mouth and began to SUCK, I'm afraid I lost it. Big time. But the discussion did not stop. And no one else was laughing. Just me. I shook. I rocked. I sweated. I snorted. I howled. And nobody said a word. Now, I may have been unforgivably unprofessional and embarrassed myself something rotten, but at least no one can ever accuse me of sucking crisps.

fields.headline: Pupils back abused teacher
fields.trailText: Five hundred pupils at Kingswood high school, Hull, yesterday demanded that a suspended teacher who was racially abused by a pupil should be allowed to return to work.
fields.body:
Five hundred pupils at Kingswood high school, Hull, yesterday demanded that a suspended teacher who was racially abused by a pupil should be allowed to return to work.

Chris Hassan, a mixed-race English teacher at the school, faces a disciplinary hearing that could cost him his job after being suspended last month for refusing to teach a pupil who had called him a "black maggot".

The 12-year-old boy was suspended for three days over the incident, but since returning to school is understood to have been suspended again, and allowed to return once more, after physically assaulting a teacher.

Mr Hassan asked that the boy be transferred to another class on his return from the original suspension, but his request was refused. When he was not removed from the class, Mr Hassan refused to teach him.

"I never said the boy should be excluded, just that he should be moved to another class," he said. "That's quite common practice. But the head said no, you teach him or else. He didn't seem to think being racially abused was anything serious. He said if the kid had said I had been bald or fat, I would have thought nothing of it."

Mr Hassan has been suspended for four weeks and is awaiting a disciplinary hearing before the school's governors next month.

Yesterday, more than 500 of the school's 800 pupils handed in a petition to the City of Kingston upon Hull education authority, demanding Mr Hassan's return. The petition comes after earlier demonstrations at the school when 70 pupils paraded placards supporting their teacher.

Mr Hassan said the backing of pupils at the school was "absolutely fantastic". He added: "I knew nothing about this. Most of the pupils have signed the petition and I'm told some of the support staff at the school as well."

fields.headline: Sleazy pickings
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: You can't blame Gary Mavers for wanting to be evil; four years of playing decent, honest Dr Andrew in Peak Practice is enough to make anyone run naked down the high street. Which is more or less what he did in ITV's Blue Murder : within the first half hour Mavers had taken his clothes off so many times that we could be in no doubt that this was an "erotic thriller".
fields.body:
You can't blame Gary Mavers for wanting to be evil; four years of playing decent, honest Dr Andrew in Peak Practice is enough to make anyone run naked down the high street. Which is more or less what he did in ITV's Blue Murder : within the first half hour Mavers had taken his clothes off so many times that we could be in no doubt that this was an "erotic thriller".

Mavers, as Detective Sergeant Adam Ross, started off as a standard-issue semi-bent copper, taking bribes to pacify his lap-dancing ex-girlfriend, but as soon as he met femme très fatale Gale (Jemma Redgrave) he embraced crime with a passion. Gale and Adam went to it hammer and tongs: all she had to do was smoulder a little and he was ripping off his shirt and hopping on. And if that wasn't enough, Mavers took a gratuitous shower, got pounced on by at least two other women and showed his bottom not once but twice. Let's face it, that's just not going to happen in Peak Practice.

Mavers played the confused, horny hunk rather well, which is a relief, as Blue Murder was posited entirely on the thesis that he is a major sex god. The wicked Gale bamboozled him into murdering her abusive husband, secure (she thought) in the knowledge that Adam himself would lead the investigation. But they hadn't reckoned on plucky, intuitive Detective Constable Vanessa Barlow (Emma Cunniffe) who saw through Gale's story and nearly got killed for her troubles. Gale persuaded superstud Adam to seduce the pesky plod, working on the theory that a woman in love is less likely to solve grisly murders than a thwarted spinster.

Blue Murder had all the trappings of modern ITV crime dramas: gorgeous urban locations (they even managed to make Adam's block of flats, actually situated in Elephant and Castle, look attractive), wet streets reflecting neon lights, and the inevitable pole-dancing club. Once the plot got underway - and it took a while - it was gripping stuff with a vicious sting in the tale. Redgrave, also tasting freedom after the straitjacket of medical drama (Bramwell), attacked her role with a carnivorous relish, dispatching her spent lover to a suitably bloody death. There was one moment of high, tongue-in-cheek comedy: Emma Cunniffe had just established her character's feminist credentials in a heartfelt speech about women who keep taking off their clothes in order to further their careers - and lo, within a minute Mavers was once again naked and furthering his career.

Channel 4's profile of The Real Lena Zavaroni formed a heartbreaking centrepiece to the Trouble With Food season. Lena was only 10 when she won Opportunity Knocks, left her home on the Scottish island of Bute and became a star in London. It's easy to forget how big a star she was: for the next six years she was on TV practically all the time, while in America she hobnobbed with President Ford and Frank Sinatra. The enduring image is of an irritating little girl in knee socks making stagey leers at the camera, but on the evidence of last night's show Zavaroni was maturing into a considerable artist when illness struck. Anorexia nervosa kicked in during her teens, and by 1979 the cute little minipop was a haunted waif. Thenceforth there was no reprieve. She retired in the early 80s and set about destroying herself, while her friends and family looked on, helpless. By the mid-90s she weighed three-and-a-half stone and looked like a Belsen victim.

It's tempting to blame the pressures of juvenile stardom for Zavaroni's illness, and it's true that she worked hard: agent and manager Dorothy Solomon recalled that she would never say no to work. But the problems, it seems, lay far deeper than that; towards the end, Zavaroni was a haunted figure, desperate for surgery to cut the demons out of her brain. She died last year, of a chest infection, three weeks after her operation.

For all the horrors of Zavaroni's mental and physical collapse, the biggest revelation of the night was the magnitude of her talent. Those of us who remember her as a kitsch joke, belting out Ma! (He's Making Eyes at Me) in those awful Shirley Temple dresses, would be surprised by the maturity that she brought to tragic showbiz-is-rough ballad Going Nowhere, performed on her own TV show in 1981. The pain in her voice, and in her eyes, was unbearable.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The BBC's dissection of a thousand years of spoken English has delved into dialect, etymology, cursing and split infinitives. Now Susan Sharpe examines that rarely considered linguistic essential in A History Of The Voice (11.30am, Radio 4). The way we use our vocal cords carries as much social baggage as our accent and grammar, though it's not always wholly within our control. Apparently the mere shape of the Neanderthal jaw ensured that, drunk or sober, they could never have pronounced "the Leith police".
fields.body:
The BBC's dissection of a thousand years of spoken English has delved into dialect, etymology, cursing and split infinitives. Now Susan Sharpe examines that rarely considered linguistic essential in A History Of The Voice (11.30am, Radio 4). The way we use our vocal cords carries as much social baggage as our accent and grammar, though it's not always wholly within our control. Apparently the mere shape of the Neanderthal jaw ensured that, drunk or sober, they could never have pronounced "the Leith police".

The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) later comes as an educational counterbalance. Since this is World Mathematical Year, Professors Keith Moffatt and Ian Stewart trawl back to Pythagoras and Archimedes to assess how the Greeks' pioneering insights still inform modern maths. In a world where even the best-educated people remain semi-numerate, the two academics debate the future of their calling.

fields.headline: Goodbye to all tat
fields.standfirst: The cast hated each other, the acting was atrocious, and the plotlines made no sense at all. But, now it's been pulled off-air, Beverly Hills 90210 will be sorely missed.  John Patterson salutes the memory of trash TV's finest hour.
fields.trailText: Ah, the mid 90s... A young Chris Farley taught us how to laugh, an ageing OJ Simpson taught us how to drive, and the citizens of Los Angeles taught us how to sack a city. Travelgate hadn't quite died down, Bubba Clinton had only just fired his $200-a-do hairdresser Christophe, and Paula Corbin Jones was still firmly attached to her old nose.
fields.body:
Ah, the mid 90s... A young Chris Farley taught us how to laugh, an ageing OJ Simpson taught us how to drive, and the citizens of Los Angeles taught us how to sack a city. Travelgate hadn't quite died down, Bubba Clinton had only just fired his $200-a-do hairdresser Christophe, and Paula Corbin Jones was still firmly attached to her old nose.

After a miserable recession at the turn of the decade, the economy was rising phoenix-like from the toilet, and good times were just around the corner. Ahead lay scandal, outrage, rancid glamour, conspicuous consumption, and the swift and steady lowering of the general public's shockability threshold.

And that was just in politics and current affairs. An era like this, however, needed its ur-cultural product, its primetime TV equivalent to the real-life filth and fury erupting at the top of every hour on CNN. The man who beamingly stepped up and provided it was Aaron Spelling. The show was high-school soap opera Beverly Hills 90210, now finally cancelled by Fox.

Considered washed up in 1990, Spelling had in the previous 35 years brokered dozens of shotgun-weddings between TV glamour and TV trash, between beauty and bullshit, out there at the crossroads of high-class and tits-and-ass. There was always a great dumbshit hook to hang Spelling's shows on: Mod Squad basically tamed hippies and juvenile delinquents and made them palatable to the 68 audience that had just voted Nixon into office. Starsky and Hutch was blaxploitation for white folks (ie no black names above the credits, please) with a sideways nod to the emerging gay market, intentionally or not (I always assumed David Soul and Paul Michael Glaser slept innocently in the same bed, like Laurel and Hardy). Charlie's Angels (half copped from Ted V Mikkels' rotten 1974 drive-in movie The Doll Squad) was kung-fu hotties in halter-tops. Dynasty was soap on amphetamine overdrive with a movie-sized budget and yards of cleavage, while Hart To Hart was a soulless Thin Man update, with glammy, married private dicks.

But 90210 was a little different. Spelling was brought in by Barry Diller, a graduate of Beverly Hills High who'd always wanted to set a TV show there. Having worked in Beverly Hills for several years in the 90s, I can assure you that the school's parking lot - thronging with surgically altered 16-year-olds driving Lexuses and HumVees, half of them on mood-stabilising medication - is one of LA's most disturbing alternative tourist attractions. Spelling, once Diller's boss, now his underling, was much taken by the idea and hired the true architect of 90210, writer Darren Star, a 28-year-old UCLA graduate who, in Spelling's words, "knew teenagers".

Quite what the teenagers of Beverly Hills, with their liberal parents, ocean-deep trust funds and Rodeo Drive threads, had in common with the teenagers of say, Compton, was always hard to discern. Perhaps that was the point, though, because within a year the stars of the show, especially male leads Luke Perry and Jason Priestley, were being mobbed at malls across the nation (with Perry once having to be smuggled out of a fan-stampede in a laundry hamper).

Once the second season was under way and the show moved into its classic incarnation, the cast received America's greatest unofficial accolade. In any mall or drive-in, at any prom or cheerleader audition in America between 1992 and 1995, one could see only six hair-cuts, all of them previously sported by 90210 cast members.

Appropriately for a show that styled itself as scandalous and in-your-face, the cast members proved to be tabloid catnip, particularly Shannen Doherty, who was fired after a catalogue of bratty onset misdemeanours (the words "bitch" and "late" featured prominently in unattributed quotes from her colleagues) and whose career went south immediately thereafter, in a cloud of court cases and anger-management programmes. Goodie-goodie Jason Priestley had to endure headlines about heroin ODs (false) and drunk driving (true). Spelling's daughter Tori had to deal with accusations of nepotism and rumours of massive taxiderminological intervention in the chest and cheekbone regions. Jenny Garth and Iain Zeiring, meanwhile, only had to cope with rumours that they were too useless to find better jobs.

No one was a 90210 fan for the whole 10 years. For me, the glory years were 1994 to 1996. Although I must have seen 60 episodes in that time, I find I'm pressed to recollect a single concrete plot detail. By then Shannen was history, replaced as top bad girl by the insanely voluptuous Tiffani-Amber Thiessen, the best scheming tramp of the whole Spelling-Star universe. I never watched it for plot anyway. I watched to see if my desire to strangle Jenny Garth or beat up Iain Zeiring would ever subside. I was more interested in whether Tiffani-Amber had managed to eat the entire desert-trolley at Spago the night before filming (one of the great unmonitored phenomena in US TV is the rate at which ingenue stars, male and female, pile on the pounds in season two, after years of starving at auditions). I wanted to know why the fatter and wickeder she got, the sexier she seemed. I wanted to know it all, and now I remember almost nothing.

Which is exactly the point. Beverly Hills 90210 was the greatest Chinese-food TV show of all time. 20 minutes after you'd consumed it, you forgot you'd ever done so. May it live forever more in reruns.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Naked Spur
fields.body:
The Naked Spur

(Anthony Mann, 1953)

9pm, TCM

One of the fine westerns Mann made with James Stewart, in which the physical action is matched by the hero's inner struggle. Stewart plays a bounty hunter bringing Robert Ryan's sneering villain to justice, through rocky Colorado locations; but on the way he is forced to reassess his own motivations.

Devil's Advocate

(Taylor Hackford, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Keanu Reeves is hotshot lawyer Kevin Lomax, who gets an offer he can't refuse: to earn mega-bucks working for a big New York firm. His boss is one John Milton (there's clue one) and he's played by devilish Al Pacino (there's clue two). Yep, it's Satan himself, and soon the company's dark dealings are making even greedy Kevin sit up and blink. Has he sold his soul, or merely leased it? More daft than dark, the whole project is as enjoyably over-the-top as Pacino's cackling, mad-eyed demon.

Safe

(Todd Haynes, 1995)

12.30am, FilmFour

The plot is mundane: well-heeled housewife Carol (Julianne Moore) falls victim of a mystery ailment eventually diagnosed as an environmental illness - an allergy to the chemical pollution of modern life - and retreats to a new age health farm. And yet her journey from vacuous Stepford Wife to a painfully vulnerable glimmer of self-awareness is riveting. Haynes's portrait of bourgeois meltdown in the San Fernando Valley has the cool, eerie detachment of a sci-fi thriller: The Andromeda Strain comes to mind.

(Michael Tolkin, 1994)

10pm, FilmFour

Peter Weller and Judy Davis are joyless Californian über -yuppies, long since grown to hate each other and openly conducting affairs. When Weller loses his ad agency job and Davis's company goes belly up, they begin to search for meaning via quick spiritual fixes from the hands of a series of dubious new-age guru characters, with predictably depressing results. But despite the intriguing premise and the quality of the acting, this film ends up as bleak as the lives of the people it satirises.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these actresses will replace one of the three female Friends characters?
fields.trailText: Which of these actresses will replace one of the three female Friends characters?
fields.body:
Neve Campbell 10/1

Shannen Doherty 12/1

Elle Macpherson 14/1

Cindy Crawford 25/1

Top-rated shows have survived the departure of beloved cast members before. Cheers pulled in the viewers after Shelley left, for example. But will the audiences be there for Friends without Mon, Rach, or Phebes? In the final months before their contract ends, NBC is in talks to triple their £600,000-an-episode pay packet. But Lisa Kudrow, Jennifer Aniston and Courteney Cox are all rumoured to be dropping Friends and concentrating on film projects.

"Rumours are rife over the departure of one, two or if you believe some of the media speculation, all three female members of Friends", confirms Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "But who would replace Rachel, Phoebe or Monica is a tough call."

"Elle Macpherson has been cast in Friends before, so that counts against her playing one of the lead characters, but at least we know the producers like her. She did faint recently, which suggests that the hectic timetable of filming may prove too much for her. I think she is an outsider in this race."

Shannen Doherty is another long shot, says Ed. "But she has had a bit of a resurgence of late thanks to a Kevin Smith film, Mall Rats and a role in Charmed. Those of us who remember her in Beverly Hills 90210 will be hoping she makes a comeback, but I doubt it."

"Neve Campbell is a name on everyone's lips - she has become a star in her own right, but grew up in the TV series Party Of Five. She has just worked with Matthew Perry in Three To Tango, and that relationship could help her. On the negative side she has said she thinks playing one character can be monotonous."

"Cindy Crawford has just joined ABC's Good Morning America as a special correspondent, and is interested in more TV work. Her model good looks and close showbusiness contacts could work in her favour."

fields.headline: One great leap for mankind
fields.standfirst: The date is February 24, making it leap year day. How come?  Duncan Steel explains
fields.trailText: The date is February 24, making it leap year day. How come? Duncan Steel explains
fields.body:
Everyone seems to think that the 29th is the extra day in a leap year, whereas it's really the 24th. That sounds bizarre, and indeed I am misleading you a little. But let me explain about leap years.

Ancient Egyptian astronomers knew that one extra day every four years was needed to keep the calendar in line with the heavens, and Ptolemy III decreed in 238 BC that this rule should be followed. But he was ignored.

Impressed by eastern astronomy while he dallied with Cleopatra, Julius Caesar employed an Egyptian to advise on the reformation of the Roman calendar and thus learnt of the quadrennial rule. In earlier times the Romans had used a calendar with only 355 days (10 too few), and a "leap month" inserted every so often: thus some years had a 13th month.

This followed February 23 or 24, which used to be the terminalia, the end of the the Roman year. But the slovenly application of the vague rules led to the Romans' dates becoming misaligned with the seasons. Julius Caesar fixed this by having 460 days in 46 BC. Thereafter one year in four was supposed to 366 days, the rest 365, all years possessing our familiar 12 months.

In fact after Julius Caesar was assassinated in 44 BC, the Senate got this wrong, having one year in three being leap, and it was not put straight until AD 8.

The Romans used an eight-day week (although they called it the nundinum which is clearly connected with nine), the days being marked off A, B,C etc up to H.

This habit was adopted by the Roman Catholic church for its ecclesiastical calendar. January 1 was always A and the days of the week were lettered up to G. That means that if the first day of the year was a Friday all Fridays in that year would be an A. The letter given to the first Sunday of the year gave the year what was called its dominical letter and from this, using a highly complex formula, the date of Easter could be calculated, a necessary task for the priests in the days before printed calendars were plentiful.

But this formula requires that March 1 is always D. How to achieve that in a leap year? The Church borrowed the Roman custom of counting February 24 and 25 as one day, using the same letter twice. So in a leap year, we leap one day.

Correctly a leap year is termed a bissextile year. The "bis" means "twice", while the "sextile" refers to "sixth". The sixth day counted (inclusively) back from March 1 is counted twice. This is what Julius Caesar decreed: that the extra day should be inserted where the Romans had previously placed an occasional extra month, but it should not be given a date of its own. Thus the days we regard as February 24 and 25 in a leap year were just one day to the Romans.

But does this apply to us? Definitely "yes and no". Confusion in early England led to a statute of Henry III in 1236 entitled De Anno Bissextili which stipulated that "the day of the leap year and the day before should be holden for one day".

That defined February 24 and 25, legally-speaking, as being a single day, although the statute is wrong in itself because the sextile day is the 24, so that it's the day after to which reference should have been made.

This is most easily seen in the liturgical calendar. In a common year February 24 is the feast day of St Matthias, but in a leap year it's the 25, and all the other saints' days are shifted onwards. That's a clear indication that the 24 is the day added.

I wrote earlier that I would mislead you a little, so now let me come clean. Pedantically, what I have described is truthful, but British lawmakers in the 18th century upset things. In 1751 an Act of Parliament was passed which brought Britain and her colonies in line with the Gregorian calendar used elsewhere. This Act was a total hash: it mis-defined the Easter computation - for anti-Catholic and anti-Semitic reasons - with the result that the rules stipulated have needed to be ignored, and the Easter dates simply copied from the tabulation of the Catholic Church.

Disregarding the origin of the bissextile day, the Act also declared that henceforth the day added should be considered to be February 29. An abomination, but that's what it says.

Legally, then, the 29 is the extra day. But historical truth shows that the bissextile day must be the 24. And maybe the 25, too.

 Duncan Steel teaches physics at the university of Salford. His book on calendar matters, Marking Time, is published by Wiley, New York.

webTitle: US space shuttle returns from 11-day mission to map the earth

fields.headline: US space shuttle returns from 11-day mission to map the earth
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: The space shuttle Endeavour and its six astronauts have returned from an earth-surveying mission that promises to yield the best maps to date of the world's peaks and valleys.
fields.body:
The space shuttle Endeavour and its six astronauts have returned from an earth-surveying mission that promises to yield the best maps to date of the world's peaks and valleys.

Glinting orange and pink from the setting sun, the shuttle became visible four minutes before touchdown on Tuesday.

"I guess we put on a fairly nice show where folks could see us from pretty far out," commander Kevin Kregel said after emerging from Endeavour. "It was even better from inside."

Gusty winds across the runway kept the astronauts up for an extra orbit and delayed their homecoming by one and a half hours.

During their 11-day flight, the astronauts worked in shifts to keep two large radar antennae running all the time - one in the shuttle cargo bay and one on the end of a 59m (197-ft) mast. The method is expected to produce precise three-dimensional maps of the earth's topography.

The radar mapped 43.5m sq miles of earth's terrain at least twice, 2.5m sq miles shy of Nasa's original goal. The surveyed land, three-quarters of the world's terrain, stretched as far north as British Columbia and as far south as Cape Horn.

A faulty thruster forced the crew to use extra shuttle fuel to steady the mast, the longest rigid structure ever deployed in space, cutting short the mapping by 13 hours.

"I thought this mission was one of the most challenging, difficult missions we ever undertook," said Daniel Goldin, a Nasa administrator.

Within three hours of touchdown, technicians had unloaded the 326 digital tapes containing the radar data - enough to fill 20,600 compact discs.

"We're really going to baby these things, obviously, because they're our crown jewels," said Michael Kobrick, the laboratory scientist in charge of the project.

Nasa and its partner, the national imagery and mapping agency, expect it will take one to two years to analyse the tapes. The best maps will be reserved for the military.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Nanometer wheels | Walking and chewing
fields.body:
Small and going nowhere fast
Professor Jim Gimzewski, of IBM Research in Zurich, has reinvented the wheel on a nanometer scale. He had been trying to make a switch, and ended with a wheel a few molecules across instead. It doesn't turn anything, he told, the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting in Washington DC. "I really don't care," he said. "The idea is we that try to build it, right? Forget the theory, build it, because I expect the fun in nanotechnology will be the things... The things we know are not that interesting to me. It is what we don't know. This device is an experiment, OK? We make the machine and we see what does this machine do? It may do something totally different, but it will do something. And unless we make it we will never get anywhere."

The dilatory two-step
Former President Lyndon Johnson once said cruelly of former President Gerald Ford that he could not walk and chew gum at the same time. Robert Adair of Yale examined the classic problem at the AAAS meeting. "While it is possible for most of us to chew gum and walk at the same time - two unrelated patterns," he said, "and we can decide to modify either pattern and walk differently - in a goose step? - or chew gum differently - blow bubbles - it is much harder to change both patterns simultaneously. It is surprisingly difficult to walk in some specific, unfamiliar, non-automatic manner, simultaneously," he said.

How the wet was won
The interior may be enormous, but the US is a maritime power, according to Donald Boesch of the university of Maryland. He told the conference that the US had 95,000 miles of coastline and 3.4 million square miles of territorial waters. In 1996, around $590bn worth of goods went through US ports. America was the fifth largest fishing nation and the third largest seafood exporter. One job in six was somehow marine-related. Around 53% lived on the 17% of the land classed as coastal. Sea levels were rising and some coasts were sinking: by the end of the 21st century the sea level in Chesapeake Bay would have risen by 3ft.

Faraway look in his eye
The future isn't what it used to be. Michael Marien, editor of the Futures Survey, told the AAAS that he estimated that non-fiction, futures-relevant books were being published in English at the rate of 1,000 a year. His French counterpart at Futuribles in Paris calculated 300 such titles in French. The editor of Pro Zukunft based in Salzburg guessed at 400-500 such books in German. But the numbers appeared to have been declining since Marien began publishing Futures Survey in 1979, he said. Not only was there a decline in quantity, he suspected one in quality. "I hold it only as a hypothesis, sensing that, in a world widely assumed to be ever more complex and dynamic, our grasp of it may well be weakening, as we retreat to our scholarly niches."

fields.headline: Fossil ruffles feathers
fields.standfirst: A hoax has helped the cause of a small band of scientists who deny that dinosaurs and birds are related. But, argues  Henry Gee,  they are still arrogant and wrong
fields.trailText: A hoax has helped the cause of a small band of scientists who deny that dinosaurs and birds are related. But, argues Henry Gee, they are still arrogant and wrong
fields.body:
The world of fossils is in a flap again about birds. The feathers started flying in 1995 when Chinese palaeontologists announced the discovery of Sinosauropteryx, a chicken-sized dinosaur with feathers. Since then, four more feathered dinosaurs have been scientifically described, all from fossil-rich sediments laid down 124 million years ago in Liaoning province, north of Beijing.

But the feathers really hit the fan with the discovery that Archaeoraptor, a Chinese fossil with the body of the bird and the tail of a dinosaur, is a fake: a collage of a birdlike front end and a dinosaur's long tail, not unearthed by scientists but bought in a rock show in the United States [see The Guardian, February 7, 2000: Nature February 17, 2000, pp689-670]. Archaeoraptor has not been described scientifically: but the fact that it achieved celebrity at all (in an article in National Geographic) is an embarrassment, particularly as it gives ammunition to a small but vocal group of scientists that stands against the current consensus that birds and dinosaurs are close relatives.

This group, known in the bone trade as the Band (Birds Are Not Dinosaurs), has generated most of the controversy. But the fact remains that their views are wrong and were wrong long before the first feathered dinosaur reared its head from the fossil beds of China.

The hypothesis that birds and dinosaurs are close relatives is not Holy Writ, just the best idea we have given the evidence. It is possible that, one day, evidence might support the Band's view that birds are most closely related to extinct, lizard-like reptiles that lived in the Triassic Period, around 220 million years ago, long before the dinosaurs got going.

The Band has not marshalled such evidence, but that is not the point: its underlying philosophy clings to an old- fashioned, authoritarian view of science. All truth in science is provisional. Science works by coming up with hypotheses - basically, educated guesses - and testing them against what's out there. This is the main difference between modern, experiment-based science and the more cerebral ruminations of the Greeks.

Crucially, hypotheses from the most eminent professors should be as amenable to test as those from students or any member of the public. For a scientist to justify a hypothesis not by test, but by standing on his or her authority, is profoundly unscientific. In science, you should never take anyone's word for it just because they are "experts". But this is precisely what the Band wants in the case of the history of birds. The current scientific consensus has seen through this, and the Band is hurting badly - which is why it is making such a fuss.

But what is the fuss? The Band's view is set out most clearly in Alan Feduccia's book The Origin and Evolution of Birds. It explains the origins of birds by looking at birds today. All modern birds either fly, or are descended from flying ancestors. This view adds evolutionary value to adaptations for flight, such as feathers.

Intuitively, this makes good sense, but there are two problems. The first is that the causal relationship between flight and the origin of birds is not testable, as any truly scientific hypothesis should be. The only way to test it would be to invent a time machine and travel back into prehistory to study precisely how the ancestors of birds took to the air.

Faced with the untestability of their own hypothesis, Bandsmen feel their authority has been challenged, which makes them understandably angry. They can appeal only to our sense of plausibility (their ideas make good sense so they must be right) or their authority (the "I've been doing this for 40 years so I know best" argument).

The second problem with the view from the Bandstand is that - in the words of the great Mr Spock - it is not logical, Captain. The Band would assert that all birds have feathers, so all animals with feathers must be birds.

This is as logical as saying that all elephants have four legs so all animals with four legs must be elephants. In a broad sense, the Band confuses the appearance of birds now with how they got that way. To be sure, feathers are wonderful adaptations for flight, but this says nothing about how or why feathers evolved to begin with.

The Band view was challenged in the 1970s by John Ostrom of the university of Yale and his colleagues, who identified birdlike features, such as wishbones and hollowed limb bones - in patently non-flying dinosaurs. Then came the discovery of "feathered" dinosaurs.

Faced with what amounted to an affront from the fossil record itself, some Bandsmen threw themselves into all kinds of contortions, claiming that the fossil feathers were not in fact feathers: but if they were, then the animals bearing them must be secondarily flightless birds, not dinosaurs.

This is almost a face-saving admission of defeat, because it is close to what Ostrom and his successors have thought all along: that once you get down to it, birds are simply dinosaurs that fly.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution (ISBN 1-885702-986-0) is published on 6 April by Fourth Estate, price £20.

In science, you should never take anyone's word for it just because they are "experts". But this is precisely what the Band wants in the case of the history of birds. The current scientific consensus has seen through this, and the Band is hurting badly - which is why it is making such a fuss. But what is the fuss? The Band's view is set out most clearly in Alan Feduccia's book The Origin and Evolution of Birds. It explains the origins of birds by looking at birds today. All modern birds either fly, or are descended from flying ancestors. This view adds evolutionary value to adaptations for flight, such as feathers. Intuitively, this makes good sense, but there are two problems. The first is that the causal relationship between flight and the origin of birds is not testable, as any truly scientific hypothesis should be. The only way to test it would be to invent a time machine and travel back into prehistory to study precisely how the ancestors of birds took to the air. Faced with the untestability of their own hypothesis, Bandsmen feel their authority has been challenged, which makes them understandably angry. They can appeal only to our sense of plausibility (their ideas make good sense so they must be right) or their authority (the "I've been doing this for 40 years so I know best" argument). The second problem with the view from the Bandstand is that - in the words of the great Mr Spock - it is not logical, Captain. The Band would assert that all birds have feathers, so all animals with feathers must be birds. This is as logical as saying that all elephants have four legs so all animals with four legs must be elephants. In a broad sense, the Band confuses the appearance of birds now with how they got that way. To be sure, feathers are wonderful adaptations for flight, but this says nothing about how or why feathers evolved to begin with. The Band view was challenged in the 1970s by John Ostrom of the university of Yale and his colleagues, who identified birdlike features, such as wishbones and hollowed limb bones - in patently non-flying dinosaurs. Then came the discovery of "feathered" dinosaurs. Faced with what amounted to an affront from the fossil record itself, some Bandsmen threw themselves into all kinds of contortions, claiming that the fossil feathers were not in fact feathers: but if they were, then the animals bearing them must be secondarily flightless birds, not dinosaurs. This is almost a face-saving admission of defeat, because it is close to what Ostrom and his successors have thought all along: that once you get down to it, birds are simply dinosaurs that fly.  Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. fields.headline: Physics gets hit for six
fields.standfirst: It's just not possible for batsmen to hit a ball, says  Tim Radford, science has proved that conclusively...
fields.trailText: It's just not possible for batsmen to hit a ball, says Tim Radford, science has proved that conclusively...
fields.body:
Certain humans do the impossible almost every day. They are batsmen facing a fast ball. They do not have enough time to calculate how to hit the ball, and they only just have time to hit it. Robert Adair of Yale university has done the physics to prove that what batsmen do ought to be impossible in a time measured in thousandths of a second.

Consider the problem of a man supposed to take a length of timber and swing it in an arc with all his strength to smash into a ball directed towards him from 60 feet away at a speed of 90mph, he told the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting which ended in Washington DC on Tuesday.

"When we calculate that the time required for a major league fast ball to travel from pitcher to plate to be about 400 milliseconds, we can see that the batter is faced with a totally impossible problem."

Yet major league players did it anyhow. The task was theoretically impossible because the minimum muscular response to a visual signal - the blink of an eye in response to a flash of light - was about 150 thousandths of a second.

Look at it from a batsman's point of view, he told a seminar on the physics of baseball. Information took about 25 milliseconds to be turned into electrical pulses in the retina. These pulses had to get from the sensory cells in the retina to the bundle of nerve fibres that processed information at the back of the brain. Signals might travel at nearly the speed of light down a copper wire, but they slowed down to 200 mph along the nervous system. So the information took about 20 milliseconds to reach the back of the brain, and about another 30 milliseconds before it could be turned into a picture.

But even 75 milliseconds after the ball left the pitcher's hand, the eye needed more data before the brain could calculate the ball's trajectory.

At 100 milliseconds, the ball would already have travelled 14 feet, and be one quarter of the way towards the plate. At that point, the batter did not have nearly enough information about the ball's speed. On the other hand, if he left the decision any later, he would not have time to make his swing.

"With 75 milliseconds required to process that last informative picture added to the 100 milliseconds, the brain-computer picture gets to 'think' about the pitch only after 175 milliseconds have elapsed and the fast ball is three eighths of the way through its trip to the plate," Dr Adair said.

By the time the batter had made the decision, and his brain had begun to send messages to arm and leg muscles, 225 milliseconds had elapsed and a swing which takes 150 milliseconds had begun. It took around 15 milliseconds for a signal to get from brain to thigh and 10 milliseconds to distribute the signal through the muscle fibres.

So the swing had to begin a quarter of a second (250 milliseconds) after the ball left the pitcher's hand if the bat was to meet the ball at 400 milliseconds. If the swing by a right handed batter was seven-thousandths of a second too early or late, he would connect but the ball would travel foul. In the first 50 milliseconds of the swing, the batter might be able to adjust the direction.

"At the end of that time, the bat is travelling at about three fourths of its final velocity," said Dr Adair. "Even if the skilled batter can use this late data, none of the subsequent information from seeing the ball over the last half of its flight can be used at all.

"If it weren't psychologically upsetting, the batter could as well close his eyes after the ball is halfway to the plate, or if it were a night game, the management could turn out the lights. The batter would hit the ball just as well."

fields.headline: All things bright and beautiful
fields.standfirst:
You don't have to be Christian to appreciate Christian art, argues Neil MacGregor - and he has a National Gallery exhibition, a TV series and a book lined up to prove it. But is he right? He talks to Jonathan Jones

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: You'll find it hard to avoid Neil MacGregor's vision of Christian art this spring. Seeing Salvation, a survey of representations of Christ over the past 2,000 years, opens at the National Gallery (where MacGregor is the director) on Saturday
fields.body:
You'll find it hard to avoid Neil MacGregor's vision of Christian art this spring. Seeing Salvation, a survey of representations of Christ over the past 2,000 years, opens at the National Gallery (where MacGregor is the director) on Saturday; a BBC2 tie-in fronted by MacGregor starts in April; the book, co-written by - yes - Neil MacGregor, is published at the end of March. Bibles are available in the National Gallery shop.

There's an evangelical fervour to this project: MacGregor calls it "the campaign". Free to all, and sponsored by the Jerusalem Trust, a foundation set up "to promote the Christian religion", and the Pilgrim Trust, which gives grants for social and educational causes, the exhibition is being promoted as the National Gallery's exploration of the Christian heritage in art at the beginning of a new millennium.

"You can't tell the history of European painting, which is what the National Gallery does, without a large proportion of Christian subject matter," MacGregor argues. "For a lot of people that subject matter is difficult. Most people feel somehow embarrassed talking about it in depth. If they do believe, they're nervous about being seen as proselytising; and if they don't, they feel it's not a subject for them to comment on. That seems to me very sad."

The trouble with MacGregor's campaign is that it cries out for misunderstanding and misappropriation. He wants to make Christian art accessible to non-Christians, but the rhetoric of Seeing Salvation - not least its title - says the opposite. It looks like a celebration of devotional art that will delight the faithful and alienate everyone else.

MacGregor has been acclaimed by sympathetic journalists on precisely those grounds, lauded for spurning political correctness and saying the unsayable, that western high art is Christian through and through. Like Kenneth Clark, a previous director of the National Gallery, in his famous television series Civilisation, he is championing the high art of Europe as a unique moral tradition. Of course, the last thing MacGregor wants to be is exclusive. "You can't say the tradition is multi-cultural," he says, "but what you can say, and what I believe very strongly, is that people from any culture can ask these pictures certain questions and will find in them very interesting subject matter."

But is the history of western European art as Christian as Seeing Salvation implies? Michelangelo was accused of "impiety" by contemporaries who thought his Sistine Chapel decorations had more to do with showing off than with promulgating the faith. The Jewish population in Rome, according to the 16th century art historian Vasari, used to go regularly to look at Michelangelo's Moses. Where does European art begin and end? Visit the Great Mosque in Cordoba in southern Spain and you can see a Moorish architectural masterpiece vandalised by conquistadors who stuck a gothic cathedral in the middle of it.

Christian art can be hypocritical and bigoted; it can exemplify exactly the reasons why most people would rather live in a secular society than in a theocratic state. Dali's vertiginous Christ of St John of the Cross, the poster image for Seeing Salvation, was painted in the early 50s at a time when he was trying to curry favour with the fascist regime of General Franco, whom he praised for "imposing clarity, truth and order" in Spain.

The more MacGregor talks, the more personal his project feels. Perhaps it is best seen as his own interpretation, his understanding, of the collection he has been in charge of since 1987. Even the poster for Seeing Salvation contains an autobiography. For him, the meaning of Dali's painting has nothing to do with its origins in Franco's Spain but with what it means to Glasgow, where it has been since the city bought it in 1951. MacGregor was born in Glasgow in 1946. After studying in Oxford, Paris and Edinburgh he was called to the Scottish bar in his 20s before studying art history. He enthuses about the way this triumphantly Catholic painting is loved by Protestants too, how it unites Glasgow by transcending religious divisions.

MacGregor was brought up a Presbyterian and is today C of E . His personal vision of Christian art is too emotional, too angry, for you not to see it as a declaration of faith. And that faith is very much about the alleviation of human suffering. Christian art is angry, he says. It wants you to act.

"Take the sculpture in the exhibition of the completely naked Christ," he says, referring to a late medieval Netherlandish statue, "sitting, waiting to be nailed to the cross. It's a moment of humiliation, destitution - you can't be near that sculpture without feeling shocked, alarmed, horrified that a human being can be humiliated like this. If you are a believer, then of course there's an extra dimension, but even without being a believer, you go away reminded of the indestructible dignity of every individual and the unacceptability of anybody being humiliated like this."

MacGregor shows me the space where the naked Christ will be installed. He says it is incredible to see Christ naked, to see his genitals. It's embarrassing. Images like this were made to provoke a visceral response. He thinks they still can if we let them. Seeing Christ as a tortured prisoner under sentence of death, "you can either respond through tenderness or through acknowledging that your job is to minimise this suffering; and as it is clear that Christ is meant to represent everybody, that means you have to do something to relieve the suffering of the world. You're meant to go away from these pictures about to act differently: that's the purpose of them."

Changing the world is what all artists worth their salt really want to do, he says, and not just Christian ones. "If you speak to many contemporary artists it's clear that they hope their work will have a social dimension, a social resonance, and that ultimately people's behaviour will be changed."

The National Gallery itself was founded on this belief. It was set up in 1824 as a free public gallery "in the belief that great works of art change people and make them better. You may dispute that, you may feel that's not the case, but that's the assumption on which the whole place was made."

MacGregor's vision of art is redemptive and radical, but not all great artists believe in God. Not all of them even believe in art. His exhibition does not, for example, include Francis Bacon. Bacon's fame began with his grotesque 1944 Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion, which could easily have been included with the paintings by Stanley Spencer and Graham Sutherland from the same period in the last room of Seeing Salvation. They saw salvation; Bacon didn't. "I know for religious people, for Christians," Bacon said, "the Crucifixion has a totally different significance. But as a non-believer, it was just an act of man's behaviour, a way of behaviour to another."

Does Bacon's atheism mean his paintings lack humanity, truth, anger? "A lot of Christian art is about the role suffering has to play in an ordinary life," says MacGregor. "Francis Bacon's art is in many ways about the same question. I think it's fair to compare a Bacon image of suffering with a traditional Christian one. Which can work more universally? Which is better able to suggest that suffering is something universal in which we all partake?" It's hard not to get the message of what he says about Bacon - he's not the first critic to be dismayed by the utter abjection of Bacon's art. So does art have to promise redemption to be truly great?

MacGregor's passionate belief in art is not something you come across every day, and what he says has a prickly honesty. He is asking big questions, the biggest, about what art can do in the world beyond the gallery. The National Gallery is practically a world unto itself, a city of art, where you can spend hours in different times and places with great artists. But for its director that's not enough. "When I leave the gallery this evening and walk home," MacGregor says, "how am I meant to behave differently?" It's just a short stroll from the National Gallery to Bacon's Soho, where you can pass the pub in Old Compton Street where three people were killed last year. The question is whether Christianity has anything to say about this or whether it is better understood, in Bacon's words, as "an act of man's behaviour, a way of behaviour to another".

Seeing Salvation: The Image of Christ is at the National Gallery, London WC2 (0171-747 2885), from Saturday. Seeing Salvation is on BBC2 from April 2. The book Seeing Salvation: Images of Christ in Art, by Neil MacGregor with Erika Langmuir, is published by BBC Worldwide on March 30, price £25.

webTitle: £1bn upgrade failed to equip Tornados for war

fields.headline: £1bn upgrade failed to equip Tornados for war
fields.trailText: RAF Tornado bombers involved in a £1bn upgrade programme have been delivered to operational squadrons without being able to use "smart" weapons, the ministry of defence admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
RAF Tornado bombers involved in a £1bn upgrade programme have been delivered to operational squadrons without being able to use "smart" weapons, the ministry of defence admitted yesterday.

The Tornado GR-4s were not used in the Kosovo war last year because their thermal imaging and laser designation (TIALD) system was not ready, forcing older Tornado GR-1s and Harrier jets to be used.

The upgraded bombers were originally due to start becoming operational six years ago.

Technical problems - including what the national audit office described as an inability to "adequately define" specifications - forced the MoD to negotiate a new contract with BAe, the manufacturer of the aircraft.

The ministry said yesterday that 54 Tornado GR-4s had been delivered, 40 of which would be properly equipped with the new system by the end of July.

It said in a statement: "At present, no Tornado GR-4s are cleared for full operational service. The GR-4 will be fully operational by late 2000. We are working hard to solve the problems and expect full clearance by the end of the year."

It said the number of Tornadoes equipped with TIALD was an operational secret. However, earlier this month the ministry told Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, that 142 were due to be upgraded.

Mr Campbell said yesterday: "Neither the Tories nor Labour can take any comfort from this affair. The truth is that with the reduction in defence expenditure over the last 10 years, capability has been sacrificed to accountancy."

Shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan Smith said: "The critical issue is to give our forces the right equipment to do the right job."

An unnamed RAF officer told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that defence procurement chiefs had blundered by delivering planes which had fewer capabilities than before they underwent their expensive refit. "We are spending a billion pounds and we have ended up with an aircraft that is less capable than when we started. We are flying round in an aircraft which can't fire precision bombs," he said.

"The whole project began in 1984," said Bruce George, Labour chairman of the Commons defence committee. "It was not successful, but seven years ago they pulled their finger out. They had learned the lessons of the end of the cold war and of the Gulf war."

fields.headline: Good day bad day
fields.standfirst: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Joyous day
fields.body:
Joyous day

Mayoral hopeful and rotund warbler Buster Bloodvessel (left) has saved Londoners a taxing choice by throwing his considerable weight behind an independent Ken Livingstone bid. The frontman for Ska band Bad Manners said yesterday that he would withdraw from the race if Ken runs. "Ken is the man that Londoners want" he said.

Bad Day

For the Union jack. According to eagle-eyed peer Lord Selsdon, the Union flag is being flown upside down throughout the EU. He said the practice of inverting the flag was to indicate distress or - horror - an insult to the crown. He has asked the government to "ensure that our EU colleagues are advised accordingly."

fields.trailText: Hundreds of millions of pounds in European aid ear marked for three of England's poorest regions could be withdrawn by Brussels because the British government refuses to say whether it will provide crucial matching funds.

Hundreds of millions of pounds in European aid ear marked for three of England's poorest regions could be withdrawn by Brussels because the British government refuses to say whether it will provide crucial matching funds.

Councils in South Yorkshire, Merseyside and Cornwall, which stand to gain £2bn for six-year programmes designed to revive flagging economies, believe that the European commission is rapidly losing patience with Whitehall.

Fears have been reinforced by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy's claims of a "real and looming threat" to the so-called "objective one" schemes, designed for EU regions where wealth measured by GDP per head is at least 25% below the EU average.

Mr Kennedy, whose party controls councils in the three areas, says is alarmed because he received no assurance that cash would be forthcoming at a recent meeting with Tony Blair.

He added: "The prime minister told me quite directly that the government could not make this commitment until the [next] comprehensive spending review was completed in June or July. I don't buy that. I can't see how the spending review will be disturbed by simply saying we've got objective one status and that support will be forthcoming."

Agencies co-ordinating programmes in the three areas are concerned because the review will not influence government spending until April 2001 when the programmes should be in full swing. Under new Brussels guidelines, the commission will quickly begin clawing back tranches of aid unless member states show that matching funds are available - £2bn over six years in England's case.

Brussels has now written to officials in the three areas pointedly asking them to "detail more precisely" how they will provide match funding.

But in a letter to the agency co-ordinating the programme in South Yorkshire, the department of trade and industry, says it is the responsibility of local councils, and other bodies, to find the necessary cash - not the government.

Geoff Fieldsend, the official co-ordinating South Yorkshire's £800m programme, said there was a "massive problem" in finding funds in a county - one of the poorest areas of Europe - which had been battered by the rundown of the coal and steel industries.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, MP for Sheffield Brightside, has faced strong criticism of the government's stand at recent meetings in South Yorkshire. In turn, he has criticised a "can't do" attitude in Whitehall.

Although the issue of match-funding for a much larger objective one programme in Wales led to the recent resignation of Alun Michael as first secretary, English councils claim Cardiff enjoys far more flexibility in moving cash between departments than Whitehall. Consequently, they argue it should be able to satisfy Brussels initially.

Concern is growing in Cornwall, the poorest county in England, where the GDP is 73% of the EU average. It has been promised £313m from the EU. Councillors say they are far from clear how matching funds will be found.

In Merseyside, which has been promised £844m to extend its existing objective one programme for another six years, officials say the government has to wake up to the full implications of not providing matching funds. "If they don't cough up, the cash goes back to Brussels," said one.

The issue was cited as one reason why the Liverpool Walton MP, Peter Kilfoyle, recently resigned as a junior defence minister. He claimed New Labour was sidelining the party's core areas.

webTitle: Section 28 row puts strain on Scots pact

fields.headline: Section 28 row puts strain on Scots pact
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in the Scottish parliament has been put under fresh strain after the junior members said they wanted the outright repeal of section 28.
fields.body:
The Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in the Scottish parliament has been put under fresh strain after the junior members said they wanted the outright repeal of section 28.

Members of the Scottish executive spent much of yesterday trying to thrash out a compromise clause to replace section 28 of the 1988 local government act, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools.

The move was prompted by first minister Donald Dewar, who ordered a committee of MSPs to produce measures to reassure parents and defuse the escalating row over repeal.

The replacement clause, which has reportedly been worded to extol the virtues of marriage, family values and stable relationships, is seen by many as a climbdown for Mr Dewar's administration.

But after hours of deliberations yesterday, Liberal Democrats in the Holyrood coalition said they did not want to see a fresh clause inserted. Their concerns are known to be shared by a number of Labour MSPs. The split mirrors that over student tuition fees which almost broke the coalition.

"The position of the Liberal Democrat group is unanimous that section 28 should be deleted and we are against putting some other form of words in its place," said Liberal Democrat MSP Donald Gorrie. "That merely perpetuates the problem for the future and it does not solve anything. If you say you like marriage and other stable relationships does that include homosexuality?"

In London the government's attempts to have section 28 repealed was heavily defeated in the Lords earlier this month. A compromise is being sought.

A spokesman for Mr Dewar said talks would continue into the night and that Mr Dewar might be in a position to make a public statement on the issue today.

fields.headline: Union backs Livingstone run
fields.standfirst:
Blair told to drop sell-off as Labour mayor crisis deepens

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone last night edged closer to declaring that he will run as an independent candidate to be mayor of London with a challenge to Tony Blair to drop his part-privatisation plans for the London underground, as the first trade union in the capital called on him to stand.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone last night edged closer to declaring that he will run as an independent candidate to be mayor of London with a challenge to Tony Blair to drop his part-privatisation plans for the London underground, as the first trade union in the capital called on him to stand.

The former Greater London council leader broke his silence to warn that the mayoral election would become a "referendum on London's right to govern itself" unless the tube policy - endorsed yesterday by Labour's official candidate, Frank Dobson - was abandoned.

Labour's Millbank headquarters feared the statement might be a defining moment and the cabinet office minister Ian McCartney said Mr Livingstone should "stop playing games", but other Labour sources believed the declaration was intended to leave a way out of the crisis for both sides.

"There seems to be an absolute panic at Millbank over the opinion polls," Mr Livingstone said last night, adding that he had received more than 1,000 emails and 350 letters during the day pressing him to stand.

Labour's leadership is understood to be increasingly alarmed by the risks of damage to the party's position in London, with the first signs that an independent Livingstone campaign could potentially lead to union disaffiliations, as well as resignations and expulsions of members.

The left-led Rail Maritime and Transport union's London regional council yesterday denounced the Labour mayoral selection as a fix and called on Mr Livingstone to stand as an independent candidate "based on the massive democratic mandate given him by our movement - we believe it is Ken's duty to do so".

Officials of the Labour-affiliated union said that they planned to censure Vernon Hince, the RMT assistant general secretary and Labour chairman, whose private correspondence with Mr Livingstone was published by the Labour party yesterday and who had claimed the union was backing Mr Dobson.

Millbank said trade unions who supported an independent Livingstone campaign against Mr Dobson would not necessarily have to disaffiliate from the party, but with some unions such as the firefighters already toying with a break with Labour, the potential fallout could be far-reaching.

Leaders of major unions are also understood to have rejected requests to repudiate Mr Livingstone publicly. One official said yesterday: "We want to stay well out of this - it's Millbank's mess. They created it, they can sort it out."

Another measure of the backwash from Labour's selection fiasco came when Peter Tatchell, the high-profile gay rights campaigner and a Labour candidate in the 1980s, wrote to Tony Blair resigning his party membership after 22 years.

He was leaving, he said, in protest against what he called an "unforgivable abuse of the democratic process", and backing Mr Livingstone.

Millbank is understood to have opened a line of communication with Mr Livingstone via an intermediary and a party spokesman said yesterday: "The time for dialogue is not yet over."
