webTitle: No reprieve for great-grandmother in Texas

fields.headline: No reprieve for great-grandmother in Texas
fields.trailText: A 62-year-old great-grandmother who shot three of her five husbands and killed at least one of them will be executed today, earning several unenviable distinctions.
fields.body:
A 62-year-old great-grandmother who shot three of her five husbands and killed at least one of them will be executed today, earning several unenviable distinctions.

Betty Lou Beets will be only the fourth woman put to death since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976 - only the second woman in Texas since the civil war and the oldest prisoner to die in 18 years.

But her death will fail to resolve the question of who exactly died by lethal injection: the diagnosed victim of battered woman's syndrome who suffered sexual, physical and emotional abuse, or the former barmaid who killed for money.

Some facts are not disputed. She was convicted 15 years ago of killing her fifth husband, a fireman, Jimmy Don Beets, having been found guilty of shooting and wounding her second, and charged with, but not tried for, killing her fourth.

The board of pardons in Texas, where 119 people have been executed since George W Bush became governor five years ago, rejected her plea for clemency. That left Mr Bush, who has spared only one death row inmate, with the sole option of granting a 30-day stay.

His spokeswoman, Linda Edwards, said: "Mr Bush upholds the law fairly and evenly for all people in Texas, including women facing the death penalty. The gender of the killer didn't make any difference to the victim."

But Laura Figueroa, of the Texas Council on Family Violence, said: "We're extremely disappointed, just devastated by this decision. Her case definitely calls for a stay so her lawyers would have the chance to present evidence demonstrating that she had endured abuse in the past."

James Beets, son of the fifth husband, said: "My dad was a good man, not an alcoholic or abuser. They keep talking about her being a grandma: well, my dad's grandkids are never going to know their grandfather."

Jimmy Don Beets was thought to be missing for two years until investigators dug up his body, buried under a wishing well in front of his wife's mobile home outside Gun Barrel City. Beside the body was that of her fourth husband, Doyle Wayne Barker.

"All my momma's life she's been abused," her daughter Faye Lane told the parole board. I've seen it with my own eyes. And I know that if the jury heard the truth about my momma, she could only have done something like this if she'd been very scared or threatened."

The prosecution said Beets had killed Jimmy Don for the payouts from his life insurance and pension, a total of $110,000 (£69,000). She claimed a daughter had killed husband number four and a son had killed number five.

 Florida carried out its first execution by injection yesterday, little more than a month after giving condemned prisoners the choice between lethal drugs or the electric chair.

webTitle: Armani adds touch of classic to his Emporio

fields.headline: Armani adds touch of classic to his Emporio
fields.trailText: By today's standards, the house of Giorgio Armani almost appears like a small, family-run business compared with the might of huge conglomerates like Gucci Group and LVMH.
fields.body:
By today's standards, the house of Giorgio Armani almost appears like a small, family-run business compared with the might of huge conglomerates like Gucci Group and LVMH.

Armani ads used to dominate glossy magazines. Now rival Italian design houses, with their big advertising budgets, can afford to dwarf Armani with their eight-page campaigns.

Armani dominated the eighties, but the nineties saw fellow Italian companies like Fendi, Prada and Versace steal a march on the designer renowned for his refined good taste.

He may have been slow to catch on to women's insatiable desire for luxury accessories - handbags, shoes and eyewear account for a large chunk of his rivals' sales - but the 66- year-old designer still has an avid following the world over.

Trends may come and go, but Armani ploughs his own furrow. This is what makes him unique in the eyes of celebrity clients like Jodie Foster and Sophia Lauren.

He is gimmick-free. No 1960s psychedelia or 1970s disco references for the man credited with inventing the power suit - just understated, muted pieces for women who prefer their clothes to whisper rather than shout.

His Emporio line, shown yesterday, is a more youthful distillation of the classic Armani range.

For autumn/winter, the designer showed sober daywear in bottle green and black, all with a very slim silhouette. Slender black velvet trousers were worn with matching fitted waistcoats and shiny flat patent brogues.

Single-breasted coats had narrow shoulders and cuffs trimmed with thick bands of fur. Like so many collections this season, this was one of contrasting textures: ruched velvet skirts, slashed velvet shawls and leather coats with frilly trims.

Only for evening wear was colour introduced, although again the key element was black. There was a Spanish feel to fringed shawls beaded with red and pink flowers, which were worn with the tiniest beaded hotpants and strapless tulle skirts came with multi-coloured stars.

fields.headline: Channel hopping
fields.standfirst: It's their biggest invasion since 1066 - an astonishing 200,000 French people now call the UK home. Is it our food they're coming for? Our weather? No, reveals Emma Brockes, it's mostly for our low taxation
fields.trailText: In 1971, a census was taken of the number of French-born citizens living in Britain. It turned up 21,000 people: a modest number but not altogether surprising to anyone who had lived on both sides of the Channel. Who would move to grotty old London if they had the good fortune to have been born in Paris?
fields.body:
In 1971, a census was taken of the number of French-born citizens living in Britain. It turned up 21,000 people: a modest number but not altogether surprising to anyone who had lived on both sides of the Channel. Who would move to grotty old London if they had the good fortune to have been born in Paris?

That figure is now an astonishing 200,000. The area around Bute Street in west London has long been known as a place where you are more likely to hear French spoken than English and for that reason is one of the most chic quarters of the capital. It is now, however, being talked of as a community of emigrés that has grown out of all proportion to the natural ebb and flow of European migration.

The French, needless to say, are not coming here for our fine education system. "It is the flexibility, the quality, the speed - they are all higher here than in Paris," says Pascal Augé, head of corporate banking at SG, the international arm of the French investment bank, Société Générale. He refers not to the British character, but to the state of the financial markets. Augé moved to London from Paris 18 months ago in recognition of its status as a major financial centre. "The type of sophisticated deals you can work on here are better and the competition is much more active than in Paris because all the major banks are on the spot."

There is some 168bn francs of French business invested in Britain, 20bn less than the level of British investment in France, and yet the number of French citizens who have chosen to follow their investments by moving to London is more than treble the traffic going the other way. The British embassy in Paris estimates that there are a mere 65,000 Britons living in France. The reasons for this are partly cultural - how many unilingual Brits could move to a country where they can only just ask for directions to the post office without having to reward themselves with a lie-down? But the primary factor - at least among the large numbers of French businessmen and women - seems to be financial.

"England's definitely the place to go to make money," says Bernard Antony. Three years ago, the 37-year-old moved from Paris to Cambridge, where he bought the Varsity Restaurant (est 1954) from his father. He had been working in Paris and the Champagne region, but, as a small business owner, found the cost of social security payments crippling.

"In France, the tax you have to pay when you employ people is horrendous. As a company you pay six or seven company taxes, so you don't have any money at all. It's more difficult to get a loan from the bank - even when you've got the collateral they can still say no."

Antony employs mostly part-time workers whose salaries come to just over £500 a month. In France, he estimates, that figure would be nearer £3,000. "When you pay someone £600 in France, it will cost you another £600 on top in taxes."

According to the financier Pierre Gerbier, a private banker at the Royal Bank of Canada who has helped 50 French millionaires move to Britain in the last year, the first great wave of business exiles from France occurred in 1981. "When the socialist president was elected a lot of big French families - the old money - upped and left. It calmed down in 1986 when the rightwing government got in." In 1995 came the second big wave, when social security payments soared again and hopes, among the rich at least, that Jacques Chirac would bring them down came to nothing. "A lot of people discovered that whether the government in place was rightwing or leftwing, the system was becoming worse by the day in terms of the tax burden."

For the past six years, Laure Zaigue has run the French Bookshop in Bute Street. "In that time," she says, "the number of French people moving over here has definitely increased. People come for tax reasons and to find a job. Unemployment in France is very bad." (At 10.4%, unemployment in France is nearly double that of the UK.) If research by Knight Frank, the estate agent, is anything to go by, evidence of a snowballing French invasion is not entirely anecdotal. A recent review of property values concluded that one in seven new homes in London is being bought by Europeans, more than likely French. "It's been murder on the phones," says the receptionist at the Lycée Francais, the French language school in Kensington. "The number of people trying to enrol their children at the school has been growing steadily since 1995."

The French embassy is reluctant to encourage this kind of undignified speculation, however. "No, no it is not the case," says Laurent Lemarchand, its spokesman, bridling at the suggestion that growing numbers of his compatriots are chasing tax breaks in Britain. "Over the last 12 months the number of French people in Britain has not increased. It has stabilised at about 200,000."

So when was the last big exodus? "1066," he says, drily. It is Lemarchand's opinion that the number of French in London is merely the natural consequence of European Union laws encouraging freedom of circulation. But Pierre Gerbier sees his reticence as an extension of the French government's denial of the brain drain. "For a long time they tried to deny the fact that a lot of money was leaving the country. But in 1999, they indirectly recognised the movement by introducing three very tough measures which made it more expensive for French entrepreneurs to leave the country."

This was primarily in the form of an exit tax imposed on unrealised capital gain for anyone who had more than 25% ownership in a business. For those who made the move - and many thought it worthwhile to shoulder the one-off exit tax for a cheaper life in Britain - the benefits have been manifold. "It is a more relaxed way of life," says Pascal Augé. "I have taken to biking, which I never dared do in Paris. I'm even a more relaxed driver."

"The labour is cheap, the taxes are low," says Bernard Antony. "We know lots of people who are thinking of moving here now. You have a better lifestyle in France, but who can afford it?"
fields.bodyText: In 1971, a census was taken of the number of French-born citizens living in Britain. It turned up 21,000 people: a modest number but not altogether surprising to anyone who had lived on both sides of the Channel. Who would move to grotty old London if they had the good fortune to have been born in Paris? That figure is now an astonishing 200,000. The area around Bute Street in west London has long been known as a place where you are more likely to hear French spoken than English and for that reason is one of the most chic quarters of the capital. It is now, however, being talked of as a community of emigrés that has grown out of all proportion to the natural ebb and flow of European migration. The French, needless to say, are not coming here for our fine education system. "It is the flexibility, the quality, the speed - they are all higher here than in Paris," says Pascal Augé, head of corporate banking at SG, the international arm of the French investment bank, Société Générale. He refers not to the British character, but to the state of the financial markets. Augé moved to London from Paris 18 months ago in recognition of its status as a major financial centre. "The type of sophisticated deals you can work on here are better and the competition is much more active than in Paris because all the major banks are on the spot." There is some 168bn francs of French business invested in Britain, 20bn less than the level of British investment in France, and yet the number of French citizens who have chosen to follow their investments by moving to London is more than treble the traffic going the other way. The British embassy in Paris estimates that there are a mere 65,000 Britons living in France. The reasons for this are partly cultural - how many unilingual Brits could move to a country where they can only just ask for directions to the post office without having to reward themselves with a lie-down? But the primary factor - at least among the large numbers of French businessmen and women - seems to be financial. "England's definitely the place to go to make money," says Bernard Antony. Three years ago, the 37-year-old moved from Paris to Cambridge, where he bought the Varsity Restaurant (est 1954) from his father. He had been working in Paris and the Champagne region, but, as a small business owner, found the cost of social security payments crippling. "In France, the tax you have to pay when you employ people is horrendous. As a company you pay six or seven company taxes, so you don't have any money at all. It's more difficult to get a loan from the bank - even when you've got the collateral they can still say no." Antony employs mostly part-time workers whose salaries come to just over £500 a month. In France, he estimates, that figure would be nearer £3,000. "When you pay someone £600 in France, it will cost you another £600 on top in taxes." According to the financier Pierre Gerbier, a private banker at the Royal Bank of Canada who has helped 50 French millionaires move to Britain in the last year, the first great wave of business exiles from France occurred in 1981. "When the socialist president was elected a lot of big French families - the old money - upped and left. It calmed down in 1986 when the rightwing government got in." In 1995 came the second big wave, when social security payments soared again and hopes, among the rich at least, that Jacques Chirac would bring them down came to nothing. "A lot of people discovered that whether the government in place was rightwing or leftwing, the system was becoming worse by the day in terms of the tax burden." For the past six years, Laure Zaigue has run the French Bookshop in Bute Street. "In that time," she says, "the number of French people moving over here has definitely increased. People come for tax reasons and to find a job. Unemployment in France is very bad." (At 10.4%, unemployment in France is nearly double that of the UK.) If research by Knight Frank, the estate agent, is anything to go by, evidence of a snowballing French invasion is not entirely anecdotal. A recent review of property values concluded that one in seven new homes in London is being bought by Europeans, more than likely French. "It's been murder on the phones," says the receptionist at the Lycée Francais, the French language school in Kensington. "The number of people trying to enrol their children at the school has been growing steadily since 1995." The French embassy is reluctant to encourage this kind of undignified speculation, however. "No, no it is not the case," says Laurent Lemarchand, its spokesman, bridling at the suggestion that growing numbers of his compatriots are chasing tax breaks in Britain. "Over the last 12 months the number of French people in Britain has not increased. It has stabilised at about 200,000." So when was the last big exodus? "1066," he says, drily. It is Lemarchand's opinion that the number of French in London is merely the natural consequence of European Union laws encouraging freedom of circulation. But Pierre Gerbier sees his reticence as an extension of the French government's denial of the brain drain. "For a long time they tried to deny the fact that a lot of money was leaving the country. But in 1999, they indirectly recognised the movement by introducing three very tough measures which made it more expensive for French entrepreneurs to leave the country." This was primarily in the form of an exit tax imposed on unrealised capital gain for anyone who had more than 25% ownership in a business. For those who made the move - and many thought it worthwhile to shoulder the one-off exit tax for a cheaper life in Britain - the benefits have been manifold. "It is a more relaxed way of life," says Pascal Augé. "I have taken to biking, which I never dared do in Paris. I'm even a more relaxed driver." "The labour is cheap, the taxes are low," says Bernard Antony. "We know lots of people who are thinking of moving here now. You have a better lifestyle in France, but who can afford it?"

fields.headline:
No: 1583
 Tom Arnold
fields.trailText: The pitch: Loveable fortysomething, GSOH, familiar from telly, seeks third wife for love and childbearing.
fields.body:
The pitch: Loveable fortysomething, GSOH, familiar from telly, seeks third wife for love and childbearing.

Didn't he use to be on Roseanne? Arnold was the estimable Ms Barr's producer and real-life husband in the early 90s.

It went pear-shaped? Roseanne's weight is her own business.

No, the marriage: Indeed. The couple divorce acrimoniously in 1994, amid claims that the pairing had been a mere publicity stunt. Arnold had the "Roseanne" tattoo on his backside removed by laser, and went on to star in his own sitcom, Tom.

He likes a snappy title: A role in Frasier surely beckons.

Where's he been hiding since then? Ever seen Coneheads? The Stupids? Golf Punk?

Nope, nope and nope. That's where he's been hiding.

That must sap a celeb's confidence: You bet. "When you're around a bunch of big stars, you look at these people and they're successful, they've got it together and they're hip and chic, and then there's Tom Arnold from Ottumwa, Iowa. I'm not in this crowd. I don't fit in."

Lonely, eh? Not for long. "Tom Arnold is searching for a bride," according to his new website, www.marrytom.com. "And you could be the lucky lady."

You don't mean? Tom divorced his second wife, Julie, six months ago, and is now seeking a replacement on the internet.

Talk about a service provider! "Just fill out the form below and do your best to convince Tom Arnold that you are the bride for him. Good luck!"

Can anyone enter? Provided they're "self-confident enough to wear a bathing suit on vacation", says new man Tom, before warning that "once we're a couple, occasionally we make love".

Romance is not dead. "Success is great," the Casanova continues, "but why have it if you can't share it with someone?"

Success? What about Coneheads! Save the "just causes and impediments" for the church.

Do say: "I'm five eleven, blonde, full-breasted, with legs as long as Venice Beach."

Don't say: "I'm a 44-year-old trucker from Stevenage."

Not to be confused with: John Goodman, Matthew Arnold, Yahoo!

fields.headline: Another Fiennes mess
fields.standfirst: So Sir Ranulph's polar trip has flopped. Time to try crossing the Andes on a frog, says  Jim White
fields.trailText: So Sir Ranulph's polar trip has flopped. Time to try crossing the Andes on a frog.
fields.body:
When the next Oxford English dictionary is published, rumour suggests that among the several neologisms registered therein will be a word specifically designed to help us define a unique area of human disaster. Fiennes: V. to undertake a perilous yet ultimately pointless journey which ends in failure long before its intended conclusion. N. futile exploration undertaken in extreme conditions involving the loss of one or more digits to frostbite.

Earlier this week, poor Sir Ranulph was yet again forced to abandon a heroic solo march across an inhospitable part of the planet. He had been attempting to walk unaided and unassisted to the North Pole to raise more than £1m for cancer research. Since he was walking without the aid of dogs or air drops, his effort required him to haul not one but two sledges of supplies and equipment, each weighing almost as much as a Nissan Micra.

Such was their weight, he was obliged to pull the sledges in relay, dragging one for a few metres, then leaving it unattended to go back for the other, presumably acting on the assumption that there were no sledge rustlers in the Arctic region. After only seven of the anticipated 50 days of abject misery, one fell through thin ice and, in the process of pulling it from freezing water, Sir Ranulph exposed his hand to the chill and contracted frostbite.

Now, you might imagine the more modern and more prescient explorer might take the precaution of having his luggage air-freighted to his destination in advance and might have worn waterproof mittens. But then modern and prescient are two words not readily associated with this eccentric old explorer. Every year, he insists on setting out to conquer some new challenge. But since the number of physical challenges are finite and there are plenty of others ticking off the achievements, his pathological need not just to do something extraordinary, but to be the first to do it, entails coming up with ever more inventive tasks.

Sir Ranulph was clearly exposed to early Monty Python shows at a formative age and took their sketch about crossing the Andes by frog not as a piece of satire but as a guiding principle for his life. So not for him simply climbing Everest or visiting the poles, he must be the first to do it without radio, without oxygen, unencumbered by back-up or assistance, dragging half a ton of equipment with his bare hands, on all fours, gargling the Ukrainian national anthem, while wearing traditional Innuit costume over Posh Spice's undergarments. Oh, and accompanied only by an ITN film crew. Which would all be fine were it not for the fact that the hurdles he sets up for himself are clearly insurmountable. Every time, it seems, he has to call his attempt off after some hideous accident resulting in the re-arrangement of his limbs.

While there is something immeasurably noble about a man of 59 setting out to tame the elements, Sir Ranulph's failure is becoming almost as regular a sight as his cousin Ralph removing his trousers in a film. And, for much of the population, much less attractive.

Sir Ranulph says he only does his walks for charity. Again a noble aim, except many people set out on sponsored walks every day and most of them manage to do it without getting purple fingers. Besides, isn't the point of a sponsored walk that the further you go the more you raise? Pulling two sledges the size of garden sheds is hardly conducive to maximising the donations.

The point is there is only one reason Sir Ranulph sets off on his idiosyncratic explorations every winter: Sir Ranulph himself. After a lifetime spent at public school and in service with the SAS, he is an inveterate masochist, addicted to making himself suffer in the most unpleasant, inhospitable, freezing environments on the planet.

Thus, whatever he might say about retirement after this latest failure, he will be back. Back with ever more inventive ways of making himself suffer which are bound to end in disaster, every winter at this time providing us with pictures of his misery, a point in the calendar as constant as football's week of shame, or Millbank rigging an election. And we should all be grateful that, next time we pack the car with camping equipment and squabbling children, fully anticipating to get stuck in a 20-mile tailback somewhere south of Taunton on the M5, thanks to him there is a word which at last encompasses the full horror, futility and ugliness of the journey we are about to undertake. We're not simply setting off on holiday, we're going on a Fiennes.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
Our art critic Adrian Searle is the latest to misspell the name of the artist Lucian Freud (the Visual arts, G2, page 12, February 22). Freud does not spell his name Lucien. This is the sixth appearance of this correction in the past two years. It has appeared previously on April 25 1998; June 4 1998; January 16 1999; January 21 1999; October 23 1999.

In the same piece in G2, February 22, Tania Kovats, the artist who is the curator of an exhibition at the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham, spells her name like that and not Kovak['s]. The singular of putti is putto.

In a report headed Olive oil power plants could give Opec the slip, page 25, February 17, we said the solid residue to be used as a fuel was called "orujillo". The correct term is "orujo". Orujillo is a strong liqueur produced by the fermentation of orujo.

In a report headed See-saw bounced by bureaucracy, page 11 of early editions, February 22, we referred to a voluntary British safety standard which had recommended that the seats of a see-saw should be stopped "203mm (less than an inch) above the ground". We should, more accurately have said, about 8 inches.

Homophone corner (G2, page 2, February 18), "The novel... was a grizzly, detailed exploration of seven ways in which Klinkhammer could conceivably have killed his wife ..."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Trade gap at 10-year high
fields.standfirst: With imports surging and exporters hurting, shortfall doubles to £15.5bn
fields.trailText: Britain suffered its worst trade deficit for a decade last year as imports surged and the strong pound started to hurt exporters, according to official figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain suffered its worst trade deficit for a decade last year as imports surged and the strong pound started to hurt exporters, according to official figures published yesterday.

With imports rising strongly across the board the trade gap in goods and services almost doubled to £15.5bn in 1999 - the second worst performance since 1989.

Only Britain's traditional strength in services and the recovery in the global oil price prevented the figures from being even worse - with trade in goods alone showing a record £26.3bn shortfall.

The surplus on services stood at £10.9bn, slightly down on 1998, while that on oil rose from £3bn to £4bn.

In the past higher trade deficits have been an early warning of inflationary pressure building up in the economy. City analysts said yesterday that domestic demand was boosting imports while exporters faced being squeezed out of overseas markets by the strong exchange rate.

The weakening of trade performance was most marked with countries outside the European Union - where the recovery of those affected by the Asian crisis in 1997 and 1998 fed through into rapidly expanding exports to Britain.

The latest figures from the office for national statistics suggested that the overall trend has been deteriorating in recent months.

The trade deficit in goods and services stood at £4.8bn in the last three months of the year - up from £2.6bn in the previous quarter. The value of exports fell by 2.1% between September and December, while imports rose by 1.6%.

Excluding oil and so-called erratics - goods such as aircraft and precious stones which have an irregular pattern of trade - the deficit in goods rose from £6.2bn to a record £8.6bn in the last three months of 1999, the ONS said.

In December the goods deficit stood at £2.7bn, up from £2.5bn the previous month, while the shortfall excluding oil and erratics rose from £2.8bn to a record £3.1bn.

The ONS also released data for non-EU trade in January, which showed the deficit in goods at £2.4bn, up from £2.3bn the previous month and almost double the £1.3bn shortfall in September.

For the year as a whole the trade gap in goods rose from £5.3bn to £6bn for EU countries and from £15.2bn to £20.3bn for non-EU nations.

Officials said their latest estimates of the underlying trends indicated that the trade deficit was widening.

Separate data for trade volumes which strips out the effects of currency movements and prices, showed that imports rose strongly last year.

fields.headline: Matthews sells stake for £900m
fields.standfirst: France's Alcatel makes £4.5bn bid for Newbridge telecoms company
fields.trailText: Welshman Terry Matthews yesterday confirmed his position as the principality's richest man when he sold his stake in his Canadian telecoms equipment business for £900m.
fields.body:
Welshman Terry Matthews yesterday confirmed his position as the principality's richest man when he sold his stake in his Canadian telecoms equipment business for £900m.

Alcatel, the French telecom equipment company, has made a £4.5bn bid for Ottawa-based Newbridge Networks, which Mr Matthews founded 14 years ago.

Mr Matthews, the company's chief executive and biggest shareholder with a 20% stake, recently built a £100m resort in the Usk Valley, complete with three championship golf courses.

Newbridge is the second telecom equipment company he has set up and sold. He founded Mitel Corporation in 1973 with Michael Cowpland and sold it to British Telecom in 1984.

Mr Cowpland subsequently founded Corel Corporation, the Canadian computer graphics software business.

Newbridge put itself up for sale in November last year after missing its earnings target for the sixth time in 10 quarters. The company had bet its future on the asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) technology widely used by telecoms companies in their data networks, only to see internet protocol (IP) technology eat into its markets.

Alcatel, the only company in bid talks after Siemens of Germany and Ericsson of Sweden pulled out, is offering an 11% premium for the Newbridge shares, which have risen 36% in the past six weeks on takeover speculation.

The French company plans to merge Newbridge into its own carrier data division, more than doubling its turnover to $2.5bn (£1.5bn).

Serge Tchuruk, Alcatel's chairman and chief executive, said the company was making a move to become a world leader in new generation networks capable of handling the expected explosive growth in data traffic.

"This acquisition combines Alcatel's leading position in fast internet access with Newbridge's strong ATM multi-service capabilities," he said.

Pearse Flynn, Newbridge's chief operating office, said that during the past quarter the company had achieved record sales, streamlined its cost structures, and made increased inroads into the American market.

Alcatel has been expanding rapidly through acquisition. Last September it acquired its fifth US business in a year.

Analysts said Newbridge was too small to remain independent when competing against the likes of Lucent, Cisco and Nortel. "Even if you have the best products it's really difficult because it's not just about technology," said one. "Even when you have the best technology you lose because Lucent has more marketing clout."

webTitle: Jumbo deficits and a consignment of elephant milk

fields.headline: Jumbo deficits and a consignment of elephant milk
fields.trailText: In June 1970 Harold Wilson was on course to win his third election. Or so he thought. Then, in the last few days of the campaign, his plans were upset by the publication of dreadful trade figures distorted by imports of two jumbo jets.
fields.body:
In June 1970 Harold Wilson was on course to win his third election. Or so he thought. Then, in the last few days of the campaign, his plans were upset by the publication of dreadful trade figures distorted by imports of two jumbo jets.

Whether the trade data was responsible for Wilson's demise remains a moot point. Some say an even bigger factor was the tummy upset that sidelined Gordon Banks for England's world cup quarter final defeat by West Germany. But whatever the reason, trade is central to Britain's economic life and always has been.

Data released by the office for national statistics yesterday showed how trade changed in the course of the 20th century. In 1900, the UK exported 44m tons of coal; today it exports less than 1m metric tonnes. Almost 40% of exports a century ago were from cotton factories, pits and iron and steel plants, but today the old staples have been supplanted by cars, office machinery and electrical appliances.

Coal's decline has gone in tandem with the rise of oil. Since 1976, Britain has exported 1,409.6m tons of crude from the North Sea - enough, said the ONS, to fill 783 Millennium Domes.

The first car was imported into Britain in 1904 at a cost of £387 - or £25,000 in today's terms. The average price of an imported car before forecourt mark-up in 1999 was £8,630. Britain imports almost as much tea per head as in 1900, but nine times as much coffee and wine.

The 4.3m paper declarations collected each month by customs and excise also throw up the weird and wonderful. Britain sells yew hedge clippings to the United States, where they are used in cancer drugs, and last year exported 126 tons of sand to Saudi Arabia for use in foundries and in bunkers on golf courses. Unusual imports last year included holy water from Saudi Arabia and a consignment of elephant's milk. Four times as many Brazil nuts come from Bolivia as from Brazil.

Overall, the UK ran an annual surplus on trade in goods and services only 25 times in the 20th century, with the longest period in the black between 1977 and 1983, when North Sea oil came on stream and the oil price was soaring. The picture for trade in goods has been even bleaker, with only six years of surpluses in the century. After 55 straight years in the red, trade in goods finally moved into surplus in 1956, with exports again higher than imports in 1958, 1971, 1980, 1981 and 1982.

For most of the period a traditional strength in services meant annual trade deficits stayed small. The trade gaps that alarmed Wilson seem insignificant against the record shortfalls of the 1980s Lawson boom, when there was a consumer spending frenzy. Only one year comes close to matching those heady days, and that was 1999.

webTitle: MPC: it's all in the minutes

fields.headline: MPC: it's all in the minutes
fields.trailText: The Bank of England yesterday sought to talk down sterling's value on the foreign exchanges amid growing government concern over the impact of the high exchange rate on industry and exporters.
fields.body:
The Bank of England yesterday sought to talk down sterling's value on the foreign exchanges amid growing government concern over the impact of the high exchange rate on industry and exporters.

Minutes of the meeting of the monetary policy committee earlier this month revealed that the Bank had discussed whether to intervene in the markets.

In the end, a majority felt any attempt to cut sterling's value would be futile and that the Bank's belief that the pound is overvalued could be demonstrated via the report of the meeting itself.

However, the MPC's discussion showed a minority in favour of tougher action, arguing that intervention would be a more powerful signal.

But most of those supporting intervention concluded that "it could be an option only if the committee decided to leave the repo [interest] rate unchanged, and even then would have to depend on market conditions".

For the past three years the Bank has been expecting the pound to fall. It has acknowledged that the effect of pushing up rates to choke off domestic demand has been to make life even more difficult for exporters.

Those opposed to intervention said they doubted whether it would be effective. They also argued that, to the extent that the pound's strength reflected the weakness of the euro, there was little the Bank could do.

Finally "the MPC's analysis of the exchange rate could be conveyed via the minutes and did not need to be demonstrated via intervention".

fields.headline: Baltimore Technologies
fields.trailText: Shares in Dublin-based Baltimore Technologies slipped yesterday despite announcements of a solid 1999 result and an agreement with American PC maker Compaq. It is also looking forward to promotion to the FTSE 100.
fields.body:
Shares in Dublin-based Baltimore Technologies slipped yesterday despite announcements of a solid 1999 result and an agreement with American PC maker Compaq. It is also looking forward to promotion to the FTSE 100.

The net security firm saw shares dip £13.37 to £114 - a fall attributed to concerns that it could bite off more than it can chew after comments by chief executive Fran Rooney that Baltimore might look at more mergers and acquisitions.

The comments were made as the group revealed losses for 1999 had grown from £18m to £31.4m, in line with analysts' expectations. Turnover rose 28% to £37.6m on better software licensing sales.

Analysts held their buy recommendations with Merrill Lynch saying it had a 12-month target of £145, buoyed up by the product deal with Compaq.

The agreement will see Compaq and Baltimore bundling their products. The deal is seen as a way of fast-tracking Baltimore's sales in the US, after the recent hacking of Yahoo, Amazon and CNN which highlighted net security concerns.

Last month, to aid this strategy, Baltimore bought American e-commerce security group CyberTrust for $150m.

Broker Beeson Gregory is looking for 20% of the company's revenues to be sourced from the US this year, compared with 5% in 1999.

"Sales were lower than I'd expected," said David Johnson, analyst at Beeson Gregory. "I think it's taken them quite a lot of time to build up a sales operation in the US."

Baltimore's coming entry to the FTSE, with a review due on March 8, has led to the stock's rise over the past few weeks.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Leading blue chips ended firmer, but off their best levels for the day, as Wall Street put in a mixed performance.
fields.body:
Leading blue chips ended firmer, but off their best levels for the day, as Wall Street put in a mixed performance.

Once again, strength in heavyweight telecom issues, Vodafone AirTouch moving higher on reweighting factors and BT up on the continuing demerge-or-be-bid for story, provided the main prop for the premier index.

At the close, the FTSE 100 index stood 129.4 points higher at 6,144.1, compared with an afternoon peak of 6,167.3. All the second and third tier indices also made good headway, and volume was again exceptionally high with more than 2bn shares changing hands - 585m of these carrying the ticker symbol VOD.

The business in Vodafone was given a push by Deutsche Bank, which issued a "strong buy" recommendation on the stock and set an extraordinary price target of 600p-a-share.

Having moved to 360p at one stage, the market price finally settled at 349p, up 5p. BT, meanwhile, put on another 64p to £11.65. Over the past week the shares have advanced 20%.

Elsewhere, there was a heavy diet of corporate results for dealers to consume. Standard Chartered attracted fresh buying, up 39p at 749p despite figures at the bottom end of market expectations. Followers liked the upbeat statement.

The well received figures from Logica fuelled interest in other software groups, sending Sema Group up from £12.92 to £13.10 and, more noticeably, Sage Group, which ended 122p higher at 843p.

Shares in BSkyB shrugged aside regulatory fears, with the market instead focusing on talk of a very bullish report from ABN Amro on the group's Open TV venture - which the broker suggested could attract many new customers. The shares added 81 to £1,5.83.

Compass Group put on 37p to 725p after shareholders attending yesterday's annual meeting were treated to an upbeat statement on current trading. The rally in precious metals prices showed through in the mining sector. Anglo American added 162p at £32.92, while Rio Tinto put on 29p to £10.55 and Billiton gained 12p to 281p.

Capita Group continued to attract support, up 122p to £14.77 as the market weighed the benefits of Tuesday's link-up with Microsoft.

Private client stockbroker Charles Stanley burst into life after signing a deal with investment group eCapital to launch a mobile net share dealing service.

The shares rocketed from 637p to 915p - a one-day gain of 43%.

webTitle: Logica profit soars on the back of telecoms boom

fields.headline: Logica profit soars on the back of telecoms boom
fields.standfirst: Chief executive predicts that liberalisation of energy and utilities sectors will produce huge growth opportunities
fields.trailText: Riding the boom in telecoms information technology group Logica has reported a 62% leap in half-year profit before tax and exceptionals to £42.5m and announced it was signing record-breaking contracts.
fields.body:
Riding the boom in telecoms information technology group Logica has reported a 62% leap in half-year profit before tax and exceptionals to £42.5m and announced it was signing record-breaking contracts.

The company's turnover rose 38% to £403m with revenues from telecommunications contracts accounting for more than a third.

"If you strip out mobile telecommunications it would have been okay but it wouldn't have been brilliant," Lucy McFetrich, analyst at Merrill Lynch said. "Their results were about 8% above what we were going for."

The company said the growth in text messages on mobile phones from more than 1bn to 3bn in less than 12 months had led to some of the increase in telecommunication revenues. Logica provides the software which allows the delivery of text messages as well as providing billing services for telecommunication companies.

"This has clearly been an exceptionally good set of results," Martin Read, Logica's chief executive said. "While telecommunications has been successful, what we can see unfolding is the exciting growth opportunities in the liberalisation of the energy and utilities sectors. We believe the growth will be as exciting as we've seen in telecommunications."

Logica's shares moved up 135p to £24.17 as the group said it had signed contracts in the electricity and utilities sector. They included a £50m trading system deal for the US's New Electricity Trading Arrangements, another trading system deal with American Electric Power and one with an undisclosed company, which is expected to be announced in the next two weeks.

Mr Read said he expected a recovery in demand for internet banking systems and other products it provided to the financial services sector, which declined because of concerns over the millennium bug.

The decline in the value of the euro wiped 3% off the company's revenues in the last half of the year. The continent also performed weakly for Logica with only acquisitions providing growth in that region in the past six months. Mr Read said he expected this would change before the year end.

Its European revenues grew 5% to £95.7m, while UK revenues leapt by a third to £180.3m because of strong growth from its acquisitions relating to the industry, distribution and transport sectors. US revenues grew 33% to £1.6m.

fields.headline: Watchdog extends Vivendi inquiry
fields.trailText: The competition commission yesterday extended its inquiry into French conglomerate Vivendi's acquisition of a stake in British Sky Broadcasting after receiving what it described as "important late evidence".
fields.body:
The competition commission yesterday extended its inquiry into French conglomerate Vivendi's acquisition of a stake in British Sky Broadcasting after receiving what it described as "important late evidence".

Vivendi, which has interests including water supply, mobile phones and French pay-TV business Canal Plus, emerged as BSkyB's second largest shareholder last year via its acquisition of film company Pathé.

The commission is investigating, among other things, the deal's potential effect on the market for sports and film rights.

The extension of the investigation comes in the wake of comments from Vivendi's chief executive Jean-Marie Messier calling on BSkyB's largest shareholder News Corporation to reconsider a merger between Canal Plus and the British satellite group after talks broke down last year.

Analysts, who had been surprised by the initial launch of the inquiry remained at a loss to explain why further scrutiny would be necessary. The only other potential explanation offered up was the deal recently struck between Vivendi and Vodafone AirTouch to set up a joint internet operation.

A statement from the commission said the new evidence "needs to be explored with interested parties to ensure that their report into the acquisition by Vivendi of a material interest in BSkyB is fair and accurate".

The commission now plans to present its report to the government by March 24 instead of on February 25 as previously stated.

Spokesmen from BSkyB and Vivendi said they were unaware of what the new evidence was.

webTitle: New nominations threaten Europe's grip on IMF

fields.headline: New nominations threaten Europe's grip on IMF
fields.trailText: Europe's attempt to retain its hold on the top job at the International Monetary Fund was in danger of being thwarted yesterday after Japan and African countries formally nominated their own candidates.
fields.body:
Europe's attempt to retain its hold on the top job at the International Monetary Fund was in danger of being thwarted yesterday after Japan and African countries formally nominated their own candidates.

Frustrated by the delays in appointing a successor to Michel Camdessus, who stepped down this month after 13 years as the IMF's managing director, a group of 20 African countries proposed that caretaker leader Stanley Fisher, Mr Camdessus' deputy, should take over the role full time.

At the same time, Japan put forward its former vice-finance minister Eisuke Sakakibara, known as "Mr Yen" for his ability to move foreign exchange markets during his time at the ministry.

The nominations came ahead of a meeting of European Union finance ministers on Monday at which member states are expected to rally behind Germany's deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser, who was until yesterday the only man in the race for the post.

The job of IMF managing director traditionally goes to a European, while its sister institution, the World Bank, is run by an American, but since the Asian crisis other countries outside the two power blocs have been arguing for a much bigger say in international financial diplomacy.

Steve Everts, research fellow at the London-based Centre for European Reform, who specialises in international finance, said the formal nominations by Africa and Japan made it much less likely that Europe and America would be able to dictate the succession process.

"It makes it even less likely that Koch-Weser will get the job," he said. "It really opens up the race."

Until yesterday's developments, the British government had been sitting on the fence over Mr Koch-Weser's candidacy but last night the treasury issued a statement saying it was now backing him.

"We have always told the German government we are prepared to support Koch-Weser," a spokesman at the treasury said.

"He is clearly a strong and experienced candidate who enjoys support in Europe as well as outside it."

fields.headline: Peugeot denies merger talk
fields.trailText: Peugeot Citroen, Europe's second largest carmaker, yesterday vehemently denied it was in merger talks with a rival as it revealed a 53% rise in pre-tax profits to €1.67bn (£1bn) and set bold targets for growth this year.
fields.body:
Peugeot Citroen, Europe's second largest carmaker, yesterday vehemently denied it was in merger talks with a rival as it revealed a 53% rise in pre-tax profits to €1.67bn (£1bn) and set bold targets for growth this year.

The French car group, which sold 550,900 206s last year, plans to sell 700,000 this year and said demand is so strong that it cannot make enough of the models at its Ryton plant, near Coventry - the most productive in the group.

Jean-Martin Folz, the group's executive chairman, said Ryton, which has three weekday shifts and one at the weekends, had a long-term future even though the pound remained at historically high levels. "From a strictly industrial point of view," he said, "I wish the UK would join the euro as soon as possible as the so-called single market is split into two different zones and this is undesirable."

Mr Folz joined forces with Pierre Peugeot, head of the family's interests, to denounce a spate of market rumours that the group is about to merge with DaimlerChrysler or be taken over by the US-German group or another American rival.

Mr Peugeot, who chairs the group's supervisory board and whose family owns 35% of the voting shares and 23% of the equity, decried "perfectly indecent" reports that it was split over the issue of selling its stake to a would-be predator.

In an unprecedented public intervention, he told a news conference that the family was "entirely welded together" on the issue and fully backed the independence strategy pursued by Mr Folz.

Mr Folz, insisting there had been no contacts with Daimler, said the speculation was "perhaps a form of manipulation" and "it is difficult to say where the borders lie between information and malevolent misinformation."

The Peugeot chairman set targets of 2.7m sales, operating margins of 4% for the car business and group earnings of €1.9bn for this year - which will see a fresh share buy-back, further cuts in operating costs and a 24% rise in spending on R&D.

He held out the prospect of cuts in prices for both Peugeot and Citroen models in the UK though he said his group planned no dramatic initiative. "If the pound remains at these levels this would mean a drop in UK prices," he said.

The group, which confirmed plans to produce 75% of its models on just three "platforms" by next year, is to launch in Geneva next week a "multi-media" Citroen enabling the driver to surf the internet.

The launch, given by Mr Folz and Jean-Marie Messier, head of Vivendi, the French media and telecoms group, comes ahead of UK plans for online buying and selling of both Peugeot and Citroen models in the coming months.

fields.headline: Tales of the city
fields.standfirst: Disused railways? Forbidding factories? Decayed flats? All cities have them, and now photographer Gabriele Basilico has coaxed out their strange beauty.
fields.trailText: Disused railways? Forbidding factories? Decayed flats? All cities have them, and now photographer Gabriele Basilico has coaxed out their strange beauty.
fields.body:
You arrive at the port two hours early. Your holiday is as good as finished - but two hours is two hours. So you turn around and drive. Given the choice, of course, you'd much rather be where you were this morning. But you don't have the choice, and anyway, you're still abroad, aren't you?

The road is climbing now, taking you high above the dock area. Occasionally you spy the sea, glimmering between shabby shops and empty maisonettes. Doubling back, you find yourself in a commercial zone. It's Sunday, though. There's not a soul in sight. The stone-faced offices and slab-sided towers hum in the afternoon sun. You could be anywhere - in Romford or Rotherham, Rotterdam or Rome.

Leaving the dual carriageway was a mistake. In an instant you are surrounded by high-rise flats. They eclipse the mountains and blot out the sky. No pizza bars here - just old mattresses and cars that rattle over gaping pot-holes. Will a U-turn get you out? You do it anyway, but almost wish you hadn't. For the arrows in the road have led you way off course, into a low place of ripped-up railways and forbidding factories. There are hoppers and gantries and pipelines that lead nowhere. You try to get your bearings.

That's where you need to be - up there where the road soars on vast concrete stilts. You know, even without asking, precisely where that highway heads. Up and away it goes, towards the magnificent bridge that crosses the great river. For such a city as this - doesn't it always have a river? Isn't there always a magnificent bridge?

You know it because you have been here 1,000 times before. The factories and the maisonettes, the ring road and the unexpected vantage point - mix them and match them and what do you get? The universal city - always changing, never finished. Forever in the mind's eye. And yet it is possible to view this place afresh - to see each of these components as the startling tableau that would surely present itself to a rural peasant set down anywhere in a modern, industrial city for the very first time.

Paradoxically, it can takes years of study for a city dweller to acquire such clarity of vision - decades of working through the familiarity, much as a certain kind of painter must know each up-close wrinkle in order to depict the essence of a subject. But then the photographer Gabriele Basilico has been years investigating what cities look like. It's what he does. Born in Milan in 1944, Basilico was almost 30 when he graduated from the faculty of architecture at the city's polytechnic. Five years later, he began detailed research into Milan's industrial area - a project that was to set the tone for much of his subsequent work.

Books and exhibitions were to follow - on Neapolitan as well as Milanese architecture. He began to take an interest in ports, and to study the look of a town as well as its buildings. Then in 1984, he was invited to participate in a government- sponsored project to record the contemporary French landscape. The Mission Photographique de la Datar, as it was called, led Basilico into the realm of the public commission. Since then, if a European government or some other institution needs to fix on film what a section of territory really looks like, Basilico is their man.

Areas in the throes of transformation are his speciality - decaying industrial districts, that sort of thing. The title of an exhibition in Houston in 1998 sums it up neatly. It was called Between Past and Present. Now 330 of Basilico's most arresting duotones have been published by Thames & Hudson. Entitled Cityscapes, this book is a portrait of the universal city - a rhythmic sequence comprising images from such apparently diverse locations as Dieppe and Palermo, Beirut and Rome.

Ravaged as much by redevelopment and rebirth as by decline and war, these are eerie places. Is that the Guggenheim in Bilbao? Are we not in St Peter's Square? It is and we are. But blink, and you'll miss these identifiable sights. Coming up now, though, is a paper mill on the Riva del Garda. Here are some houses on the out skirts of Bray-Dunes, and on your left, a goods yard in Barcelona. Know where you are now? Of course you do. For you have been here a thousand times before. Drive on through the city until you hit the ring road. Your boat isn't going anywhere just yet.

Cityscapes by Gabriele Basilico is published by Thames & Hudson, £24.

fields.headline: The pre-school pill poppers
fields.standfirst: Britain's hidden Prozac patients, aged one to 12
fields.trailText: Americans are renowned for their pill-popping tendencies, but a study suggests the habit has even spread to the kindergarten. Toddlers between the age of two and four are being prescribed stimulants, anti-depressants and other drugs in dramatically increasing numbers for perceived psychiatric problems.
fields.body:
Americans are renowned for their pill-popping tendencies, but a study suggests the habit has even spread to the kindergarten. Toddlers between the age of two and four are being prescribed stimulants, anti-depressants and other drugs in dramatically increasing numbers for perceived psychiatric problems.

The use of stimulants such as Ritalin to treat hyperactivity is increasingly common in the United States among school-age children. The study discovered a three-fold rise in prescriptions of medical drugs for children under five.

Paedriatricians expressed shock yesterday that the drug-dependent culture was afflicting pre-school children before any conclusive research had been carried out on the effect of psychiatric drugs on brain development. Nor are there clear guidelines on how to tell whether a two-year-old has attention deficit disorder or is just a lively toddler.

The study, published in Jama, the Journal of the American Medical Association, analysed prescriptions to 200,000 toddlers under the national Medicaid and private health systems. Doctors' prescriptions of stimulants (mainly Ritalin) increased from 4.1 to 12.3 per 1,000 pre-school children between 1991 and 1995. The use of anti-depressants increased from 1.4 to 3.2 toddlers per 1,000.

Although psychiatric drugs of all kinds were prescribed to only 1.5% of the toddlers in the study, the trend was sharply upwards and the Jama researchers said they suspected it had continued on its steep trajectory in the five years since the study was conducted.

The recent explosion in the use of "lifestyle" drugs such as the anti-depressant Prozac has generated fears that a significant part of the population is becoming dependent on prescription medicines to solve its problems. Increasingly drugs such as Ritalin have been used to address the problems of "difficult" children.

Nearly 3% of all Americans between the ages of five and 18 are on Ritalin - almost 3m children. The Jama study confirms evidence that surfaced in a smaller survey in Michigan in 1998, that children were being put on medication for supposed psychiatric problems even before they were old enough to go to school.

US experts have suggested that the growing trend towards treating "problem" children with drugs may be a consequence of a health system in which both wholly private and subsidised systems are reluctant to pay for counselling or other non-drug treatments, which are harder to quantify. Paediatricians also point to growing pressure from parents and schools to diagnose troublesome children as having medical problems such as attention deficit disorder.

Steven Hyman, director of the US national institute of mental health, told the New York Times he was "more than shocked" by the findings, adding that the use of psychiatric drugs in young children was "an area of enormous concern".

Reasons given by American doctors for prescribing these medicines include pain relief (analgesics and sedatives/hypnotics), anxiety associated with medical or dental procedures (hydroxyine), bed-wetting in children over six years old (tricyclic antidepressants), and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children of three years and older, for which they are given a variety of drugs. There are concerns that some drugs may affect children's growth.

Few of the psychiatric drugs mentioned in the Jama study are approved for treating children of preschool age, and packets of methylphenidate (the generic name for Ritalin) carry warnings against prescribing the drug to children under six.

Most psychiatric drugs work by neutralising or enhancing chemicals in the brain, but animal studies suggest that those chemicals play a critical role in the growth of nerve cells in the brain.

Joseph Coyle, chairman of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, said: "These interventions are occurring at a critical time in brain development and we don't know what the consequences are."

He argued that the normal behaviour of many two- or three-year-olds is hard to distinguish from hyperactivity.

Julie Zito, an associate professor of pharmacy and medicine at the University of Maryland and the study's lead author, said: "It is not really clear that children this young could meet the diagnostic criteria for either attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or depression."

Ritalin, being given to more and more hyperactive children, has caused enormous controversy in the US and now the UK.

webTitle: Britain's hidden Prozac patients, aged one to 12

fields.headline: Britain's hidden Prozac patients, aged one to 12
fields.standfirst: The pre-school pill poppers
fields.trailText: Far less is known than most people imagine about the prescribing of medicines to children in Britain, because many are used in what is known as an "off-label" or "outside the licence" way. These drugs are not licensed for children because they have only been tested on adults, and doctors who prescribe them for minors must do so without guidance from the manufacturers on the dosage or side-effects.
fields.body:
Far less is known than most people imagine about the prescribing of medicines to children in Britain, because many are used in what is known as an "off-label" or "outside the licence" way. These drugs are not licensed for children because they have only been tested on adults, and doctors who prescribe them for minors must do so without guidance from the manufacturers on the dosage or side-effects.

So statistics are not kept in an organised way. Only when researchers choose to examine what is going on by asking questions of GPs or hospital doctors does a picture emerge of the use of adult medicines like anti-depressants.

One such small study by the drug safety research unit at Southampton university looked at the prescription of SSRIs - the Prozac breed of antidepressants - for children aged 12 and under in 100 general practices. They found just 19 children on SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) - but the average age of these children was six, and they ranged from one year-old to 12.

Of 10 children who were given Prozac tablets, three were said to be depressed and two were diagnosed with obsessive compulsive disorder. Two were anxious, one had febrile convulsion - a condition that affects small children - one had a mental disorder and the condition of one was described as unknown.

Of those given Prozac as a liquid, one was constantly soiling, one was bereaved, one had behavioural problems and two were anxious. Among the others was a child with endogenous depression, which conventional wisdom says should not affect anybody under 30 to 40 years old.

We know far more about Ritalin because it is licensed for use on children who have attention deficit disorder - hyperactivity. The vast majority of prescriptions for Ritalin, in fact, will be for children.

And the story with Ritalin is a massive surge in use, following the American example, once an initial reluctance to prescribe had been overcome. About five years ago, there were only about 2,000 prescriptions written for the drug and the manufacturers were considering withdrawing it from the UK market. But between 1996 and 1997, the numbers rose to some 92,000.

The drug - a stimulant which helps people to focus on what they are doing - undoubtedly benefits some children with a serious case of the disorder. But in the UK, as in the US, there are worries that it is being over-prescribed for any child whose behaviour is causing parents and school serious difficulties.

webTitle: Astronauts test sex in space - but did the earth move?

fields.headline: Astronauts test sex in space - but did the earth move?
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: US and Russian astronauts have had sex in space for separate research programmes on how human beings might survive years in orbit, according to a book published yesterday.
fields.body:
This note was added on 30 January 2010:

In the story below, the Nasa report cited by Pierre Kohler proved to be a hoax. See this later explanatory Guardian blog: theguardian.com/news/blog/2007/dec/06/sexinspaceornot

US and Russian astronauts have had sex in space for separate research programmes on how human beings might survive years in orbit, according to a book published yesterday.

Pierre Kohler, a respected French scientific writer, says in The Final Mission: Mir, The Human Adventure that the subject is taboo both at Nasa and at mission control in Moscow, but that cosmic couplings have taken place.

"The issue of sex in space is a serious one," he says. "The experiments carried out so far relate to missions planned for married couples on the future International Space Station, the successor to Mir. Scientists need to know how far sexual relations are possible without gravity."

He cites a confidential Nasa report on a space shuttle mission in 1996. A project codenamed STS-XX was to explore sexual positions possible in a weightless atmosphere.

Twenty positions were tested by computer simulation to obtain the best 10, he says. "Two guinea pigs then tested them in real zero-gravity conditions. The results were videotaped but are considered so sensitive that even Nasa was only given a censored version."

Only four positions were found possible without "mechanical assistance". The other six needed a special elastic belt and inflatable tunnel, like an open-ended sleeping bag.

Mr Kohler says: "One of the principal findings was that the classic so-called missionary position, which is so easy on earth when gravity pushes one downwards, is simply not possible."

webTitle: Prudential admits bigger losses for floating Egg

fields.headline: Prudential admits bigger losses for floating Egg
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Prudential yesterday admitted its internet banking arm, Egg, will run up bigger losses than predicted after it announced plans to float the operation on the stock market this year.
fields.body:
Prudential yesterday admitted its internet banking arm, Egg, will run up bigger losses than predicted after it announced plans to float the operation on the stock market this year.

Egg, which ate into Pru's profits to the tune of £150m last year, is expected to break even in the "latter part of 2001". The City had originally expected it to move into profit in the early months of next year.

The insurance and banking group, which has a relationship with one in six of the adult population, reported a 10% slide in operating profits for last year to £776m. The company said Egg is again expected to make losses of £150m this year. Excluding Egg, "re-engineering costs" and amortisation of goodwill, operating profits were £996m, up 6%.

Pru, whose position as the country's largest insurer is threatened by the planned merger between CGU and Norwich Union, also revealed that the cost of its bill to redress pensions mis-selling had hit £2bn, though the cost will not be borne by shareholders.

The Pru confirmed it intends to spin off a "minority" of Egg this year, and indicated the offer would only be open to existing customers and institutional investors.

Jonathan Bloomer, who will become chief executive when Sir Peter Davis moves to Sainsbury's next month, described the extension as a "minor shift".

He said that by selling off 15%-25% of Egg, valued in its whole by the City at between £1.5 to £4bn, the Pru would give the maximum return to its shareholders.

A separate stock market quotation for Egg would also make it easier for it to make acquisitions and "incentivise" its staff to prevent them being lured to other dot.com companies.

While Egg's 800,000 customers will be allowed to subscribe for shares in the company, they cannot expect any "windfalls" of the kind made by demutualising building societies.

When it was launched 18 months ago, Egg jolted the traditional financial services firms, luring away their business by its market-beating savings rates. It now has £7.6bn of deposits and, along with Prudential's bank, mortgages of £1.7bn.

Egg alone has sold £452m of mortgages. It has also attracted 250,000 customers for its credit card and plans to launch a unit-trust "supermarket" later this year as well as setting up an on-line share dealing service.

Egg will also set up current accounts and offer Wap (wireless application protocol) banking from mobile phones and other devices later in the year.

The bank is expected to start to break even if it has to "cross sell" products to its existing customers. Pru, which is cutting 5,000 jobs to cut costs, is also undergoing a "fundamental reorganisation" of its £170bn fund management operation since the takeover of M&G.

It is in the advanced stages of selling off its British institutional, segregated, balanced and specialist equity business which - with £10bn under management - is too small to compete, Mr Bloomer said.

He said the group was still looking for a finance director to replace Les Cullen who is leaving after just five months at the group.

The Pru is paying a 23p dividend, a rise of 9%. Its shares fell 10p to 929p yesterday.

webTitle: Standard stakes its claim to e-venture

fields.headline: Standard stakes its claim to e-venture
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Standard Chartered yesterday joined the growing number of banks staking their future on the internet when it claimed to be involved in more than 20 e-commerce ventures.
fields.body:
Standard Chartered yesterday joined the growing number of banks staking their future on the internet when it claimed to be involved in more than 20 e-commerce ventures.

But the bank, which operates mainly in emerging markets, admitted that while the net had huge potential its pace of development would vary across the crucial areas of Asia, the Middle East, Africa and parts of Latin America.

Chief executive Rana Talwar said the bank thought e-commerce could work to its advantage because these markets tended to be highly protected by regulation.

The bank also revealed plans for a net-based motor venture in Britain through its Chartered Trust operation, which is intended to bundle all motoring costs into a single package.

Mr Talwar reported a 28% fall in pre-tax profits to £507m but he painted an upbeat picture for the coming year.

"There is clear evidence that economic growth has resumed in many of our major markets," he said.

The company's shares rose off recent lows by 39p to 749p. Had it not been for a provision to cover bad and doubtful debts in Asia of £495m, the profit figure would have been over £1bn.

But the bank, which operates mainly in emerging markets, admitted that while the net had huge potential its pace of development would vary across the crucial areas of Asia, the Middle East, Africa and parts of Latin America. Chief executive Rana Talwar said the bank thought e-commerce could work to its advantage because these markets tended to be highly protected by regulation. The bank also revealed plans for a net-based motor venture in Britain through its Chartered Trust operation, which is intended to bundle all motoring costs into a single package. fields.headline: Greenspan calms Wall Street jitters
fields.trailText: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the US federal reserve, came to the rescue of a jittery Wall Street yesterday when his endorsement of America's so-called productivity miracle boosted share prices.
fields.body:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the US federal reserve, came to the rescue of a jittery Wall Street yesterday when his endorsement of America's so-called productivity miracle boosted share prices.

Despite renewed warnings of the dangers of an overheated American economy, Mr Greenspan's remarks reversed an early 140-point plunge in the Dow Jones index which left it teetering close to the psychologically important level of 10,000.

"The issue of stock prices and equity values generally going up as a consequence of accelerating productivity is a perfectly understandable and appropriate thing to happen," he said.

Mr Greenspan's twice-yearly economic outlook report caused a sell-off in shares last week when they were first presented to Congress.

The Dow Jones industrial average is at present trading at about 13% below its all-time high. The slight relief came in spite of the fact that Mr Greenspan continued to warn in the second instalment of his speech to the senate banking committee that four interest rate increases since June have not sufficiently slowed the economy.

"To date, interest sensitive spending has remained robust, and the FOMC [federal open market committee] will have to stay alert for signs that real interest rates have not yet risen enough to bring the growth of demand into line with that of potential supply - even should the acceleration in productivity continue," Mr Greenspan said.

Although he said yesterday that "there is no evidence of inflation right now", the federal reserve is concerned that inflation will accelerate later on if the economy does not slow down.

In one of his clearer statements to the gathering of senior politicians, the central banker compared monetary policy to the rudder on a ship heading for shore.

"If instead of turning before you reach the dock you go straight into the dock," he said, it would "do very serious damage to this economy".

He also joined those worried about the impact of the strong oil price on inflation by saying that the price spike "could have a damaging impact on economic growth".

He warned too that growth may be slower in the second half of this year. Market reaction was mixed yesterday as the Nasdaq composite rose on the back of strong corporate news.

fields.headline: The Abduction from the Seraglio
fields.standfirst:
Linbury Studio Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Abduction from the Seraglio
Linbury Studio Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Written before his popular operas, Mozart's The Abduction from the Seraglio is not often performed today. Technically a singspiel, the work has spoken dialogue between the arias; the bad guy, the Pasha Selim, doesn't sing at all. The singing involves embellishment rather than action, and the drama is slow. Even in a good production, like this one by the British Youth Opera, the work can get stuck.

Jamie Hayes's imaginative, witty staging was matched in spirit by Amanda Holden's flowing translation. The Turkish setting was a good excuse for a colourful chorus, with the four protagonists characterised as English innocents abroad.

There were many genuine laughs, interspersed with a few unintentional giggles. Most of the dreadful lines belong to the Pasha, unfortunately for James Staddon, but he sneered through them admirably.

Marie Birve rose to the arduous role of Constanze, whose florid arias are a cruel test of stamina as well as technique. She was supported by some expressive playing from the pit, conducted by Timothy Dean. Birve can't make the role sound easy, but she makes it musical. Her Belmonte, Fredrik Strid, has the tone of a heroic tenor, but couldn't match the agility of Justin Miles Olden's Pedrillo. Gabriella Santinelli's comic turn as the maid Blonde was a big hit with the audience; she has a nicely focused soprano, too. This wasn't an easy work for a young company, but there were no half measures on stage.

fields.headline: Randy Newman
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Randy Newman
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Many artists like to talk to their audience between songs. Randy Newman prefers to do it during them. A thought will suddenly pop into his head - something about his ex-wife, or US foreign policy - and he'll have to share it, no matter how complex the passage he's negotiating. You imagine this is the way he scouts lyrics, too - random thoughts plucked out of a daydream as he sits at home playing the piano.

The problem is, when Randy Newman stops mid-song at the Festival Hall, a full orchestra's worth of others have to stop with him. While Newman's compositions have always lent themselves to the orchestral, he's such a stubborn, misanthropic creature that he's always going to be restricted by the presence of any other musicians on stage - never mind 50 of them.

Part of Newman's charm is the way his songs can break up, fall to bits, then pick themselves up off the floor and come right back together. In the middle of Short People, he tells us that he thinks this song's "sounding particularly vicious tonight", and it's great. I Love LA and Rednecks are equally wonderful (although the former loses something without the full call-and-response chorus), but Newman seems stifled during his more recent, less sardonic, songs from Bad Love and Toy Story, where the orchestra takes a bigger role. You hold your breath for him, knowing that this is far from his natural, broken-voiced, shambolic, cynical home territory.

The night's highlight is I'm Dead But I Don't Know It, his tribute to geriatric rockers who don't know when to stop. It features some creative audience participation, and self-deprecating lines like, "Here's my new album. It's like all the others, but not as good". You wonder why Newman would put himself through the evening's symphonic obstacle course, when he must be realise that most of his fans don't come to see him for his professionalism. Perhaps he needed a challenge. Or perhaps he'll be writing tonight off as research for yet another bit of observational songwriting.
