webTitle: I'm being bullied but my boss won't back me up

fields.headline: I'm being bullied but my boss won't back me up
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I work in a large university and work is getting me down. It all started five years ago when I was brought in to a new job, in an academic capacity. Two of my colleagues had been employed for 20-plus years previously and resented the "newcomer".

The tension between us descended into physical abuse and one of the old employees was reprimanded and removed from the office as a result. However, this year I was told - because of management changes - that I would be working with the abusive colleague again.

I told my boss I was not happy with the situation, but was informed that I would have to grin and bear it. For the past six months I have suffered constant emotional abuse and bullying.

The solution

You are being treated appallingly and should not have to put up with this. Bullying at work is increasingly common and a huge source of stress for the victim. In your case, this is made a whole lot worse by your employer's poor or non-existent anti-bullying policy.

I think it is time to stop going it alone with this burden. Writing to me was an important first step, but there are other bodies that can support you on an ongoing basis and give you advice on how to act and what action to take.

For instance, although there is not (as yet) any legislation to protect you directly from bullying at work, there are laws that give you some rights; the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act and the newish Protection from Harassment Act could both help you. In addition, the Health and Safety at Work Act means that your employer is legally bound to protect you from physical and mental harm - and certainly bullying and harassment are known to be a cause of stress-related illness.

Invoking any of these legal redresses should, of course, be last resorts, and would necessitate your seeking advice from your union or a solicitor. Before going down this avenue, you really should exhaust all possible internal lines of action.

Start by logging every incident (backdate as many as you can remember) with dates, times and full details. Note any witnesses to the bullying. Include incidents of you doing your colleagues' work, your feelings and any adverse effects on health that you think result (eg headaches).

The next step would be to invoke a grievance procedure (since you have already tried going to your line manager) and there should be a policy on how to do this in your staff handbook or contract.

However, I strongly suggest that before trying to do this yourself, you contact the UK National Workplace Bullying advice line on 01235 212286 or visit its web site, Bully Online, at www.successunlimited.co.uk. This will give you much more detailed advice on all the avenues open to you than I have space to do in this column.

I do hope things work out for you and that you have the strength to fight for your right to a healthy work environment.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: Net threat to interest rates
fields.standfirst:
True productivity gains may be masked, says leading monetary policymaker

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Failure by the Bank of England fully to take on board the revolutionary impact of the internet raises the risk of interest rates being set too high to control inflation, one of the bank's leading policymakers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Failure by the Bank of England fully to take on board the revolutionary impact of the internet raises the risk of interest rates being set too high to control inflation, one of the bank's leading policymakers said yesterday.

Sushil Wadhwani, who sits on the nine-member monetary policy committee, suggested that the UK authorities could damage growth by continuing to base policy on old rules of thumb about productivity and price rises which may no longer apply.

In his personal view, Mr Wadhwani - who joined the Bank's committee last summer - said there was plenty of evidence to warrant a re-examination of the Bank's working assumption that productivity growth had not risen from its long-term trend rate of 2% a year, even though there was no sign of it in the official data.

His analysis rests in part on likely growth of the high-tech sector, the example set by America, where productivity has soared in recent years, and on the dramatic cost savings being made by companies through shortened supply chains.

Mr Wadhwani said productivity improvements were probably being masked by the costs of adjusting to new technology and measurement problems.

His comments, in a speech last night at the London School of Economics, place him squarely at the dovish end of the spectrum on rates along with DeAnne Julius, although he was one of eight committee members to vote for a quarter point increase to 6% earlier this month.

Mr Wadhwani believes that in the short-term, the disinflationary impact of the internet could easily be more than offset by a housing market bubble. He is also concerned that rapid internet-related corporate investment could have a perverse impact on inflation at a time when demand is already strong.

"The internet has important disinflationary effects without implying the death of inflation," he told the LSE audience.

Mr Wadhwani view put him at odds with Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, who last week dismissed the notion that the internet was transforming the performance of the British economy. However Mr Wadhwani, a former hedge fund manager, who joined the committee last summer, said the stock market's optimism about the potential of the high tech sector may be overstated.

Citing a survey of 133 internet companies carried out last year, he pointed out that the firms would have to expand their revenues by more than 80% per year for the next five years to justify their current market valuations - more than Microsoft, which grew by 53% a year in the first five years, and Dell, which grew by 66%.

He also he thought the Bank was being too conservative in its estimate of extent to which profit margins were being squeezed by the extra competition associated with the net.
